Other retentions of h than those mentioned cannot be reduced to rule. a^ for e. This also is Doric. So skiaro/s (O. 3.14. 18) for skiero/s. Still Pindar does not say i(aro/s nor (*ia/rwn. ta/mnw a^ for e.is Ionic and Epic as well as Doric, ta/mnoisai (O. 12.6), tra/foisa = tre/foisa (P. 2.44), tra/fen = tre/fein (P. 4.115), tra/xon = tre/xon (P. 8.32).

Under e note that Pindar has keneo/s (or keino/s), a)delfeo/s, never keno/s, a)delfo/s. i is rejected in a)fneo/s, as a)fnea/n (O. 1, e.10), a)fneai=s (P. 11.15). For kleino/s, faeino/s, keladeino/s, we find also the Aiolic form in -ennos. So kleenna=s (P. 5.20, etc.), keladennw=n (P. 3.113 al.), faenno/n (O. 1.6, etc.).

ou)=n in Pindar is always w)=n (O. 1.111 al.). *ou)/lumpos (O. 3.36 al.) varies with *)/olumpos (O. 1.54 al.), but the *)ol. form ou.is far more common (more than 4:1). mo/nos is more common than mou=nos, no/sos than nou=sos, kou=ros alone is used, but ko/ra outnumbers kou/ra. We find douri/ (O. 6.17) as well as dori/ (I. 4 [5], 42), ou)=ros less frequently than o)/ros. *diw/nusos is the normal form for Pindar. Syracuse is
*sura/kosai (P. 2.1) or *sura/kossai (O. 6.6), never *sura/kousai. So the derivatives. The Aiolic o)/numa has expelled both o)/noma and ou)/noma, the Aiolic -oisa (for -ontia) in the present participle has taken the place of -ousa. So fe/roisa (P. 3.15), *krei/oisa (P. 9.17), *moi=sa (for *montsa). Aiolic -oisi is used as well as Doric -onti, peripne/oisin (O. 2.79). See p. lxxxv.

CONSONANTS. — gle/faron for ble/faron (O. 3.12 al.), but e(likoblefa/rou (P. 4.172). e)slo/s for e)sqlo/s is Boeotian. So Consonants.everywhere (O. 1.99 al.). The first syllable is short, O. 2.19; P. 3.66; N. 4.95. au)=tis for au)=qis everywhere (O. 1.66), de/kesqai for de/xesqai (O. 4.8 al.). For to/te is found the Doric form to/ka (O. 6.66). Noteworthy are o)/kxos = o)/xos (O. 6.24), and o)kxe/onti = o)xe/onti (O. 2.74), and petoi=sai = pesou=sai (O. 7.69), peto/ntessi = pesou=si (P. 5.50), e)/mpetes = e)ne/peses (P. 8.81), ka/peton = kate/peson (O. 8.38).

Pindar has o(/ssos (O. 9.100 al.) as well as o(/sos (O. 2.75 al.), tossa/de (O. 1.115) as well as to/sa (O. 13.71), me/ssos (P. 4.224) as well as me/sos (P. 11.52 al.), w(=te, after the Doric fashion (O. 10 [11], 86 al.), as well as w(/ste (O. 9.74), though in different senses.

*fh/r for qh/r is Aiolic, and is used of the Centaur. *fersefo/na (P. 12.2) is familiar from the Iliad (1, 268; 2, 143). d is not changed before m in kekadme/non (O. 1.27), teqmo/s is a Doric form for qesmo/s (O. 8.25 and often). Metathesis and other slight variations explain themselves.

DIGAMMA. — Pindar seems to have used the digamma both in speech and in writing, and in this edition the example of Digamma.Mommsen and Christ has been followed after some hesitation, and the digamma, though in skeletonform, has been restored to the text.Against the introduction of the digamma, see MUCKE, p. 39. That the use was not rigid is clear. But from this irregularity we are not to draw the inference that Pindar only imitates the effects of the digamma, as seen in Epic poetry, although it must be admitted that the digammated words in Pindar are nearly all Homeric.
voi=, ve/, vo/n (= e(o/n), orig. svoi=, sve/, sveo/n. oi)=da and i)/don (compare wot and wit) have the digamma: polla\ veidw/s (O. 2.94), pa/nta vi/santi no/w| (P. 3.29), e)pei\ vi/don (P. 5.84), and yet ou)/t' i)dei=n (O. 6.53), o)/fr' i)doi=s' (O. 14.22). Add vei=dos (O. 8.19), vei/domai (P. 4.21). vanda/nein (fr. svanda/nein) is found (P. 1.29), vado/nti (P. 6.51). ve/rgon and its congeners, me/ga ve/rgon (P. 1.29), veipei=n (O. 13.68 al.), yet ei)pei=n (O. 1.52 al.), ve/pos (O. 6.16; P. 2.16; 3, 2; N. 7.48), but e)/pos is more common, though some examples may be got rid of by emendation. voi=kos (P. 7.4) occurs, but also oi)=kos (P. 1.72), oi)kei=n is certain (P. 11.64), not so voikei=n: va/nac, and vana/ssw, once a)na/ktwn (O. 10 [11], 54). velpi/s (O. 13.83), but e)lpi/s (O. 12.6), as often. ve/tos (O. 2.102). vei/kosi (N. 6.67). vespe/ra (I. 7 [8], 44), but e(/speron (O. 10 [11], 82), vi/dios (O. 13.49). There are examples of vi/sos in Nemeans and Isthmians; i)/son (O. 4.22). ta\ veoiko/ta occurs (P. 3.59), e)oiko/s everywhere else, ve/kati (O. 14.20), vh=qos (O. 11 [10], 21), vio/plokon (O. 6.30), but i)oploka/mwn (P. 1.1). In proper names vaxoi= (O. 14.21), e)s de\ viwlko/n (P. 4.188), vilia/da (O. 9.120), vio/laon (P. 9.85 al.), via/luson (O. 7.76) [?]. In the Isthmians visqmo/s, elsewhere *)isqmo/s (O. 8.48). Probably vw/anin (O. 5.11). The digamma in the middle of a word, a)velpti/a| (P. 12.31), a)/vidris (P. 2.37), is seldom indicated in this edition, e. g. a)va/tan (P. 2.28; 3, 24), as the chief object of the insertion is the very practical one of avoiding the perpetual explanation of hiatus, to which the young student of Greek should be made as sensitive as possible.

HIATUS. — True hiatus is rare in Pindar, though he sometimes keeps a long vowel long before another vowel, as glw/ssa| Hiatus.a)ko/nas (O. 6.82). For *)orqwsi/a| e)/grayen (O. 3.29) Ahrens writes *)orqwsi/as. The shortening of a long vowel before a vowel is not hiatus, as a)bouli/a| u(/statos (O. 10 [11], 45), e)n *pi/sa| e)/lsais (O. 10 [11], 47). In the case of a diphthong it would seem that i and u may be semi-consonant. Notice especially ei short in Pindar before a vowel, e. g. i(/ppei^on (O. 13.68 al.). au)- is short in a)ua/tan (P. 2.28), but in this ed. a)va/tan is preferred. eu)- is short in i)xneu^/wn (P. 8.35).

CRASIS. — The ordinary crases, such as those with kai, to/, tou=, belong to the grammar. Some read w)=nac (P. 8.67). w)= 'risto/menes (P. 8.80), Crasis and Aphaeresis. is APHAERESIS rather than crasis. Bergk goes so far as to write a)rxh 'kde/cato (P. 4.70), and o)lbw n)dei/cato (P. 4.256).

ELISION. — a is sometimes elided in 1 s. perf. act., e)pile/laq' (O. 10 [11], 4); ai in 1 s. midd., me/mfom' ai)=san (P. 11.53), Elision.yeu/som' a)mfi/ (O. 13.52); in 3 pl. (often), kuli/ndont' e)lpi/des (O. 12.6); in inf., a)poqe/sq' a)/poron (O. 10 [11], 44). i is elided in 1 s., a)fi/hm' a)grou/s (P. 4.149); in 3 pl. (Doric), a)gapa/zont' au)ti/ka (P. 4.241). Also per' for peri/ (see p. lxxxvii.). o is elided in tou=to (O. 6.57 al.), kei=no (P. 9.74), deu=ro (O. 8.51), even in du/o (O. 6.101; 9, 86), in 3 pl. midd.; 2 s. opt. midd., ge/noi' oi(=os (P. 2.72), and in the genitive singular O-declension in -oio, a non-Homeric freedom, *da/loi' a)na/sswn (P. 1.39).
Synizesis and Diaeresis.SYNIZESIS is very common in Pindar, and it has been thought best to indicate it in the text as well as DIAERESIS.

FIRST DECLENSION. — Pindar usually follows the Doric dialect here. Notice, however, the Aiolic shortening of *pe/llana^ First Declension.for *pellh/nh (O. 7.86; 13, 109), *ne/mea^ (O. 13.24), *ku/kneia^ (O. 10 [11], 17), *minu/eia (O. 14.17). Compare the Aiolic form *)odu/sseia, retained in standard Greek. Also xrusoxai=ta (P. 2.16), e)/pibdan (P. 4.140), and words in -tri/aina (O. 1.40, 70; O. 8.48; P. 2.12). G. s. masc. -ao (Aiolic), *kroni/dao (P. 4.171), more commonly -a_ (Doric), *kroni/da (O. 8.43). G. pl. -a=n (Doric), the only form: a)reta=n a)/po pasa=n (O. 1.14). So the adj. a)lla=n (O. 6.25), etc., with the accent on the last syllable, not a)/llwn. Dat. pl. -ais far more frequently than -aisi, as -ois far more frequently than -oisi. Acc. pl. -as, but also the Aiolic -ais (I. 1, 24), as Aiolic -ois is suspected by Bergk (O. 2.82). Proper names in -laos become -las (Doric), and follow the A- declension *)arkesi/las (P. 4.65), *)arkesi/la| (P. 4.2), voc. *)arkesi/la (P. 4.250. 298), but *)io/laos usually retains the open form (O. 9.105; P. 9.85 al.).

SECOND DECLENSION. — The genitive ends in -oio or -ou, -oio being susceptible of elision, as is noted p. lxxxii. The Second Declension.Doric acc. pl. in -os is favored by the metre (O. 2.78), where, however, the best MSS. have na=son: the metre does not require kakago/ros (O. 1.53).

THIRD DECLENSION. — The dat. pl. ends in -si, more frequently in -essi, sometimes (in s- stems) we find -eessi, pa- Third Declension.lai/smasi (O. 9.14), palaisma/tessi (P. 8.35), megalokeuqe/essin (P. 2.33). There is a good deal of variation, but nothing puzzling. So possi/ (O. 10 [11], 71 al.), posi/n (O. 10 [11], 62 al.), po/dessin (N. 10.63). frasi/ has better warrant than fresi/. Genitive -eos and -ewn are never contracted, but do admit synizesis. -ei is more common than -ei+. In the nominative and accusative plural -ea is seldom contracted. From words in -klh=s we find N. *(hrakle/hs, G. *(hrakle/os, D. *(hraklei= and *(hraklh=i, A. *(hrakle/a, V. *(hra/klees. From words in -eus, G. *eu)rusqe/os (O. 3.28), rarely *eu)rusqh=os (P. 9.86), D. basilei= (P. 1.60), basile/i (I. 3, 18), basilh=i (P. 4.2), basile/a (P. 4.32), basilh=a (O. 1.23), *)odussh= (N. 8.26). N. pl. basilh=es (O. 9.60), basile/es (P. 5.97). Acc. basilh=as (P. 3.94), a)riste/as (I. 7 [8], 55). Words in -is retain -i, pra/cios (P. 12.8), u(/brios (O. 7.90). quga/thr has qugate/ri (P. 2.39) as well as qugatri/, qu/gatra (O. 9.62) as well as qugate/ra, and always qu/gatres (P. 3.97). *dama/thr has *da/matra (O. 6.95). pate/ros (O. 7.36 al.) occurs as well as patro/s, mate/ros (P. 4.74 al.) and matro/s, mate/ri (N. 9.4), and matri/. a)nh/r, besides the usual forms which are more common, has a)ne/ri (P. 4.21), a)ne/ra (O. 9.110), a)ne/res (P. 4.173), a)ne/rwn (O. 1.66). From *zeu/s *dio/s is far more common than *zhno/s, *zhni/ is nearly as common as *di/ (*di/). *zh=na occurs twice (P. 4.194; 9, 64), *di/a once. *poseida/wn contracts aw into a, *poseida=n, or keeps open, and so all the cases except the dat., which is always *poseida/wni. A variant is *poteida=nos (O. 13.5. 40).

The termination -qen (-qe) occurs frequently. se/qen takes -qen, -de, -qi.the prepositions of the genitive e)k and para/. The local -de (whither) is not common, -qi except in po/qi, to/qi, occurs only thrice.

GENDER. — *ta/rtaros (P. 1.15) is fem. So is *)isqmo)s always (O. 7.81; 8, 48 al.), ki/wn, commonly fem. in the Od., Gender.is always fem. in Pindar. *maraqw/n is fem. (O. 13.110), ai)w/n varies (fem. P. 4.186; 5, 7), ai)qh/r is sometimes fem., as in Homer (O. 1.6; 13, 88), sometimes masc. (O. 7.67 al.).

ADJECTIVES. — Pindar, like other poets, sometimes uses adjectives of two terminations instead of three, su\n moiridi/w| pa- Adjectives.la/ma| (O. 9.28), sigalo\n a)maxani/an (P. 9.100); more commonly and more poetically adjectives of three terminations instead of two: a)qana/ta *qe/tis (P. 3.100), *da/lou qeodma/tas (O. 6.59), a)kinh/tan r(a/bdon (O. 9.35), parmoni/man eu)daimoni/an (P. 7.15). Of the less common forms of polu/s note pollo/n = polu/ (O. 10 [11], 40), polei=s = pollou/s (P. 4.56), pole/sin = polloi=s (O. 13.44). The old accentuations — o(moi=os, e)rh=mos, e(toi=mos — are retained.

COMPARISON. — Pindar is fairly regular in his comparison. Eustathios says that he has a leaning to the endings -esteros, Comparison.-estatos, as a)fqone/steron (O. 2.104), a)pone/steron (O. 2.68), ai)doie/staton (O. 3.42). taxuta/twn = taxi/stwn (O. 1.77) is peculiar to Pindar. po/rsw forms po/rsion (O. 1.114). makro/s forms ma/sswn (O. 13.114) as well as makro/teros.

PRONOUNS, Personal. — N. e)gw/n once before a vowel (P. 3.77). su/ or tu/. Genitive se/o, seu=, se/qen. D. e)moi/ or moi/ (the Pronouns.latter being far more common), soi/, toi/, ti/n, of which toi is always enclitic, while ti/n like tu/ is emphatic. voi= is common. I have not ventured to write vin with Hermann and Bőckh (P. 4.36). (See G. Meyer, Gr. Gram. §§ 411, 414.) Acc. e)me/ and me/, se/, ve/ (O. 9.15). In the plural N. a)/mmes. D. a)/mmin, a)/mmi, u(mi=n (once), u)/mmin, u)/mmi, sfi/si, sfi/sin, sfi, sfi/n. Acc. a)/mme, u)/mme, sfe/. ni/n (Doric) is preferred by recent editors to the Epic mi/n, which is found not infrequently in the MSS. There are no reflexives. The emphatic forms of au)to/s suffice. Of the possessives note a)mo/s = h(me/teros = e)mo/s (P. 3.41; 4, 27); teo/s (Doric) is far more common than so/s, e(o/s is nearly four times as common as o(/s: for u(me/teros we
find u(mo/s (P. 7.15; 8, 66), sfo/s occurs once (P. 5.102), sfe/teros = au)tw=n (P. 10.38; I. 2, 27) twice, sfe/teros usually being = e(o/s, while e(o/s is once used for the possessive of the pl. (P. 2.91). The article has Doric a in the fem. So has the relative. Notice tai/ = ai(, o(/ = o(/s (P. 1.74 al.).

VERB. — The augment is often omitted, both syllabic and temporal, but it is safer to read a before two consonants long; Verb. Augment.hence a)=rxe (O. 10 [11], 51), u(pa=rxen (P. 4.205). ai, au, eu, ei are unchanged.

Of the terminations in the pres. act. -onti (Doric) or -oisi (Aiolic) is used to the exclusion of -ousi. onti cannot take Terminations.n e)felkustiko/n, and hence -oisin must be used before vowels. On the so-called short subjunctive, see note on O. 1.7.

-men is more common than -ein in the inf. sta=men = sth=nai (P. 4.2), ba=men = bh=nai (P. 4.39), whereas a long vowel before -men would not be allowed in Homer. e)/mmenai occurs, but e)/mmen is nearly twice as common. The Doric garu/en (O. 1.3), tra/fen (P. 4.115) has the authority of the MSS., not the cogency of metre.Impugned by CHRIST, Philol. XXV. p. 628; MUCKE, p. 29. gega/kein (Doric) is from a theoretical gega/kw, and is = gegone/nai (O. 6.49).

In the participles -oisa (Aiolic) is used exclusively in the fem. pres. -ais and -aisa (Aiolic) in the masc. and fem. aor., Participle.but never in ba/s: a)naba/s (O. 13.86), kataba/s (O. 6.58). Two perfect participles have present endings: pefri/kontas (P. 4.183), kexla/dontas (P. 4.179).

In the passive the open forms, -eai, -eo, are preferred, with synizesis, if needful (but always de/keu). -mesqa for -meqa ocPassive.curs (P. 10.28). In the 3 pl. aor. pass. -en is used as needed, fa/nen (O. 10 [11], 88), dma=qen (P. 8.17). So in the active e)/ban (O. 2.38), e)/gnon (P. 4.120).

Many verbs in -zw form the future and aor. in c instead of Classes.the ordinary s (see G. Meyer, Gr. Gram. § 529). klei+/cein (O. 1.110), eu)klei+/cai (P. 9.99), katefa/micen (O. 6.56), a)poflauri/caisa (P. 3.12). i)/ucen (P. 4.237), a
Pindaric word, simply follows the analogy of onomatopoetic verbs in -cw, which regularly have c as a)la/lacen (O. 7.37). Verbs in -cw.Others vary. kwma/zw forms kwma/cate (N. 2.24) and kwma/sais (N. 11.28); komi/cw, ko/mison (O. 2.16) and komi/cais (P. 5.51); u(pantia/cw, u(panti/asen (P. 4.135) and u(pantia/caisa (P. 8.11); a(rpa/cw, a(/rpase (P. 3.44) and a(rpa/cais (P. 4.34); a(/rmosan (P. 3.114), but in the compound e)narmo/cai (O. 3.5). Only a few verbs in -cw double s in the s- forms, as qemissa/menos (P. 4.141), whereas future and aor. s, preceded by a short vowel, are often doubled: e)ra/ssato (O. 1.25), e)ka/lesse (O. 6.58), a)/nussen (P. 12.11). This so-called gemination is a reappearance (G. Meyer, Gr. Gram. § 224).

Pindar uses the Homeric e)do/khsen (P. 6.40), but also the common e)/docan (O. 5.16); once he uses e)kdida/skhsen (P. 4.217); ai)ne/w increases in h except three times; verbs in -ai/nw have -ana in the aor.

Contract Verbs. Pindar contracts regularly the verbs in -aw. naieta/w, an Epic verb, is the only one left open, naie- Contract Verbs.ta/ontes (O. 6.78; P. 4.180). Verbs in -ew contract -ee and -eei into -ei, but -eo, -eoi, -ew are never contracted. Verbs in -ow contract.

Verbs in -mi. tiqei=s (P. 8.11), didoi= (P. 4.265), are found as from verbs in -w, but ti/qhsi (P. 2.10) and di/dwsi (P. 5.65) Verbs in -mi.also occur. There is much dispute about the reading in P. 4.155 (where see the notes). di/doi (Aiolic) is the only form used for the imperative. The short forms, ti/qen (P. 3.65), pare/stan (O. 10 [11], 58), kate/stan (P. 4.135) = e)ti/qesan, pare/sthsan, kate/sthsan may be noticed. dou=nai occurs once (P. 4.35), otherwise do/men is the rule (see p. lxxxv.). The passive forms require no special exhibit. The first aorist middle of ti/qhmi balances the second, each occurring four times, qhka/menos (P. 4.29), qe/menai (O. 14.9). Notice e)/ra_tai, 3 s. pres. subj. midd. from e)/ramai (P. 4.92).

Pr. s., 1. ei)mi/, 2. e)ssi/, 3. e)sti: pl., 1. ei)me/n, 3. e)nti/, once ei)si/n (P. 5.116). Inf., e)/mmen or e)/mmenai. Part., e)w/n, e)oi=sa. Impf. s., 3. h)=n: pl., 3. e)/san or e)/ssan. Fut. s., 1. e)/ssomai, 3. e)/ssetai, e)/setai, e)/stai. Inf., e)/sesqai, e)/ssesqai. Part., e)sso/menos.
fami/ has for its third pers. pl. fanti/. i)/sami is a Doric verb = oi)=da.

PREPOSITIONS. — para/, a)na/, kata/ are apocopated when apocope is needful. a)mna/sei (P. 4.54) = a)namna/sei, so a)mna/seien Prepositions.(P. 1.47). ka\n no/mon (O. 8.78) = kata\ no/mon, ka/peton (O. 8.38) = kate/peson. Compare Alkm. fr. 38: kabai/nwn. poti/ (Doric) = pro/s. It is elided once pot' a)stw=n (O. 7.90), and rarely used in compounds potista/zwn (P. 4.137), and in five other words. The regular pro/s is far more common.

ei)s is suffered only before vowels, and when a long syllable is needed, and in composition ei)side/tw (I. 7 [8], 36) is the only example. Everywhere else we find e)s. e)n with the acc., especially noticeable in Boeotian inscriptions, is found only in Aiolic odes (P. 2.11. 86; 5, 38).

peri/ is elided per' a)tla/tou (O. 6.38), per' au)ta=s (P. 4.265), pera/ptwn (P. 3.52). For meta/ Aiol.-Dor. peda/ is found (P. 5.47; 8, 74). In compare peda/meiyan (O. 12.12). cu/n occurs only three times, once alone (N. 4.25), twice in composition.

div2.head: Syntax
div2.p: Pindar's syntax differs from Homer's at many points, but it is not easy to tell what belongs to the period, what to the department, what to the individual. Only the most important points can be touched here,ERDMANN, De Pindari usu syntactico, Halle, 1867. and completeness of statistic is not attempted.

One mark of advance is the extension of the substantive use of the neuter adjective, which can itself take another adNeuter Adjective.jective. We feel ourselves nearer to Thukydides than to Homer when we read terpno\n e)pa/meron (I. 6 [7], 40), a)teirei= su\n a)gaqw=| (O. 2.33), e)n a)mei/bonti (N. 11.42).

The scarcity of the dual is also noteworthy. The dual is Dual.preserved chiefly by Homer and the Attic writers. In the Attic orators, even, it dies out as we come down. It is not found in the Ionic of Herodotos. It is a
stranger to Asiatic Aiolic, as it is a stranger to Latin. In P. there are very few examples. The dual substantive, xeroi=n (O. 13.95), is a rarity, and so is podoi=n (N. 9.47), but such duals are found occasionally even in the so - called common dialect. kasignh/ta (O. 13.6) is not dual, and we must be satisfied with an occasional dual participle, a)tuzome/nw (O. 8.39), kataba/nte (O. 9.46). It is very unlikely that P. should have used the few dual verbs (O. 2.97: garu/eton, O. 9.49: ktissa/sqan) without a full appreciation of the dual force.The dual is claimed as Boeotian on slight evidence, MEISTER, Gr. Dial. I. p. 272.

The distributive plural as O. 12.9: tw=n mello/ntwn fradai/, O. 9.21: stefa/nwn a)/wtoi, P. 1.4: prooimi/wn a)mbola/s, P. 10.72: poli/wn kuberna/sies, the use of the plural abstract as concrete, a)glai+/ai, a)retai/, and the like, are Pindaric. The Homeric use of the abstract plural is not common. See note on O. 5.20. The plural of stateliness — a)ggeli/ai, do/moi, qa/lamoi, le/ktra — occurs often. In P. 3.66 we have a plural of courtliness and reserve. A remarkable plural for singular is found in O. 9.60.

Peculiarities of concord, such as the singular verb with combined subjects (O. 5.15; P. 2.10; 4, 66; 10, 4. 10; 11, Concord. sxh=ma *pindariko/n.45), and neut. pl. with verb pl. (O. 8.12; 10 [11], 93; P. 1.13; 4, 121), may be passed over with bare mention. Not so the sxh=ma *pindariko/n, which, however, hardly deserves its name, for the trustworthy examples are few. The peculiarity of this figure is the combination of a plural substantive with a singular verb. But the singular is the general and the plural the particular; and if the verb precedes, we have not so much a want of concord as an after-thought. As it is, most of the Pindaric instances have disappeared under critical treatment. See the note on O. 11 (10), 6.

The case-register of a poet is of especial importance for his style, and Pindar's use of the cases shows in an eminent degree
his genius for vivid presentation.ERDMANN, l. c.; FRIESE, De casuum singulari apud Pindarum usu, Berlin, 1866. His free use of the accusative is a return to the original sweep of the case. What Cases. Accusative.is called the outer object is really an extension of the inner object. a)/ndra ktei/nein is a)ndroktasi/an poiei=sqai or else a)ndrokto/non ei)=nai. The countless number of outer objects is apt to obscure the inner object, in which almost all the variety of the accusative lies. In Pindar the inner object has its wide poetic, its wide popular sweep. nika=n *(ella/da (P. 12.6) is commonplace. Not so nika=n dro/mon (O. 4.20), nika=n ste/fanon (N. 5.5). To the same class belongs pu=r pneo/ntwn (O. 7.71; 13, 90), a)lka\n o(rw=nta (O. 9.119), u(=se xruso/n (O. 7.50), o)fqalmo\n a)nte/flece *mh/na (O. 3.20), ou) kala\ de/ndrea qa/llen o( xw=ros (O. 3.23). A very different effect would have been produced by u(=se xrusw=|, de/ndressin e)/qallen.

The adverbial accusative is so familiar a form of the inner object that it is not necessary to cite examples, especially of Adverbial Accusative.the neuter accusatives. Nor need we note such common uses as di/khn and tro/pon. kairo\n ei) fqe/gcaio (P. 1.81) reminds one of Sophokles' kairo\n d' e)fh/keis (Ai. 34) . The appositive accusative, the object effected, of the sentence, a)/poina (O. 7.16 al.), xa/rin (O. 10 [11], 86 al.), is often distinctly felt in its case-relation, though the post-Homeric deadening of xa/rin is also found, *dio\s xa/rin (P. 3.95).

An old use of the accusative of the outer object is the combination with passives, intransitives, adjectives, verbal nouns, Accusative of part.not otherwise felt than such loose English compounds as “hoof-bound,” “shoulder-shotten,” “footsore,” “heart-sick.” In Pindar these accusatives refer chiefly to the body and its parts, either as such or as the seat of thought and emotion, seldom to abstracts. sw=ma, me/lh, xrw=ta, ka/ra, pro/swpa, nw=ta, h)=tor, ke/ar, fre/nas, o)rga/n, yuxa/n, qumo/n, no/on, fu/sin, ta/xos, mh=tin, a)reta/n. ei)=dos and o)/yin are hardly felt as abstracts.

Double accusatives in Pindar show few extensions of any importance. e)re/fw takes the acc. of the whole and the acc. Double Accusative.of the part, a familiar Homeric figure, la/xnai nin me/lan ge/neion e)/refon (O. 1.68). e)rhmo/w takes the acc. of the person and the acc. of the thing (P. 3.97), somewhat strangely; me/ros, however, may be an after - thought. The factitive predicate is boldly used in P. 4.6: xrh=sen oi)kisth=ra *ba/tton, “Battos for the leader.” Proleptic (predicative) uses must be watched. The absence of the article leaves the adjective and substantive, as in Latin, without any external indication of the figure. So O. 1.68: la/xnai nin me/lan (“to blackness”) ge/neion e)/refon, v. 82: ta/ ke/ tis a)nw/numon gh=ras . . . e(/yoi; v. 88: e(/len . . . parqe/non su/neunon, and so in almost every ode.

The acc. of extent in space and time requires no notice.Two rather free uses of the acc. of extent are to be found in P. 4.83; 5, 33. The terminal accusative, which is not a whither-case, but only Terminal Accusative.a characteristic of motion, occurs in Pindar, who, like Homer, limits it to a comparatively narrow range of verbs and substantives. i(/kein and its kindred should not be counted, — they are transitive like Shakespeare's “arrive,” — but e)lqei=n, molei=n, bh=nai, ni/sesqai cannot be excluded. So e)lqei=n with pedi/on (P. 5.52), me/garon (P. 4.134), do/mon (O. 14.20), *kro/nion (O. 1.111), *libu/an (I. 3 [4], 72). I. 2, 48: h)qai=on e)/lqh|s seems doubtful. O. 2.105: ai)=non e)/ba ko/ros has given way to ai)=non e)pe/ba, but O. 9.76: pedi/on molw/n, and N. 10.35: e)/molen *(/hras to\n eu)a/nora lao/n stand. Pindar far prefers the more concrete preposition, and it is a mistake to attempt the extension of the terminal accusative, as has been done.

The genitive as a fossilized adjective stands in the same relation to the substantive as the accusative to the verb. The Genitivedenominative verb takes the genitive by reason of its substantive element, just as the adjective takes the accusative by reason of the verbal activity in the floating predicate. Noteworthy is the large employment of the adj. in -ios
for relations otherwise expressed by the genitive, especially of possession, origin, time, place. The dialectical preference for and Adj. in -ios.-ios instead of the genitive of the father is marked.BERGK, G. L. G. I. p. 57. Possession: su\n *)agamemnoni/a| yuxa=| (P. 11.20), *nesto/reion a(/rma (P. 6.32), a)/nqe) *)afrodi/sia (N. 7.53). Time: e(spe/rios fle/gen (N. 6.43), me/lpontai e)nnu/xioi (P. 3.78), e(speri/ais a)oidai=s (P. 3.19), e)fameri/an ou)de\ meta\ nu/ktas (N. 6.7), pemptai=on gegenhme/non (O. 6.53). The Hebrew says “the son of five days.” Place: e)nali/an ba=men (P. 4.39), e)pigouni/dion bre/fos (P. 9.67). In Attic o( me\n *kleini/eios ou(=tos (Plat. Gorg. 482 D) is said with a tone of poetic persiflage; to Pindar himself the effect must have been less striking than it is to us. So w)= *kro/nie pai= (O. 2.13), *poseida/nion *kte/aton (O. 10 [11], 30), *cena/rkeion . . . ui(o/n (P. 8.19).

With the genitive proper is blended the ablative. The sigAblative Genitive.nifications of the two cases often meet in languages in which the forms are quite distinct. Of special uses of the genitive in either direction there is not much to note. Possession, origin, cause, material, are familiar everyGen. of Material.where. The genitive of material varies with the adjective. li/qinos is the rule, but *pari/ou li/qou (N. 4.81) is a necessity, as in prose.For an application of this in criticism, see P. 4.206. a)dama/ntinos is used once (P. 4.224), a)da/mantos once (P. 4.71), e)c a)da/mantos once (fr. IX. 2, 3). xru/seos, which, however, is often used figuratively, is far more common than xrusou=.

Quality is everywhere in the language expressed by the adjective, and there is no example of a genitive of quality in Pindar.It is almost incredible that scholars should have been found to combine do/mous a(bro/tatos = do/mous a(brou/s (P. 11.34). The appositive genitive is rare, as drako/ntwn fo/bai (P. 10.47), where drako/nteioi fo/bai might have been used. *ka/storos bi/a (P. 11.61), *ai)/antos a)lka/ (I. 3 [4], 53), sqe/nos h(mio/nwn (O. 6.22), lh=ma *korwni/dos (P. 3.25), are familiar idioms. Pindar can even say, P. 6.35: *messani/ou ge/rontos donhqei=sa frh\n bo/ase pai=da vo/n, and the boldness of P. 1.73: *tursanw=n a)lalato\s . . . i)dw/n, is exemplary. Cf. N. 3.60.

The genitive in the predicate is common. So after ei)=nai
(O. 9.57; P. 3.60). futeu/esqai has the privilege of gi/gnesqai (P. 4.256), keklh=sqai is an extension of ei)=nai (P. 3.67). On the genitive with pemfqe/n, see O. 8.43, and consult further the note on O. 4.10.

The comparative genitive, which is an ablative, allows the well-known brachylogy, hardly felt in English. *)olumpi/as Comparatio compendiaria.a)gw=na fe/rteron (O. 1.7) = (tou=) *)olumpi/as (a)gw=nos) a)gw=na fe/rteron, where I have not thought it worthy of a note. A remarkable comparative is pri/n with the genitive, pri\n w(/ras (P. 4.43), where it is quasi-prepositional.

Of the verbs of hitting and touching the most remarkable deviations are in the direction of the dative, for which see Unusual Constructions.p. xciv. An unusual construction is u(/mnon a)/rxe (N. 3.10), where we should expect the genitive. The a)rxh/ is the u(/mnos, a)/rxe is a)rxome/nh u(/mnei or a)naba/llou.

The common uses of the genitive, whether referred to the genitive proper or the ablative genitive, or left to hover between the two, need not detain us. So the genitive after verbs of desire (P. 2.27; 3, 20), under which class o)rou/ein (P. 10.61) and o)rga=n, after Christi's conjecture (P. 6.50), the genitive of remembering (P. 9.95) and forgetting (O. 8.72; P. 4.41), of hearing (P. 1.2; 4, 135), of the part by which such as xeiro/s (P. 9.132), au)xe/nwn (N. 1.44) — with strong ablative leaning — the genitive of price (O. 12.12; P. 1.39), of cause (O. 7.6), of time within which (O. 6.61; P. 4.40).

The genitive as a whence-case is used with somewhat more freedom than in prose. Outside of the verbs of separation Gen. as a whence-case.the boldest is O. 1.58: kefala=s balei=n, and the interpretation there is doubtful. See also note on O. 4.10. For all local uses Pindar greatly prefers the preposition, which he employs with peculiar clearness and force. lu/w with the genitive is perfectly legitimate (O. 2.57; P. 3.50; 11, 34), but he has e)k twice (O. 4.19; I. 7 [8], 5).
The genitive absolute will be taken up under the participle, but it may be said here that Pindar seems to go somewhat beyond the Homeric limits.

The dative case in Pindar shows the three elements — the dative proper, or personal dative (Latin dative), the local dative, Dative.and the instrumental, or, better, comitative. The personal dative is a locative plus sensibility; the locative is limited in its range; the comitative has a personal as well as a local character, and this is brought out especially when it is reinforced by su/n.

The personal dative is used in Pindar with poetic freedom, but the differences from Homeric use and from prose use are Personal Dative.not startling for the most part. The differences are differences of degree, not of kind, and it is unnecessary to go through the categories of the dative of possession (so-called), of profit and loss, freely combined with verbal nouns as well as with verbs, the ethic dative. It may, however, be worth while to say that there is no double dative in the sense of whole and part as in the acc. (sxh=ma kaq' o(/lon kai\ me/ros). In Pindar, as in Homer, the dative of the whole depends on the complex with the second dative. So O. 2.16: a)/rouran patri/an sfisi\ ko/mison loipw=| ge/nei, sfisi/ depends on the whole group, a)/rouran patri/an ko/mison loipw=| ge/nei. The dative of reference (O. 2.93: fwna/enta sunetoi=sin), the dative of the participle (O. 8.60: ei)do/ti, “to one that knows”), (P. 10.67: peirw=nti, “to one that tests”), which is the beginning of a dat. absol. that did not ripen, the dative with verbals in -to/s all belong to the common apparatus of the language. The so-called dative of the agent, however, is really a dative of personal interest. The agency is only an inference. The prose construction is generally with the perf. or equivalent aor. (cf. P. 1.73: a)rxw=| damasqe/ntes). On the construction with the present, see O. 8.30; 12, 3. The Homeric construction of de/xomai with dat. is used in Pindar also. The giver is interested as well as the receiver. See notes on O. 13.29 and P. 4.21.

The conception often seems to be in suspense between the personal dative and the local. The dat. of inclination is a personal dative. So the dat. with kli/nesqai, N. 4.15: tw=|de me/lei kliqei/s, but in O. 1.92: *)alfeou= po/rw| kliqei=sa, it would
seem to be rather instrumental, as in P. 10.51: e)/reison xqoni/. In O. 6.58: *)alfew=| kataba\s me/ssw|, it is better to personify.

An unusual extension of the personal dative is seen in verbs of touching, which in Pindar are construed as verbs of approach, though the other construction with the genitive is also known to him. yau/w has the dat., P. 9.130; the normal genitive, O. 6.35; N. 5.42; a(/ptomai the dat., P. 10.28; N. 8. 36 (e)f.); I. 3 (4), 30; the genitive, O. 3.43; P. 3.29; N. 8.13. 22; qigga/nw the dat., P. 4.296; 9, 42; genitive, I. 1, 18.
With some verbs which familiarly take the dative, Pindar occasionally uses a preposition to make the image more vivid. So especially e)n with the favorite mi/gnumi, O. 1.90; P. 4.251; I. 2, 29.

The adjectives that vary between genitive and dative vary according to the predominance of the fixed element or floating element (“his like,” “like him”), N. 5.8. fi/los as a subst. takes genitive, as an adj., the dat., N. 4.22; I. 1, 5. There is a certain caprice in these matters that it is not profitable to pursue. In O. 3.30: *)orqwsi/a| e)/grayen i(era/n, the dat. gives an ugly but not unexampled hiatus which can be removed by substituting the genitive.

Of the adverbs, e)/ndon, which regularly takes the genitive (as O. 2.93; 7, 62; P. 11.64), takes the dat. (N. 3.52; 7, 44). a)/gxi with dat. (N. 6.11) is figurative, but a)gxou= (N. 9.40) is local. The government of a dative by such a word as koinwni/an (P. 1.98) is an extension not to be wondered at in postHomeric Greek, though not very common in the standard language.

The comitative, or, as it is more usually called, the instrumental dative, is common enough in Pindar, as O. 1.49: Comitative (Instrumental) Dative.maxai/ra| ta/mon, but he often uses the more personal su/n, as su
 e)/ntesi (P. 12.21), the more concrete e)n, as e)n xersi/ (P. 2.8). As the verbal noun has much of the verbal motion in Pindar, we are prepared for such extensions as I. 2, 13: *)isqmi/an i(/ppoisi ni/kan. Instrument, manner, cause, run into one another. They are all common in Pindar, and need not be cited. The causal
dative construction, however, it may be noted, is not so common in Homer. Whether the dative as the measure of difference is instrumental or local is open to discussion. The local conception has simplicity in its favor. We can say diafe/rein e)n, we can say e)n basa/nw|. So pa/la| krate/wn (O. 8.20) is “wherein” rather than “whereby,” though local and instrumental are not far apart. The descriptive dative, or dat. of manner, a)laqei= no/w| (O. 2.101), e)leuqe/ra| freni/ (P. 2.57), a)sqenei= xrwti/ (P. 1.55), is common, and there are a few dative adverbs varying with prepositional combination. tu/xa| is less common than su
 tu/xa| di/ka| than su
 di/ka|, a)na/gka| than su
 a)na/gka|.

From the local dative must be separated the locative proper, such as *)isqmoi= and *puqoi=. Whatever rights the local dative Local Dative.may have, Pindar does not exercise them freely. When the simple dative is followed by e)n with the dat., as P. 5.70: *lakedai/moni | e)n *)/argei te, we have every reason to suppose that the e)n was forefelt just as the ou) may be forefelt when ou)/te follows. Some examples may be construed personally, as P. 3.4: ba/ssaisi(n) a)/rxein *pali/ou, or instrumentally, as O. 6.31: kru/ye de\ parqeni/an w)di=na ko/lpois.

Nor is the temporal dative very common. xro/nw| by itself is not temporal, but comitative or instrumental. It means, as in Temporal Dative.prose, “at last,” e. g. O. 10 [11], 93; P. 4.258. For the active side see N. 1.46. Yet xro/nw| has a temporal sense with an adjective, as P. 4.55: xro/nw| | u(ste/rw|, though we find P. 10.17: u(ste/raisin | e)n a(me/rais. So O. 1.43: deute/rw| xro/nw|, O. 2.41: a)/llw| xro/nw|. In a(me/raisin (P. 1.22) the e)n of e)n o)/rfnaisin is forefelt. nukti/ occurs only in O. 1.2. The dative of time of sacred festivals and games is claimed by some for O. 5.5; N. 2.24, but even these are doubtful. The explanation of Pindar's limited use of the dat. of place and time is to be sought in his liking for the preposition, which in his hands is potent.

-qen.The suffix -qen is freely used by Pindar, and sometimes takes the place of the ablative genitive, a)/neu se/qen (N. 7.2), pa\r se/qen (P. 1.88), e)k se/qen (I. 3 [4], 5), and
so of the possessive, se/qen o)/pa (N. 3.5), se/qen pai=das (I. 1, 55), not that the whence force is lost. The local -de is little used. We find it in oi)/kade, *puqw=na/de, *troi/ande.

The limits of this outline make it impossible to go into the details of the use of the prepositions in Pindar.BOSSLER, De praepositionum usu apud Pindarum, Darmstadt, 1862. A few illusPrepositions.trations must serve to show the plastic power he puts forth. The local signification is seldom effaced; we feel the motion in space, the rest in space, everywhere. e)s ge/nos — the MSS. have e)s genea/s — (N. 4.68) is not simply ge/nei, there is an element of purpose moving to an a)po/.end. In O. 6.12: ti\n d' ai)=nos e(toi=mos o(\n e)n di/ka| | a)po\ glw/ssas *)/adrastos ma/ntin *oi)klei/dan pot' e)s *)amfia/rhon | fqe/gcato, each preposition is used in its full force. The word moves roundly off the tongue, the praise is not simply about Amphiaraos, but goes out towards the lost stratia=s o)fqalmo/s. Compare the festal picture, O. 7.1: a)fneia=s a)po\ xeiro\s dwrh/setai. Another passage where the a)po/ of time is also the a)po/ of space is P. 5.114: potano\s a)po\ matro\s fi/las, “a winged soul from his mother's lap,” “from the time he e)c.left his mother's lap.” e)c is to e)n as a)po/ is to e)pi/, and while a)po/ and e)c occur in similar combination, e)c largely outnumbers a)po/. In N. 5.7: e)k de\ *kro/nou h(/rwas futeuqe/ntas kai\ a)po\ *nhrhi+/dwn, it would be unwise to insist on the difference, but a)po\ qeou= would not satisfy us for e)k qeou= in O. 11 (10), 10: e)k qeou= d' a)nh\r sofai=s a)nqei= prapi/dessin. e)c in the sense of “outside of,” “beyond,” “above,” occurs once e)n.in O. 6.25. Pindar's favorite preposition is e)n, Every one who has watched the behavior of e)n in composition, where the original force best shows itself, is acquainted with its realistic touch. Compare, for instance, even in prose, a)podei/knumi, e)pidei/knumi, and e)ndei/knumi. Pindar uses it adverbially. So O. 13.22 and O. 7.5. He uses it occasionally in Aiolic odes for ei)s with the acc., P. 2.11. 86; 5, 38; N. 7.31. Especially noteworthy is what is called the instrumental use of e)n, a use which is especially familiar to us
from the Greek of the New Testament, although there it is the result of Semitic influences. Everywhere in this so-called instrumental e)n we can trace the local e)n, the seat of the manifestation, the abode of the power. In many of the examples English itself would tolerate the local “in” as well as the instrumental “with.” We can understand N. 11.28: a)ndhsa/menos ko/man e)n porfure/ois e)/rnesin, as well as I. 1, 28: a)ndhsa/menoi e)/rnesi xai/tas. So N. 1.52: e)n xeri\ tina/sswn fa/sganon, P. 2.8: a)ganai=sin e)n xersi\ poikilani/ous e)da/masse pw/lous, which brings before us the image of the reins in the hands of the tamer. O. 5.19: a)pu/wn e)n au)loi=s is a perfectly comprehensible combination to any one who considers the nature of that wind-instrument. The combination of e)n with no/mw| gives the limits, the environment (P. 1.62; N. 10.28; I. 2, 38). e)n di/ka| is not a stranger to prose. The proleptic use of e)n with the dat., instead of ei)s with the acc., is common everywhere with tiqe/nai, and common in Pindar, who, however, extends it. The anticipation of the result has the same effect of resistlessness that thrusts the local dia/ with the acc. out of prose in favor of dia/ with the genitive. In some of the Pindaric passages e)n has been made adverbial, or, in other words, tmesis has been assumed, but the image often loses by it. There can be no tmesis in O. 7.69: lo/gwn korufai\ | e)n a)laqeia| petoi=sai = a)laqei=s geno/menai.

su/n is an intensely personal preposition. In standard prose its use is limited to consecrated phrases of religion (su
 qew=|) su/n.and business. The comparatively frequent use of it in Xenophon and in later Greek has made scholars regardless of its infrequency in model prose. Thukydides does not use it often, Isokrates never. Pindar, as a poet, has su/n very often, meta/ with the genitive very rarely. The use of su/n where we should have expected the simple dative has already been touched. It serves to personify, to make the tool an accomplice. To bring this to our consciousness we sometimes do well to translate “with the help of,” as “with” by itself has become faint to us. P. 12.21: o)/fra su
 e)/ntesi mimh/sait' e)rikla/gktan go/on, N. 9.48: neoqalh\s d' au)/cetai | malqaka=| nikafori/a su
 a)oida=| .
The su/n of time is not infrequent, P. 11.10: keladh/set' a)/kra| su
 e(spe/ra|, P. 8.7: kairw=| su
 a)trekei=i, but it is well to remember that the Greek considers time as an attendant (cf. o( xro/nos makro\s sunw/n) and not as a medium merely.

With dia/ in a local sense, the genitive is more common, as it is the exclusive use in prose. With the genitive the pasdia/.sage is already made, or as good as made. With the accusative dia/ is ‘along’ as well as ‘through’ (compare a)na/ and kata/), but it is not safe to insist. He who says pe/tetai d' e)pi/ te xqo/na kai\ dia\ qala/ssas (N. 6.55), says also e)pi\ xqo/na kai\ dia\ po/nton be/baken (I. 3, 59). In a transferred sense, dia/ with the acc. is “owing to,” never “by means of.” So N. 7.21: dia\ to\n a(dueph= *(/omhron, is “thanks to,” “because of;” so dia\ dai/monas (I. 4, 11).

u(pe/r in Pindar with the genitive is “above,” both literally and metaphorically; once “beyond” (N. 3.21), where u(pe/r with u(pe/r.acc. would be more common. He who stands over stands to protect, hence u(pe/r is “in behalf of;” only once “by reason of” (I. 5 [6], 29); with the acc. it is “beyond” (O. 1.28); “above” (P. 2.80).

kata/ occurs only once with the genitive, O. 2.65: kata\ ga=s. With the acc. the perpendicular motion is transformed into kata/.horizontal motion, “along,” and then, to extent, position. kat' oi)=kon (P. 1.72), is “at home,” kat' *)/olumpon (N. 10.17), of the abode of Hebe, kat' a)/kran (O. 7.36), of the head of the Olympian, the stage of Athena's first appearance. The transferred meaning of kata/, “according to,” “in accordance with,” needs no illustration. kata/, “after the likeness of,” is found in P. 2.67: kata\ *foi/nissan e)mpola/n. In P. 4.125, kata\ kle/os, k. is “following hard.”
a)na/.a)na/, which has little scope in prose, has in P. the poetical use with the dat. (O. 1.41; 8, 51, etc.), and is as horizontal as kata/ with the acc. (P. 2.60, etc.).

a)mfi/.a)mfi/, another preposition for which prose has little use, is frequent in Pindar. It is an adverb, O. 1.50 (though the passage is disputed); P. 4.81. On P. 8, 85,
see note. As a preposition it has all the oblique cases, most frequently the dat. The “both-sidedness” of a)mfi/ may be inside, or, more commonly, outside the dat., a)mfi\ podi/, “about the foot” (P. 4.96), a)mfi\ ko/mais, “about the hair” (O. 13.39). In this outside use a)mfi/ is sometines weakened as the English “about” is weakened. So a)mfi\ krounoi=s, “at the fountain” (O. 13.63), a)mf' a)ndria/nti sxedo/n, “hard by the statue” (P. 5.41). In a)mfi\ tokeu=sin (P. 6.42), where we should use in prose peri\ toke/as, encompassing affection may come in. The parents are guarded on the right hand and on the left. Then a)mfi/ with the dat. is used of the prize, like peri/ with dat., a)mf' a)rguri/dessin (O. 9.97), and thence transferred to other relations. For the inside use compare P. 1.12, where a)mfi\ sofi/a| is “with the environment of art,” and P. 8.34: e)ma=| potano\n a)mfi\ maxana=|. So in O. 13.37: a(li/w| a)mf' e(ni/, it is the sun that compasses, where a)mfi/ is felt almost as an adverb. a)mfi/ is also found with genitive and accusative. The most noteworthy use is O. 10 (11), 85, where to\n e)gkw/mion a)mfi\ tro/pon seems to make the tune the centre of the song. In a)mfi\ ka=pon (P. 5.24) and a)mfi\ pana/gurin (O. 9.103) the ka=pos and the pana/guris are measured from within.
As a)mfi/ is comparatively common in Pindar, so peri/ is comperi/.paratively rare. In peri\ dei/mati (P. 5.58) it is fear that surrounds. In peri\ yuxa/n (P. 4.122) joy fills the heart from within.

meta/ (used adverbially, P. 4.64), besides the usual prose constructions (O. 1.60 al.; P. 5.11 al.), has the acc. (O. 1, meta/, peda/.66) and the dat. (O. 2.32) in the sense of “amid,” and the acc. as “after” in the sense of “to get,” as O. 4.21: meta\ ste/fanon i)w/n. Noteworthy is meta/ with genitive in the general sense of “among,” i. e. “as part of” (me/toxos), P. 5.94. peda/, which answers in meaning to meta/, is construed with acc. peda\ me/gan ka/maton (P. 5.47), and in sofo\s ped' a)fro/nwn (P. 8.74) would be represented in prose by e)n with dat. e)pi/.e)pi/, the most difficult of the Greek prepositions, is used most frequently with the dative, when the superposition sense makes itself felt. So O. 11 (10), 13: e)pi\ stefa/nw|
is not “on account of,” but “in addition to.” (See note on O. 9.121.)

para/ is limited in prose to persons and personified things, except in the acc. As P. uses para/ freely, there is danger para/.of feeling the personal sense too much. An old phrase is pa\r podo/s (P. 3.60; 10, 62). para/ is used freely with the dat. of place. See note on O. 1.20. para/ with the acc.=propter, appears once in P., keina\n para\ di/aitan (O. 2.71). It is the first instance of this use, which does not become common until much later times.

pro/s, not unfrequently in the form poti/, once in the form pot' (O. 7.90), is a favorite preposition with persons and pro/s.seems sometimes to personify slightly. Hence P. 4.295: qumo\n e)kdo/sqai pro\s h(/ban polla/kis, we feel h(/ban almost as a person, and the difference from the personal dative is not great. So pro/s me in prose is almost moi. Even with designations of time, pro\s a)w= (P. 9.27), pro\s gh=ras (N. 9.44), the coming of dawn, of old age, is felt as the approach of an enemy. pro/s with the dat. is seldom used. u(po/.pro/s with the genitive of the agent is preferred to u(po/ with the genitive, which is the ordinary prose construction, and therefore colorless. Pindar tries to keep his u(po/ fresh, and his u(po/ with the genitive is still “under,” still what we should call u(pe/k, although the local meaning comes out more distinctly with the dative. See note on O. 6.35. These are only specimens, but they are sufficient to show that in Pindar's poetry the prepositions stand out with local vividness.

The large use of the adjective instead of the genitive has already been remarked on, and needs no further emphasis, Adjective. Proleptic use.except so far as it seems to show that neither genitive of place nor genitive of time is local. The proleptic, or predicative, use of the adjective is common, and must be watched. See p. xc.
In the use of the demonstratives Pindar differs from the tragic poets in his comparatively scant employment of o(/de, which is pre-eminently dramatic.

Lyric poetry makes little use of the article proper. This is best shown by a comparison of chorus and dialogue in the Article.drama. In Pindar the old demonstrative sense is still conspicuous, the article can still represent and does represent freely an independent demonstrative pronoun; it can be used as a relative. In combination with the substantive it has the familiar anaphoric use, the emphatic reference to that which is known, the use in vision, like o(/de. In the dactylo-epitrite poems, in which the article is generally less freely employed, the article seems to serve to bind the qualifier to the far-distant substantive, as in the noted passage, O. 12.5: ai(/ ge me\n a)ndrw=n | po/ll' a)/nw, ta\ d' au)= ka/tw yeudh= metamw/nia ta/mnoisai kuli/ndont' e)lpi/des. That this occurs only in the dactylo-epitritesSTEIN, De articuli apud Pindarum usu, Breslau, 1868, p. 34. is not surprising. It is only in the dactylo-epitrites that the movement is deliberate enough to allow the separation. In the tumult of the logaoedic the nexus would be lost. The ordinary use of the article is also found in Pindar, but it would take very little stress to revive the demonstrative meaning. The extensions of the article that are most noteworthy, in comparison with Homer, are the combination with the adjective ta\ terpna/ (O. 9.30), that with the participle o( mh\ suniei/s (N. 4.31), and especially that with the inf., always, except in the disputed passage, O. 2.107, in the nominative. The full development of the articular inf. was reserved for prose.

The free position of the relative and its equivalent article Relative.belongs under another head. Especially worthy of note is the use of the relative in transitions.See Index of Subjects under Relative.

The voices present few peculiarities in Pindar, and it is hardly worth while to notice the so-called intransitive use of Voices.transitive verbs, as any verb can be used intransitively in any sphere of the language. The shifting use of dre/pein and dre/pesqai, of kti/sai and kti/sasqai, may be easily explained on general principles. The middle is no more
causative than the active, and it is a mistake to apply the causative formula as the key wherever the conception seems remote to us. Difficult is ba/leq' a(liki/an (P. 1.74), and the causative explanation may be the true one there, though bale/sqai as a nautical term may have been extended. The middle has more color, more feeling, than the active, and we might be tempted to see in Pindar's use of eu(rei=n, where we might expect eu(re/sqai (P. 2.64), a certain aristocratic contempt of effect, but we find the fut. middle of keladw= (O. 10 [11], 79) and of garu/w (I. 1, 30) where it is worth while to notice the analogy of a)/|somai, boh/somai, and the rest.See the list in RUTHERFORD'S New Phrynichus, p. 383. In a)nadh/santes ko/mas (P. 10.40), ko/mas takes the place of the reflexive pronoun as corpus does in Latin, and so does xai/tan in e)stefa/nwse xai/tan (O. 14.24). On the passive use of katasxo/menos, see P. 1.10. Pindar has no future passive apart from the future middle (see note on O. 8.45: a)/rcetai).

As to the present indicative in Pindar, chiefly worthy of note is the absence of the so-called historical present. Brugmann Present Tense.has recently vindicated the proethnic rights of the historical present on the just ground of the timelessness of the present. It is therefore not a little remarkable that Pindar uses it as little as Homer uses it. To them the historical present must have been either too vulgar or too hurried. ni/setai (O. 3.34) is a true present, and so is de/kontai (P. 5.86). The oracular use of the praesens propheticum is put in the mouth of Apollo, O. 8.40: a(li/sketai, of Medeia, P. 4.49: e)cani/stantai.

The conative force of the present participle is conspicuous, so that it may stand, as in prose, where we might expect the fut., though some would read komi/cwn (P. 4.106) and komi/contas (O. 13.15). But all Pindar's uses of the present participle can be paralleled in good prose. The present inf. in Imperfect and Aorist.oratio obliqua to represent the imperfect after a pres. tense occurs in O. 7.55, a usage very common in Herodotos. A special study has been consecrated to the
use of the imperfect and aorist in Pindar,American Journal of Philology, IV. pp. 158-165. and it has been shown that the aorist, preponderating as it does in lyric narrative, is used, as a rule, with more frequency in the logaoedic poems than in the dactylo-epitrite. An interchange of tenses is not to be conceded. lei=pe is not equivalent to e)/lipe, but means “had to leave” (O. 6.45), ti/kte, “she was a mother” (O. 6.85). The negatived aor. of a negative notion has for its pendant a positive imperfect in P. 3.27: ou)d' e)/laqe skopo/n . . . a)/ien naou= basileu/s. The conative imperfect is Perfect.Panhellenic. The perfect has originally nothing to do with completed action as such. Completed action is only the result of intense action. The perfects of the senses, such as de/dorke (O. 1.94), of emotion, ge/gaqe (N. 3.33), like the perfects of sound, ke/kraga, ke/klagga, te/triga, are not perfects in the ordinary sense. The perfect of the result of action requires no notice. The pluperfect, the perfect of the past, is of rare occurrence in Pindar (O. 6.54) as in Aischylos. The picturesque Homeric use is not found. The Aorist.aorist abounds in sharp summaries, and is used with full consciousness. The gnomic aorist, either as the aorist of the typical action, or as the aorist of experience (empiric aorist), with a negative as ou)/ pw/ tis eu(=ren (O. 12.8), or with pote/ as eu)nai\ para/tropoi e)/balo/n pote (P. 2.35), has many examples in Pindar. In combination with the universal present it sometimes produces the effect of sharp, incisive action (see note on P. 2.90); but we must not overstrain the point.

The future has many marks of a modal origin. It is not simply predictive. Like the English periphrastic “shall” and Future.“will,” it was originally something more than the foretelling of what was to come. Traces of this modal future are found here and there in P. e)re/w, “I must needs tell” (O. 8.57). So kwma/somai (P. 9.96).

The tenses of the moods — durative (present) and complexive Tenses of the Moods.(aoristic) — are used in conformity with the general principles of the language. When a verb of thinking
becomes a verb of wishing or willing, there is no difficulty about the use of the aorist as a future (see note on P. 1.44), but the fut. often lies too near, as P. 4.243, where pra/casqai must give way to pra/cesqai on account of the negative.

The indicative mood requires little comment. In one place the future takes a)/n, N. 7.68: maqw\n de/ tis a)\n e)rei=, where Indicative.a)nerei= is possible. The large use of the indic. in the conditional sentence is especially characteristic of Pindar's love of the concrete.See American Journal of Philology, III. p. 438.

The pure subjunctive in prose, whether in dependent or in independent clauses, is always imperative in its character, Subjunctive.whether we call it adhortative, interrogative, or final. The subjunctive question expects an imperative answer. Examples of familiar constructions are P. 1.60: a)/g' e)/peit' e)ceu/rwmen u(/mnon, I. 7 (8), 6: mh/t' e)n o)rfani/a| pe/swmen stefa/nwn | mh/te ka/dea qera/peue, O. 5.24: mh\ mateu/sh| qeo\s gene/sqai. On the short-vowel subj., see O. 1.7. In O. 2.2: keladh/somen may be either fut. or subj. The Homeric use of the subjunctive in which the imperative tone is lowered to simple prediction (compare the toning - down of “shall” and “will,” just referred to) is not found in Pindar.

The opt. when standing free is regularly a wishing mood in Pindar, the wish passing easily, at times, into the semblance of Optative.a command. The opt. of wish usually dispenses with ei) ga/r in P. — ei) ga/r with opt. is found in P. 1.46; N. 7 (8), 98 — and the present seems to occur more frequently than is usual in proportion to the aor. Pres. e. g. O. 1.115; 4, 12; 6, 97 (?). 102; 8, 85. 88; 9, 80; P. 1.46. 56; 10, 17; 11, 50. Aor. e. g. O. 8.29; 9, 84; 13, 25; P. 1.47; 9, 90. In one breath we have the opt., O. 13.26: a)fqo/nhtos ge/noio, in the next the imperative, eu)/qune (v. 28). fe/rois (O. 9.44), u(poska/ptoi tis (N. 5.19), are to all intents imperatives, and so the optatives O. 3.45 and P. 10.21, where ei)/h is commonly set down as potential opt., and equivalent to opt. with a)/n. Of this old potential use of the opt. there are only
a few examples, and hardly one of these beyond cavil. The clearest is O. 11 (10), end: ou)/t' ai)/qwn a)lw/phc | ou)/t' e)ri/bromoi le/ontes dialla/cainto h)=qos, where Hartung reads dialla/caint' a)\n h)=qos despite digamma, Schroeder, dialla/canto (gnomic aor.).

The imperative follows the rule. As every other idiomatic Greek author, Pindar has many examples of the weight of the Imperative.present imperative — a string, P. 1.86 foll. — of the impact of the aor., see O. 1.76 foll. Special uses have not been noted.

Inseparably connected with the use of the moods is the use of the particles a)/n and ken.For particulars see American Journal of Philology, III. pp. 446-455; B. BREYER, Analecta Pindarica, p. 12 foll. In Homer ken prepondera)/n and ken.ates over a)/n: in Pindar a)/n has gained greatly on ken. In the Iliad ken stands to a)/n as 4 to 1. In Pindar they nearly balance. In all Homer there is but one ken with inf., Il. 22. 11, and that used in a confused way, but one a)/n, Il. 9. 684, and that with direct reference to v. 417. Pindar has no a)/n with the inf., but he uses ken three times with the inf., with pres. (P. 7.20), with aor. (P. 3.111), with fut. (O. 1.110). Pindar has Homer's leaning to a)/n with the negative, but he does not use it in the formulated conditional sentence, although it has effected a lodgment in the generic relative and in the temporal sentence, from which in Attic it was destined to shut out the old constructions with the pure subjunctive.

A short space must suffice for the behavior of the moods in compound sentences. The structure of the sentence is very much simplified by the large use of the participle and the freedom of the infinitive. Pindar has much less variety than Homer, and in syntax, as in other matters, shows a certain daintiness of selection.

The Homeric form of oratio obliqua is also the Pindaric. The reigning form is the infinitive. So with le/gonti, O. 2.31; Oratio obliqua.9, 53; fanti/, O. 7.54; P. 4.88; fa=, O. 6.49; fa/to, P. 4.33; eu)/xonto, O. 6.54; fqe/gcomai, O. 1.36. Even with ei)=pe (against the rule), O. 7.62. (Cf. J. Mart. Ap. I. 12, 32.)
The ind. with w(s (N. 1.35) or o(/ti (O. 1.48) is occasionally used. Notice the prolepsis in O. 14.22: ui(o\n ei)/ph|s o(/ti . . . voi . . . e)stefa/nwse xai/tan.

Homer does not use the opt. after a past tense to represent the indicative, except after an interrogative.American Journal of Philology, IV. p. 419. So in Pindar the indicative after an interrogative may remain as P. 4.63; N. 1.61; 3, 25, or be changed into the opt. as P. 9.126, where one would be tempted to turn the fut. opt. into the fut. indic. were it not for O. 6.49, where the relative, being confounded with the interrogative, takes the opt.

In the causal sentence we find o(/ti, O. 1.60; 3, 39; 8, 33; 10 (11), 35; P. 2.31. 73 al.; w(s, O. 13.45; N. 6.34, but Causal Sentences.chiefly e)pei/, O. 2.108; 3, 6; 4, 12; 6, 27; 7, 61. 90 al. The mood is the indicative or an equivalent opt. and a)/n (O. 13.45).

The chief final particle is o)/fra, a particle that was already obsolescent. Selected by Pindar doubtless for its antique Final Sentences.sound, it was soon to disappear from classical poetry. That he had no feeling for its original signification is shown by the fact that he never employs it in its temporal sense.See WEBER, Entwickelungsgeschichte der Absichtssätze, p. 72; American Journal of Philology, IV. p. 431. o)/fra occurs eleven times, w(s three times, w(s a)/n once, o(/pws once, mh/ four times, i(/na, “in order that,” never. For w(s a)/n see O. 7.42; o(/pws (N. 3.62) has been needlessly attacked. The sequence is regular, principal tenses being followed by the subj., historical tenses by the opt. — a rule fixed by Homer. The two exceptions are easily explained. P. 4.92: o)/fra . . . e)/ratai is good for all time, O. 7.13: kate/ban is an aorist used as a perfect, the perfect form being regularly used as a present.American Journal of Philology, IV. p. 429 (note).

Remarkable for its narrow range and its sharpness is PinConditional Sentences.dar's treatment of the conditional sentence.For details see American Journal of Philology, III. pp. 434-445. The most striking feature is the predominance of the
logical hypothesis, the indicative in protasis, the indicative or equivalent in apodosis. This form outnumbers far all the others put together. It is largely a mere formal condition. It is based on what the poet knows or sees. Sometimes it is generic (see O. 11 [10], 4), but it almost always has in view a particular illustration of the principle involved.

The generic condition proper is put in the old form of this hypothesis, ei) with the subj., chiefly, perhaps exclusively the aorist subj., for in I. 4 (5), 12: ei) a)kou/sh|, almost forces itself on the reader. Pindar knows nothing of ei)/ ke, h)/n, ei) a)/n.

Pindar's few ideal conditions (ei) with opt.) occur in dreamy, wistful passages, which seem to show that the optative is, after all, not ill-named. Sometimes we can feel the growth out of the wish (O. 1.108; P. 3.110), sometimes formal wish is followed by an apodosis (P. 1.46). Still fewer are the unreal conditions, conditions against fact, and in these we hear the hopeless wish (P. 3.63. 73). We are evidently in a different world from Homer's, we are lapsing into formulae.For examples see Index of Subjects, s. v. Condition.

The relative sentence follows the lines of the first two classes of the condition, except that it admits ken and a)/n in generic Relative Sentences.sentences with the subj. ken, N. 4.7 (acc. to the Schol.), a)/n, P. 1.100; 5, 65; 10, 23; N. 4.91; pure subj., O. 3.11; 6, 75; 8, 11; N. 3.71; 9, 44; I. 1, 50; 6 (7), 18. The Homeric ken with subj. of a more exact future occurs in the most epic of all the odes, P. 4.51. Opt. with a)/n occurs in P. 9.129: o(\s a)\n yau/seie, for which see the passage.

It is in the temporal sentence that the need of expressing generic and particular action, prior and subsequent action, is Temporal Sentences.felt most distinctly. The original generic here too was the pure subj. which Pindar retains here and there in the fragments. But a)/n with the temporal particles has already formed a stable compound for the expression of indefinite and future relations. O. 2.23; 6, 67; 10 (11), 100; P. 1.4; 2, 11; 3, 106; 5, 2; 8, 8. 96. This a)/n with
subj. is retained after a past tense, O. 13.80; N. 1.67; there is no frequentative opt., no opt. representing a)/n w. subj. in Pindar.
Of course the indicative is used of particular occasions. Noteworthy is the use of o(po/te with the indic. (see note on P. 3.91). The fulness of the form gives it the effect of the exact h(ni/ka.

Of the temporal particles of limit Pindar uses a(=s = e(/ws once, O. 10 (11), 56, pri/n with the aor. inf., according to the norm, in the sense of “before,” as P. 2.92; 3, 9; 9, 122; N. 7.73; 8, 51; 9, 26, pri/n with the indic., also according to the norm, in the sense of “until,”American Journal of Philology, II. pp. 467-469. O. 9.57; 13, 65, with neg., N. 4.28.

The infinitive plays a large part in Pindar. It has been sufficiently deadened to admit the article (post-Homeric).American Journal of Philology, III. p. 192 foll. Transactions Amer. Philol. Assoc., 1878, p. 11 (for the position). Most Infinitive.of the examples are in the aorist, O. 2.56. 107; 8, 59. 60; 9, 40; P. 1.99; N. 8.44. The present occurs in O. 9.41; P. 2.56; N. 5.18. These are all nominatives except the disputed O. 2.107, and all retain the demonstrative force of the article. The language has not yet allowed itself to violate the sense of form by using a preposition with what had been so long felt as a dative. And this dative force — for the infinitive seems to be the dative of a verbal noun — accounts for all that is peculiar in the use of the Pindaric infinitive. Whether we call it epexegetic, whether we call it final, we are still in the sphere of the dative. It is hardly needful to cite a)gaqo\n ma/rnasqai (O. 6.17), sofo\s korusse/men (P. 8.74), or even eu(rhsieph\s a)nagei=sqai (O. 9.86), and e)pifane/steron puqe/sqai (P. 7.7). What the later language has retained only here and there in phrases, Pindar uses as of right, dw=ke . . . xri/esqai (P. 4.222), pe/mpen a)nadei=sqai (I. 2, 16). The inf. is consecutive enough, and seldom takes w(/ste, but four times in all, once O. 9.80. The
consecutive notion proper (w(/ste with indic.) is not suited to epic and lyric, in which the final abounds. Of course the infinitive had long been so far deorganized as to serve as a representative of the indic. in oratio obliqua, and in this respect Pindar presents no peculiarities, except that he sometimes holds the aorist inf. to its timelessness. See above, p. civ.
The infinitive is closely akin to the opt., and it is not surprising that it should be used as such. P. 1.67: *zeu= te/lei), ai)ei\ diakri/nein lo/gon a)nqrw/pwn (= ei)/qe diakri/noi lo/gos).
For the inf. as an imperative see O. 13.114, where some read kou/foisi/ m' e)kneu=sai posi/n, and give the inf. an optative use.

After a long discourse, in which participles had been used very freely, Sokrates says in Plato's Phaidros, 238 D: ta\ nu=n ga\r ou)ke/ti po/rrw diqura/mbwn fqe/ggomai, and it is natural Participles. that the lyric poet should make large use of the participle, which enables him to concentrate his narrative on the main points, while preserving the color of the thought or the description. We are prone to analyze the participle, to call it temporal, conditional, adversative, whereas the participial form avoids and often defies the analysis. When the later rhetorician wanted logical clearness, he would none of the participle, and Dionysios of Halikarnassos makes a distinct point against IsaiosIudicium de Isaeo, 598 (R). Compare Am. Journ. of Phil. IX. p. 142. for multiplying the genitive absolute. In narrative the participle gives color, gives atmosphere. Turn it into a finite verb and you have a catalogue, at best an outline, and not a picture. Notice the effect of O. 1.49-51, where each point of horror is accentuated, ta/mon . . . dieda/santo kai\ fa/gon. When the poet finds that he has been too leisurely in his narrative, his haste is marked by the use of finite verbs. So at the close of the story of the Argonautic expedition, after recounting the adventure with the fire-breathing oxen, in which descriptive participles play a conspicuous part (P. 4.224-237), Pindar, as if feeling that his time was short, has not a participle to throw away on the adventure of
the dragon, and when he openly acknowledges (v. 247) that he must be brief, he touches off each stage in the subsequent action with a single finite aorist verb, and does not even allow a parenthetic imperfect.

Instead, then, of the formal sentences of time, cause, adversative relation, condition, purpose, we often find the participle, although in many cases it is best not to analyze. The temporal relation is of course that which is rooted in the partiTemporal Participle.ciple, and all the others come from that. Ordinarily the aorist part. precedes in time the finite verb with which it is associated. O. 1.71: e)lqw
 . . . a)/puen, O. 6.37: pie/sas xo/lon . . . w)/|xet' i)w/n, O. 13.86: a)naba\s . . . e)/paizen, P. 4.112: ka=dos . . . qhka/menoi . . . pe/mpon, v. 149: a)pou/rais . . . ne/meai, P. 9.32: semno
 a)/ntron . . . prolipw
 qumo
 . . . qau/mason, N. 1.43: peira=to de\ prw=ton ma/xas . . . doiou\s . . . ma/ryais . . . o)/fias. The tenses are often so combined that the durative tense of the participle accompanies and colors the leading verb in the aor. The effect of this is to hold the balance between the tenses. Any descriptive passage will give examples.See American Journal of Philology, IV. p. 165. So O. 6.46: e)qre/yanto . . . kado/menoi, v. 48: e)lau/nwn i(/keto, P. 4.95: i(/keto speu/dwn, v. 135: e)ssu/menoi . . . kate/stan. The action is often coincident. O. 10 (11), 53: e)/qhke do/rpou lu/sin | tima/sais po/ron *)alfeou=, I. 5 (6), 51: ei)=pe/n te fwnh/sais a(/te ma/ntis a)nh/r, P. 3.35: e)s kako
 tre/yais e)dama/ssato/ nin. So with the durative tenses, P. 4.271: xrh\ malaka
 xe/ra prosba/llonta trw/man e(/lkeos a)mfipolei=n. The coincidence is sometimes disguised by the negative. So O. 8.29: tou=to pra/sswn mh\ ka/moi (= karteroi/h), O. 6.36: ou)d' e)/laqe (=fanera\ h)=n) . . . kle/ptoisa.

The participle is used after verbs of perception (intellectual and actual) as usual. O. 6.8: i)/stw . . . e)/xwn, I. 6 (7), 27: Participle after Verbs of Perception.i)/stw . . . au)/cwn, O. 14.16: i)doi=sa to/nde kw=mon . . . kou=fa bibw=nta, P. 2.54: ei)=don . . . *)arxi/loxon . . . piaino/menon, N. 11.15: qnata\ memna/sqw periste/llwn me/lh, O. 10 (11), 3: o)fei/lwn e)pile/laqa. Actual perception is
seldom put in the aor. part., usually in pres. or perf., P. 5.84: kapnwqei=san pa/tran . . . i)/don, P. 10.23: o(\s a)
 . . . ui(o
 i)/dh| tuxo/nta stefa/nwn, I. 7 (8), 36: ui(o
 ei)side/tw qano/nt' e)n pole/mw|.

Causal is an inference from temporal. So often with verbs of emotion. So P. 1.13: a)tu/zontai . . . a)i/onta, P. 4.112: Causal Participle.dei/santes u(/brin . . . pe/mpon, v. 122: ga/qhsen . . . go/non i)dw/n, N. 3.33: ge/gaqe . . . tamw/n. For a remarkable construction, where the participle is treated exactly as o(/ti with a finite verb, see P. 7.15.

The adversative relation is expressed in Greek chiefly by the participle. The language is sometimes kind enough to Adversative Participle.give warning of this by kai/per and o(/mws, but often no notice is given, and failure to understand it is charged to stupidity. I. 7 (8), 5: kai/per a)xnu/menos, N. 6.7: kai/per ou)k ei)do/tes, P. 4.140: traxei=an e(rpo/ntwn pro\s e)/pibdan o(/mws, O. 1.46: maio/menoi, N. 4.85: kei=nos a)mf' *)axe/ronti naieta/wn e)ma\n | glw=ssan eu(re/tw keladh=tin. So P. 1.64: nai/ontes, P. 4.180: naieta/ontes.

Pindar has a number of participles, which, if analyzed, would yield a conditional precipitate. This analysis is someConditional Participle.times forcibly suggested by ke. So O. 6.7: e)piku/rsais=ei) e)piku/rseie, O. 10 (11), 22: qh/cais=ei) qh/ceie, P. 10.29: i)w/n = ei) i)/ois, v. 62: tuxw/n = ei) tu/xois, N. 4.93: ai)ne/wn = ei) ai)noi/h, N. 9.34: u(paspi/zwn = ei) u(ph/spizes. But it is often best to let analysis alone. Given, eu(rh/seis e)reunw=n (O. 13.113), and causal and conditional meet. The Attic would resolve: e)a\n e)reuna=|s, eu(rh/seis, not so Pindar.

The fut. participle, as is well known, has a very limited range in Greek, being employed chieflye)ssome/nas amounts to an adj. (O. 12.8), like the Lat. futurus. An extension of the use is seen in N. 5.1: e)linu/sonta verga/zesqai a)ga/lmata. I. 2, 46: ou)k e)linu/sontas au)tou\s ei)rgasa/man. in the old modal Future Participle.sense of the future after verbs of motion, or as the representative of the indicative after verbs of perception and after w(s — the last a comparatively late growth.
After verbs of motion Pindar has the future participle, e. g. O. 6.38: w)/|xet' i)w
 manteuso/menos, O. 5.19: e)/rxomai ai)th/swn: but the present participle occurs so often with verbs of motion that it is not worth while to change a)gkomi/zwn (P. 4.105) into a)gkomi/cwn, P. 2.3: fe/rwn me/los e)/rxomai, N. 5.3: stei=xe . . . diagge/lloisa, N. 10.16: au)la
 e)sh=lqen . . . fe/rwn, v. 66: h)=lqe . . . diw/kwn, N. 11.34: e)/ba . . . a)na/gwn. There is of course a difference, as appears O. 5.19: e)/rxomai *ludi/ois a)pu/wn e)n au)loi=s ai)th/swn, but the two blend, as is seen O. 8.49: a(/rma qoo
 ta/nuen a)pope/mpwn . . . e)poyo/menos.

This is not the place to discuss the origin and development of the genitive absolute. The detachment must have been Genitive Absolute.gradual, beginning probably with the genitive of the time within which with the present and extending to the aorist, beginning with the pure genitive and extending to the abl. genitive until it became phraseological and lost to consciousness. The last step is taken when the subject is omitted, a step not taken by Homer except Il. 18. 406 = Od. 4. 19. In Pindar it is rare. See note on P. 8.43.

In Pindar the genitive absolute is evidently not so free as it is in later times, and whenever there is easy dependence we must accept it. P. 3.25: e)lqo/ntos eu)na/sqh ce/nou | le/ktroisin a)p' *)arkadi/as, P. 11.33: purwqe/ntwn | *trw/wn e)/luse do/mous a(bro/tatos. See also note on P. 8.85. In Homer the present part. is far more common than the aor.;CLASSEN, Beobachtungen über den homerischen Sprachgebrauch, p. 180. in Pindar, acc. to a recent count, aor. and pres. nearly balance. The relation is chiefly temporal; cause and condition come in incidentally. Of time aor., P. 1.80: a)ndrw=n kamo/ntwn, O. 3.19: bwmw=n a(gisqe/ntwn,N. 1.41: oi)xqeisa=n pula=n. Fennell in his note admits the possibility of the dragons having opened the gates. This would have been naturally oi)/cantes pu/las. In Latin the first inference with the passive form of the abl. absol. is the identity of the agent with the subject of the sentence; in Greek with the passive form of the genitive absolute it is the last, and, to say the least, rare. P. 4.69: pleusa/ntwn *minua=n, P. 4.292: lh/cantos ou)/rou
al., pres., O. 5.23: ui(w=n paristame/nwn, P. 11.17: foneuome/nou patro/s. Of cause or condition, O. 3.39: eu)i/ppwn dido/ntwn *tundarida=n, P. 10.55: *)efurai/wn . . . proxeo/ntwn al.

The participle differs from the infinitive, from the verbal noun in concreteness, and concreteness is one of the marks of Concrete use of Participle.Pindar's style; so that it is not surprising to find him using the participle instead of the infinitive, instead of the abstract noun. We are so used to this in certain Latin authors that we overlook its rarity in Greek, and yet we are startled when we meet such a specimen as O. 9.111: a)/neu de\ qeou= sesigame/non | ou) skaio/teron xrh=m' e(/kaston, where the participle has a much more cogent effect than sesiga=sqai. An analysis into e)a\n sesighme/non h)=| would weaken the sentence hopelessly. P. 11.22: po/tero/n nin a)/r' *)ifige/nei) e)p' *eu)ri/pw| | sfaxqei=sa th=le pa/tras e)/knisen; P. 3.102: [*)axilleu\s] w)=rsen puri\ kaio/menos | e)k *danaw=n go/on. See note on O. 3.6. In like manner interpret P. 2.21: *)ici/ona fanti\ tau=ta brotoi=s | le/gein e)n ptero/enti troxw=| | panta=| kulindo/menon. Ixion does not preach; he gives an object lesson.

The few examples of the participle in the predicate fall under the rule. They are either adjectives or are dissociated Participle in Predicate.from the copulative verb.See W. J. ALEXANDER in American Journal of Philology, IV. 291 foll., and my Justin Martyr, Apol. I. 3, 4; 19, 5. Compare note on P. 6.28, and notice the parallelism, N. 9.32: e)nti/ toi fi/lippoi/ t' au)to/qi kai\ ktea/nwn e)/xontes kre/ssonas a)/ndras.

Many other points must be omitted for want of space, and the reader is referred to the commentary for further particulars. The large use of parataxis makes the Pindaric handling of the particles of especial interest to the grammarian, and we find exactness as in the use of te . . . te . . ., te kai/, paired with bold variation as me\n . . . te. It must suffice here, if the impression has been produced that in syntax, as in everything else, Pindar is sharp, cogent, effective. There is no “subjectivity” about his pictures, and the syntax plays its part, too often overlooked, in producing the bold contour.
A complete Pindaric syntax would be at the same time a theory of Pindaric style.

The order of words in Pindar is of prime importance to those who would study “composition” in the antique sense, Order of Words.but the effect of the sequence of sounds must be left to special studies.HARRE, De verborum apud Pindarum conlocatione, Berlin, 1867. Noteworthy is Pindar's fondness for alliteration in d, p, k, t, m. Sigmatism, which his teacher, Lasos of Hermione, avoided so much that he actually composed a number of asigmatic poems, was not shunned by Pindar, as appears in P. 2.80. Nor did he scrupulously avoid the recurrence of the same groups in successive syllables, P. 2.80: u(pe\r e(/rkos, O. 6.16: ei)=pen e)n *qh/baisi, O. 4.22: e)n e)/ntesi, P. 1.69: a(ghth\r a)nh/r. Rhymes are not infrequent. Of course they are felt chiefly when rhythmical stress brings them out, P. 4.193: xruse/an xei/ressi labw\n fiala/n, P. 4.32: a)lla\ ga\r no/stou pro/fasis glukerou=, less where the rhyming words have different stress, as O. 9.24: malerai=s e)pifle/gwn a)oidai=s. To the average reader, however, the position of words is chiefly of interest, so far as it gives emphasis to the leading elements, and in this respect the study of the rhythms aids very much in removing the difficulties that the beginner may find. In the equable measures of the dactylo-epitrites the separation of the words gives very little trouble. Our minds are attuned to the leisurely motion, and we can afford to wait. The stress - points of the verse signal to one another. No matter what the distance between beginning and end of a verse, they are never really far apart, and then again the meaning is often to be gathered from the edge of the ode in a manner of acrostic. The attention is often kept alive by suspense, the object being held back as if it were the answer to a riddle, and this very suspense serves to preserve the organic unity as well as to bind epode more closely to antistrophe. Sometimes when the thought seems to have reached its legitimate end, a message follows, a momentous codicil to the poetic testament, a condition, a restriction. Sometimes again a word is
held by the power of the rhythm until it penetrates the whole structure. Sometimes the poet strikes sharply two or three notes that convey to the student the movement of the whole, and O. 2 and P. 5 give up their secret to the skilled in song. All this is capable of demonstration, but it is a weariness to demonstrate what every one who attacks Pindar resolutely will soon find out for himself.See Index of Subjects under Position. Certain peculiarities of position,More stress might have been laid on the regular interposition of the preposition between attribute and substantive or substantive and attribute. See notes on O. 1.37; 5, 22; P. 8.88. such as hyperbaton and chiasm have been duly noticed in the commentary. The hyperbata are not over-common nor over-harsh. Chiasm is not unfrequently overlooked by the beginner; it is the beautiful Greek method of giving a double stress to opposing pairs, a stress that we are prone to bring about by the mechanical expedient of hammering emphasis and dead pause.

A word here as to the figure known as hypallage, for while hypallage is not the result of the order of words, it is the reHypallage.sult of the close knitting of words. By hypallage an attribute that belongs in logical strictness to one word of a complex is applied to another. Sometimes it makes so little difference that no notice has been taken of it in this edition. If, for instance, the kine are dun, what trouble is given by bow=n canqa\s a)ge/las (P. 4.149)? In other cases, however, the effect is much more marked, the words are rolled together so as to give a superb unity, as O. 3.3: *qh/rwnos *)olumpioni/kan u(/mnon rather than *qh/rwnos *)olumpioni/kou u(/mnon, as in O. 10 (11), 6: yeude/wn e)nipa\n a)lito/cenon, as in P. 4.255: u(mete/ras a)kti=nos o)/lbou . Of Pindar's noble compounds something has been said already, but the range is much extended if we consider the manner in which he gathers up word after word into the sweep of his movement, and we begin to feel that there is something in the profundo ore of Horace.

SyracuseIn the historical introductions, especial acknowledgments are due to Mezger. was founded by a colony of Dorians from Corinth, under the Herakleid Archias, in Ol. 11, 3 (734 B.C.). The first point settled was the island Ortygia ( N. 1.1: a)/mpneuma semno\n *)alfeou=, | kleina=n *surakossa=n qa/los *)ortugi/a ), with which Achradina, on the mainland, was afterwards united. The city grew until it embraced in its circuit five districts, each worthy to be called a city; but even in the earlier time Pindar's address was no figure of speech, P. 2.1: megalopo/lies w)= *sura/kosai .

The constitution of Syracuse, originally aristocratic, was changed into a tyrannis by Gelon, prince of Gela, who reconciled the factions of the city, Ol. 73, 4 (485 B.C.). After Gelon became lord of Syracuse, he made it his residence, enlarged it, built up Achradina, added Tyche, and what was afterwards called Neapolis. All this was not accomplished without high-handed measures, such as the transplanting of the populations of other cities. Gela lost half its inhabitants.
