Kamarina was razed to the ground, and the Kamarinaians transferred in a body to Syracuse (see O. 4). Under Gelon's rule Syracuse became the chief city of Sicily, the tyrant of Syracuse one of the most important personages on Grecian soil. Applied to by the Greeks for aid, when the invasion of Xerxes was impending, Gelon offered two hundred triremes, twenty thousand men-at-arms, two thousand cavalry, two thousand archers, two thousand slingers, two thousand light troops, and provisions for the whole Greek army until the close of the war, on condition that he should have the command in chief
(Herod. 7, 158). Soon after this offer was declined, Gelon was called on to help his father-in-law, Theron of Akragas, against the Carthaginians, who had espoused the cause of Terillos of Himera (see O. 12), and Anaxilas of Rhegion, son-in-law of Terillos.

The great battle of Himera, popularly put on the same day as the battle of Salamis — really fought somewhat earlier — ended in the signal defeat of the Carthaginians, who lost one hundred and fifty thousand men dead on the field. The Carthaginians sued for peace, which was granted on singularly easy terms; for the Carthaginians were backed by the Persian empire with its vast resources. The battle of Salamis had not yet shown the weakness of the Persian power; and, in fact, the immediate effect of that battle has been exaggerated. Persia lost little of her prestige until the close of the fifth century, and Persian gold was a potent element in Greek history far into the fourth.

The consequence of the victory at Himera was a vast accession of power and influence for Gelon. Anaxilas of Rhegion, and a number of Sicilian cities, recognized his supremacy. But in the midst of his plans and projects Gelon died of dropsy, Ol. 75, 3 (478 B.C.). To his brother, Polyzelos, he left the command of the army, the guardianship of his minor son, and the hand of his widow, daughter of Theron. Hieron, the elder of the surviving brothers, who had been prince of Gela, succeeded to the government. Owing to the machinations of Hieron, Polyzelos was forced to take refuge with Theron of Akragas, who was at once his father-in-law and his son-in-law; and a war between Hieron and Theron was imminent, had not a reconciliation been effected by Simonides, the poet. Polyzelos was allowed to return to Syracuse, but Hieron was thenceforward sole ruler. In 477 the Epizephyrian Lokrians invoked the help of Hieron against Anaxilas of Rhegion; the prince sent his brother-inlaw, Chromios (see N. 1 and 9), to Anaxilas, and the lord of Rhegion held his hand. In 474 the inhabitants of Kyme (Cumae) were hard pressed by the Etruscans. Hieron immediately granted the desired aid, and defeated the Etruscans in a naval engagement off Cumae. A helmet with the inscription *(ia/rwn o( *deinome/neos | kai\ toi\ *surako/sioi | tw=| *di\ *tura/n' a)po\ *ku/mas was found at Olympia in 1817 (Hicks, No. 15). The year after — Ol. 76, 4 (473 B.C.) — Hieron defeated Thrasydaios, son of Theron, and Akragas and Himera both acknowledged his sway; but he granted them their independence and a democratic constitution.

To his success in war Hieron wished to add the heroic honors paid to the founder of a new city. This new city, Aitna, was founded, Ol. 76, 1 (476 B.C.), in the territory of Katana, the old inhabitants having been removed to Leontini. Ten thousand citizens were imported, half from Syracuse and Gela, the other half Peloponnesian immigrants. The constitution was Doric; and Hieron's son, Deinomenes, and his brother-in-law, Chromios, were put in charge. Hieron often called himself *ai)tnai=os (P. 1); Chromios followed his example (N. 1), and the founding of the city was celebrated by the “Aitnaian women” of Aischylos, and by Pindar's first Pythian.

The court of Hieron was a centre of literature and art. Epicharmos was a frequent guest. Aischylos, Simonides, Bakchylides, Pindar were among the visitors. No Doric prince ever reached such a height of glory. He was brilliantly successful at the great games: Ol. 73 and 77, with the single horse; Ol. 78, with the chariot; Pyth. 26 and 27, with the single horse; Pyth. 29, with the chariot, and again with mules. Successes elsewhere are not unlikely. He devised and performed liberal things. A special treasury was erected at Olympia for the Carthaginian booty, and the noble gift which he vowed to the Olympian Zeus was set up after his death by his son Deinomenes — a bronze four-horse chariot and driver, the work of Onatas, on either side a horse with a boy rider by Kalamis.

As a Doric prince, Hieron has found as little favor with posterity as he did with his Athenian contemporary Themistokles. A tyrant, he helped the moralists to make the uneasiness of crowned heads still more uneasy. He became the type of splendid success and of splendid misery; for he was tortured by bodily suffering, he was surrounded by sycophants and informers, and lived in an atmosphere of treachery and meanness. Those who see in Pindar's Hieronic odes sermons levelled at the unfortunate prince will be inclined to despise the greatest ruler of his day. A more humane judgment will recognize high qualities impaired by the faults that were engendered and exaggerated by the tyrannis.
Hieron died Ol. 78, 2 (467 B.C.), at Aitna, and upon his death received heroic honors.

The first Olympian celebrates the victory gained by Hieron, Ol. 77 (472 B.C.), with his race-horse Pherenikos. He was then
at the height of his power and glory. Some put the ode four years earlier, Ol. 76 (476 B.C.).

The theme of the poem is given in v. 7, mhd' *)olumpi/as a)gw=na fe/rteron au)da/somen ; and while every Olympian does honor to Olympia, this is the pro/swpon thlauge/s, this is, as Lucian says (Gall. 7), to\ ka/lliston tw=n a)|sma/twn a(pa/ntwn. It may have been put first, because it was the most beautiful; but it owes, in turn, no little of its celebrity to its position, for which it was commended by its myth as well as by its theme. The chariot-race of Pelops for Hippodameia was the true beginning of Olympian contests, and the Pelopion was the heart of Pisa. The Aiolian rhythms are bright and festal, and glitter as the language glitters. Pindar is consciously treading a lofty measure. “No better element than water,” he says, “no brighter blaze than fire by night, no form of wealth that outdazzles gold, no light of heaven so luminous, so warming, as the sun, which dims the ether into voidness, no contest more noble than the Olympian, the source of highest songs to highest bards, chanting Zeus supreme in the palace of Sicily's chief lord, who plucks the loftiest fruits of emprise, who is decked with the sheen of the fairest flower of poesy. For him the noblest chords must be struck, the sweetest musings of the poet recalled, and the scene brought back when the steed Victor bore his lord to triumph (vv. 1-22). Forth shines his glory in the land which Lydian Pelops made his own, for Pelops, the favorite of the gods, has found his resting-place (v. 93) where Hieron, favorite of the gods, has won his victory. The fame of Hieron shines forth (v. 23) — the fame of the Olympiads looks forth (v. 94) — and the story of Pelops is encircled by a belt of glory.”

In his version of the Pelops legend (vv. 25-96), Pindar contradicts the popular account: hence the elaborate caveat at the outset. To make the myth resplendent as his theme, he must remove the foulness of envious tongues. No cannibal feast was offered to the gods by Tantalos, none shared by them (v. 52). Tantalos's sin — the giving of the sacred nectar and ambrosia to his fellows — brought ceaseless woe on himself; but his son, though sent to earth again, was remembered by Poseidon, to whom he had been what Ganymede was afterwards to Zeus. The darkness of the fate of Tantalos only heightens the brilliancy of the fortunes of Lydian Pelops.

The story told, the tone is sensibly lowered. An Olympian victory is still sunshine for life, and Pindar avers that no prince
more deserving of what is noble — none of more powerful sway — shall be set forth by his hymns; but there is the old moral that the present good is the highest, and the old restlessness of hope for a yet sweeter song, and a yet more glorious victory. And then, at the last, the poem rises to the height at which it began. The Muse has her most powerful shaft in keeping for the poet's bow. The king, as king, whatever else others may attain, is at the summit of human fortune. Look no further. Prayer can only seek the keeping of this lofty height for king and bard alike (vv. 97-116).
The poem is an epitome of Pindar's manner — approach by overlapping parallels, the dexterous use of foils, implicit imagery. His moralizing is national. No Greek lets us off from that.
The rhythm is Aiolian (*ai)olhi+/di molpa=|, v. 102), the tune the rider-tune (i(ppei/w| no/mw|, v. 101). On the reconciliation of this statement with v. 18, *dwri/an fo/rmigga, see the passage.

div3.head: Strophe 1
div3.p:
a)/riston me
 u(/dwr: Much cited in antiquity, and variously interpreted. h( xrh=sis u(pere/xei, says Aristotle, o(/qen le/getai a)/riston me
 u(/dwr (Rhet. 1, 7, 14) . No profound philosophical tenet is involved, as is shown by the parallel passage, O. 3.42: ei) d' a)risteu/ei me
 u(/dwr, ktea/nwn de\ xruso\s ai)doie/staton, kte( . The poet emphasizes, after the Greek fashion, water as the source and sustenance of life. The copula e)sti/, ei)si/ is rare in P. This first sentence is characteristic of P.'s advance by a series of steps. “Water,” “gold,” “sun” are only for the enhancement of the Olympic games. Much in P. is merely foil.

o( de/: The article is still largely deictic in P. Notice the rhythm, which is an important guide. o( de/, “but there is another — gold — a blazing fire like it loometh — a night fire far above all proud wealth.”
pu=r is brought into close relation with nukti/ by its position.
nukti/: The local-temporal dative. Below e)n a(me/ra|.
mega/noros: P. 10.18: a)ga/nora plou=ton.
garu/en: Dor. for ghru/ein. The inf. in -en is well authenticated in several Pindaric passages.
mhke/ti: More vivid than mh/ (Herm.). Look for no other light, now that the sun has risen.
e)n a(me/ra| faenno/n: suggested by pu=r nukti/.

e)rh/mas: Not otiose. There are no rivals;
mo/nos a(/lios e)n ou)ranw=|, Simonid. fr. 77 (Bgk.). *ai)qh/r is Homerically fem. here and O. 13.88: ai)qe/ros yuxra=s a)po\ ko/lpwn e)rh/mwn.
di' ai)qe/ros: Note P.'s peculiarly plastic use of the prepositions.

au)da/somen: There is no good reason for denying to P. the so-called short subj., as here and O. 7.3. The imper. fut. with mh/, which so many commentators accept here, has little warrant anywhere. In So. Ai. 572, still cited in some books, qh/sousi depends on o(/pws. See note on O. 6.24. I. 7 (8), 8, damwso/meqa was understood by the Schol. as subj., and de/cetai in a generic sense — Fr. X. 4: oi(=si . . . de/cetai — is in all likelihood a subj.

a)mfiba/lletai: Variously rendered. P.'s usage (see O. 2.98; 9, 5; 13, 93 al.) indicates a shower of poetic be/lh or kh=la whirring about the minds of the bards. So the mantei=a in So. O.R. 481 a)ei\ zw=nta peripota=tai. Cf. Eur. H. F. 422: a)mfibalei=n be/lesin.
sofw=n = a)oidw=n. They are called e)pe/wn te/ktones, P. 3.113 .
keladei=n: Favorite word with P., who has ennobled it. “Sound forth,” “praise.” The inf. in its old final sense.

*kro/nou pai=da: There is always a certain stateliness in genealogy. The adjective is still statelier than the genitive. Cf. O. 2.13: a)ll' w)= *kro/nie pai= *(re/as. There is good reason for the specially common mention of Kronos in the Olympians. See v. 111.
e)s a)fnea\n . . . ma/kairan: See v. 6. Compare P. 5.11: tea\n ma/kairan e(sti/an, and I. 3 (4), 35: e)rh/mwsen ma/kairan e(sti/an.

i(kome/nous: Concord with the involved subject of keladei=n. The v. 1. i(kome/nois is not to be considered. Cf. I. 5 (6), 21: te/qmio/n moi fami\ safe/staton ta/nd' e)pistei/xonta na=son r(aine/men eu)logi/ais.

div3.head: Antistrophe 1
div3.p: qemistei=on . . . ska=pton: Lit., “staff of doom,” “judicial sceptre.”
o(/s: For position, compare O. 2.9.

poluma/lw| = poluka/rpw|: The Schol. Germ. cite Il. 9. 542, in which mh=lon is “fruit.” Strabo, 6, 273, puts oi( karpoi/ in the first line for Sicily. Others polumh/lw|, “rich in flocks.” Demeter is malofo/ros, Paus. 1, 44, 3.
dre/pwn: Where we might expect drepo/menos, P. 1.49; 4, 130; 6, 48. The dre/panon is a woodman's bill, Lycurg. 86.
korufa/s: O. 2.14: a)e/qlwn korufa/n, 7, 4: pa/gxruson korufa\n ktea/nwn.

a)glatzetai de/: The change to the finite construction brings out the nearer image in bolder relief. Special reason is discernible also in P. 3.53. When there is no me/n the change is easier, I. 3 (4), 12.
e)n a)w/tw|: P. uses e)n with plastic vividness. Compare N. 3.32: e)n a)retai=s ge/ghqe, as in Latin sometimes gaudere in.
oi(=a: Not to be roughly explained as = o(/ti

toiau=ta. It is the exclamatory relative from which the causal sense can be
picked out. “Such are the plays we play.” Compare P. 1.73; 2, 75; 3, 18.

*dwri/an . . . fo/rmigga : *d. does not refer to the metres, as is shown by v. 103, *ai)oghi/di molpa=|. Hieron is a Doric prince; the fo/rmigc may well be a Doric instrument. O. 3.5: *dwri/w| pedi/lw| does refer to the measure; but pe/dilon is not fo/rmiyc, and at the worst the Aiolic melody may be considered as a subdivision of the Doric. See Aristot. Pol. 4, 3, where it is said that some recognize only two a(rmoni/ai, the Dorian and the Phrygian.
la/mbane: Here the aor. might be expected, but the pres. shows that the action is watched. The poet addresses himself, his fi/lon h)=tor.
ei)/ ti . . . e)/qhke: This the regular form of condition in adjurations. Cf. I. 5 (6), 42.
*fereni/kou: Name of Hieron's horse, “Victor.” In the form *berevi/kh (Macedonian), the name is familiar. The *f. of P. 3 was doubtless grandsire to this *f.

te kai/: This combination is common in P.; the occurrence varies much in various authors. In P. it serves to unite complements, both opposites and similars. Here *pi/sas, the scene, and *f., Victor, make up the sum of the song.

xa/ris: Usu. rendered “beauty,” “charm.” Why should it not be “song,” the grace of poetry, as below? Pindar had pledged himself to sing the victory; and, when the steed sped to the goal, the promised song made him feel the stir of sweetest cares.
glukuta/tais . . . fronti/sin: fronti/des is used of the poet's musings. “Brought me under the empire of sweet musings.”

tar' *)alfew=|: para/ in prose, with genitive or dative, is shrivelled into an exclusively personal preposition, like Fr. chez. It is freer and more original in Pindar, although “in the domain of Alpheios” would err only in suggesting too much.
de/mas: The living body, originally distinct from sw=ma. Used plastically as the Lat. corpus = se.

prose/mice: The concrete, personal mignu/nai is common in Pindar, and must have its rights of contact. Here “brought to victory's embrace.” “Wedded,” “clasped,” “embraced,” “encircled,” will answer for many cases. With this passage compare P. 9.77: kai/ nun e)n *puqw=ni/ nin a)gaqe/a| *karneia/da | ui(o\s eu)qalei= sune/mice tu/xa|.

div3.head: Epode 1
div3.p: i(ppoxa/rman: From xa/rma or xa/rmh? See P. 2.2.
kle/os: Echoed, v. 93.
*audou=: The gold of v. 1 glitters in the rich adjective.
*pe/lopos a)poiki/a|: Emphasizes the scene for the third time, and prepares the transition.
tou=: The story often begins with a relative.
e)pei/: “Since” (causal).

kaqarou= le/bhtos: k. possibly to present a contrast to the miaro\s le/bhs of the familiar story (Ov. Met. 6, 407), which P. is at the pains of denying below. The ablatival genitive is used below v. 58. Later Greek meets poetry here.
*klwqw/: Klotho, Lachesis, and Atropos, the three fates, are lo/xiai qeai/, acc. to Euripides, I. T. 206.
e)le/fanti fai/dimon w)=mon kekadme/non: w)=. depends on kek. fai/dimon is explained by e)le/fanti.
qaumata/: So the best MSS. On the omission of e)sti/, see v. 1.
kai/ pou/ ti kai/: So Thuk. 2, 87: kai/ pou/ ti kai\ h( a)peiri/a prw=ton naumaxou=ntas e)/sfhlen.

fa/tis: The interpolated MSS. have fre/nas, Christ suggests fro/nin. fa/tis cannot be acc. pl., and would not do us much good, if it were. We must connect closely, after the Pindaric fashion, fa/tis u(pe\r to\n a)laqh= lo/gon, as one element, put dedaidalme/noi . . . mu=qoi in apposition with it, and make e)capatw=nti absolute, “mislead” = “are misleading.” So kle/ptei, absol. N. 7.23; cf. P. 2.17. Notice the contrast between fa/tis, the poetical story, and lo/gos, the prosaic truth; mu=qos has departed from its Homeric sense.

poiki/lois: The etymology points to embroidery (h( poikilei/mwn nu\c a)pokru/yei fa/os) and embroidery to falsehood, as we have learned from Fr. broder, whereas a(plou=s o( mu=qos th=s a)lhqei/as e)/fu.

div3.head: Strophe 2
div3.p: *xa/ris: The charm of poetry. Compare O. 14.5, where there are three *xa/rites: su\n ga\r u)/mmin ta/ te terpna\ kai\ ta\ gluke)/ a)/netai pa/nta brotoi=s.
teu/xei: The rule, present.
e)mh/sato: The manifestation, aor.
a(me/rai d' e)pi/loipoi . . . sofw/tatoi: O. 10 (11), 59: o(/ t' e)cele/gxwn mo/nos a)la/qeian e)th/tumon *xro/nos.
e)/sti: e)/. in this position is never otiose. Often=o)/ntws e)/sti. “In truth it is.”
a)ndri/: Not differentiated from a)nqrw/pw|. So often in poetry.

a)mfi/: A favorite preposition in P., esp. with dat., little used in prose. In the sense of this passage peri/ is more commonly employed even in P.: a)mfi/, being the narrower, is the more picturesque.

ui(e\ *tanta/lou, se\ de/: The effect of de/ after the vocative is to give pause. It is not uncommon in Pindar, and is used where ga/r would seem more natural, de/=dh/. Cf. O. 6.12; 8, 15; P. 10.10 al.

se\ . . . fqe/gcomai: The position shows that se/ is not felt as the object of a(rpa/sai (v. 41) until a(rpa/sai is reached, when the impression is renewed. “Touching thee I will utter what wars with earlier bards.”

o(po/te: Where the simple o(/te might have been used. O. 9.104; P. 8.41 al. The tendency of the compounds is to crowd out the simple
forms.
e)ka/lese: Sc. qeou/s.

to\n eu)nomw/taton | e)s e)/ranon: P. likes to put the preposition between attribute and substantive or substantive and attribute. The article is added, as here, P. 2.3: ta=n lipara=n a)po\ *qhba=n. to/n is deictic, and eu)nomw/taton gives an anticipatory refutation of the gastrimargi/a.
e)/ranon: This word is selected to show the familiar footing of Tantalos. Nor is w(i/lan *si/pulon idle. The adjective there also is intended to enhance the intimacy of the a)moibai=a dei=pna.
pare/xwn: P. nowhere uses the middle of this familiar verb.

*)aglaotri/ainan: An original feminine, “Bright - trident,” then a surname, like “Bright-eyes” (Jh. Schmidt). The Greek cares little about possible ambiguity of accusatives before and after an infinitive.

div3.head: Antistrophe 2
div3.p: i(me/rw|: P. uses i(/meros and po/qos both so little that we can only say that his usage is not inconsistent with the traditional distinction. Of passionate desire i(/meros is used, O. 3.33: tw=n nin gluku\s i(/meros e)/sxen . . . futeu=sai. For poqe/w compare O. 6.16: poqe/w stratia=s o)fqalmo\n e)ma=s.
xruse/aisin a)n' i(/ppois : i(/., here of the chariot. a)na/ is another Pindaric preposition that is very little used in prose, even with the acc.
metaba=sai: Depends on i(me/rw|, as, in the passage cited above, futeu=sai.
deute/rw| xro/nw|: So without e)n, O. 2.41: a)/llw| xro/nw|, P. 4.55: xro/nw| u(ste/rw|.

*zhni/ depends on h)=lqe; in its moral sense not simply to, but for. Ganymede, according to Böckh, was considered by P. to be the son of Laomedon, Pelops was a contemporary of Laomedon, and so the chronology is saved, if it is worth saving.
twu)/t' e)pi\ xre/os: “For the same service.”
matri/: More tender than pro\s mate/ra.
polla\ maio/menoi: “Despite many a search.”
fw=tes: fw/s (poet.) is colorless, or=“wight.”
puri\ ze/oisan: To be closely connected. The Schol. renders u(/datos a)kma/n by u(/dwr a)kmai/ws ze/on. The position of the words shows impatience and horror.
maxai/ra| makes the butchery more vivid.
kata\ me/lh =melei+sti/ rather than ta/mon ka/ta me/lh, with me/lh in apposition to se.

trape/zaisi/ t' a)mfi/: a). is an adverb in P. 4.81, and P. 8.85. The tra/pezai were arranged in two rows facing each other, each guest having a tra/peza. “They divided among themselves the flesh to the tables on both sides.”
deu/tata: “The last morsels,” implying a cannibalic delicacy.
dieda/santo: The finite verbs throughout force attention to the horrid details.

div3.head: Epode 2
div3.p:
a)/pora: O. 10 (11), 44: a)/poron. The plur. exaggerates,
P. 1.34.
gastri/margon: “Cannibal” approaches the effect.
a)fi/stamai: Asyndeton is especially in place where repugnance is to be expressed. See Dissen, Exc. II.
a)ke/rdeia le/logxen: Gnomic perfect. For the sentiment compare P. 2.55. lagxa/nw has more commonly a person for a subject.
kakago/ros: Dor. for kakhgo/rous.
h)=n: See v. 35.
a)lla\ ga/r : ga/r gives the reason for the a)lla/, as who should say, a)/llws d' h)=n, “but all in vain; for.”
katape/yai . . . ko/rw|: The same homely sphere of imagery as concoquere, “stomach.” Nor is “brook” far off. So Il. 1. 81: ei)/ per ga/r te xo/lon ge kai\ au)th=mar katape/yh|.
e(/len: P. 2.30: e)cai/reton e(/le mo/xqon.
a(\n . . . li/qon: Apposition “which in the form of a stone.”

voi path/r: We could dispense with voi or au)tw=|. Yet voi path/r gives the punisher, au)tw=| li/qon the punishment, and the apposition makes it easier, a(/n going with voi and li/qon with au)tw=|. Compare I. 7 (8), 9: to\n u(pe\r kefala=s a(/te *tanta/lou li/qon para/ tis e)/treyen a)/mmi qeo/s.
kefala=s balei=n: Ablatival genitive, which is better than to make menoinw=n “expecting,” and kefala=s the mark, with balei=n=teu/cesqai.
eu)frosu/nas a)la=tai: a)la=tai with genitive as Eur. Tro. 640.

div3.head: Strophe 3
div3.p: a)pa/lamon=pro\s o(\n ou)k e)/sti palamh/sasqai. Schol.

meta\ triw=n: Supposed to refer to the three great sinners, Tityos, Sisyphos, and Ixion. Tityos is mentioned in Od. 11. 576, Tantalos in v. 582, and Sisyphos, v. 593, and Ixion may have dropped out of the list. In any case, we are to understand with triw=n, not a)ndrw=n, but po/nwn, which, on the hypothesis mentioned, would refer to the punishments of Tityos, Sisyphos, and Ixion. If we analyze the woes of Tantalos, the stone, the hunger, and the thirst, we shall have three. What is the fourth? Is it the bi/os e)mpedo/moxqos, the thought that nectar and ambrosia had made him immortal (a)/fqiton), or the remembrance of the nectareous and ambrosial life of the immortals, the “sorrow's crown of sorrow,” or the reflection that his son had been banished from heaven for his fault (tou)/neka proh=kan)? As Tantalos is mentioned only for Pelops' sake, the last view gains probability.
ne/ktar a)mbrosi/an te : te here, like -que, makes ne/ktar and a)mbrosi/an a whole. te, connecting single words, is chiefly poetic or late.

e)/qesan: It is better to admit a tribrach than to accept the MS. qe/ssan, or Mommsen's qe/n nin, although we miss an object. Hartung would read a)fqi/tous qh=ken, referring to the a(/likes sumpo/tai, but the point is the favor shown by the gods to Tantalos.
oi(=s nin is tempting.
ti with e)/rdwn.

laqe/men=lh/qein. Inferior MSS. have lase/men, making e)/lpetai refer to the future as e)/lpomai does v. 109; but e)/lpomai in the sense of “think,” “suppose” — compare spero — may take the present as it does repeatedly in Homer. Il. 9. 40; 13, 309. Mommsen reads lelaqe/men.
proh=kan : pra., “straight(forward).”
ui(o\n . . . voi: The dat. shows how he felt it.
a)ne/rwn: v. 36.
pro\s eu)a/nqemon . . . fua/n: Even in the three temporal passages, here, P. 9.27, and N. 9.44, pro/s shows its “fronting” sense.
nin . . . ge/neion: sxh=ma kaq' o(/lon kai\ me/ros, not different from “they bound him hand and foot.”
me/lan: “To blackness.” Proleptic use, esp. common in tragic poets. So. Antig. 881; O. C. 1200; Eur. H. F. 641: blefa/rwn skoteino\n fa/os e)pikalu/yan.

e(toi=mon a)nefro/ntisen ga/mon: e(. here is almost equivalent to “tempting.” a)nefro/ntisen, “woke to the desire of.” Love is a fronti/s. Notice that this triad is welded together, and moves very fast, with stress on ga/mon (v. 69, 80).

div3.head: Antistrophe 3
div3.p: *pisa/ta . . . patro/s = *oi)noma/ou, v. 76. Oinomaos, king of Pisa, had offered his daughter Hippodameia in marriage to any one who should overcome him in a chariot race. Fragments of the sculptures representing the a)gw/n of Pelops, from the eastern pediment of the temple of Zeus, have been unearthed at Olympia.
sxeqe/men: It is better to make the whole passage from *pisa/ta . . . sxeqe/men explanatory to ga/mon than to make ga/mon “bride,” in apposition to *(ippoda/meian. sx. “to win.”
oi)=os e)n o)/rfna|: Cf. P. 1.23: e)n o)/rfnaisin. A similar scene, O. 6.58, where Iamos invokes Poseidon by night.
a)/puen: Loud call to the loud sea. h)pu/ein, of a cry that is intended to carry — “halloo.”
pa\r podi/: On para/, with dat., see v. 21.
ei)=pe: Regular word to introduce the language of the speaker. Hence seldom with any other than the finite construction in the best period.
*fi/lia dw=ra: Note the effective position and the shyness.
e)s xa/rin te/lletai: “Come up to favor” = “count aught in one's favor.” Verg. Aen. 4, 317, cited by Dissen, is not so delicate: fuit aut tibi quicquam dulce meum.
pe/dason . . . po/reuson . . . pe/lason: Neither the three aorists nor the three p)s are accidental.
kra/tei . . . pe/lason=kr. pro/smicon. Cf. v. 22.
Oinomaos was wont to transfix the suitors from behind.

div3.head: Epode 3
div3.p:
qugatro/s: The sense was fairly complete with na/mon. Compare the structure of the strophe. P. likes this method
of welding the parts of the triad, e. g., O. 2.105: *qh/rwnos. O. 6.50: patro/s. O. 9.53: newte/rwn. With the nominative the effect is startling. See P. 11.22.

o( me/gas . . . lamba/nei: “Great peril takes no coward wight.” l., according to one Schol.=katalamba/nei, “takes possession of,” “inspires” (cf. P. 4.71: ti/s de\ ki/ndunos krateroi=s a)da/mantos dh=sen a(/lois;); according to another= de/xetai, “admits of,” “allows of,” less vigorous.
a)/nalkin ou) fw=ta: So I. 1, 15: a)llotri/ais ou) xersi/. The rhythm calls for a prolonged ou), and a)/nalkin is thought over again with fw=ta. “A coward — no! no coward wight.”
oi(=sin: Not to be dissected into tou/twn oi(=sin.
ta/: So Mommsen after good MSS. Doric for ti/.
a)nw/numon . . . ma/tan: An impressive cumulation in which it must be remembered that kaqh/menos means more than “sitting” in English. It is “sitting idle, useless.”
e(/yoi: “Nurse.”
ma/tan: “Aimlessly,” “and all to no good end.”
u(pokei/setai: Acc. to Schol.=prokei/setai. “On this I shall take my stand.” “This struggle shall be my business.”
pra=cin: “Achievement,” “consummation,” not yet colorless.
di/doi = di/dou: More solemn and impressive than the aorist with which he began.
e)/nnepen: Bergk writes h)/nepen everywhere in P. A formal imperf., but it has no clear imperfect force in P.
a)kra/ntois: e)pi/ in e)fa/yato eases the dat., which P. however uses, as well as the genitive, with verbs of contact. Dative P. 8.60; N. 8.36; Genitive O. 9.13; P. 3.29.
a)ga/llwn: “Honoring,” “by way of honoring.” N. 5.43.
di/fron . . . xru/seon: v. 42.
pteroi=sin: The horses of Pelops on the chest of Kypselos were winged, Paus. 5, 17, 7. pt. instrumental rather than local.

div3.head: Strophe 4
div3.p: e(/len . . . su/neunon: Commonly set down as a zeugma, yet hardly so to be considered. “He overcame Oinomaos, and the maid to be his bedfellow.” te, consequential.
*oi)noma/ou bi/an: b. not otiose.
a(\ te/ke: So the best MSS. a(/ short in Aiolic. te/ke te, the reading of the inferior MSS., would suggest a change of subject, not surprising in Greek, but clearly a metrical correction.

a)retai=si memao/tas: “Forward in deeds of valor.” Not “to deeds of valor,” for which there is no warrant, as Il. 8. 327, and 22, 326, have e)pi/. The Schol., however, understands the passage as e)piqumou=ntas th=s a)reth=s kai\ tau/ths a)ntexome/nous, thus giving memao/tas the Pindaric construction of a verb of approach, a(/ptesqai, qigei=n. *)aretai=si memalo/tas, another reading, is frigid. P. does not personify a). The Scholiasts give the names of the six,
among whom figure Atreus and Thyestes. Pindar is supposed not to know the horrors of the house any more than Homer, but one cannibalic incident was enough for one poem, to say nothing of the rule ta\ kala\ tre/yai e)/cw.
ai(makouri/ais=toi=s tw=n nekrw=n e)nagi/smasi. A Boeotian word (Schol.). The yearly offering was the sacrifice of a black ram, Paus. 5, 13, 2.
me/miktai: With e)n, I. 2, 29. On m. see v. 22.
po/rw| kliqei/s: The conception is that of support (instrumental).
tu/mbon a)mfi/polon: See O. 10 (11), 26: a)gw=na . . . a)rxai/w| sa/mati pa\r *pe/lopos bwmw=n e(ca/riqmon. The tomb of Pelops was near the great altar of Zeus in the Altis.
para\ bwmw=|: On para/, see v. 20.

to\ de\ kle/os . . . de/dorke: Echo of la/mpei de/ voi kle/os, v. 23. Combine to\ kle/os ta=n *)olumpia/dwn and e)n dro/mois *pe/lopos. The dro/moi refers not to the exploits of Pelops, but to the scene (i(/na), where not only speed but strength is shown.
de/dorke: Perceptual perfect = present. Compare o)/pwpa, o)/dwda. Glory is an o)fqalmo/s.

taxuta\s podw=n . . . a)kmai/ t' i)sxu/os: The two great elements of speed and strength are set forth, N. 9.12, i)sxu/os t' a)ndrw=n a(mi/llais a(/rmasi/ te glafuroi=s. Here podw=n suggests the a)kamantopo/dwn i(/ppwn a)/wton (O. 3.3). There is another division, po/nos dapa/na te, with the same complementary te (O. 5.15), the po/nos for the feats of bodily strength (qrasu/ponoi), the dapa/na for the horse-race (dapa/na| xai=ron i(/ppwn, I. 3, 47).
e)ri/zetai: The middle of reciprocal action, as if we had po/des taxei=s e)ri/zontai. Compare I. 4 (5), 4: kai\ ga\r e)rizo/menai na=es e)n po/ntw| . . . qaumastai\ pe/lontai.
loipo\n a)mfi\ bi/oton: His life has light on both hands.
melito/essan: “Delicious,” which we also extend beyond its proper sphere.

div3.head: Antistrophe 4
div3.p: a)e/qlwn g' e(/neken: The necessary amari aliquid. “So far as sunshine is to be found in games.” Religiose dictum (Dissen). Then follows a bit of cheerful philosophy.

to\ d' ai)ei\ . . . brotw=n: “The highest boon is aye the blessing of the day.” to\ ai)ei\ para/meron e)slo/n is not, as one of the old Scholia has it, to\ kaq' h(me/ran kai\ a)dialei/ptws para\ toi=s a)nqrw/pois a)gaqo/n. P. emphasizes the supremeness of the day's blessing as it comes.
e)slo/n: A curious Boeotian form everywhere in Pindar.
panti\ brotw=n: The reading of the best MSS., as if e(ka/stw| brotw=n or panti/ tini brotw=n. Compare also Plat. Legg. 6, 774 c: pa=si tw=n e)n tau/th| th=| po/lei.
e)me\ de\ stefanw=sai: P. passes over to his highest duty and his highest pleasure.

i(ppei/w| no/mw|: The rider-tune, to\ *kasto/reion (Castor gaudet equis), well suited to the achievement.
Compare P. 2.69: to\ *kasto/reion d' e)n *ai)oli/dessi xordai=s qe)lwn, I. 1, 16: h)\ *kastorei/w| h)\ *)iola/oi) e)narmo/cai nin u(/mnw|. The Aiolians were the great equestrians of Greece.
pe/poiqa ... mh/: Verbs of believing incline to the swearing negative mh/. “I am confident,” “I am ready to swear that.”
a)mfo/tera: Adv., like a)mfo/teron.
a)/mme: With Mommsen for a)/ma.

daidalwse/men: Acc. to Mommsen, an old aor. inf., like a)ce/men, Il. 24. 663. But even if this is granted, it does not affect the sphere of time, as an aorist inf., after such a verb as pe/poiqa, may be thrown into the future. See note on e)/lpomai, P. 1.43. The compliment of a comparison with the past is not so great as with the future. The case O. 2.102 is different.
u(/mnwn ptuxai=s: “Sinuous songs,” the in and out of choral song and music and dance.
teai=si . . . meri/mnaisin: Depends on e)pi/tropos. me/rimnai, as in N. 3.69: semno\n a)glaai=si meri/mnais *puqi/ou. Here God makes the plans of Hieron his own.

mh/detai: Might be used absol. “Is full of watchful thought.” Dissen compare N. 6.62: e(/pomai de\ kai\ au)to\s e)/xwn mele/tan, but it would be easy to get an acc. meri/mnas out of the dat., “is meditating the accomplishment of them.” Schol.: mh/detai de/, e)rga/zetai/ de nikhth/n.
e)/xwn tou=to ka=dos: “With this for his great concern.”
ei) de\ mh\ taxu\ li/poi: The original wish element is plain in all or nearly all Pindar's ideal conditionals. Subject of li/poi is qeo/s, and li/poi is intr.
glukute/ran: Sc. me/rimnan, “a sweeter care,” “a sweeter victory.”

ken . . . klei+/cein: ken with fut. inf. here, and only here, in P. Some of the Scholiasts use the aor. in the paraphrase. But it is better not to change. The construction is due to anacoluthia rather than to survival.

div3.head: Epode 4
div3.p: su\n a(/rmati qow=|: For su/n compare N. 10.48: su\n podw=n sqe/nei nika=sai, and the older use of Lat. cum.

e)pi/kouron . . . o(do\n lo/gwn: Combine e)pi/kouron lo/gwn. The path is the path of song, which will help forward the glory of Hieron, as told in the lo/goi by the lo/gioi. See P. 1.94: o)piqo/mbroton au)/xhma do/cas | oi)=on a)poixome/nwn a)ndrw=n di/aitan manu/ei | kai\ logi/ois kai\ a)oidoi=s. The path is to be opened by poesy for rhetoric.
par' eu)dei/elon . . . *kro/nion: The famous hill at Olympia, on the summit of which sacrifices were offered to Kronos. See O. 5.17; 6, 64; 9, 3. The sunniness of Olympia is emphasized, O. 3.24.
be/los . . . tre/fsi: Poetical and musical bolts are familiar. O. 2.91; 9, 5; 13, 95; P. 1.12; I. 4 (5), 46.

a)lka=|: Dissen comb. with karterw/taton,
and compare O. 13.52: pukno/taton pala/mais. So, too, the Schol. It is more vigorous to combine it with tre/fei, as Böckh does. “Keeps in warlike plight.”
tre/fei: “Nurses,” “keeps.” t., a favorite word with Sophokles, and so perhaps ridiculed by Ar. Vesp. 110: ai)gialo\n tre/fei .
e)p' a)/lloisi: e)pi/ = “in,” though it suggests the various altitudes of the great.
korufou=tai: “Heads itself,” “caps itself.” The topmost summit is for kings.
mhke/ti: e)/ti suggests the temptation; see v. 5.

pa/ptaine po/rsion: P. 3.22: paptai/nei ta\ po/rsw. I. 6, 44: ta\ makra\ d' ei)/ tis paptai/nei. p., originally of a restless, uneasy search in every direction. In P. pa/ptaine is little, if anything, more than sko/pei. “Look no further.”
ei)/h: Asyndeton in a prayer. The present is more solemn and less used in prose than ge/noito. P. 1.29: ei)/h, *zeu=, ti\n e)/h vanda/nein.
tou=ton: “Thy.” Pronoun of the second person.
tossa/de: “All my days.”

sofi/a| = e)pi\ sofi/a|. s. is “poetic art.” The tone is high enough, for P. pairs himself with Hieron by the parallel te . . . te, “as . . . so” (se/ te . . . e)me/ te), but e)o/nta is part of the prayer, and not an assertion merely.

div2.p: Akragas (Agrigentum) was a daughter of Gela. Gela was founded, Ol. 22, 4 (689 B.C.), by a Rhodian colony; Akragas more than a hundred years afterwards, Ol. 49, 4 (581 B.C.). In Ol. 52, 3 (570 B.C.) the notorious Phalaris made himself tyrant of the city, and, after a rule of sixteen years, was dethroned by Telemachos, the grandfather of Emmenes or Emmenides, who gave his name to the line, and became the father of Ainesidamos. Under the sons of Ainesidamos, Theron and Xenokrates, the name of the Emmenidai was brought to the height of its glory, and an alliance formed with the ruling house of Syracuse. Damareta, the daughter of Theron, married first Gelon, and, upon his death, Polyzelos, his brother. Theron married a daughter of Polyzelos, and, finally, Hieron married a daughter of Xenokrates.

The Emmenidai belonged to the ancient race of the Aigeidai, to which Pindar traced his origin, and claimed descent from Kadmos, through Polyneikes, who was the father of Thersandros by Argeia, daughter of Adrastos. Evidently a roving, and doubtless a quarrelsome, race, the descendants of Thersandros went successively to Sparta, to Thera, to Rhodes, and finally to Akragas. Such was the ancestry of Theron, who made himself master of Akragas by a trick, which he is said to have redeemed by a just, mild, and beneficent reign. Under his rule Akragas reached its highest eminence, and Theron's sway extended to the neighborhood of Himera and the Tyrrhenian sea. When he drove out Terillos, tyrant of Himera, and seized his throne, Terillos applied to his son-in-law, Anaxilas of Rhegion, for help, who, in his turn, invoked the aid of the Carthaginians. Thereupon Theron summoned to his assistance his son-in-law, Gelon, of Syracuse, and in the famous battle of Himera the Sicilian princes gained a brilliant victory. (See Introd. to Ol. 1.) The enormous booty was spent on the adornment of Syracuse and Akragas. Akragas became one of the most beautiful cities
of the world, and the ruins of Girgenti are still among the most imposing remains of antiquity. A few years after the battle of Himera, Gelon died, Ol. 75, 3 (478 B.C.), and was succeeded by his brother Hieron in the rule of Syracuse. To the other brother, Polyzelos, were assigned the command of the army and the hand of Damareta, daughter of Theron, widow of Gelon, with the guardianship of Gelon's son; but the two brothers had not been on the best terms before, and Hieron took measures to get rid of Polyzelos, who was a popular prince. Polyzelos took refuge with Theron, who had married his daughter, and who in consequence of this double tie refused to give him up to Hieron. The Himeraians, oppressed by Theron's son Thrasydaios, made propositions to Hieron; two cousins of Theron, Kapys and Hippokrates, joined his enemies, and the armies of Hieron and Theron faced each other on the banks of the Gela. Thanks, however, to the good offices of the poet Simonides, peace was made; Polyzelos was suffered to return, and Hieron married the daughter of Xenokrates, brother of Theron. The rebellious spirits in Himera were quelled, and our just, mild, and beneficent prince, who was elevated to the rank of a hero after his death, so thinned the ranks of the citizens by executions that it was necessary to fill them up by foreigners. Kapys and Hippokrates having been put to flight, Theron sat firmly on his throne again, and, after putting to death all his enemies, had the great satisfaction of gaining an Olympian victory, Ol. 76 (476 B.C.), which Pindar celebrates in this ode and the following.

Theron died Ol. 76, 4; Xenokrates, his brother, who won two of the victories celebrated by Pindar (P. 6 and I. 2), died either before him or soon after. Thrasydaios, his son and successor, whose cruelty had roused the Himeraians to revolt, chastised the Agrigentines with scorpions, and attacked Hieron with 20,000 mercenaries. After his defeat, Akragas and Himera rose against him, and he fled to Megara, where he died, and the revolted cities became democracies. Thrasybulus, the son of Xenokrates, continued to live in Akragas, but the memory of Thrasydaios was a stench in the nostrils of the Himeraians; hence their gratitude to *zeu\s *)eleuqe/rios and *sw/teira *tu/xa for having delivered them from such a monster (O. 12).

In the opening of the second Olympian, Pindar himself points out the threefold cord that runs through the ode, and recent
commentators have found triads everywhere. It is best to limit ourselves to the poet's own lines. When Pindar asks, “What god, what hero, what man shall we celebrate?” he means to celebrate all three, and god, hero, and man recur throughout: the god helping, the hero toiling, the man achieving. God is the disposer, the hero the leader, and the man the follower. The man, the Olympian victor, must walk in the footsteps of the greater victor, must endure hardness as the hero endured hardness, in order that he may have a reward, as the hero had his reward, by the favor of God. This is a poem for one who stands on the solemn verge beyond which lies immortal, heroic life. But we must not read a funeral sermon into it, and we must notice how the poet counteracts the grave tone of the poem by the final herald cry, in which he magnifies his own office and champions the old king.

Hymns, lords of the lyre, what god, what hero, what man shall we sound forth? Pisa belongs to Zeus (qeo/s), Olympia was stablished by Herakles (h(/rws), Theron (a)nh/r) hath won the great four-horse chariot race. His sires (h(/rwes) founded Akragas; Zeus (qeo/s) send the future glorious as the past has been (vv. 1-17). Done cannot be made undone. The past was toilsome and bitter, but forgetfulness comes with bliss, and suffering expires in joyance. So in the line of Theron himself, the daughters of Kadmos (h(rw=|nai, h)oi=ai), Semele, Ino, suffering once, as the founders of Akragas toiled once, are now glorified. Yet this light was quenched in deeper gloom. After Semele, after Ino, comes the rayless darkness of Oidipus, so dark that even his name is shrouded. Polyneikes fell, but Thersandros was left, and after him came Theron (a)nh/r), and Theron's noble house, with its noble victories (vv. 17-57). But this is not all. Earthly bliss is not everything. There is another world, and the poet sets its judgment-seat, unfolds the happiness of the blessed, and introduces into the harmony of the blissful abode a marvellous discord of the damned. In that land we hear of Kronos and of Rhea (qeoi/), Peleus, and Kadmos, and Achilles (h(/rwes). Of men there is expressive silence (vv. 58-91). Theron is old, and the poet, instead of working out his triad mechanically, vindicates the reserve of his art. He has arrows enough in his quiver; he has power enough in his pinion. He can shoot, he can fly, whithersoever he will; and now, that we have left that other world, and have come back to this realm of Zeus, he bends his bow, he
stoops his flight, to Akragas. Now he can praise Theron with all the solemnity but without the gloom of an epitaph, and the last words fall like a benediction on the gracious king (vv. 92110).

There is no myth proper. The canvas is covered by the prefiguration-picture of the house of Kadmos and the vision of the world beyond. Innocent suffering is recompensed by deep happiness, heroic toil by eternal reward. Theron's achievements have the earnest of an immortal future. Time cannot express his deeds of kindness.
The rhythms are Paionian, manly, vigorous, triumphant, but Bakcheiac strains seem to have been introduced with the same effect as the belts of darkness which chequer the poem.

Of the five triads, the first opens the theme, the last concludes it; the second triad deals with the mythic past; the third returns to Theron, and connects the second with the fourth, which is taken up with the world beyond.

div3.head: Strophe 1
div3.p: a)nacifo/rmigges: Originally song dominated instrumental music. Music was “married to immortal verse,” as the woman to the man. Pratinas ap. Athen. 14, 617 D. makes song the queen: ta\n a)oida\n kate/stase *pieri\s basi/leian: o( d' au)lo\s u(/steron xoreue/tw: kai\ ga/r e)sq' u(phre/tas. In P. 1 init. the fo/rmigc gives the signal, but there is no difference in the relation.

ti/na qeo/n, ti/n' h(/rwa, ti/na d' a)/ndra: Imitated by Hor. Od. 1, 12: quem virum aut heroa lyra vel acri | tibia sumis celebrare, Clio, | quem deum? Horace follows the artificial climactic arrangement, which brings him up to — Augustus. So Isok. Euag. 39: ou)dei\s ou)/te qnhto\s ou)/q' h(mi/qeos ou)/t' a)qa/natos. Antiphon (1, 27) gives us Pindar's order: ou)/te qeou\s ou)/q' h(/rwas ou)/t' a)nqrw/pous ai)sxunqei=sa ou)de\ dei/sasa. The triplet here announced runs through the poem. To Zeus (A) belongs the place (a), to Herakles (B) the festival (b), to Theron (C) the prize (c), and the order is * with a subtle variation of case.
keladh/somen: See O. 1.9. Whether we have subj. or fut. here it is impossible to tell, nor does it matter.
*)olumpia/da . . . *(hrakle/hs: See O. 10 (11), 56, for the story.

a)kro/qina: Compare O. 10 (11), 62: ta\n pole/moio do/sin | a)kro/qina dielw\n e)/que kai\ pentaethri/d' e)/stasen e(orta/n.
Usually a)kroqi/nia, as in N. 7.41.
gegwnhte/on: “We must proclaim so far as voice can be heard.” The post-Homeric -te/os forms are not common in lyric poetry.

o)/pin: So Hermann, as acc. of extent to di/kaion. Others o)/pi. Most of the MSS. have o)pi/, glossed by dia\ fwnh=s lampra=s, and all have ce/non, which is interpreted as di/kaion o)/nta kata\ th\n fili/an tw=n ce/nwn. o)/pis as a masc. subst. = o( o)pizo/menos (cf. P. 4.86; I. 3 [4], 5) would not be unwelcome to me, “a just respecter of guests.” So la/tris = o( latreu/wn and si/nis = o( sino/menos, besides others in -is.
ce/nwn: Supposed to have reference to Polyzelos, the fugitive brother of Hieron.

e)/reism' *)akra/gantos: The reference is to the great day of Himera. So Athens, for her share in the Persian war, is called (fr. IV. 4, 2) *(ella/dos e)/reisma. The compliment is heightened by the well - known strength of Akragas.
eu)wnu/mwn . . . pate/rwn: Notice the auspicious beginning of the last lines in the four stanzas: v. 8, eu)wnu/mwn, v. 16, eu)/frwn, v. 38, eu)qumia=n, and, like a distant echo, v. 104, eu)erge/tan.

o)rqo/polin: Continuation of the figure in e)/reisma. This raising of the city to its height is supposed to refer to the adornment of Akragas with great temples and other magnificent public buildings.

div3.head: Antistrophe 1
div3.p: kamo/ntes oi(/: This position of the relative is not so harsh as in Latin, on account of the stronger demonstrative element of the Greek relative. So v. 25: e)/paqon ai(\ mega/la.
qumw=|: Od. 1. 4: polla\ d' o(/ g' e)n po/ntw| pa/qen a)/lgea o(\n kata\ qumo/n.
i(ero/n: All cities were dedicated to some deity, but Akragas especially, having been given to Persephone by Zeus, ei)s a)nakalupth/ria. Preller, Gr. Myth. 1, 485.
e)/sxon: “Got” (of conquest). So P. 1.65. The ingressiveness of e)/sxon is due to the meaning of the verb.

oi)/khma potamou= = oi)/khma pota/mion. In such combinations the full adj. is more common than the fossilized adj. or genitive. Compare P. 6.6: potami/a| *)akra/ganti. The river bore the same name as the city. Compare further Eur. Med. 846: i(erw=n potamw=n po/lis , Theogn. 785: *eu)rw/ta donakotro/fou a)glao\n a)/stu, and O. 13.61, where Corinth is called a)/stu *peira/nas.

*sikeli/as . . . o)fqalmo/s: Compare O. 6.16: poqe/w stratia=s o)fqalmo\n e)ma=s. Athens and Sparta were the two eyes of Greece. See Leptines ap. Aristot. Rhet. 3, 10, 7, whence Milton's “Athens, the eye of Greece.”
ai)w\n . . . mo/rsimos: “Time followed as it was allotted.”

e)/fepe: In innumerable passages ai)w/n, xro/nos, bi/os are represented as the attendants of men. This personification is easier to the
Greek than it is to us, and must be looked for. See O. 6.56.

plou=to/n te kai\ xa/rin: Notice the close connection of “wealth and honor.” x. is the glory lent by poesy, and “wealth and poesy” would represent the material and the spiritual elements of happiness. On xa/ris, see O. 1.18. 30.

gnhsi/ais e)p' a)retai=s: In prose we should consider e)pi/ “on account of.” Here it is more plastic. “Wealth and poesy crown their native gifts.” See O. 11 (10), 13: ko/smon e)pi\ stefa/nw|, and compare note on P. 5.124.

*kro/nie pai= *(pe/as: Much more vigorous than w)= pai= *kro/nou te kai\ *(re/as, though we must not forget dialectic preferences for the forms in -ios. Rhea is mentioned again with Kronos, v. 85: po/sis o( pa/ntwn *(re/as u(pe/rtaton e)xoi/sas qro/non, and Zeus is called pai=s *(re/as, fr. XI. 5. For this Kronos element, see O. 1.10. P. himself was a servant of Rhea (Magna Mater). The special allusions detected by the commentators to Theron's personal history are due to fanciful combinations.

e(/dos *)olu/mpou: Here again *)olu/mpou is = *)olu/mpion, as potamou= = pota/mion. The triplet here reminds one of the triplet in the first strophe, and by assigning a)e/qlwn korufa/n to Herakles (O. 6.69), and po/ron t' *)alfeou= to Theron (compare O. 1.20: par' *)alfew=| su/to de/mas), we should have the same order.
po/ron t' *)alfeou=: So, O. 10 (11), 53: “The watercourse of the Alpheios.” So-called genitive of apposition.
i)anqei/s = eu)franqei/s, but the old “warming,” “dissolving,” “melting” sense is not wholly lost. See P. 1.11.

sfi/sin depends on ko/mison loipw=| ge/nei. There is no sxh=ma kaq' o(/lon kai\ me/ros for the dat. For the construction, compare O. 8.83, and P. 1.7; Eur. Bacch. 335:
i(/na dokh=| qeo\n tekei=n
h(mi=n te timh\ panti\ tw=| ge/nei parh=|.
ko/mison, like our “convey,” always connotes “care,” “safety.”

div3.head: Epode 1
div3.p: tw=n . . . te/los: Familiar commonplace. The meaning is essentially complete without e)/rgwn te/los, so that these two words come in as a reinforcement. “When fully consummated.”
a)poi/hton: We should expect a)/prakton like Lat. factum infectum, but a)poi/hton embraces a)/prakton.
la/qa: N. 10.24: nika/sais di\s e)/sxen *qeai=os dusfo/rwn la/qan po/nwn. P. 1.46: ei) ga\r o( pa=s xro/nos kama/twn e)pi/lasin para/sxoi.
po/tmw| su\n eu)dai/moni: su/n semi-personifies po/tmos.
ge/noit' a)/n: “Must come.” “Cannot fail to come.”
e)slw=n=e)sqlw=n, itself a poetic word. See O. 1.99; 2, 69.

u(po\ xarma/twn: u(po/, with the genitive of things, keeps the personification alive in prose. But the “under”
element of u(po/ is felt in P., though, of course, it is more evident with the dat., “Under the weight of.” xarm. is echoed in v. 109 (Mezger).
pali/gkoton damasqe/n: “Quell'd in spite's despite.” The ph=ma resists, but resists in vain. pali/gkoton is adversative, not attributive merely.

div3.head: Strophe 2
div3.p: pe/myh|: So the Ambrosianus and the Schol. Otherwise pe/mph| might stand. The durative tenses of pe/mpein are often used where we should expect the complexive (or aoristic) tenses. p. has not the same notion of “detachment” as our “send.”

a)neka\s . . . u(yhlo/n: Ar. Vesp. 18: a)neka\s e)s to\n ou)rano/n.
u(yhlo/n is predicative. The figure is that of a wheel.
e(/petai: “Sorts with,” “suits,” a(rmo/zei, Schol.
eu)qro/nois: Elsewhere of goddesses only, P. 9.65; N. 3.83; I. 2, 5. *(omhriko\s zh=los, says a Scholiast. Cf. Il. 8. 565: e)u/qronon *)hw= mi/mnon, al.
*ka/dmoio kou/rais: Semele, Ino, Autonoë, Agaue, were all in trouble. P. selects those who emerge.

e)/paqon ai(/: See v. 8. Ino, pursued by her mad husband, leaped into the sea and became a goddess, Leukothea. Semele, killed by lightning because she wished to see her celestial lover, Zeus, in full array, was afterwards received up into heaven.
pe/nqos de\ pitnei=: An intercalated reflection, and not a part of the narrative, as e)/pitnen would make it.
baru/: Position as in pali/gkoton damasqe/n, v. 22.
kresso/nwn pro\s a)g.: “Before the face of mightier blessings.”
bro/mw| | keraunou=: The instrumental “by” is more poetic than the locative “mid.” The tenderness of Semele is brought out by the womanly tanue/qeira.

*palla/s: The Scholiasts call attention to the significant omission of Hera; the specific mention of Pallas may be explained in half a dozen ways. She was one of the guardian deities of Akragas, a close sympathizer with her father. The triad here is not to be emphasized.
pai=s o( kissofo/ros: Dionysos. Cf. fr. IV. 3, 9: to\n kissode/tan qeo/n.

div3.head: Antistrophe 2
div3.p: e)n kai\ qala/ssa|: Here kai/ belongs to le/gonti (Bossler).

ko/raisi *nhrh=os a(li/ais: Compare v. 13: w)= *kro/nie pai= *(re/as. The Nereids are the daughters of Nereus and the sea (h( a(/ls). Nereus is “water” (mod. Gr. nero/), as his spouse is Doris — the sea being a symbol of riches (e)/stin qa/lassa, ti/s de/ nin katasbe/sei;).
bi/oton a)/fqiton . . . to\n o(/lon a)mfi\ xro/non: The expression seems redundant, unless we remember that bi/oton expresses the enjoyment of life, and not the mere duration (xro/nos).

to\n o(/lon . . . xro/non: Compare o( pa=s xro/nos, P. 1.46. On a)mfi/ see O. 1.97, where the “both” signification is plainer. As peri/ w. acc. may mean “around” (without) and “around” (within), so a)mfi/ may be “about” (without) and “about” (within), and so be loosely used for e)n.
brotw=n ge: However it may stand with high and mighty heroines.
pei=ras qana/tou: The qa/natos is the pei=ras. Cf. v. 19: e)/rgwn te/los.

ou)d' h(su/ximon a(me/ran , kte(.: Instead of a mechanical te/los a(me/ras to balance pei=ras qana/tou, instead of a mechanical o(po/q' i(co/meqa to balance o(po/te teleuta/somen, P. varies the structure: “Surely in the case of mortals a certain goal of death is in no wise fixed, nor [is it fixed] when we shall bring one day, child of a single sun (spanned though it be but by a single sun), with unfretted good to its end in peace.” The position removes all harshness. brotw=n at the head of the sentence is only semi-dependent. h(su/ximon a(me/ran, in like manner, allows us to wait for its regimen.
pai=d' a)eli/ou: The personification may have faded somewhat, but the mind dissociates teleuta/somen from the apposition.
e)/ban: Gnomic.

div3.head: Epode 2
div3.p: *moi=ra: In P. Moira is above the gods, but in harmony with them.
a(/ te: “She who.”
patrw/ion , kte(.: “Maintains as an heirloom [= from sire to son] this fair fate of theirs.”
tw=nde: As usu. of the victor's house, the Emmenidai.
e)pi/ ti . . . ph=ma: The calamity is gently touched. The name of Oidipus is not even mentioned. Where P. does mention the hero, it is to honor him, P. 4.263.
palintra/pelon: “Reverse.” Pendant to pali/gkoton damasqe/n, v. 22.
e)c ou(=per: “Since.”
mo/rimos ui(o/s=o( kata\ moi=ran au)tw=| geno/menos.
sunanto/menos: On his way from the Delphic oracle, where Apollo had told him that he would be the murderer of his father that begot him (So. O.R. 793).
xrhsqe\n | palai/faton te/lessen: P. ignores the first part as recorded by So. O.R. 791: w(s mhtri\ me\n xrei/h me mixqh=nai.

div3.head: Strophe 3
div3.p: o)cei)= *)erinu/s: o)ce/ws ble/pousa, Schol. She saw, while Oidipus was blind. So. Ai. 835: kalw= d' a)rwgou\s ta\s a)ei/ te parqe/nous, | a)ei\ d' o(rw/sas pa/nta ta)n brotoi=s pa/qh, | semna\s *)erinu=s tanu/podas.

su\n a)llalofoni/a|: The comitative su/n with the dat., instead of the simple instrumental dat., which has forgotten its comitative origin. Cf. P. 12.21: o)/fra . . . su\n e)/mtesi mimh/sait' e)rikla/gktan go/on.

ge/nos a)rh/ion: “His fighting
stock,” his sons, the spear-side of his house.
*qe/rsandros: The son of Polyneikes and his wife Argeia, daughter of Adrastos.
e)n ma/xais . . . pole/mou: He was slain by Telephos before Troy.
qa/los: Cf. O. 6.68: *(hrakle/hs semno\n qa/los *)alkai+da=n.
a)rwgo/n: Aigialeus, the only son of Adrastos, had fallen before Thebes, so that Thersandros became the avenger of the family in the war of the Epigonoi. (So Böckh with the Schol.)
spe/rmatos . . . r(i/zan: “Seed root,” origin.

e)/xonta: So Aristarchos. The MSS. have e)/xonti, which some Scholiasts take as e)/xousi, while others note the change from dat. (e)/xonti) to acc. (to\n *ai)nhsida/mou), a change which, however natural from substantive to participle, is not natural from participle to substantive.
mele/wn lura=n te: Blended in v. 1: a)nacifo/rmigges u(/mnoi.

div3.head: Antistrophe 3
div3.p: ge/ras: “Prize.”
o(mo/klaron: Likewise victorious. The brother was Xenokrates. Compare P. 6 and I. 2.
koinai/: “Impartial.”
*xa/rites: Who give and grace victories. See O. 6.76; N. 5 (end); N. 10.38.
a)/nqea teqri/ppwn: The chariots are wreathed with the flowers they have gained. See P. 9.133: polla\ me\n kei=noi di/kon | fu/ll' e)/pi kai\ stefa/nous.
duwdekadro/mwn: Chariots had to make twelve courses. Cf. P. 5.33. Hence O. 3.33: dwdeka/gnampton te/rma, and O. 6.75.
to\ de\ tuxei=n = to\ nikh=sai, Schol. N. 1.10: e)/sti d' e)n eu)tuxi/a| | pandoci/as a)/kron.
a)gwni/as: The bad sense is late.

dusfrona=n: Formed like eu)fro/nh, a)fro/nh = a)frosu/nh. The best MSS. have dusfrosu/nan paralu/ei. dusf. is glossed by a)qumi/a. This is the recurrent thought of the ode — the balance of good and bad.
o( ma\n plou=tos: m., a faded oath, by way of confirmation. Often used to meet objections.

a)retai=s dedaidalme/nos: See O. 13 for a poetic lesson on the necessity of something more than wealth. Cf. P. 5.1: o( plou=tos eu)rusqenh/s, o(/tan tis a)reta=| kekrame/non kaqara=| au)to\n a)na/gh| | polu/filon e(pe/tan.
tw=n te kai\ tw=n: “This and that.” Not “good and bad,” but “indefinite blessings.” So, in prose, to\n kai\ to/n, “this man and that man.”

baqei=an u(pe/xwn me/rimnan a)grote/ran: Acc. to the majority of interpreters this means “rousing a deep and eager yearning for achievement,” “putting into the heart of man a deep and eager mood.” So the Schol.: suneth\n e)/xwn th\n fronti/da pro\s to\ a)greu/ein ta\ a)gaqa/. a)gro/teros is used of the Centaur, P. 3.4; a)grote/ra of Kyrene, P. 9.6. But lions are a)gro/teroi, N. 3.46, and as me/rimna leans in P. to the bad, and u(pe/xwn occurs nowhere else in P., diversity of opinion may
be pardoned. u(pe/xein, “sustain,” is the other side of kate/xein, “keep down,” and that other side appears, v. 21: e)slw=n . . . u(po\ xarma/twn ph=ma qna/|skei | pali/gkoton damasqe/n. There the monster is crushed, here the high (deep) load of carking care is shouldered. Wealth is an Atlas.

div3.head: Epode 3
div3.p: a)sth\r a)ri/zhlos , kte(.: The shifting of the imagery is facilitated by the beginning of the epode. a)ri/zhlos = a)ri/dhlos, an Homeric word.
fe/ggos is used of the sun, the moon, or any great or conspicuous light.

ei) de/: The passage has an enormous literature to itself. In despair, I have kept the reading of the MSS., with the interpretation “If, in truth, when one hath it (nin = plou=ton) he knows (of) the future that,” etc. de/ in P. is often not far from dh/. This would make the sentence an after-thought. Böckh's ei)/ ge, which is simple, is not lyrical (Mommsen). eu)= de/ and e)\n de/ are not convincing conjectures. eu)=te has been suggested. Bergk considers oi)=den to have been used once by brachylogy instead of twice, and punctuates ei) de/ nin e)/xwn tis, oi)=den to\ me/llon, “If any one that hath it knows, he (Theron) knows.” In that case, Theron would have been mentioned. Mezger makes ei)/ tis oi)=den . . . a)na/gka| the protasis, and i)/sais de/ . . . tu/rsin the apodosis, or rather the apparent apodosis, the real apodosis being some verb of ascertainment understood. See my Lat. Gr. (3 ed.), 601. “If one knows . . . (why, then, he must know that) . . . the good,” etc. This makes de/ apodotic. See O. 3.43. It would be better to leave the first sentence frankly without an apodosis.

qano/ntwn: The sins committed in the world below are punished here on earth. Earth and Hades are mutual hells. P.'s view of the yonder world, as set forth in this passage, may be supplemented by the fragments of the qrh=noi. P. believes in the continued existence of the soul after death, in transmigration, in retribution, in eternal blessedness. Immediately after death the soul is judged and sent to join the ranks of the pious or of the wicked. Good souls dwell with Pluton and Persephone in perpetual light and happiness, the bad must endure anguish past beholding for punishment and purification. If they do not mend, they are sent back to earth, and after death come again before the inexorable judgment-seat. Those who are purified return to earth in the ninth year, and are made kings, heroes, sages. When a man has maintained himself in each of these transition stages, and has kept pure from all wrong, he becomes
a hero, and dwells forever in the islands of the blessed. (After Mezger.)
au)ti/k': “Straight,” eu)qe/ws, Schol.
a)pa/lamnoi: Cf. O. 1.59: a)pa/lamon bi/on.
e)/tisan: The aor. disposes of Rauchenstein's au)=tis.
ta=|de *dio\s a)rxa=|: On earth. — 65: kata\ ga=s: kata\ with genitive in P. only here
tis: Dread indefiniteness.
lo/gon fra/sais: “Rendering his sentence.” fra/zein, of deliberate, careful, clear speech. lo/gos is used of an oracle, P. 4.59.

div3.head: Strophe 4
div3.p: i)/sais de\ nu/ktessin ai)ei/, | i)/sais d' a(me/rais: I follow Mommsen. The best MSS. have i)/sais d' e)n a(m. Various changes have been made to save the uniformity and avoid — for ˘ ˘ in v. 68. So, v. 67: i)/son de/, v. 68: i)/sa d' e)n a(m., which J. H. H. Schmidt follows. Equal nights and equal days may be equal to each other (equinoctial) or equal to ours; may be equal in length or equal in character. “Equal to each other in character” seems to be the safest interpretation. “The night shineth as the day; the darkness and the light are both alike.” To some the passage means that the blessed have the same length of day and night that we do, but their lives are freer from toil. This interpretation is favored by a)pone/steron, which shows that the standard of comparison is earthly life, though Dissen makes it refer to the wicked.
de/kontai: It is a boon. de/rkontai, the reading of the mass of our MSS., is unmetrical, and not over-clear
ou) xqo/na: The position of the negative in P. is especially free; here it is to be justified by ou)de\ po/ntion u(/dwr.
e)n xero\s a)kma=|: So, P. 2.8: a)ganai=sin e)n xersi\n poikilani/ois e)da/masse pw/lous. N. 1.52: e)n xeri\ tina/sswn fa/sganon. Local more vivid than instrumental.
a)kma=|: “Strength;” as a)kma\ podw=n, I. 7 (8), 37, is “speed.”

keina\n para\ di/aitan: “For the sake of unsatisfying food,” as mortals do. This use of para/, “along,” “by way of,” and so “by reason of,” “for the sake of,” is solitary in P., but becomes common in the later time. So par' o(/.
timi/ois | qew=n: At the court of Pluton and Persephone.
e)/xairon: When they were on earth.
eu)orki/ais: Ps. 24, 3: Who shall stand in His holy place? He that hath clean hands and a pure heart; who hath not lifted up his soul unto vanity, nor sworn deceitfully.
toi\ de/ = oi( kakoi/.
o)kxe/onti = o)xe/ousi = u(fi/stantai kai\ basta/zousin (Schol.).

div3.head: Antistrophe 4
div3.p: e)to/lmasan: “Persevered.”

e)stri\s | e(kate/rwqi : tri\s e(kate/rwqi would naturally mean six times. e)stri/s may mean three times in all. The soul descends to Hades, then returns to
earth, then descends again for a final probation.
e)/teilan: Act. only here in P.
*dio\s o(do/n: The king's highway (mystic).
para\ *kro/nou tu/rsin: Not “along,” as in prose, but “to the neighborhood of,” as if para\ *kro/non, “to the court of Kronos,” who presides over the happy isles.
va=sos: Dor. = nh/sous.
a)/nqema xrusou= = a)/. xrusa=. So I. 1, 20: fia/laisi xrusou=. Cf. P. 1.6; 4, 71. 240; N. 5.54; I. 7 (8), 67.

ta\ me\n xerso/qen . . . u(/dwr d' a)/lla: Chiasm. The world below is a brilliant repetition of the world above. The prizes are of gold — gold instead of olive and laurel. In u(/dwr, Dissen sees an allusion to the water-parsley of the Isthmian games.

stefa/nois: I have given what seems to be the best MS. reading. kefala/s is used in a gloss to explain stefa/nois, as st. is not applicable to xe/ras, o(/rmoi being used for neck and breast, ste/fanoi for heads. Bergk suggests: o(/rmois e) (= e)k in Lokrian inscriptions) tw=n xe/res a)naple/konti kai\ stefa/nois — o(/rmois and stefa/nois being Aeolic accusatives.

div3.head: Epode 4
div3.p: boulai=s e)n o)rqai=si: Like e)n no/mois, P. 1.62; e)n no/mw|, N. 10.28; I. 2, 38; and e)n di/ka|, O. 2.18; 6, 12; P. 5.14; N. 5.14. e)n di/kh| is common even in prose
*(radamanquos: The tis of v. 65.

o(\n . . . pa/redron: The best MSS. have o(\n path\r e)/xei ga=s with a gap. The true reading cannot be elicited with certainty from the Scholia and glosses. Even in antiquity the critics were at a loss. I have resigned myself with Dissen and Schneidewin to the reading of the interpolated MSS.
*(pe/as . . . qro/non: Rhea, as mother of the gods, thrones above all.

*phleu/s: An Hellenic saint, a Greek Joseph. See N. 5.26, where he resists the wiles of Hippolyta, and I. 7 (8), 41: o(/nt' eu)sebe/staton fa/tis *)iwlkou= tra/fein pedi/on. Peleus and Kadmos are associated again, P. 3.87. Here they are linked by te kai/ on account of the like fortune in marriage, l. c. 91: o(po/q' *(armoni/an ga=men bow=pin | o( de\ *nhre/os eu)bou/lou *qe/tin pai=da kluta/n.
*ka/dmos: Called a)nti/qeos, P. 3.88.

*)axille/a: e)n nh/sois maka/rwn se/ fasin ei)=nai | i(/naper podw/khs *)axileu/s, acc. to the famous skolion of Kallistratos ap. Athen. 15, 695 A. See Plat. Symp. 179 E, 180 B. Acc. to N. 4.49 Achilles has another abode, an island in the Euxine. It has been fancied that Theron was a Peleus, a Kadmos, and an Achilles in one.

div3.head: Strophe 5
div3.p: a)/maxon a)strabh= ki/ona: An allusion to *(/ektwr (acc. to Greek feeling = *e)xe/twr) as the “upholder” is not impossible, though the metaphor is common enough.

*ku/knon: Son of Poseidon,
who opposed the landing of the Greeks.

qana/tw| po/ren: Compare P. 5.60: e)/dwke qh=ras ai)nw=| fo/bw|, N. 1.66: fa=se/ nin dw/sein mo/rw|, and Lat. dare morti, “put (in)to (the maw of) death.” Instead of flattening antique personification, let us emboss our own. porei=n is combined with ne/mein and dido/nai, P. 5.65.
*)aou=s te pai=d' *ai)qi/opa: Memnon. Kyknos, Hektor, and Memnon are grouped, I. 4 (5), 39, another triad.
polla/ moi , kte(.: Asyndeton common on announcing the end.
u(p' a)gkw=nos: Compare Theokr. 17, 30: u(pwle/nio/n te fare/trhn.
be/lh: Of poetry, I. 4, 46; O. 13.93.
e)nti/: Is explained as a singular, but Gust. Meyer, Gr. Gr., § 483, dissents. It is livelier as a plural, O. 10 (11), 93; P. 1.13.
fwna/enta sunetoi=sin: A stock quotation, “that have a voice only for the wise.”

e)s de\ to\ pa/n: Sometimes written topa/n or to/pan to save the quantity, like su/mpan, a(/pan, pro/pan. to\ pa/n is glossed by to\ koino/n, Shakespeare's “the general,” pou\s pollou\s kai\ xudaiote/rous. The other rendering, “generally,” is less satisfactory. The change from the dative sunetoi=sin to e)s and the acc. is in P.'s manner. Mr. Verrall argues (Journal of Philol., No. XVII.) at length in favor of topa/n from *toph/, “divination,” a word which he elicits from topa/zein.
sofo/s: Of poetic art.

fua=|: A Pindaric cry to be heard often, e. g. O. 9.107: to\ de\ fua=| kra/tiston a(/pan, for while P. does not despise training, O. 8.60, where, by the way, he is praising a trainer, he believes in Ruskin's first rule, “Be born with genius.” God, Apollo, the Muse, the Muses, Charis, the Charites — these are the sources of the poet's inspiration. It is part and parcel of his aristocratic “blood” theory.

maqo/ntes: The old sneer that finds an echo in Persius, Quis expedivit psittaco suum xai=re? The commentators refer this characteristic to Simonides and Bakchylides. Simonides was considered sofw/tatos, and if Simonides was meant, sofo\s o( polla\ veidw\s fua=| would be spiteful. Bakchylides was the nephew of Simonides, disciple, imitator, and collaborator of his uncle. It is supposed that P. gained the contract for writing this poem over S. and B., and hence this scornful and, we should say, ignoble note of superiority. As Simonides had just made peace between Hieron and Theron, it is very unlikely that P. should have made this arrogant fling at this time.
la/broi: With ko/rakes. The antithesis is the o)/rnis qei=os (Mezger). Usually punctuated la/broi pagglwsi/a|, ko/rakes w(/s.

ko/rakes w(/s . . . garu/eton: The dual certainly suggests definite pairs, especially as it is often used with mocking effect, e. g. in Plato's
Euthydemos (compare Arcades ambo). The use of the dual on metrical (?) grounds for the plural is not tolerable. Mr. Verrall's suggestion that the reference is to the two Sicilian rhetoricians, Korax and Tisias (the latter of whom was called kakou= ko/rakos kako\n w)|o/n) is ingenious. See P. 1.94, where the panegyric side of oratory is recognized. If we must have rivalry, why not rivalry between the old art of poetry (fua=|) and the new art of rhetoric (maqo/ntes)? Besides, la/broi ko/rakes of this kind succeed best in the la/bros strato/s (P. 2.87).
a)/kranta: “Ineffectual stuff.”

div3.head: Antistrophe 5
div3.p:
*dio\s pro\s o)/rnixa qei=on: See P. 1.6. The eagle (Pindar) sits quiet and disdainful on the sceptre of Zeus. His defiant scream will come, and then the ineffectual chatter will cease. Compare Soph. Ai. 169:
me/gan ai)gupio\n d' u(podei/santes ta/x) a)\n e)cai/fnhs ei) su\ fanei/hs,
sigh=| pth/ceian a)/fwnoi.
e)/pexe nu=n skopw=|, kte(.: Resumption of the figure in vv. 92-94. Cf. N. 9.55: a)konti/zwn skopoi)= a)/gxista *moisa=n.
qume/: So N. 3.26.
ti/na ba/llomen: Not exactly = balou=men: “Whom are we trying to hit?” The pres. for fut., except in oracles (O. 8.42), is rare, conversational, passionate. See Thuk. 6, 91, 3.
e)k malqaka=s . . . freno/s: The quiver usually has a hostile significance, hence freno/s is qualified. The arrows are kindly (a)gana/), not biting (pikra/).
e)pi/: As in O. 8.48: e)p' *)isqmw=| ponti/a| | a(/rma qoo\n ta/nuen.
tanu/sais au)da/somai = tei/nas to\ to/con a)pofanou=mai (Schol.). Böckh punctuates tanu/sais: and makes it an optative (imperative opt.), counter to the Pindaric use of toi.
au)da/somai: In its full sense of “loudly proclaim.”
e)no/rkion lo/gon: O. 6.20: me/gan o(/rkon o)mo/ssais.

tekei=n mh/: The neg. is mh/ on account of the oath. Commentators are divided as to tekei=n, whether it is past or future. For the future, see O. 1.105. For the past, P. 2.60: ei) de/ tis h)/dh ktea/tessi/ ti kai\ peri\ tima=| le/gei | e)/tero/n tin' a)n' *(ella/da tw=n pa/roiqe gene/sqai | xau/na| prapi/di palaimonei= kenea/. The past is better on account of the e(kato/n ge vete/wn: “These hundred years,” with an especial reference to Akragas, which was founded about a hundred years before (Ol. 49, 3 = 582 B.C.).

div3.head: Epode 5
div3.p:
*qh/rwnos: Effective position. Compare v. 17: loipw=| ge/nei, and O. 1.81. The sense is fairly complete in the antistrophe; and the use of the dependent genitive here renews the
whole thought with a challenge. — ai)=non: In prose this word was reserved for religious occasions. P. uses e)/painos but once
e)pe/ba: Is supposed to have an actual basis in the behavior of Kapys and Hippokrates, two kinsmen of Theron, who went over to Hieron (Schol.). But gnomic aorists have an actual basis also.
ou) di/ka| sunanto/menos: “Not mated with justice, but [set on] by rabid men. Compare I. 2, 1: xrusampu/kwn | e)s di/fron *moisa=n e)/bainon kluta=| fo/rmiggi sunanto/menoi.
ma/rgwn: Of men besotted in their fury. So margoume/nous, N. 9.19.

to\ lalagh=sai qe/lwn: The articular infinitive, which is not fully developed in P., is seldom used after verbs of will and endeavor, and then always has a strong demonstrative force — often with a scornful tang. So. Ant. 312: ou)k e)c a(/pantos dei= to\ kerdai/nein filei=n , 664: tou)pita/ssein toi=s kratou=sin e)nnoei= , O. C. 442: to\ dra=n ou)k h)qe/lhsan (cited by De Jongh). So in prose with speu/dein, qarrei=n, diw/kein, and the opposite. “Full fain for this thing of babbling.”
kru/fon: A very rare substantive.
te qe/men: Better than tiqe/men, which would depend awkwardly on lalagh=sai.

e)pei\ . . . du/naito : e)pei/ is “whereas.” Madmen may attempt to babble down and obscure his praises, but his deeds of kindness are numberless, and cannot be effaced any more than they can be counted.
xa/rmata: Echo of xarma/twn, v. 21 (Mezger).

div2.p: The third Olympian celebrates the same victory as the preceding ode. In what order the two were sung does not appear. O. 2 was probably performed in the palace of Theron; O. 3 in the Dioskureion of Akragas. The superscription and the Scholia indicate that this ode was prepared for the festival of the *qeoce/nia, at which Kastor and Polydeukes entertained the gods. It is natural to assume the existence of a special house-cult of the Dioskuroi in the family of the Emmenidai, but we must not press v. 39 too hard.

The third Olympian, then, combines the epinikian ode with the theoxenian hymn. The Tyndaridai are in the foreground. It is the Tyndaridai that the poet seeks to please (v. 1) by his *)olumpioni/kas u(/mnos. It is the Tyndaridai, the twin sons of Leda (v. 35), that are the ruling spirits of the Olympian contests. It is the Tyndaridai that are the givers of fame to Theron (v. 39). The victory is the same as that celebrated in the previous ode, but there Theron is always present to our minds. We are always thinking of the third member of the triad — god, hero, man. Here Theron is kept back. The poet who was there almost, if not altogether, defiant in his heralding of Theron, utters scarce a word of praise here. Before it was merit, here it is grace.

The poem is a solemn banquet-hymn. The victory calls for the fulfilment of a divine service, a qeo/dmaton xre/os (v. 7). Pisa is the source of qeomoroi a)oidai/ (v. 10). The myth has the same drift. It is the story of the Finding of the Olive, the token of victory. This is no native growth. It was brought by Herakles from the sources of the Istros, a memorial of Olympic contests (v. 15). It was not won by force, but obtained by entreaty from the Hyperborean servants of Apollo (v. 16), and the hero craved it as shade for the sacred enclosure of his sire, and as a wreath for human prowess (v. 18). Already had the games been established,
but the ground was bare to the keen scourgings of the sun (v. 24). Sent to Istria on another errand by Zeus, he had beheld and wondered (v. 32). Thither returning at the impulse of his heart, he asked and received, and planted the olive at Olympia (v. 34), which he still visits with the sons of Leda (v. 35).
The parallel with Herakles is revealed at the end. Theron has reached his bound — his Herakles' pillars. Beyond lies nothing. Seek no further (v. 45).

The olive was a free gift of God. So is this victory of Theron. It might be dangerous to press the details. Yet it is not unGreek to say that the beauty of life is found of those who walk in the path of duty. Theron's praise is no less because it is indirect.

The dactylo-epitrite rhythms are peculiarly appropriate in a hymn addressed to deities so Dorian in their character as the Dioskuroi. The compass of the strophe is not great, but especial stateliness is given to the composition by the massiveness of the epode. It is noteworthy that strophe and epode end with the same measure.

Of the three triads, the central one contains the heart of the Finding of the Olive. The story is begun at the close of the first triad, and finished at the beginning of the third, and thus the parts are locked together.

div3.head: Strophe 1
div3.p: filocei/nois: The Dioskuroi were in an especial manner gods of hospitality, though an allusion to the *qeoce/nia is not excluded
a)dei=n = a(dei=n, Aeolic yi/lwsis, P. 2.96.

kalliploka/mw| q' *(ele/na|: k., used of Thetis and Demeter in Homer, who is more lavish in his use of e)uplo/kamos. Helen is kalli/komos, Od. 15. 58. te . . . te, as the brothers, so the sister. See O. 1.115. H. shares her brothers' hospitable nature. See Od. 4. 130 foll., 296 foll.
kleina\n *)akra/ganta: With P.'s leaning to the fem.
gerai/rwn: “While honoring.”
eu)/xomai: A prayer and not a boast. So also P. 8.67, where ai)te/w forms a sufficient contrast.
*qh/rwnos *)olumpioni/kan u(/mnon: Instead of the prosaic *)olumpioni/kou u(/mnon.
o)rqw/sais: Simply “raising,” without any sidenotion of column (O. 7.86) or statue (I. 1, 46):
a)kamantopo/dwn: O. 5.3: a)kamanto/podos . . . a)ph/nas.
a)/wton: Appos. to u(/mnon. Compare O. 5.1; 8, 75.

ou(/tw moi paresta/koi: So with Mommsen,
instead of ou(/tw toi pare/sta moi. ou(/tw, as she had done before. In a wish, P. 1.46. 56. With paresta/koi compare P. 8.70: kw/mw| me\n a(dumelei= | *di/ka pare/stake.
neosi/galon: “With its gloss fresh upon it.” We say, with another figure, “fire-new.” O. 9.52: a)/nqea d' u(/mnwn newte/rwn.
tro/pon: The novelty consists in the combination of honor to God and honor to man, of theoxenia and epinikion. See the Introduction.
pedi/lw|: The pe/dilon strikes the measure.

div3.head: Antistrophe 1
div3.p: e)pei\ . . . gegwnei=n: Gives the double element — the victory of Theron (e)pini/kion), and the right of the Tyndaridai to Pisa (*qeoce/nia). Compare v. 9: ta=s a)/po | qeo/moroi ni/sont' e)p' a)nqrw/pous a)oidai/, with v. 34: i(/laos a)ntiqe/oisin ni/setai | su\n baquzw/nou didu/mnois paisi\ *lh/das. The song is the refluence of the coming of Herakles and the Tyndaridai.

xai/taisi me\n zeuxqe/ntes: P. prefers this warmer participial conception to the colder infinitive (to\) xai/taisin e)pizeuxqh=nai stefa/nous. See P. 2.23; 3, 102; 11, 22; N. 4.34; I. 4, 49; 7, 12. Dem. 18, 32: dia\ tou/tous ou)xi\ peisqe/ntas, much more vigorous than dia\ to\ tou/tous mh\ peisqh=nai. The familiarity of these constructions in Latin deadens our perception of them in Greek, where they are very much rarer. me/n, with an answering te, v. 9. See O. 4.13.
pra/ssonti: P. 9.111: e)me\ d' w)=n . . . tis pra/ssei xre/os. The more familiar middle occurs O. 10.33.
qeo/dmaton: The last part of the compd. is felt elsewhere, O. 6.59; P. 1.61; 9, 11; though faintly in I. 5, 11: qeodma/tous a)reta/s. There is no echo of o)rqw/sais.
fo/rmigga/ te . . . kai\ boa\n au)lw=n e)pe/wn te: te . . . kai/ unites the instrumentation, te adds the words as an essential element.
poikilo/garun: Cf. O. 4.2: poikilofo/rmiggos a)oida=s.
qe/sin = poi/hsin. Etym. Magn. p. 319, 31: qe/sis h( poi/hsis par' *)alkai/w|, and p. 391, 26: *pi/ndaros qe/sin to\ poi/hma le/gei. Sappho, fr. 36 (Bgk.): ou)k oi)=d' o)/tti qe/w.
*ai)nhsida/mou paidi/: In honor of Theron.
summi=cai: Cf. O. 1.22.
a(/ te *pi/sa: See v. 7.

gegwnei=n: Supply pra/ssei, which is easier, as the near neighborhood of summi=cai keeps the construction wide-awake. ge/gwnen (Christ) does not give a clear sense, though the shift is in P.'s manner.
ta=s a)/po: O. 1.8.
qeo/moroi: “God-given,” as I. 7, 38: ga/mou qeo/moron ge/ras.

div3.head: Epode 1
div3.p: w(=| tini = tou/tw| (in his honor), w(=| tini. — krai/nwn . . . ba/lh|: Pres., the rule; aor., the exemplification. Simple subj. in generic sentence as in Homer
e)fetma/s: See P. 2.21.

prote/ras:
“Of old,” “of yore.” O. 7.72: e)pi\ prote/rwn a)ndrw=n.
a)trekh/s: “Unswervable.”

*(ellanodi/kas: The judge of the contest, so called because Greeks alone could participate in the games. Originally the number is said to have been two, afterwards ten, according to the number of the fulai/ of the Eleians, and afterwards still further enlarged.
glefa/rwn . . . u(yo/qen: The eyes of the victor would naturally follow the movement of the prizegiver's hand, hence u(yo/qen.
*ai)twlo/s: The Eleians were called Aitolians, after their leader, Oxylos, who accompanied, or rather guided, the Herakleidai on their return.

glauko/xroa: Cf. So. O. C. 701: glauka=s . . . fu/llon e)lai/as . The hue is grayish-green. On the symbolism of the olive, see Porphyr. de Antro Nymph. c. 33. P. does not distinguish the e)lai/a from the ko/tinos (wild olive).
ta/n pote: The relative begins the myth. Cf. O. 1.25.
*)/istrou: A half-fabulous river.
*)amfitruwnia/das: Herakles. The mouth-filling word, well suited to the hero, occurs again, I. 5, 38. Cf. Catull. 68, 112: falsiparens Amphitryoniades.

div3.head: Strophe 2
div3.p: da=mon *(uperbore/wn: The well-known favorites of Apollo, who lived “beyond the North,” according to P., as he brings them into contrast with the Nile (I. 5 [6], 23). Perseus' visit to the Hyperboreans is described in P. 10 (Pindar's earliest poem).
*)apo/llwnos qera/ponta: P. 10.34: w(=n qali/ais e)/mpedon | eu)fami/ais te ma/list' *)apo/llwn | xai/rei.
pei/sais . . . lo/gw|: l. has an emphatic position. Herakles does not often stoop to plead.
pista\ frone/wn: “With loyal soul,” if “loyal” were antique; “true to his sire.”
