ai)/tei: “He had to ask.” Not ai)tei=, the histor. pres., which is very rare in P., and turns on P. 5.82, which see.
pando/kw|: Compare O. 1.93; 6, 69.
a)/lsei: “Every place consecrated to the gods is an a)/lsos, even if it be bare of trees,” says the Schol.
skiaro/n te fu/teuma: It had shaded the *)/istrou pagai/, v. 14.
cuno\n a)nqrw/pois: The shade is common to all men, the wreaths are for the victors (Böckh). “A common boon.”
au)tw=|: With a)nte/flece. “In his face.” — dixo/mhnis: “Monthhalver.” The full moon lighted the height of the festival.
o(/lon: “Full” (proleptic).
xrusa/rmatos: Compare the “yellow harvest-moon.”

e(spe/ras: “At eventide” (cf. P. 4.40), acc. to Böckh, but the moon may flash full the Eye of Even, which is herself. Still the adverbial interpretation is favored by O. 10 (11), 81: e)n d' e(/speron | e)/flecen eu)w/pidos | sela/nas e)rato\n fa/os.

div3.head: Antistrophe 2
div3.p: a)e/qlwn . . . kri/sin: So N. 10.23, but O. 7.80: kri/sis a)mf' a)e/qlois.
a(gna/n: The decision is “pure” (intemerate) as the judge is “true” (unwarped), v. 12.
a(ma= (Dor.) = a(/ma here, and P. 3.36; N. 5.11, but=o(mou=, N. 7.78.
krhmnoi=s: “Bluffs,” as in Homer. P. 3.34: para\ *boibia/dos krhmnoi=s, fr. XI. 64: pa\r krhmno\n qala/ssas.
ou) kala\ , kte(.: On the position of ou) compare O. 4.17.
de/ndre' e)/qallen: d. is inner object: de/ndra teqhlo/ta ei)=xe.

*kroni/ou. Böckh combines *kroni/ou *pe/lopos. This would require *kroni/da (Herm.). Aristarchos combines xw=ros *pe/lopos, e)n ba/ssais *kroni/ou. Hence we read xw=ros — e)n ba/ssais *kroni/ou — *pe/lopos, which is very much in P.'s manner.
tou/twn . . . gumno/s: As tw=n is used as a relative, the asyndeton is not felt with the fuller tou/twn, which need not be = tou/twn ou)=n.
ka=pos: So “garden” of any favored spot, P. 9.57: *dio\s e)/coxon ka=pon (Libya).
u(pakoue/men: As a slave. “To be exposed to,” “lashed by” (cf. “that fierce light which beats upon a throne”).
o)cei/ais . . . au)gai=s: O. 7.70: e)/xei te/ min o)ceia=n o( gene/qlios a)kti/nwn path/r, Theogn. 425: au)ga\s
o)ce/os h)eli/ou.
poreu/ein: The Schol. makes this form here = poreu/esqai, but it is better to make poreu/ein transitive and w(/rma intransitive. Bergk reads w(/rmain'.

div3.head: Epode 2
div3.p: i(pposo/a: I. 4 (5), 32: i(pposo/as *)io/laos. In P. 2.9 Artemis puts on the trappings when Hieron yokes his horses. Homer calls her (Il. 6. 205) xrush/nios.

de/cat' e)lqo/nt' . . . a)po\, kte(.: Refers to a previous visit, the memory of which was recalled by the nakedness of the ka=pos. The circumstances of the two visits are different; the first visit (from Arcady) was under the stress of a)na/gka, and at the bidding of the hated Eurystheus, and the second visit (from Elis) was in faithful love (pista\ frone/wn), at the bidding of his own spirit.
deira=n: O. 9.63: *mainali/aisin e)n deirai=s.

a)ggeli/ais: The plural of an impressive message, also I. 7 (8), 43: i)o/ntwn . . . au)ti/k' a)ggeli/ai. Eurystheus sent his message to Herakles by Kopreus (Il. 15. 639), a proceeding which both Homeric and Pindaric Scholiasts ascribe to fear.
e)/ntue: As in P. 9.72: w(\s a)/r' ei)pw\n e)/ntuen terpna\n ga/mou krai/nein teleuta/n. The extension of e)nt. from paraskeua/zein to diegei/rein (Schol.) is not Homeric.
patro/qen: The a)na/gka bound sire as well as son. The story of the oath of Zeus and the consequent subjection of Herakles to Eurystheus is told, Il. 19. 95 sqq.

xruso/kerwn e)/.
qh/leian: Mythic does have mythic horns.

*tau+ge/ta: One of the Pleiades, daughter of Atlas, mother of Lakedaimon and Eurotas. In order to escape the pursuit of Zeus, she was changed by Artemis into a doe, and after she returned to her human form she consecrated a doe to the goddess.
a)ntiqei=sa = a)natiqei=sa (Schol.).

*)orqwsi/a|: The hiatus is paralleled by O. 6.82; N. 6.24; I. 1, 16 (Bergk). — 'O. is not different from *)/artemis *)orqi/a, before whose altar boys were scourged at Sparta. Both doe and scourging indicate a substitution for human sacrifice. As the capture of the doe ordinarily precedes the cleansing of the Augean stables, and so the founding of the Olympic games, v. 34 foll., see Ol. 10 (11), we have another indication that there were two visits to the land of the Hyperboreans.
e)/grayen: The Scholiast is good enough to give us the inscription on the doe's collar: *tau+ge/th i(era\n a)ne/qhken *)arte/midi.

div3.head: Strophe 3
div3.p: pnoia=s o)/piqen *bore/a: P. comes back to the Hyperboreans with an explanatory touch. See on P. 4.29. To emphasize the distance is to emphasize Herakles' devotion to his sire. This P. has done here and in vv. 14, 26. pnoia=s has scarcely any MS. warrant, but pnoiai=s can only be defended by vague analogy.
qa/mbaine = qau/maine, which is an inferior reading.
tw=n: Depends on i(/meros.
dwdeka/gnampton: See O. 2.55.
futeu=sai: Epexegetic infinitive. The place was called to\ *pa/nqeion (Schol.).
tau/tan e(orta/n: The Theoxenia.
ni/setai: The only correct spelling, acc. to the best MSS., and borne out by G. Meyer, Gr. Gr., § 497, ni_/somai for ni-ns-i-o-mai.
baquzw/nou: Epithet applied to the Graces, P. 9.2; to the Muses, I. 5 (6), 74; to Latona, Fr. V. 2, 2. See P. 1.12.

div3.head: Antistrophe 3
div3.p: e)pe/trapen = e)pe/treyen (Schol.).
qahto\n a)gw=na ne/mein: The Dioskuroi were qeoi\ e)nagw/nioi. N. 10.52: eu)ruxo/rou tami/ai *spa/rtas a)gw/nwn.

a)ndrw=n t' a)reta=s: Especially of those games that require personal prowess. O. 1.95: i(/na taxuta\s podw=n e)ri/zetai | a)kmai t' i)sxu/os qrasu/ponoi, N. 9.12: i)sxu/os t' a)ndrw=n a(mi/llais a(/rmasi te glafuroi=s a)/mfaine kudai/nwn po/lin, N. 5.52: pu/ktan te/ nin kai\ pagkrati/w| fqe/gcai e(lei=n *)epidau/rw| diplo/an | nikw=nt' a)reta/n. Still charioteering was not without its dangers. See P. 6.
r(imfarma/tou: So. O. C. 1062.
difrhlasi/as: As a)feth/rioi the Dioskuroi had an altar at the starting-post of the Hippodrome (Paus. 5, 15, 5).

pa\r qumo\s o)tru/nei: The pa| of the MSS. (= pws,
Schol.) cannot be construed; with o)tru/nei it makes no sense, and dido/ntwn is too far off. pa/r, Böckh (parotru/nei), with poor and late MSS. The old Scholiasts show uneasiness.
*)emmeni/dais | *qh/rwni/ te: Theron crowns the line. The dat. with e)lqei=n as often when equiv. to gene/sqai.
e)poi/xontai: Sc. the Emmenidai. Compare what is said of Xenokrates, brother of Theron, I. 2, 39: kai\ qew=n dai=tas prose/ptukto pa/sas.

div3.head: Epode 3
div3.p: teleta/s = ta\s e(orta/s (Schol.).
ei) d' a)risteu/ei , kte(.: “If” (which no one will deny). A familiar sentiment, such as the Greeks did not hesitate to repeat on occasion. See O. 1.1.
nu=n de/: The reading nu=n ge is at first sight more natural, but nu=n de/ has the better warrant “Now in his turn.” This comes near an apodotic de/.
e)sxatia/n: Of one that casts anchor. I. 5 (6), 12: e)sxatia\s h)/dh pro\s o)/lbou | ba/llet' a)/gkuran qeo/timos e)w/n.
a)retai=sin: “By his deeds of emprise.”

oi)/koqen: Variously interpreted. As oi)/koqen oi)/kade is proverbial for ease and comfort of transmission and transition (O. 6.99; 7, 4), so the omission of oi)/kade shows difficulty, trouble, arduous effort. Compare I. 3 (4), 30: a)nore/aisin d' e)sxa/taisin oi)/koqen sta/laisin a(/ptonq' *(hrakleiais. The effect is “the far distant pillars of Herakles.”
*(hrakle/os stala=n: Proverbs weary less by repetition than original figures.
ou)/ nin diw/cw: nin = to\ po/rsw. Neither ou) ma/n nor ou) mh/ is Pindaric. Suavius dicit de se quae Theroni dicere vult (Dissen).
keino\s ei)/hn: “Set me down an empty fool” (if I do). There is no omission of a)/n. Compare Lys. 21, 21: mainoi/mhn (= dokoi/hn mai/nesqai), ei) a)nali/skoimi .

div2.p: Kamarina was founded by the Syracusans, 599 B.C., one hundred and thirty-five years after Syracuse itself. Destroyed by Syracuse in consequence of a revolt, it was some time afterwards restored by Hippokrates. Again stripped of its inhabitants by Gelon, it was rebuilt once more by men of Gela, Ol. 79, 4 (461 B.C.). The proverb mh\ ki/nei *kama/rinan: a)ki/nhtos ga\r a)mei/nwn is supposed to refer to the unhealthy situation of the city, but Lobeck reads kama/rinan, cloacam.

Of Psaumis we know absolutely nothing, except what Pindar is pleased to tell us in this ode and the next. Both odes are supposed to refer to the same victory, a)ph/nh|, that is, with a mule chariot. The MSS. have in the superscription a(/rmati or i(/ppois: a)ph/nh| is due to Böckh's combinations. This gives us a terminus. The mule-race was done away with, Ol. 84 (444 B.C.). Böckh puts Psaumis's victory Ol. 82 (452 B.C.), and maintains that the victor had failed in the four-horse chariot race, and in the race with the single horse (ke/lhti). The a)ph/nh| victory then was a consolation, and there seems to be a note of disappointment in the rhythm.

According to Böckh the ode was sung in Olympia; according to Leopold Schmidt in Kamarina. The latter view seems to be the more probable. The fourth ode was sung in the festal procession, the fifth, the genuineness of which has been disputed, at the banquet.

The key of this brief poem is given, v. 16: dia/peira/ toi brotw=n e)/legxos. The final test is the true test. Success may be slow in coming, but when it comes it reveals the man. The thunderchariot of Zeus is an unwearied chariot. What though his Horai revolve and revolve ere they bring the witness of the lofty contest? Good fortune dawns, and then comes gratulation forthwith. The light comes late, but it is a light that shines
from the chariot of a man who hastens to bring glory to Kamarina. Well may we pray, “God speed his other wishes.” Well may we praise the man — liberal, hospitable, pure-souled, lover of peace, lover of his state. No falsehood shall stain this record of a noble life. The final trial is the test of mortals.

So, by trial, Erginos, the Argonaut, was saved from the reproach of the Lemnian women. Unsuccessful before, he won the race in armor, and said to Hypsipyle as he went after the crown: “This is what I am in swiftness. My hands and heart fully match my feet. The race is for the young, but I am younger than my seeming. Gray hairs grow often on young men before the time. The final trial is the test of mortals.”
Psaumis had every virtue but success; now this is added. So Erginos was a man of might, of courage; now he has shown his speed.

The logaoedic rhythms are handled so as to produce a peculiar effect. Prolongation is frequent (3 for -u), and the result is a half-querulous, half-mocking tone. The lively Aiolian mood is tempered by the plaintive Lydian. Psaumis is only half satisfied, after all, and his enemies are not wholly confounded.
The triad distributes itself fairly into prayer, praise, and story.

div3.head: Strophe
div3.p:
e)lath u(pe/rtate bronta=s a)kamanto/podos *zeu=: Plat. Phaidr. 246 E: o( me
 dh\ me/gas h(gemw
 e)n ou)ranw=| *zeu\s pthno
 a(/rma e)lau/nwn prw=tos poreu/etai , which pthno
 a(/rma becomes a stock quotation in later Greek. Compare Hor. Od. 1, 34, 8:
per purum tonantes
egit equos volucremque currum.
a)kamanto/podos: O. 3.3; 5, 3.

teai\ ga\r w(=rai: ga/r gives the reason of the invocation. The Horai, originally but two, *karpw/ and *qallw/ (Paus. 9, 35, 2), are the daughters of Zeus and Themis; they who in their steady course — *(=wrai being from √ja, “go” — bring things at their season. It has taken time for Psaumis's success to ripen.
u(po\ . . . a)oida=s: Compare O. 7.13: u(p' a)mfote/rwn (fo/rmiggos kai\ au)lw=n) kate/ban.
poikilofo/rmiggos: Cf. O. 3.8: fo/rmigga poikilo/garun, N. 4.14: poiki/lon kiqari/zwn.
e(lisso/menai: “In their circling dance.”

e)/pemyan . . . ma/rtura: It is deplorable literalism to suppose that P. actually went and bore witness to the contests. See N. 1.19: e)/stan d' e)p' au)lei/ais qu/rais. The poet is said to go whithersoever his song goes. Compare N. 5.3: stei=x' a)p' *ai)gi/nas, diagge/llois' o(/ti, kte(.; also I. 2, 46.
ma/rtura = u(mnhth/n (Schol.).

cei/nwn . . . eu)= prasso/ntwn, kte(.: The only possible meaning for cei/nwn
forces us to take e)/sanan in a good sense, which is otherwise strange to P. See P. 1.52; 2, 82. The figure was not so coarse to the Greek as it is to us. So. O. C. 320: faidra\ gou=n a)p' o)mma/twn sai/nei me prosstei/xousa . We can hardly make poetry of Horace's leniter atterens caudam. cei/nwn refers to Psaumis and e)sloi/ to Pindar. “When friends fare well, forthwith the heart of the noble leaps up to greet the sweet tidings.” Some make the passage ironical.
a)ll' w)= *kro/nou pai=: Resumption of the address. Cf. O. 8, init.: *ma=ter . . . *ou)lumpi/a . . . a)ll' w)= *pi/sas.
*ai)/tnan . . . o)bri/mou gives the repressive, as e)lath\r . . . *zeu= the aggressive, side of Zeus's power. Compare also O. 6.96: *zhno\s *ai)tnai/ou kra/tos.
i)=pon: A trivial word (almost = “dead - fall”), ennobled like “canopy” (kwnwpei=on).
a)nemo/essan: Od. 9. 400: a)/krias h)nemoe/ssas.
*tufw=nos: P. 1.16.
*ou)lumpioni/kan . . . kw=mon: O. 3.3: *)olumpioni/kan u(/mnon.

*xari/twn: N. 6.42: *xari/twn | e(spe/rios o(ma/dw| fle/gen, and 9, 54: eu)/xomai tau/tan a)reta\n keladh=sai su\n *xari/tessin. The fourth of the bwmoi\ e(/c di/dumoi, O. 5.5, was dedicated to *xa/rites kai\ *dio/nusos. Compare O. 2.55, and remember also the enmity between Typhon (qew=n pole/mios, P. 1.15) and the Graces.

div3.head: Antistrophe
div3.p: xroniw/taton: The Horai have not hastened. Hence x., “late” with Mezger, not “lasting.”

*yau/mios . . . o)xe/wn: It is not necessary to supply w)/n nor to make o)xe/wn the ablatival genitive i(/kei is only an e)sti/ in motion. “'Tis Psaumis's that has come, his chariot's” (revel song of victory). o)x. prevalently of an a)ph/nh (Schol., O. 6.24).
speu/dei: Psaumis's own eagerness is brought into contrast with the deliberateness of the Horai.
loipai=s eu)xai=s: A mild personification after the Homeric *litai/, Il. 9. 502.

me
 . . . te: me
 . . . de/ balances, te . . . te parallels, me
 . . . te shifts from balance to parallel. Cf. O. 3.6; 6, 88; 7, 12. 69; P. 2.31; 4, 249; 6, 39 al. Notice the triple praise in two groups: I. trofai=s e(toi=mon i(/ppwn, and II. (1) ceni/ais pando/kois, (2) *(hsuxi/an filo/polin.
*(hsuxi/an filo/polin: High praise in the disturbed state of Sicily. Personify with Bergk.

ou) yeu/dei+ te/gcw: N. 1.18: ou) yeu/dei balw/n. For other eccentric positions of the negative, see O. 1.81; 2, 34. 69. 106; 3, 23; 7, 48; 8, 79. Here it amounts to, “I will not lie-dye my word.” Cf. also P. 4.99: e)xqi/stoisi mh\ yeu/desin | katamia/nais ei)pe\ ge/nnan.
dia/peira/ toi brotw=n e)/legxos: Cf. N. 3.71: e)n de\ pei/ra| te/los | diafai/netai. dia- is “final,” “decisive.”

div3.head: Epode
div3.p: *klume/noio pai=da: Erginos, the Argonaut, son of Klymenos (acc. to Apollodoros, 1, 9, 16, 8, son of Poseidon), was ridiculed by the Lemnian women (P. 4.252), on account of his white hair, when he undertook the weapon-race in the funeral games held by Hypsipyle in honor of her father, Thoas. His victory over Zetes and Kalaïs, the swift sons of Boreas, gave the mockers a lesson, not to judge by appearance, but to judge righteous judgment (after the Schol.). According to Pausanias, 9, 37, 4, Erginos, son of Klymenos, late in life consulted the oracle as to the propriety of marriage with a view to offspring, and received the answer: *)ergi=ne *klume/noio pa/i *presbwnia/dao, | o)/y' h)=lqes geneh\n dizh/menos a)ll' e)/ti kai\ nu=n | i(stoboh=i ge/ronti ne/hn poti/balle korw/nhn. The sequel showed that his natural force was not abated, and this gives point to Erginos's reply to the taunt of the Lemnian women.

e)/lusen e)c a)timi/as: Concrete power of the preposition. So I. 7 (8), 6: e)k penqe/wn luqe/ntes. l. without a preposition in P. 3.50: lu/sais . . . a)xe/wn, where, however, e)/cagen is sufficiently plastic.
xalke/oisi d' e)n e)/ntesin: Compare P. 9, init.: A game usu. at funerals.
nikw=n dro/mon: O. 13.30.
*(uyipulei/a|: See Ovid's Heroides VI. and Chaucer's Legend of Good Women.
ste/fanon: The prize was raiment (vesqa=tos a)mfi/s, P. 4.253). The wreath was given besides, I. 1, 18 foll.

*ou(=tos: Tauntingly: “You see.” Kayser, Rauchenstein, and others punctuate ou(=tos e)gw/: taxuta=ti xei=res de\ kai\ h)=tor i)/son, the position of de/ as O. 10 (11), 76. 109; P. 4.228. But we should lose dramatic power by this. Erginos is slightly out of breath.

xei=res: The hands and feet show the first symptoms of age, Hesiod, O. et D. 114. The feet give way before the hands. Notice the scene between Euryalos and Odysseus in Od. 8. 147 foll., and especially where Odysseus shows some concern about his running. For jubilant assertion of the power of old age in boxing (xei=res), see Aristoph. Vesp. 1383. If the feet are all right, then the rest follows a fortiori.
i)/son: “Are a match” (to say the least).
fu/ontai: Erginos is still speaking.
poliai/: An allusion to the gray hairs of Psaumis, who is supposed to have been an w)moge/rwn, if a ge/rwn at all, is an unnecessary hypothesis of the mechanical order.

div2.p: The victory celebrated here is the same as that of the preceding ode.

The verse about which the poem revolves is v. 15: ai)ei\ d' a)mf' a)retai=si po/nos dapa/na te ma/rnatai pro\s e)/rgon | kindu/nw| kekalumme/non. The preceding poem dwells on the importance of the final trial (4, 16); this gives the conditions of success, po/nos dapa/na te. The wain must be untiring (v. 3), the sacrifices great and various (v. 6). To gain an Olympian victory, to found a new city, costs toil and money. The flower of victory is sweet (a)/wtos gluku/s), the abode of Pelops lovely (eu)hratoi staqmoi/), now that the work is over, the price paid. So the daughter of Okeanos, Kamarina, who is to greet the victor with laughing heart (v. 2), was builded with much toil, much cost. The stately canals, the grove of houses — these, like a)ph/nh, like bouqusi/ai, were not made for naught. May blessings rest on city and on Olympian victor! May the one have the adornment of the noble deeds of her sons, the other a happy old age, with his sons clustering about him! po/nos dapa/na te have brought their reward. Wealth sufficient remains. Add fame. What more? Let him not seek to become a god.
There is no myth. The founding of Kamarina is fairy-tale, is magic achievement, enough.

This poem, short as it is, has given rise to much discussion. The Breslau Scholiast (A) tells us that it was not in the e)da/fia (original texts), but it was considered Pindar's from the time of Didymos on. In O. 2 and 3 we have two poems on one and the same victory, but the treatment is very different, as we have seen. P. 4 and 5 celebrate the same success, but different sides are turned out. Here, too, it might be said that O. 4 dwells on the achievement, O. 5 on the conditions; and O. 5 shows a more intimate acquaintance with local circumstances than O. 4 does. But this makes it only the harder to understand the resemblance in diction.
With u(yhla=n a)reta=n (5, 1) compare u(yhlota/twn a)e/qlwn (4, 3); with a)/wton gluku/n (5, 1), a)ggeli/an glukei=an (4, 4); with a)kamanto/podos a)ph/nas (5, 3), bronta=s a)kamanto/podos (4, 1). de/keu occurs 4, 8, and 5, 3; ku=dos a)ne/qhke is found 5, 7; ku=dos o)/rsai, 4, 11; i(/kwn, 5, 9; i(/kei, 4, 10; and if the more common interpretation of 4, 4 be accepted, e)/sanan au)ti/k' a)ggeli/an poti\ glukei=an e)sloi/, it is echoed by 5, 16: h)u\ d' e)/xontes sofoi\ kai\ poli/tais e)/docan e)/mmen: if not, 5, 16 is a sarcastic comment. gh=ras (5, 22) is a reflex of poliai/ (4, 26). It is also well to remember the very narrow limits within which these resemblances, some of them in themselves trifling, are crowded, and Pindar's disinclination to repeat himself. In all P. de/keu occurs but four times, a)kamanto/pous three times, forms of i(/kw seven. The chances of an accidental coincidence are remote. The poet must have had his own ode in mind, or another — perhaps Pindar's local representative, another Aineas (O. 6.88) — must have imitated his manner. Add the point adduced above, the evidence of a more intimate acquaintance with local circumstances.

Much of the other detail is hyper-Pindaric. kardi/a| gelanei=, v. 2, seems to be modelled, and not very happily modelled, on P. 4.181, qumw=| gelanei=, and a)kamanto/podos a)ph/nas, v. 3, on O. 3.3, a)kamantopo/dwn i(/ppwn. u(yhla=n a)reta=n, v. 1, is matched by I. 4 (5), 45, u(yhlai=s a)retai=s, po/lin laotro/fon, v. 4, by O. 6.60, laotro/fon tima/n. ku=dos a(bro/n, v. 7, is found I. 1, 50; semno\n a)/ntron, v. 18, is found P. 9.32. On the other hand, a)/wtos is o)rqo/polis, O. 2.8; e)pi/nikos, O. 8.75; i(ero/s, P. 4.131; ka/llistos, N. 2.9; a)/lpnistos, I. 4 (5), 12; a)/kros, I. 6 (7), 18, never gluku/s except here. Mezger has called attention to the resemblance between this ode and the beginning and the end of the fifth Isthmian; and we can hardly resist the impression that we have before us a clever copy of Pindar's manner.

But if it is a copy of Pindar, the copy is faithful to Pindaric symmetry. Of the three triads, the first has for its main theme the victory of Olympia, the second the founding of Kamarina, the third contains a prayer for well-earned enjoyment of the glory gained abroad as well as at home. The three triads have been compared to the three krath=res of the symposium, at which the ode was sung.

The metres, logaoedic acc. to J. H. H. Schmidt, are often called dactylo-ithyphallic, not elsewhere found in P. Moriz Schmidt insists on the strong resemblance between the movement of O. 4
and of O. 5, in opposition to Böckh, who says: A ceteris Pindari carminibus mirum quantum distans. Von Leutsch emphasizes the brief compass of the strophes and epodes, the simplicity of the verse, the peculiarity of the sequence, all indicating the Lesbian style of composition. According to him the poem is too light, and has too little art, for Pindar.
If we had a wider range of Pindaric poems, we might obelize with more certainty. To me the poem is exceedingly suspicious.

div3.head: Strophe 1
div3.p: a)/wton: “The prime.” See O. 2.8.
*)wkeanou= qu/gater: The nymph of the lake, Kamarina, from which the city received its name.
gelanei=: P. 4.181: qumw=| gelanei=.

div3.head: Antistrophe 1
div3.p: au)/cwn: P. 8.38: au)/cwn pa/tran.
laotro/fon: With reference to the rapid growth of the restored Kamarina.

bwmou\s e(\c didu/mous: According to Herodoros, Herakles built six altars to twelve deities, and the pairs of su/mbwmoi are these: 1. Zeus and Poseidon; 2. Hera and Athena; 3. Hermes and Apollo; 4. Charites and Dionysos; 5. Artemis and Alpheios; 6. Kronos and Rhea.
e)ge/rairen: More natural than e)ge/raren, on account of au)/cwn: “Strove to honor.”
u(po\ bouqusi/ais: Compare I. 5 (6), 44: eu)xai=s u(po\ qespesi/ais | li/ssomai. b. denotes the height of liberality, and sorts with au)/cwn. Do not extend u(po/ to a(mi/llais.

pemptame/rois: This is the reading of the best MSS. Hermann thinks that the contests were held on the fifth day. Fennell considers pemptame/rois a formation analogous to e(bdomh/konta, o)gdoh/konta, and so equivalent to pempame/rois, “lasting five days,” which many editors have.

div3.head: Epode 1
div3.p: i(/ppois h(mio/nois te monampuki/a| te: The various games in which he strove to honor (e)ge/raire) the city. He succeeded only in the mule-race (a)ph/nh). The controversy about this passage is endless.

monampuki/a|: “And with the riding of single horse.” The mona/mpuc was a ke/lhs. “Sole-frontleted” for “single,” like oi)o/zwnos a)nh/r. See commentators on So. O. C. 718: tw=n e(katompo/dwn *nhrh/|dwn a)ko/louqos .
nika/sais a)ne/qhke: The success is in the aor., the effort (v. 5) in the imperf.
e)ka/ruce: Causative.
ne/oikon: See Introduction to O. 4.

div3.head: Strophe 2
div3.p: *oi)noma/ou kai\ *pe/lopos: See O. 1.24 foll. P. does not couple closely the luckless king and his fortunate successor.
*palla/s: Brought from Lindos in Rhodes to Gela, from Gela to Kamarina.
a)ei/dei me\n ... potamo/n te: See O. 4.13.

*)/wanin: K. lay on a hill, eighty feet high, between the mouth of the Oanis (Frascolaro) and the mouth of the Hipparis (Camarana), at the eastern end of the great bay, the innermost point of which is occupied by Gela (Holm). *)/wanis bears a suspicious resemblance to *)wa/nnhs, an Oriental fish-god, germane to Dagon. te *)/wanin points to vw/anis. See Curtius, Gr. Et.^{4}, p. 561.
e)gxwri/an: Not otiose. Kamarina gets its name from the lake of the land.

div3.head: Antistrophe 2
div3.p: semnou\s o)xetou/s: “Stately canals” (Am. Journ. of Phil. VII. p. 407). Others “sacred” because of the river.
strato/n: Doric use of the word “host” for “folk.”

kolla=|: The commentators are divided as to the subject; part take *(/ipparis, part *yau=mis. Assuming, as we may, that Psaumis had done much to improve the navigation of the river, the praise is more delicate if we make the river the agent of all this good, and put, instead of the benefactor, the benefaction. “The river doth build with speed a lofty forest of stedfast dwellings” (Myers). The canal enables the builders to float down wood rapidly for the new houses. Fennell transl. kolla=|, “makes into rafts.”
u(yi/guion a)/lsos: As it were, “a forest of tall houses.”
u(p' a)maxani/as: Livelier than the other reading, a)p'. See O. 6.43, and N. 1.35: spla/gxnwn u(/po mate/ros qahta\n e)s ai)/glan molw/n.
e)s fa/os: To light and life.

div3.head: Epode 2
div3.p: a)mf' a)retai=si: N. 5.47: e)sloi=si ma/rnatai pe/ri pa=sa po/lis.
po/nos dapa/na te: I. 1, 42: a)mfo/teron dapa/nais te kai\ po/nois.
ma/rnatai: The singular number of a welded pair.
pro\s e)/rgon: “With victory in view, veiled though it be with risk.” The chariot-race was a risk to person as well as to property. See P. 5.49.
h)u\ d' e)/xontes: The successful are the wise — an old sneer. So Eurip.: to\n eu)tuxou=nta kai\ fronei=n nomi/zomen.
kai\ poli/tais: Who are the last to recognize merit in a fellow-citizen. P. 11.28: kakolo/goi de\ poli=tai.

div3.head: Strophe 3
div3.p: *swth/r: Kamarina was a redeemed city. The voc. sw=ter is post-Homeric.

vidai=on: According to Demetrios of Skepsis this Idaian cave was at Olympia. If so, it was doubtless named after the great Ida in Crete. There were many
Cretans among the original founders of Kamarina.
*ludi/ois a)pu/wn e)n au)loi=s: The Lydian flute melody was used in supplications. On e)n, see O. 7.12: pamfw/noisi ... e)n e)/ntesin au)lw=n.

div3.head: Antistrophe 3
div3.p: eu)anori/aisi: “With hosts of noble men.”
*)olumpio/nike: The victor is apostrophized, as often, at the close of the poem.
*poseidani/aisin i(/ppois: Cf. O. 1.77; 8, 49.
eu)/qumon: P.'s usage would lead us to combine eu)/qumon with teleuta/n, but this is an exceptional poem, and we may follow the Schol., who combines it with gh=ras. See O. 1.37; P. 8.88.

div3.head: Epode 3
div3.p: paristame/nwn: Cf. Od. 12. 43: tw=| d' ou)/ ti gunh\ kai\ nh/pia te/kna | oi)/kade nosth/santi pari/statai ou)de\
ga/nuntai. — u(gi/enta = u(gia=. Proleptic.

e)carke/wn: Cf. N. 1.31: ou)k e)/ramai polu\n e)n mega/rw| plou=ton katakru/yais e)/xein a)ll' e)o/ntwn eu)= te paqei=n kai\ a)kou=sai fi/lois e)carke/wn. That prosperity is sound which streams in and out, helping others and gaining good report. Whoso hath this, and Psaumis hath it, let him not seek to become a god.
mh\ mateu/sh| qeo\s gene/sqai: So I. 4 (5), 14: mh\ ma/teue *zeu\s gene/sqai. An abrupt end, like O. 3.

div2.p: Agesias, son of Sostratos, was a Syracusan of the noble family of the Iamidai, descendants of Iamos, son of Apollo. The Iamidai were hereditary prophets among the Dorians, hereditary diviners at the great altar of Zeus in Olympia. Early settlers of Italy and Sicily, they retained their connection with Arkadia. Our Agesias, a citizen of Syracuse, was also a citizen of Stymphalos. As a Syracusan he was an active partisan of Hieron, and after the fall of the tyrannis was put to death by the Syracusans.

The composition of the ode cannot be earlier than Ol. 76, 1 (476 B.C.), nor later than Ol. 78, 1 (468 B.C.), the earliest and the latest Olympian celebrations that fall within the reign of Hieron. Ol. 77 (472 B.C.) is excluded, because Pindar was at that time in Sicily, and the poem was composed in Greece. Ol. 78, 1 is the date to which the ode is assigned by Böckh. *zeu\s *ai)tnai=os (v. 96) would seem more appropriate after the founding of Aitna (Ol. 76). The arguments advanced by Leop. Schmidt in support of the same date, such as the character of vv. 58-63, which he regards as a feeble reflection of O. 1.71-85, and the confidential tone in which Hieron is spoken of at the close, do not seem to be cogent.

The ode was probably sung at Stymphalos and repeated at Syracuse. One Aineas brought the poem from Thebes to Stymphalos, and directed the performance. We do not know whether he was an assistant of Pindar's or a local poet of the Iamid stock.

The verses to which one always comes back in thinking over this poem are these (100, 101): a)gaqai\ de\ pe/lont' e)n xeimeri/a| | nukti\ qoa=s e)k nao\s a)peski/mfqai du/' a)/gkurai. In the second Olympian we have noticed a recurrent three; here there is clearly a recurrent two. Agesias, the hero of the poem, unites in his person
Syracusan and Stymphalian. At Olympia he is victor in the games and steward of an oracle (vv. 4, 5). At Syracuse he is sunoikisth/s of the city and beloved of the citizens (vv. 6, 7). He is prince and prophet, as Amphiaraos (v. 13) was warrior and prophet, and his victory must be celebrated at Pitana (v. 28), as it must be celebrated at Syracuse (v. 99). His charioteer, Phintis (v. 22), must speed to the banks of the Eurotas, and Pindar's leader, Aineas (v. 88), must conduct the festal song. Agesias's maternal stock was Arkadian; from thence came his prophetic blood — from Euadne, daughter of Poseidon (v. 29), a prophetic god; from Iamos (v. 43), whom Euadne bore to Apollo, a prophetic god.

The myth of Iamos (vv. 29-70) shows the value of this double help — the result, a double treasure of prophecy. Prosperity and fame attend the Iamidai. Herakles helped Iamos at Olympia (v. 68); Hermes the Iamidai in Arkadia (v. 79). Thebes and Stymphalos are akin (v. 86), as Herakles, Boeotian hero, and Hermes, Arkadian god, unite to bless the Iamidai. So the song must praise Hera (v. 88), for Arkadia was the home of her virginity, and vindicate Boeotia, home of Herakles (v. 90); must remember Syracuse, and wish the victor a happy reception in one home as he comes from another home — as he comes from Arkadia to Syracuse (v. 99). He has two homes in joy — two anchors in storm. God bless this and that (tw=nde kei/nwn te kluta\n ai)=san pare/xoi file/wn, v. 102). Nor is the mention of the two anchors idle. May Amphitrite's lord speed Agesias's ship, and prosper the poet's song (v. 104).

This is one of the most magnificent of Pindar's poems, full of color, if not so dazzling as the seventh Olympian. The myth of Iamos, the ma/ntis ancestor of a ma/ntis, is beautifully told. Profound moral there is none to me discernible. “He that hath gods on either side of his ancestry shall have the gods to right and left, of him for aye,” shows an aristocratic belief in blood (ou)de/ pot' e)klei/yein genea/n, v. 51).

There is such a ganglion of personal and tribal relations involved in this piece that one is tempted to long historical and antiquarian disquisitions; but if we accept Pindar's statement as to the connection between Thebes and Arkadia, nothing more is necessary to the enjoyment of the ode.
The rhythm is Doric (dactylo-epitrite).

Of the five triads, the first contains a glorification of the victor, who is compared to Amphiaraos, also a prince and a prophet; the second takes us to Arkadia, and begins the story of Iamos, which is continued in the third and the fourth. The latter half of the fourth prepares the return to Syracuse, which forms the conclusion of the poem.

div3.head: Strophe 1
div3.p: xruse/as: “Golden” for “gilded.”
u(posta/santes: O. 8.26: u(pe/stase ... ki/ona daimoni/an.
qala/mou: “House,” as O. 5.13.

w(s o(/te: Without a verb, as P. 11.40; N. 9.16; I. 5 (6), 1. With w(s o(/te the verb is in the ind., and not in the Homeric subj. (N. 8.40); therefore supply pa/gnumen, if anything. The ellipsis was hardly felt.
pa/comen: On the mood, see O. 2.2.

a)rxome/nou d' e)/rgou, kte(.: A favorite quotation in modern as in ancient times. The genitive absolute, though not “pawing to get free,” is not used with perfect freedom in P. Hence a). e)/. is felt to depend on pro/swpon.
ei) d' ei)/h, kte(.: The ideal conditional (O. 1.108) of a fair dream, too fair to come to pass, and yet it has come to pass. ei)/h has no subject, no tis, as might be expected. So N. 9.46.
me\n ... te: See O. 4.13.

bwmw=| ... mantei/w| tami/as: The dative often varies with the genitive so as to produce a chiastic or cross-wise stress, thus emphasizing each element alternately. Here the stress is on tami/as, while in sunoikisth ta=n kleina=n *surakossa=n it is on *surakossa=n. Compare Hdt. 7, 5: h)=n *ce/rch| me
 a)n eyio/s, *darei/ou d e\ a)delfeh=s pai=s . Cf. Isai. 3, 13: e(tai/ra h)=n tw=| boulome/nw| kai\ ou) gunh\ tou= h(mete/rou qei/ou . Cf. Ar. Ach. 219, 220:
nu=n d' e)peidh\ sterro
 h)/dh tou)mo
 a)ntiknh/mion
kai\ palaiw=| *lakrati/dh| to\ ske/los baru/netai.
mantei/w| = mantikw=|.
tami/as = dioikhth/s (Schol.). The Iamidai had the right of divining by fire.
sunoikisth/r: Of course only by hereditary right.

e)piku/rsais: Not with e)n i(mertai=s a)oidai=s, but with a)fqo/nwn a)stw=n. Cf. v. 74. Citizens are apt to show envy in such circumstances. Those who count three columns in the pro/quron forget Pindar's implicit way. There are four. A. is an Olympian victor, a tami/as *dio/s, a sunoikisth/r of Syracuse, and beloved of his people. The outside columns are personal, the inside are hereditary.
a)stw=n: Both Stymphalians and Syracusans.

div3.head: Antistrophe 1
div3.p: i)/stw ... e)/xwn: N. 9.45: i)/stw laxw/n.
pedi/lw|: O. 3.5.

daimo/nion po/d' e)/xwn: Cf. Aisch. Ag. 907: to\n so\n po/d', w)=nac, *)ili/ou porqh/tora .
The Greeks drew largely on foot and footgear for their imagery, and yet Aristoph. laughs at xro/nou po/da (Ran. 100). d., “blessed of heaven.”
*swstra/tou ui(o/s: Effective suspense.
a)ki/ndunoi ... a)r.: On the risk of the chariotrace, see So. El. 745 sqq.; also O. 5.16; P. 5.49, and Introd. to P. 6.
par' a)ndra/sin: “On land.” Hymn. Apoll. 142: nh/sous te kai\ a)ne/ras. N. 5.9: *ai)/ginan, ta/n pot' eu)/andro/n te kai\ nausikluta\n qe/ssanto.

ei)/ ti ponaqh=|: The position throws this clause up in opposition to a)ki/ndunoi. The generic conditional in P. takes the pres. indic. (rarely pres. subj.) or the aor. subj.: e)a/n (h)/n, ei)/ ke) does not occur. For the thought, see O. 11 (10), 4.
*)aghsi/a, ti\n de/: Cf. O. 1.36. ti/n = soi/.
e(toi=mos: Cf. P. 6.7: e(toi=mos u(/mnwn qhsauro/s.
a)po\ glw/ssas: He flung it off — “roundly,” “freely.”
*)/adrastos: Leader of the Argive host that came to help Polyneikes to his rights, P. 8.51, and elsewhere.

*)amfia/rhon: Amphiaraos, noblest of the seven against Thebes. N. 9.24: o( d' *)amfia/rh| sxi/ssen keraunw=| pambi/a| | *zeu\s ta\n baqu/sternon xqo/na, kru/yen d' a(/m' i(/ppois. N. 10.8: gai=a d' e)n *qh/bais u(pe/dekto keraunwqei=sa *dio\s be/lesin.
kata/: With e)/maryen.
faidi/mas i(/ppous: White, acc. to Philostr. Imagg. 1, 27. On the gender, see P. 2.8.

div3.head: Epode 1
div3.p:
e(pta\ ... telesqe/ntwn: The MS. telesqe/ntwn is understood now as “consumed,” now as “composed” in the sense of Lat. compositus. “The corpses of seven pyres,” one pyre for each contingent, not for each leader, as Adrastos escaped death, Amphiaraos disappeared, Polyneikes was buried by his sister. Of the many conjectures, van Herwerden's te daisqe/ntwn is the most convincing. Cf. N. 9.25: e(pta\ ga\r dai/santo purai\ neogui/ous fw=tas, and Eur. Herakl. 914: puro\s flogi\ sw=ma daisqei/s.
e)desqe/ntwn is one of Bergk's experiments. Christ's text has e)tasqe/ntwn. The Scholiasts seem to have had before them te lexqe/ntwn (so says Moriz Schmidt also), which they understand now as “counted” (katariqmhqe/ntwn), cf. Il. 3. 188: meta\ toi=sin e)le/xqhn — now as sullexqe/ntwn = sullege/ntwn — cf. Ar. Lys. 526; Plat. Legg. 6, 784 A. The former is the more likely. Bergk: te nhsqe/ntwn, from ne/w, “pile up.”
*talai+oni/das: Mouth-filling patronymic for *talai+/das (Adrastos). Compare u(perioni/dhs for u(peri/w|n (Od. 12. 176), *)iapetioni/dhs for *)iapeti/dhs (Hesiod, O. et D. 54).
o)fqalmo/n: O. 2.11.
a)mfo/teron: A clear Homeric reminiscence. Cf. Il. 3. 179: a)mfo/teron basileu/s t' a)gaqo\s kratero/s t' ai)xmhth/s.
a)ndri\ kw/mou despo/ta| ... *surakosi/w|: The Schol. combines a). *s. and k. d., and this must stand despite the affinity of a)ndri\ for despo/ta|.

filo/neikos: Bergk writes filo/nikos from ni/kh, as he thinks with Cobet, N. L. 691, that nei=kos would require filoneikh/s. The passage is referred to by Isokr. 1, 31: o(milhtiko\s d' e)/sei mh\ du/seris w)\n mhde\ dusa/restos mhde\ pro\s pa/ntas filo/nikos (so the Urbinas).
me/gan o(/rkon o)mo/ssais: P. is a challenging herald. O. 2.101: au)da/somai e)no/rkion lo/gon a)laqei= no/w|.
meli/fqoggoi: So I. 2, 7: melifqo/ggou *teryixo/ras.
e)pitre/yonti = sumfwnh/sousin (Gloss), “will approve,” “shall not say me nay” (E. Myers).

div3.head: Strophe 2
div3.p: *fi/ntis = *fi/ltis. A Sicilian-Doric name. Compare Phintias in the story of Damon and Phintias (falsely Pythias).
a)lla/: With imper., as O. 1.17 and often.
zeu=con: P. harnesses his poetic chariot only on grand occasions. O. 9.87; P. 10.65; I. 2, 2; 7 (8), 62.
h)/dh: “Straight.”

sqe/nos h(mio/nwn: Compare P. 2.12: sqe/nos i(/ppeion. sq. is not limited by P. to animals, Fr. II. 1, 4: sqe/nos *(hrakle/os. Homer has Il. 13. 248: s. *)idomenh=os, and 18, 486: sqe/nos *)wri/wnos. Plato says in sport of Thrasymachos, Phaidr. 267 C.: to\ tou= *xalkhdoni/ou sqe/nos.
a(=| ta/xos = w(s ta/xos.
o)/fra: P.'s favorite final particle.

keleu/qw| e)n kaqara=|: For the path of poesy see N. 6.52: pro/sodoi, 62: o(do\n a(macito/n, I. 2, 33: ou)de\ prosa/nths a( ke/leuqos gi/netai, I. 3 (4), 19: muri/a pa/nta| ke/leuqos. kaq. “illumined.”
ba/somen: o)/fra, as a relative, may take the fut. (Il. 16. 243; Od. 4. 163; 17, 6), and P. has P. 11.9: o)/fra ... keladh/sete, but the “short” subj. is more likely. See O. 1.7.
kai\ ge/nos: k., “actually,” “at last,” shows impatience, like h)/dh.
e)c a)lla=n: “Above (all) others.” e)c as Il. 18. 431: e)moi\ e)k pase/wn *kroni/dhs *zeu\s a)/lge' e)/qhken. a)lla=n Dor. fem. pl. = a)/llwn (h(mio/nwn).
stefa/nous: The chariot was wreathed as well as the victor.
pro\s *pita/nan: The nymph of the town in Laconia — not the town itself.

div3.head: Antistrophe 2
div3.p: a(/: The myth is often introduced by a relative or equivalent demonstrative, O. 1.25; 3, 13; 8, 31.
mixqei=sa: P. much prefers the first aor. p. of this verb to the second.
*kroni/w|: See O. 2.13.
vio/plokon: “Black - tressed.” So Bergk for i)oplo/kamon (unmetrical) of the best MSS. Cf. P. 1.1: vioploka/mwn | *moisa=n. Allusion to the *)i a mi/dai.
parqeni/an w)di=na: “Fruit of unwedded love.”

ko/lpois: “With the folds of her robe.” References to change of belting, in the circumstances,
are common enough in all literature.
kuri/w| e)n mhni/: The decisive month.
pe/mpoisa: See O. 2.23.
a)mfipo/lous: As a). is uniformly fem. in Homer, it may be considered fem. here.
porsai/nein do/men: So P. 3.45: po/re *kentau/rw| dida/cai, and P. 4.115: tra/fein *xei/rwni dw=kan.
*ei)lati/da|: This son of Elatos was Aipytos, v. 36.
*faisa/na|: In southern Arkadia, on the upper Alpheios.
oi)kei=n: Epexegetic inf.
u(p' *)apo/llwni: Compare N. 1.68: bele/wn u(po\ r(ipai=si, Fr. X. 3, 3: u(po\ zeu/glais a)fu/ktois, and esp. I. 7, 45: lu/oi ken xalino\n u(f' h(/rwi+ parqeni/as.

div3.head: Epode 2
div3.p: ou)d' e)/laqe ... kle/ptoisa: The aor. e)/laqe would more naturally take the aor. part., but the neg. is killed by the neg. (ou)k e)/laqen = fanera\ h)=n). Cf. Il. 17. 676. kl., “hiding.”
o)cei/a| mele/ta|: As with a bit (o)cute/rw| xalinw=|, Soph.).
per': Allowed in P. for peri/.
foiniko/krokon: The passage is characteristically full of color. f., “crimson.”
kataqhkame/na: P. gives in detail for the daughter what he had only hinted at for the mother.
ka/lpida: As in Od. 7. 20: parqenikh=| e)ikui=a neh/nidi ka/lpin e)xou/sh|.
lo/xmas u(po\ kuane/as: The genitive with the notion of overarching. Mommsen reads with A lo/xmais u(po\ kuane/ais. For genitive, compare O. 2.91; 13, 111. For lo/xma, P. 4.244: kei=to ga\r lo/xma|.
kuane/as: The colors are contrasted, dark blue with yellow, cold with warm.
ti/kte = te/cesqai e)/melle. The imperf. of this verb is in very common use. Sometimes “she was (a) mother” (v. 85), sometimes “she had to bear.”
qeo/frona: Fit word for a future prophet, “upon whom was the spirit of God.”
*xrusoko/mas: O. 7.32. Compare P. 2.16: xrusoxai=ta.
*)elei/quian: Cf. N. 7.1: *)elei/quia pa/redre *moira=n baqufro/nwn. O. 1.26, *klwqw/ is the pa/redros of *)elei/quia.
*moi/ras: P. speaks of *klwqw\ kasignh/tas te, I. 5 (6), 17, and mentions *la/xesis at the la/xos of Rhodes (O. 7.64), but nowhere calls *)/atropos by name.

div3.head: Strophe 3
div3.p: w)di=nos ... e)rata=s: An oxymoron, like “sweet sorrow.” Compare N. 1.36: spla/gxnwn u(/po mate/ros au)ti/ka qahta\n e)s ai)/glan pai=s *dio\s | w)di=na feu/gwn didu/mw| su\n kasignh/tw| mo/len.
au)ti/ka: Effective position. The favorites of the gods are sped in childbirth.
knizome/na: On the savagery of the primipara, see Plat. Theaitet. 151 C: mh\ a)gri/aine w(/sper ai( prwtoto/koi peri\ ta\ paidi/a . Fennell, “though sore distressed.”
lei=pe: The imperf. denotes reluctance, “had to leave,” “felt that she had to leave.”

du/o ... dra/kontes: Two also in Eur. Ion, 23. The serpent
is notoriously mantic and Apollinic, and occurs everywhere in the history of Greek religion. The dra/kontes are children of Gaia. Notice the rarity of dual nouns in P.
glaukw=pes: P. 4.249: glaukw=pa poikilo/nwton o)/fin. The basilisk eye is proverbial.
e)qre/yanto: The affectionate middle, P. 9.20. 95.

a)memfei= | i)w=|: An oxymoron contrast to the natural i)o/s of the dra/kontes. The honey, which is also mantic, was a miraculous exudation of the serpent's fangs, and so melissa=n is = melissai/w|. i)w=| is another play on *)iami/dai.
kado/menoi: As if they were human.
petrae/ssas ... *puqw=nos: So. O.R. 463: a( qespie/peia *delfi\s pe/tra.
e)lau/nwn: “Hasting.”

to
 ... te/koi: The opt. for the ind. in Homer is virtually confined to the interrogative sentence. This Pindaric experiment with the relative is due to the interrogative character of ei)/reto, and has few parallels in classic Greek. So. O.R. 1245:
kalei= to
 *la/ion
mnh/mhn palaiw=n sperma/twn e)/xous' u(f' w(=n
qa/noi me
 au)to/s, th
 de\ ti/ktousan li/poi . The examples mainly in Herodotos.
gega/kein: A Doric perfect, such as we find most frequently in the Sicilian dialect. teteleutakou/sas occurs in a Delphic inscription (Curtius).

div3.head: Antistrophe 3
div3.p: peri\ qnatw=n: As in Od. 1. 66: o(\s peri\ me\n no/on e)sti\ brotw=n, peri\ d' i(ra\ qeoi=sin | a)qana/toisin e)/dwke. Bergk reads pe/ri with most of the codices.
ma/nue: Specialized in prose. Here of prophetic revelations.
eu)/xonto: “Vowed,” “declared.”
a)lla\ ... ga/r: “But (in vain) for.” See O. 1.55.
sxoi/nw|: So Odysseus, Od. 5. 463: sxoi/nw| u(pekli/nqh.

a)peira/tw|: Bergk writes a)peiri/tw| (as Od. 10. 195), “limitless.” The quantity a)peira^/tw|, “unexplored,” is, to say the least, very problematic (a)pei/rhtos, Hom.), but a)pei/ra^tos might be to pei=ras as pe/ratos is to pe/ras. “Boundless brake.”

i)/wn: The colors assigned to the violet here seem to show that the pansy is meant(viola tricolor), the yellow eye of the violet being too small for the prominence of canqai=si. i)/on means also “gillyflower.”
pamporfu/rois: “Deep purple.”
bebregme/nos: “Steeped.”
to/: “Therefore.”
sw=ma: In Homer only of the dead body.
katefa/micen: She dedicated him to be called. Her calling was a dedication; the nomen was an omen, as often.
xro/nw| su/mpanti: “For all time,” where e)s pa/nta xro/non would be coarser, and e)n panti\ xro/nw| would make us lose the intent.

div3.head: Epode 3
div3.p: tou=t' o)/numa: Iamos

xrusostefa/noio ... *(/hbas:
So P. 9.118: xrusostefa/nou de/ voi *(/hbas | karpo\n a)nqh/sant' a)podre/yai | e)/qelon. A consecrated epithet, Hes. Theog. 17: *(/hbhn te xrusoste/fanon kalh/n te *diw/nhn.
*)alfew=| me/ssw|: Dat. of approach. The god of the sea is also god of the river. Besides, Alpheios runs straight to the main. “Mid-Alpheios” (Schol.). Others, “into the middle of the Alpheios.”
eu)rubi/an: P. 2.12.
pro/gonon: v. 29.
skopo/n: Compare P. 3.27: ou)d' e)/laqe skopo/n.
qeodma/tas: Here in its full sense. See O. 3.7.
laotro/fon tima/n: The honor of a poimh\n law=n.
e(a=| kefala=|: Cf. O. 7.67: e(a=| kefala=| ... ge/ras.
nukto\s u(pai/qrios: Compare the scene, O. 1.71.
a)rtieph/s: “Clear speaking.” So I. 4 (5), 46. Compare a)rti/pous, a)rti/stomos. Not *loci/as, the riddlesome, this time.
meta/llasen: The voice sought him in the dark and (when it found him) said. The commentators have made much difficulty about the highly poetical expression.
pa/gkoinon e)s xw/ran: Compare O. 3.17: *dio\s ai)/tei pando/kw| a)/lsei. p., a prophecy rather than a prolepsis in the usual sense of that word.
fa/mas o)/pisqen: “In the track of my voice.”

div3.head: Strophe 4
div3.p: a)li/baton: An Homeric word (h)li/batos) of uncertain meaning. “Steep” might answer here, “brambly” (Goebel) would not. eu)dei/elon *kro/nion (O. 1.111) does not help us.
to/ka = to/te.
qrasuma/xanos: Cf. N. 4.62: qrasumaxa/nwn te leo/ntwn, which shows the survival of the etymological meaning of mhxanh/, “might,” “power.”
qa/los: So O. 2.49: *)adrastida=n qa/los a)rwgo\n do/mois.
*)alkai+da=n: From *)alkai=os, the father of Amphitryon. We are more familiar with the form Alcides, *)alkei/dhs.

e)p' a)krota/tw| bwmw=|: The altar was built of the ashes of the sacrifices, and consisted of two parts; on the upper and lesser the thighs of the victims were burned, and the divination performed, Paus. 5, 13, 9.
to/t' au)=: The contrast to to/ka me/n is put characteristically at the end, not at the beginning of the de/ clause.
ke/leusen: A shift of construction, instead of leaving qe/sqai in apposition with qhsauro/n.

div3.head: Antistrophe 4
div3.p: e)c ou(=: “Since when,” not a part of the promise. Supply e)sti/ as usual, “has been and is.” Some have no stop at *)iamida=n, and make ge/nos depend on e(/speto, a rare accusative, on the strength of N. 10.37.
timw=ntes: “Prizing.”
e)s fanera\n o(do/n: Compare v. 23: keleu/qw| ... kaqara=|, and contrast the picture of home-sneaking youths, P. 8.87: kata\ lau/ras d' e)xqrw=n a)pa/oroi ptw/ssonti.
xrh=m' e(/kaston: Each action is a proof (thereof). So xrh=m' e(/kaston, of achievements, O. 9.112. Others: Action proveth each man.
mw=mos: Cf. fr. XI. 42: poti\ mw=mon e)/painos ki/rnatai. Blame and praise are inseparable.
e)c: Of the source.
kre/matai = e)pikre/matai (Schol.).
peri\ dwde/katon dre/mon: See O. 3.33.

potista/ch| ... morfa/n: Victory transfigures. So the Schol.: oi( nikw=ntes dokou=sin eu)eidei=s ei)=nai. No one who has seen can forget the light of battle even on vulgar faces, and everybody notices the beauty of homely brides. As Iamos is steeped in violet light (v. 55), so Agesias has beauty distilled upon him. potista/ch| with Bergk for potista/zei. For the generic subj. (without a)/n), see O. 3.13: w(=| tini ... ba/lh|.
u(po\ *kulla/nas o)/rous: So Christ, after the Schol., for o(/rois. The genitive in O. 13.111: tai/ q' u(p' *ai)/tnas u(yilo/fou kalli/ploutoi po/lies.
ma/trwes a)/ndres: The double lineage is insisted on. The maternal stock is one of the two anchors, v. 100.

div3.head: Epode 4
div3.p: e)dw/rhsan: The aor. act. occurs also Hes. O. et D. 82.

qew=n ka/ruka: Hermes is often Cyllenius.
Od. 24, 1: *(ermh=s de\ yuxa\s *kullh/nios e)cekalei=to.
litai=s = litaneutikai=s (Schol.). “Supplicatory.” Compare P. 4.217.
a)gw=nas e)/xei moi=ra/n t' a)e/qlwn: On e)nagw/nios *(erma=s see P. 2.10; for a)e/qlwn ... moi=ra, I. 3 (4), 10.
eu)a/nora: Applied to the Peloponnesos, O. 1.24; to the Lokrians, O. 10 (11), 109; to Argos, N. 10.36; to the sturdy Acharnians, N. 2.17.

do/can ... pnoai+s: One of the harshest combinations in P., at least to our feeling, but the tongue is freely handled in Greek. It is a bow, I. 4 (5), 47: glw=ssa/ moi toceu/mat' e)/xei. It is a dart, N. 7.71: a)/konq' w(=te xalkopa/ra|on (compare the use of glwxi/n, So. Tr. 681). Being a dart, it can be hammered, P. 1.86: xa/lkeue glw=ssan, or sharpened, as here. The trainer is a *naci/a a)ko/na, I. 5 (6), 73, and the poet's tongue is to be edged as the spirit of athletes is edged, O. 10 (11), 22. The word ligura=s is not used in a bad sense; the Greeks liked piercing sounds, and kalliro/oisi pnoai=s shows that in this case, at any rate, the sound of the whetstone was the voice of the Muses. The shrill whetstone that P. feels on his tongue accosts him with sweet breathings, and with a welcome message.
glw/ssa|: We want the dative and accept the hiatus, as O. 3.30: *)orqwsi/a| e)/grayen.

prose/rpei: So with Mommsen and the best MSS. The inferior MSS. have prose/lkei, “draws to,” with e)qe/lonta as an oxymoron, “which to harmonious breath constraineth me nothing
loth” (Myers). We should expect rather some such word as prosei/lei (proseilei=), “forces.”
kalliro/oisi pnoai=s: If prose/lkei is read, k. p. is the dat. of approach.
matroma/twr e)ma\, kte(.: Metope, daughter of Ladon, and nymph of a body of water near Stymphalos, was the mother of Thebe by Asopos.

div3.head: Strophe 5
div3.p: pla/cippon *qh/ban: Hes. Scut. 24: *boiwtoi\ plh/cippoi.
e)/tikten: See v. 41. P. 9.18: o(/n pote ... *krei/ois' e)/tikten.
e)rateino\n u(/dwr: Much stress is laid everywhere on the waters of Thebes. Compare P. 9.94: kwfo\s a)nh/r tis, o(\s ... mhde\ *dirkai/wn u(da/twn a)e\ me/mnatai.
pi/omai: A pres. form used everywhere as a fut. except here, where Curtius (Gr. Verb. II^{1}. 290) considers it to have a pres. force.

*ai)ne/a: Aineas was P.'s xorodida/skalos, and was to him what Phintis was to Agesias. It is supposed that Aineas was a Stymphalian relative of Agesias, and a local poet — the proper man for the performance of an ode intended to be sung at Stymphalos. The task *(/hran *parqeni/an keladh=sai was to be the work of Aineas himself, to be followed by P.'s ode, which Aineas was to produce, and to find out by its effect whether P. was open to the old sneer against Boeotians. Aineas is a man whom he can trust with the execution of a commission which should silence the cavillers in Stymphalos.
*(/hran *parqeni/an: A Stymphalian goddess. Hera had three temples there, and three names, pai=s (parqe/nos), telei/a, xh/ra, Paus. 8, 22, 2.

a)rxai=on o)/neidos ... *boiwti/an u(=n: Compare fr. IV. 9: h)=n o(/te su/as to\ *boiw/tion e)/qnos e)/nepon. The *(/uantes were old inhabitants of Boeotia. The moral character of the swine was not exactly the same among the Greeks as it is among us and the Semites. Compare Phokyl. 3, 5: h( de\ suo\s blosurh=s ou)/t' a)\n kakh\ ou)de\ me\n e)sqlh/.
a)laqe/sin | lo/gois = tai=s a)lhqei/ais: “In very truth” (after an honest calculation).
feu/gomen = perf.
a)/ggelos o)rqo/s: Of the words. He is faithful.
h)uko/mwn skuta/la *moisa=n: Of the musical and orchestic part. He is retentive.
gluku\s krath/r: Shifting of the metaphor. He adds a charm of his own. See Introductory Essay, p. xli.

div3.head: Antistrophe 5
div3.p: ei)po/n: So the best editors with Ailios Dionysios.
*)ortugi/as: Sacred to Artemis, an Arkadian goddess.
foiniko/pezan: So called with reference to the color of the ripening grain

*da/matra: Hieron was an hereditary priest of Demeter and Persephone, who belonged to the Triopian deities, as did Apollo
(Hdt. 1, 144), and Demeter and Persephone were much worshipped in Arkadia.
leuki/ppou: So, especially, when she returns in the spring.
*zhno\s *ai)tnai/ou: Cf. N. 1.6: *zhno\s *ai)tnai/ou xa/rin. Aitna was an especial pet of Hieron, who is called *ai)tnai=os in the title of P. 1, *ai)tnai=os ce/nos P. 3.69.
lu/rai molpai/ te: P. composed in his honor three Pythians, one Olympian, and fragments of a skolion and a hyporchema remain.
ginw/skonti: So O. 7.83: o( e)n *)/argei xalko\s e)/gnw nin.

qra/ssoi = tara/ssoi: So for qrau/soi, with the Schol., Böckh. The fut. opt. cannot be defended. Bergk cites So. O.R. 1274, where o)yoi/aq' ou) gnwsoi/ato are in oratio obliqua, and represent fut. ind. We should have to read qrau/sai with Hermann, or qrau/oi with van Herwerden.

div3.head: Epode 5
div3.p: oi)/koqen oi)/kad': With a sweet security of transfer (compare Aus Gottes Hand in Gottes Hand). So also O. 7.3: dwrh/setai ... oi)/koqen oi)/kade, and, for the opposite, see O. 3.44.
mate/r' *)arkadi/as: Stymphalos. Cf. O. 9.22: kluta\n *lokrw=n e)paei/ronti mate/r' a)glao/dendron. The metropolis is not necessarily the oldest town.
eu)mh/loio: Heyne reads eu)ma/loio. See O. 1.12.
du/' a)/gkurai: On either side of the prow (Paley). Starboard and port, not fore and aft. Proverbial. The two homes, with the double line of descent.
tw=nde: Stymphalians.
kei/nwn te: Syracusans.
de/spota ponto/medon: Return to Poseldon, suggested by the ship. With ponto/medo_n, compare P. 3.6.
eu)qu\n de/: On de/ after the voc., see O. 1.36.
di/doi = di/dou.
xrusalaka/toio: “Gold-distaff” is a poetic way of sexing the sea (Böckh).
*)amfitri/tas: Amphitrite has, as her special province, the waves (Od. 3. 91) and the great fishes, kh/tea, Od. 5. 422, and 12, 97.
u(/mnwn ... a)/nqos: Cf. O. 9.52: a)/nqea d' u(/mnwn | newte/rwn.

div2.p: Diagoras of Rhodes, most famous of Greek boxers, won the victory here celebrated Ol. 79, 1 (464 B.C.).
The poem was composed soon afterwards, as we may gather from v. 13: su\n *diago/ra| kate/ban, and was sung at Rhodes.

Diagoras was a Herakleid. In the third generation after Temenos a Doric colony went from Argos to Rhodes by way of Epidauros. The leaders were descendants of Tlepolemos, son of Herakles, and Pindar makes Tlepolemos himself the founder of the colony. The Herakleidai occupied three cities of Rhodes, and established a triple kingdom. Those who inhabited Ialysos were called Eratidai, and this was the stock of Diagoras, who also counted among his ancestors a son-in-law of the famous Messenian leader, Aristomenes. The royal power of the Eratidai ceased after Ol. 30, and in the time of Pindar prytaneis ruled instead; and it is supposed that the father of Diagoras, Damagētos, was such a prytanis. Of an illustrious family, Diagoras won for himself unparalleled distinction as a boxer. Besides being victorious at many local games, he was successful at all the national games, and so became a periodoni/khs. His sons emulated the head of the house. His youngest, Dorieus, had a career only less brilliant than that of his father. Damagētos won the pankration at Olympia, Akusilaos a boxing-match. The two sons of his daughters were also victors at Olympia, and one of his daughters enjoyed the exceptional privilege of being present at the Olympian games. The statue of Diagoras, surrounded by his three sons and two grandsons, the work of Kallikles of Megara, was erected at Olympia; and familiar is the story of the Spartan who, when he saw Diagoras borne on the shoulders of his two laurelled sons, exclaimed, “Die, Diagoras, for thou canst not mount to heaven” (Cic. Tusc. 1, 46, 111). It is not known whether Diagoras followed the advice or lived to see the downfall of his family. Rhodes belonged to the Delian league. Two years before the victory here celebrated the battles of Eurymedon
were fought (466), and Athens was at the height of her power. Enemies of aristocratic government, the Athenians favored the commons as against the Doric aristocracy of Rhodes. Diagoras's son, Dorieus, fled to Thurioi, but returned and fought against the Athenians in his own ships, was captured, but liberated. Again exiled, he went to the Peloponnesos, where he was arrested by the Spartans and executed. But these events befell many years after the date of the victory celebrated in this ode.

The good fortune of Diagoras was proverbial. The Morere, Diagora of Cicero's version of his story, cited above, is in the school-books. But if we had no evidence outside of this ode, we should know by Pindar's recital that his career was brilliant, as his home was brilliant — Rhodes, child of Aphrodite, bride of the sun (v. 14). No wonder that the golden beaker and the foaming wine are used to symbolize the song in honor of such a victor and such a home (v. 1, foll.). But there must be shade as well as light. Nemesis does not allow too much happiness, and in the history of the line of Diagoras, Pindar finds enough trouble for contrast, each trouble ending in higher joy. So, should the happiness of Diagoras ever be interrupted, there is good hope of more than recompense. Tlepolemos, founder of the house, slew the brother of Alkmena — passion had overmastered him (v. 27) — but Apollo sent him to Rhodes, where he received “sweet ransom for grievous disaster” (v. 77). The sons of Helios, lord of Rhodes, were bidden to raise an altar to Athena and sacrifice to the Great Sire and the Warrior-maid. Wise as they were, they forgot fire, and offered flameless sacrifices. Yet the gods forgave; Zeus sent them gold, Athena cunning craft (vv. 39-53). Helios himself, pure god, was absent at the partition of the earth; yet he received a boon that he himself preferred to all besides (vv. 54-76). In each of these three cases we have a good beginning followed by misfortune, and yet a good ending crowns all. Diagoras was fortunate. Both a)reta/ and xa/rmata were his (cf. v. 44), but he might one day forget; he trod a noble path, u(/brios e)xqra\n o(do/n (v. 90), but passion might overtake him; he was a prince among men as Helios was a prince among gods, but he might, in his absence, be forgotten; but should Nemesis have aught against Diagoras, he may yet hope to find, like Tlepolemos, like the sons of Helios, like Helios himself, lu/tron sumfora=s oi)ktra=s gluku/ (v. 77).
The winds shift (v. 95), but the divine helmsman steers the ship to its haven.

A remarkable feature of the myth is the reversal of the usual chronological order. We begin with Tlepolemos and end with the emergence of Rhodes. The climax is in the rank of those who have sinned, who have forgotten, who have been absent. Note that the fault is less the higher we mount. No wonder that an explanation has been sought of the triple shadow that falls across the poem. The Scholiast on v. 94 assumes that Diagoras had got into discredit by killing one of his opponents. But this must have been in some previous contest, for in such an event there would have been no victory, as is shown by the case of Kleomedes (Paus. 6, 9, 6). The shadow may come from the future, as has been assumed above, but there is danger of being a *promhqeu\s meta\ ta\ pra/gmata, and to Diagoras the words tou=to d' a)ma/xanon eu(rei=n, | o(/ ti nu=n e)n kai\ teleuta=| fe/rtaton a)ndri\ tuxei=n (v. 25) need not have been ominous. The changing breezes of the close may bring good as well as evil.
The rhythms are dactylo-epitrite.

Of the five triads, the first is occupied with the introduction; the second, third, and fourth unfold the fortunes of the house — Tlepolemos, the Heliadai, Helios himself. The last triad turns to Diagoras. The divisions are all clear-cut, the triads do not overlap — a rare thing in Pindar.

On the statement that this ode was preserved in the temple of Athena at Lindos in letters of gold, see Ch. Graux, Rev. de Phil. V. 117, who thinks that the offering was “a little roll (bibli/on, volumen) of parchment or fine leather, bearing on its inner surface the ode written in gold ink.”

div3.head: Strophe 1
div3.p: fia/lan: The father of the bride pledged the bridegroom in a beaker of wine and then presented him with the beaker, evidently a formula of espousal. See Athen. 13, 35, p. 575 D. The fia/lh was not a drinking-vessel in Homeric times.
a)fneia=s a)po\ xeiro/s: Combined with dwrh/setai. a)po/ has the connotation of “freely.” Compare a)po\ glw/ssas, O. 6.13.
e(lw/n. For “pleonastic” (Dissen) read “plastic.”
kaxla/zoisan: “Bubbling,” “foaming.”

dwrh/setai: P. has w(s ei) only here, w(s o(/te once with the ind. (N. 8.40). Homer has w(s ei) with subj.
once (Il. 9, 481), with ind. once (Il. 13. 492). dwrh/setai is the generic subj., and the shift from subj. to indic., qh=ke, may be compared to the shift with w(s d' o(/te in Homer (e. g., Il. 11. 414), in which “the most important point of the comparison is usually expressed by the subjunctive, while details and subordinate incidents are given in the ind.” (Monro after Delbrück). Still qh=ke produces the effect of an apodosis (compare N. 7.11: ei) de\ tu/xh| tis e)/rdwn, meli/fron' ai)ti/an r(oai=si *moisa=n e)ne/bale). It is not a mere picturesque addition, but forms an organic part of the comparison. However, as this use of de/ is not absolutely certain in P., in spite of nu=n de/ (O. 3.43), it may be well not to urge it here. The effect can be got at all the same. P. is nothing, if not implicit.
propi/nwn: propi/nein e)sti\ kuri/ws to\ a(/ma tw=| kra/mati to\ a)ggei=on xari/zesqai (Schol.).
oi)/koqen oi)/kade: From home to home and so binding home to home. See O. 6.99.
korufa/n: O. 1.13.

sumposi/ou te xa/rin: a)nti\ tou= tw=n e)n tw=| sumposi/w| (Schol.). “For the sake of them that sat at drink with him.” s. = oi( sumpi/nontes, as qe/atron = oi( qew/menoi. Others, “to grace the banquet.”
tima/sais: Coincident with dwrh/setai as an aorist subj. Compare P. 4.189.
e)\n de/: “Therein” = “thereby.”
qh=ke: So often in P., as O. 8.18: qh=ken *)olumpioni/kan, 13, 98: qh/sw fane/r' a)qro/a, P. 9.58: e)/nqa nin a)rxe/polin qh/seis.
zalwto\n o(mo/fronos eu)na=s: The present is a prelude and a pledge of an harmonious wedlock — a great boon now as then. eu)na=s, so-called genitive of the source of emotion.

div3.head: Antistrophe 1
div3.p: kai\ e)gw/ = ou(/tw kai\ e)gw/. Compare O. 10 (11), 94: w(=te ... kai/.
ne/ktar xuto/n: Persius, Prol. 14, Pegaseïum nectar. x., acc. to the Schol., denotes to\ au)to/maton kai\ a)/kraton, “liquid.”

*moisa=n do/sin: The Muses have given it a)fneia=s a)po\ xeiro/s. But the figure is not carried out, though it might have been. The fia/la would have represented the maestro di cappella. Compare O. 6.91, where Aineas is called gluku\s krath\r a)gafqe/gktwn a)oida=n.
a)ndra/sin ... nikw/ntessin: Class for individual. Diagoras had been successful at both places.

gluku
 karpo
 freno/s: Follows as an after-thought, like pa/gxruson korufa
 ktea/nwn above.

i(la/skomai = i(larou\s poiw= (Schol.), “I cheer them,” but the equipoise of the passage demands a graver sense, such as timw=, corresponding to tima/sais (v. 5), “pay homage.” If i(larou\s poiw= is not for i(la/ous (i(/lews) poiw=, the Scholiast manufactured the sense “cheer” on account of the superhuman sphere of i(la/skomai.

kate/xonti: See P. 1.96: e)xqra\ *fa/larin kate/xei panta=| fa/tis | ou)de/ nin fo/rmigges u(pwro/fiai koinwni/an | malqaka\n pai/dwn o)a/roisi de/kontai. Song is the earnest of abiding good report, as the cup is the pledge of harmonious wedlock; but Charis, the goddess of the epinikion, casts her eyes now on one and now on another.
e)popteu/ei: “Looks” (with favor). P. 3.85: lage/tan ga/r toi tu/rannon de/rketai.
cwqa/lmios: “That giveth life its bloom” (more fully expressed, O. 1.30: a(/per a(/panta teu/xei ta\ mei/lixa qnatoi=s). A similar formation is bioqa/lmios, Hymn. in Ven. 190.
qa/ma = a(/ma, whereas qama/ is qama/kis, “often” (Bergk). The assumption of this qa/ma has been vigorously opposed by J. K. Ingram in Hermathena, No. 3, 217-227.
fo/rmiggi: The regimen is suspended until e)n comes in with e)/ntesin. (But see note, O. 9.94). So the first negative of two or more may be omitted, P. 6.48.
pamfw/noisi: See P. 12.19: au)lw=n pa/mfwnon me/los, and 21: su\n e)/ntesi. For e)n of instruments, see O. 5.19; N. 11.17; I. 4, 27.

div3.head: Epode 1
div3.p: u(p' a)mfote/rwn: O. 4.2: u(po\ poikilofo/rmiggos a)oida=s.
kate/ban: Figuratively. So O. 9.89; *n. 10, 43. For the verb, see P. 3.73, which there also is used absolutely.

ta
 ponti/an: Depends on u(mne/wn. ta
 ponti/an is usu. combined with *(ro/don. As to the distance, see O. 12.5. Still it is better to take the words as they come — the daughter of the sea (ta
 ponti/an = ta
 po/ntou) — child of Aphrodite — bride of the sun. With ta
 ponti/an pai=d' *)afrodi/tas, compare w)= *kro/nie pai= *(re/as (O. 2.13).
par' *)alfeiw=|: So below para\ *kastali/a|. In prose this would be felt as personal, “in Alpheios's demesne,” “in Kastalia's home;” here not so much. See O. 1.20.

pugma=s a)/poina: The full acc. force is felt in a)/poina, which has to be revived for xa/rin, di/khn. The ai)=nos is the a)/poina, as the u(/mnos is the a)/poina, I. 3 (4), 7: eu)kle/wn d' e)/rgwn a)/poina xrh\ me\n u(mnh=sai to\n e)slo/n.
para\ *kastali/a|: So N. 11.24.
*dama/ghton: A prytanis, as Böckh infers from what follows.
a)do/nta: See O. 3.1. P.'s yi/lwsis of this word is neglected in some editions and lexicons. With the phrase compare I. 3 (4), 33: xalke/w| t' *)/arei va/don.
tri/polin: So Il. 2. 655: oi(\ *(ro/don a)mfene/monto dia\ tri/xa kosmhqe/ntes | *li/ndon, *)ihluso/n te kai\ a)rgino/enta *ka/meiron.
na=son: With an easy transition from the nymph to the island.
e)mbo/lw|: The “ship's beak” headland is *kuno\s sh=ma in Karia.
*)argei/a|: Rhodes was colonized from Argos.
ai)xma=| = ai)xmatai=s.

div3.head: Strophe 2
div3.p: e)qelh/sw ... diorqw=sai = e)qe/lwn diorqw/sw. P. uses the more prosaic bou/lomai only once.
toi=sin e)c a)rxa=s: Explained by a)po\ *tlapole/mou, and magnified by *(hrakle/os eu)rusqenei= ge/nna|.
cuno/n: “That touches the common stock.” Compare P. 9.101: to/ g' e)n cunw=| peponame/non, I. 1, 46: cuno\n o)rqw=sai kako/n, 5 (6), 69: cuno\n a)/stei ko/smon e(w=| prosa/gwn.
a)gge/llwn: Of public announcements. So P. 9.2: e)qe/lw ... a)gge/llwn ... gegwnei=n.
diorqw=sai = dielqei=n o)rqw=s.

e)k *dio/s: The line is:
Alektruon
Likumnios
Alkmene
Zeus
Herakles
Tlepolemos
Amuntor
Astudameia
e)k is omitted with the nearer in the line, *)astudamei/as. Acc. to Il. 2. 658, the mother was *)astuo/xeia, but in these far-away matters we must be satisfied with any feminine ending. Compare *)ifige/neia and *)ifia/nassa, *persefo/neia and *perse/fassa.
*)amuntori/dai: Amyntor, king of Armenion in Magnesia, overcome by Herakles.
a)mfi\ ... kre/mantai: Cf. I. 2, 43: fqonerai\ qnatw=n fre/nas a)mfikre/mantai velpi/des. There seems to be an allusion to lures or nets.

div3.head: Antistrophe 2
div3.p: nu=n e)n kai\ teleuta=|: For the trajection of kai/, which gives especial emphasis to the second member, compare O. 2.31; P. 10.58; N. 7.31.
tuxei=n: Epexegetic infinitive.

*liku/mnion ... *mide/as: L. was the son of Elektryon and his concubine Midea, and as Elektryon was the father of Alkmene, Tlepolemos killed his father's uncle. See table, and cf. Il. 2. 662: au)ti/ka patro\s e(oi=o fi/lon mh/trwa kate/kta | h)/dh ghra/skonta *liku/mnion o)/zon *)/arhos.
e)s qeo/n: e)s of motion to a person is rare in Pindar, O. 2.38 and 54. The person is the place.

div3.head: Epode 2
div3.p: *xrusoko/mas: O. 6.41.
eu)w/deos: Sweet odors rose every now and then from the opening covered by the tripod.
plo/on: Involves plei=n. ei)=pe plo/on = e)ke/leuse plei=n. Cf. P. 4.6: xrh=sen *ba/tton oi)kisth=ra = x. *b. oi)ki/sai.
a)mfiqa/lasson nomo/n: Oracles delight in circumlocution for the saving of their credit. So P. 9.59: o)/xqon e)s a)mfi/pedon.

*lernai/as: Dwellingplace of the hydra, forty stades from Argos, Strabo, 8, p. 368 and
371.
a(ni/x': Compare P. 4.48.
te/xnaisin: For the pl. compare O. 9.56; P. 3.11; 4, 249; 8, 60.
kat' a)/kran: We should expect e)c, but Athena makes her sire's head the stage of her first appearance. So N. 10.17: *(hrakle/os ou(= kat' *)/olumpon a)/loxos *(/hba ... e)/sti.

div3.head: Strophe 3
div3.p: fausi/mbrotos: Od. 10. 191: *)he/lios faesi/mbrotos.
*(uperioni/das: An overdone patronymic, like *talai+oni/das, *o. 6, 15.
xre/os: “Duty.” The service was the worship of Athena with burnt-offerings.

w(s a)/n = o(/pws a)/n, due to fula/casqai, which involves the “how” of an action. So even in prose. Cf. Dem. 6, 3 (with pareskeua/sqai), to say nothing of Xenophon, who has it often with e)pimelei=sqai (e. g. Cyr. 1, 2, 5). In Homer with a verb of will, Od. 17. 362: w)/trun' w(s a)\n pu/rna kata\ mnhsth=ras a)gei/roi.
e)gxeibro/mw|: Formed like e)gxeike/raunos, P. 4.194.
e)/balen: Gnomic.

*ai)dw/s: As a personification. Reverence is the daughter of Wisdom. If knowledge were wisdom, it would not be necessary to say “Let knowledge grow from more to more | Yet more of reverence in us dwell.” The reverence here is the respect to the xre/os. For the personification see P. 5.27: ta\n *)epimaqe/os ... o)yino/ou qugate/ra *pro/fasin.

div3.head: Antistrophe 3
div3.p: e)pi\ ma\n bai/nei ti: Surprise is shown by tmesis and ma/n, mystery by ti, which goes with ne/fos. ti: “A strange.”
a)te/kmarta: “Bafflingly” (Myers).
pare/lkei: The cloud of forgetfulness “sails over and makes nothing” of the right road, effaces it and so “trails it out of the mental vision.” The changes proposed ruin the highly poetical passage.
spe/rma ... flogo/s: Od. 5. 490: spe/rma puro/s.
a)ne/ban: To the acropolis of Lindos, where Athena was worshipped a)pu/rois i(eroi=s.
ou)/: The effect of the position is almost as if there were an interrogation point after flogo/s, and ou)/ were the answer. On the position of the negative in P., see O. 4.17.
o( me/n = *zeu/s.
canqa/n: The cloud takes its color from the gold that it contains.
xruso/n: The poem is full of gold, vv. 4, 32, 34, 50, 64.
u(=se: A metaphor turned into a myth. Compare Il. 2. 670: kai/ sfin (sc. *(rodi/ois) qespe/sion plou=ton kate/xeue *kroni/wn, and Chaucer's “It snewed in his hous of mete and drynke.”
te/xnan: Depends on w)/pase, and is felt over again with kratei=n. “Every art to excel” (therein). Rhodes was a centre of art from the earliest times.

div3.head: Epode 3
div3.p: kratei=n: Depends on w)/pase. kratei=n usu. absolute in P.: with the acc. “o'ermaster,” “surpass,” P. 4.245; *n. 5, 45; 10, 25: with the genitive only here.

zwoi=sin e(rpo/ntessi/ q' o(moi=a: “That looked as if they lived and moved.” The Greeks, like the Japanese, were fond of exaggeration about art and artists. So the Rhodians were fabled to have tied the feet of their statues to keep them from running away. Michael Angelo's “Cammina” is a stock story.
fe/ron: The statues were set up in the streets. There is no reference to moving along the roads, as Dissen thinks.

h)=n de\ kle/os baqu/: It was to this fame that Rhodes owed her prosperity. Pindar skilfully suppresses the loss incurred by the neglect of the Heliadai. Athena transferred her presence to Athens, but did not leave the Rhodians comfortless.

dae/nti ... tele/qei: “To the wise man (to him that knows), e'en surpassing art is no magic trick.” The mythical artisans of Rhodes, the Telchines, who came up out of the water with the island, were supposed to be wizards. All folk-lore is full of magicians of this kind, and the devil figures largely as a craftsman in mediaeval legends. All these miracles of art, says P., were wrought by a)ristopo/noi xei=res, and there is no trick in any of them. The refutation of this charge naturally brings up the story of the birth of Rhodes. There are other renderings. “The subtlety that is without deceit is the greater altogether,” that is, the Heliadai, who received their knowledge from Athena, were greater artists than the Telchines, who were magicians. Yet others refer dae/nti to the artisan and not to the judge. Bergk transl. in prudente homine etiam maior sapientia fraudis est expers.
fanti\ ... r(h/sies: pro\ *pinda/rou de\ tou=to ou)x i(sto/rhto (Schol.).

pela/gei ... ponti/w|: po/ntos is practically the deep sea: even according to Curtius's etymology deep water is the only true pa/tos or “path” for the mariner. pe/lagos, whatever its etymology, has often the effect of “expanse.” “In the wide sea,” “in the open main.”

div3.head: Strophe 4
div3.p: e)/ndeicen: e)ndeiknu/nai is the practical deiknu/nai, “then and there.”
a(gno\n qeo/n: Notice the after- thought position, which has the effect of a protest against the ill-treatment of Helios.
mnasqe/nti: Sc. *)aeli/w|.
a)/mpalon=a)na/palon. “A new cast.”

me/llen: As a verb of purpose, me/llw may take the aor. inf. as well as the present, which is far more common. As a verb of thinking it has the future inf., which is the
norm, though P. does not use it. See O. 8.32.
ei)=pe ... o(ra=n: Instead of the usual finite construction. Cf. O. 1.75.
au)come/nan pedo/qen: Allusion to the name *(ro/dos, the Island of the Rose. Hence also bla/ste (v. 69).
polu/boskon , kte(.: Clara Rhodos was famous for grain, and pasture also.

div3.head: Antistrophe 4
div3.p: xrusa/mpuka: “With golden frontlet.” Compare P. 3.89; I. 2, 1: xrusampu/kwn *moisa=n.
*la/xesin: Cf. v. 58. *l. only here. See O. 1.26.

qew=n o(/rkon me/gan: Cf. Hesiod, Theog. 400. The formula is given Il. 15. 36; Od. 5. 184; Hymn. in Apoll. 83: i)/stw nu=n to/de gai=a kai\ *ou)rano\s eu)ru\s u(/perqen | kai\ to\ kateibo/menon *stugo\s u(/dwr o(/ste me/gistos | o(/rkos deino/tato/s te pe/lei maka/ressi qeoi=si.
mh\ parfa/men: “Not to utter falsely,” “to take in vain.” So P. 9.47: parfa/men tou=ton lo/gon.
pemfqei=san = o(/tan pemfqh=|.
e(a=| kefala=|: Compare O. 6.60.
teleu/taqen: So for teleu/tasan, Bergk.
lo/gwn korufai/: Compare P. 3.80. The chief points of the compact were fulfilled, came true.
e)n a)laqei/a| petoi=sai: Coincident action with teleu/taqen, a more vivid expression for a)laqei=s geno/menai. Compare O. 12.10: para\ gnw/man e)/pesen (“fell out”).

div3.head: Epode 4
div3.p: o)ceia=n ... a)kti/nwn: O. 3.24: e)/docen gumno\s au)tw=| ka=pos o)cei/ais u(pakoue/men au)gai=s a)eli/ou.
sofw/tata: Mommsen transposes thus: e)/nqa sofw/tata mixqei\s | te/ken e(pta\ *(ro/dw| | pote\ noh/mat', with an unfortunate juxtaposition of sofw/tata and mixqei/s.
e(pta\ ... paidas: Favorite position.
paradecame/nous: From sire to son.
w(=n ei(=s: Kerkaphos. — *ka/miron: Schneidewin, with inscriptions, for *ka/meiron.
*)ia/luson: v (vial.) is suspected, but not proved.
dia\... dassa/menoi: Tmesis.
sfin “In their honor,” “by their names.”

div3.head: Strophe 5
div3.p: lu/tron = poinh/, a)/poina, “requital.” So I. 7 (8), 1: lu/tron ... kama/twn.
sumfora=s: Euphemism for the affair of v. 29.
i(/statai: Not historical present. The offering is still kept up (w(/sper qew=|). i(/. = gi/netai (Schol.), telei=tai.
mh/lwn te knisa/essa pompa/: It is forced to make m. depend on knisa/essa, as Mezger does, nor is it necessary to the sense. Compare bow=n canqa\s a)ge/las, P. 4.149.
kri/sis a)mf' a)e/qlois: N. 10.23: a)e/qlwn kri/sin. For a)mfi/ thus used, see O. 9.97.
a)/nqesi: The wreath was white poplar acc. to the Schol.
kleina=|: *)isqmo/s is fem., O. 8.49, and elsewhere.

a)/llan e)p' a)/lla|: The ellipsis of
ni/kan is not violent. “One upon another,” in immediate succession.

div3.head: Antistrophe 5
div3.p: xalko/s: The prize was a shield, for the fabrication of which arm the Argives were famous.
ta/ t' e)n *)arkadi/a| | e)/rga: The prizes in Arkadia were bronze tripods and vessels, e)/rga being “works of art.”
*qh/bais: The prize of the Herakleia or Iolaia was a bronze tripod.
e)/nnomoi: “Wonted.”
*pe/llana: In Achaia. The prize was a mantle, O. 9.104; N. 10.44: e)k de\ *pella/nas e)piessa/menoi nw=ton malakai=si kro/kais.
*ai)gi/na: There is no warrant for the form *ai)gi/na, yet *ai)gi/na| would be unbearably harsh, as we should have to supply a verb of showing out of ou)x e(/teron e)/xei lo/gon.
ou)x e(/teron ... e)/xei lo/gon: “Has no other tale to tell,” the “tale” being the “count,” “shows the same number.”
liqi/na | ya=fos: “The reckoning on stone,” of the sth/lh on which the victories were recorded.
*zeu= pa/ter: Zeus is more conspicuous here than is usual even in an Olympian ode. See v. 23.
*)ataburi/ou: Atabyron, or Atabyris, a mountain in Rhodes, with a temple of Zeus. Strabo, 10, 454; 14, 655.
ti/ma me/n: Followed by di/doi te. See O. 4.13.
u(/mnou teqmo/n: Cf. O. 13.29.
*)olumpioni/kan: Extension of the freedom involved in u(/mnos *)olumpioni/kas, for which see O. 3.3.

div3.head: Epode 5
div3.p: a)reta/n = a)reta=s kle/os. O. 8.6.
eu(ro/nta: Where one might expect eu(ro/menon (P. 2.64).
pot' = pro/s.

pate/rwn o)rqai\ fre/nes e)c a)gaqw=n: This is poetry for “hereditary good sense.” Compare v. 72: e(pta\ sofw/tata noh/mat' e)pi\ prote/rwn a)ndrw(=n paradecame/nous | pai=das. The o)rqai\ fre/nes are patropara/dotoi. Diagoras is a)gaqo\s e)c a)gaqw=n. See P. 8.45.
e)/xreon = parh/|noun, u(pe/qento (Schol.). The oracle of Diagoras is the wisdom of his ancestors, which is personated in him.
mh\ kru/pte: Let it ever shine.
koino/n: A common glory.
*kallia/naktos: Kallianax was a conspicuous ancestor of Diagoras.
*)eratida=n: D. belonged to the Eratidai. *)e. depends on xari/tessin. Each joy of the Eratidai is a festivity to the city.
mia=|: “One and the same.”
diaiqu/ssoisin au)=rai: P. 3.104: a)/llote d' a)lloi\ai pnoai\ | u(yipeta=n a)ne/mwn, I. 3 (4), 23: a)/llote d' a)lloi=os ou)=ros. See the Introduction to the ode.

div2.p: The victory celebrated in this ode was gained Ol. 80 (460 B.C.) by Alkimedon of Aigina. We know nothing about the victor except what Pindar tells us. He was a Blepsiad (v. 75) of the stock of Aiakos, son of Zeus. There had been much sickness in the family (v. 85). He had lost his father, Iphion (v. 81); his uncle, Kallimachos (v. 82). His grandfather was still living (v. 70). His brother, Timosthenes, had won a Nemean victory (v. 15). His teacher was the famous trainer Melesias, who is mentioned N. 4.93 and 6, 74. There is much dispute whether Alkimedon was an e)/fedros or not. See v. 68.
The song seems to have been sung immediately after the victory during the procession to the altar of Zeus in the Altis.

Pindar knew Aigina well, and the universal of the Aiginetan odes is often so pegged in the knotty entrails of the particular that it is hard to set it free. The victory is the victory of a boy, and the a)lei/pths, who is entitled to a fair share of the praise in all the boy-odes, seems to have a disproportionate space allotted to him. As an Athenian, Melesias had a certain amount of odium to encounter, and P. found it necessary to vindicate him by recounting the successes of Melesias as well as the successes of those whom he had trained. Mezger sees in the ode a jubilee-tribute to Melesias for the thirtieth victory of his pupils (v. 66) — a notion more German than Greek.

After an invocation of Olympia as the mistress of truth, by reason of the happy issue of the oracle delivered by the diviners at the great altar of Zeus (vv. 1-10), the poet says: There are other blessings, but Olympia's prize is the chief. There are other gods, but Zeus is the patron of the Blepsiadai, head of their race (v. 16). Themis, the glory of Aigina, sits by the side of Zeus (v. 22). Apollo, son of Zeus, Poscidon, brother of Zeus, take Zeus's son Aiakos to Troy (v. 31). Then the poet tells the story of Aiakos to show what honor Zeus puts on his son. Aiakos is
sunergo/s to the gods (v. 32), and *zhni\ geneqli/w| (v. 16) is echoed in *zeu\s ge/nei (v. 83).
