So far the poem runs smoothly enough, and if the poet had returned to the victor after despatching Aiakos to Aigina, the ode would be less difficult; but the introduction of the trainer jars us, and, in fact, Pindar himself apologizes for it (v. 56). Timosthenes, who ordered the ode — Alkimedon is nowhere addressed, and his youth is emphasized — required this mention of Melesias, who must have been his trainer too; and so Pindar dwells on the importance of having an old athlete as a trainer both for man (v. 63) and boy, both for Timosthenes and for Alkimedon. This brings Alkimedon forward again, but he is soon lost again in the mention of his race — in the mention of the dead sire, who hears in the other world the glory that has come to the house.

The prose line of thought would be: The blessing of Zeus on Aiakos was on children's children; and so the brothers, Timosthenes, trained by Melesias, and now Alkimedon, have gained the prize, at Nemea one, at Olympia the other, both in games of Zeus, and even in the lower world the gracious boon is not unknown.
The poem is full of prayers, but Aigina was near the point when she would be past praying for.
The rhythms are dactylo-epitrite. According to Böckh the mood is a mixture of Dorian and Lydian, in which we should have the blending of sadness with manly joy.

Of the four triads, the first is introductory; the second contains the brief myth; the last two are divided between Timosthenes, Melesias's patron, who ordered the ode, and Alkimedon, who won the victory.

div3.head: Strophe 1
div3.p: ma=ter: P. makes free use of family figures. So O. 7.70: o( gene/qlios a)kti/nwn path/r, P. 4.176: a)oida=n path\r *)orfeu/s, *o. 13, 10: *(/ubrin *ko/rou mate/ra qrasu/muqon N. 5, 6: te/reinan mate/r' oi)na/nqas o)pw/ran, N. 9.52: biata\n a)mpe/lou pai=da, P. 5.28: *)epimaqe/os qugate/ra *pro/fasin. These are not to be effaced, as Dissen would have it.
xrusostefa/nwn = kallistefa/nwn. So O. 11 (10), 13: xruse/as e)lai/as, and P. 10.40.
i(/na: Always “where” in P.

e)mpu/rois tekmairo/menoi: Pyromancy, divination by means of altar flames, was practised by the Iamidai (see
O. 6).
parapeirw=ntai: para/ here produces the effect of reverent shyness.
a)rgikerau/nou: The thunderbolt is figured on coins of Elis.
ei)/ tin' e)/xei lo/gon: “If (whether) he hath any utterance to make,” “any decision to give.” ei) interrog. also in P. 4.164.
maiome/nwn ... qumw=|: “Eagerly seeking.”
a)reta/n = a)reta=s kle/os, as O. 7.89
a)mpnoa/n: Well chosen for a wrestler.

div3.head: Antistrophe 1
div3.p: a)/netai: Impersonal. “Accomplishment is accorded.” The pass. impersonal is not over-common in Greek.
pro\s xa/rin eu)sebei/as: “In requital of their piety.”
a)lla/: Invocation renewed with fervor. “Nay.” Compare O. 4.6.
eu)/dendron ... a)/lsos: See O. 3.23.
stefanafori/an: Of the winner.
so\n ge/ras: Such an honor as thine — the wreath of victory.

e(/spht(ai): The generic relative may omit a)/n in P. This is, in fact, the original form. So O. 3.11; 6, 75 al. In e(/sphtai, e( represents the reduplication (for sesp.), and is not dropped. See Od. 12. 349.
a)/lla ... a)gaqw=n: In prose a)/lla a)gaqa/. This reflection is intended to console Timosthenes. The neut. pl. with verb pl. is especially appropriate here, as the notion is distributive.

div3.head: Epode 1
div3.p: *timo/sqenes: A brother of Alkimedon. On de/ after voc. see O. 1.36.
po/tmos: Here = *moi=ra.
*zhni\ geneqli/w|: Every man has his dai/mwn gene/qlios (O. 13.105). He who has *zeu\s gene/qlios has the highest. Compare P. 4.167: o(/rkos a)/mmin ma/rtus e)/stw *zeu\s o( gene/qlios a)mfote/rois.
pro/faton = pro/fanton, “illustrious.”
e)/rgw|: Parallel with e)sora=n, as if the dat. force of the inf. were felt (= o)/yei). The te complements: appearance and reality are exhaustive.
kata\ vei=dos e)le/gxwn: kata/ with e). Tyrtai. 10, 9: ai)sxu/nei te ge/nos, kata\ d' a)glao\n ei)=dos e)le/gxei.
e)ce/nepe: Causative, as O. 5.8: e)ka/ruce. Compare P. 1.32: ka=ruc a)ne/eipe/ nin. — dolixh/retmon: Od. 8. 191: *fai/hkes dolixh/retmoi.
*sw/teira ... *qe/mis: O. 9.16: *sw/teira ... *eu)nomi/a, O. 12.2: *sw/teira *tu/xa.

*dio\s ceni/ou: Owing to the active commerce of Aigina, many suits were brought by strangers before the courts, hence the special propriety of ceni/ou. The probity of the Aiginetans was conspicuous. So just below, pantodapoi=sin ... ce/nois | ki/ona daimoni/an.
pa/redros: So. O. C. 1384: *zhno\s *di/kh pa/redros a)rxai/ois no/mois.
a)skei=tai: “Is honored,” “receiveth homage.” N. 11.8: kai\ ceni/ou *dio\s a)skei=tai *qe/mis. The personification is kept up. P. 3.108: to\n a)mfe/pont' ai)ei\ frasi\n | dai/mon' a)skh/sw.

div3.head: Strophe 2
div3.p: e)/cox' a)nqrw/pwn: Compare O. 1.2.

o(/qi ... r(e/ph|: I read o(/qi with the Schol., r(e/ph| with Bergk. “Where there is heavy weighing in many ways.” “Where there is much in the balance and the balance sways much.” Aigina was a great commercial centre; Aiginetan standards were known all over Greece, and Aiakos, the son of Aigina, was a famous judge. Compare P. 8.98: *ai)/gina, fi/la ma=ter, e)leuqe/rw| sto/lw| | po/lin ta/nde ko/mize *di\ kai\ kre/onti su
 *ai)akw=|. This makes the r(oph/ signification of r(e/ph| the more probable. We have to do with the scales of justice and the Aiginetan talent. Schol.: o(/tan ga to\ e)n tw=| zugw=| e)lafro
 h)=|, eu)xere\s th
 i)so/thta gnw=nai: e)a
 de\ baru/, dusxere/s.
duspale/s: More or less pointed allusion to the pa/lh of the victor.
a(lierke/a: See P. 1.18; I. 1, 9.
ki/ona: O. 6.2.
daimoni/an: O. 6.8.
e)pante/llwn: Coming time is a rising sun. Neither time nor sun grows weary. But three or four years afterwards (456 B.C.) the island was taken by the Athenians. See Thuk. 1, 108.

div3.head: Antistrophe 2
div3.p: *dwriei= law=| tamieuome/nan: For the dat. see O. 12.3: ti\n ... kubernw=ntai qoai\ | na=es. The island obeys the rule of the Doric folk, as the ships obey the helm of Tyché.

e)c *ai)akou=: “From the time of Aiakos.” Aiakos was an Achaian, but the Dorians appropriated the mythic heroes of the tribes they succeeded, especially as the chiefs were often not Dorian. Note that we have to do with oracle and prophecy from the beginning of the ode.
pai=s o( *latou=s: The partnership is well known. Il. 7. 452 (Poseidon speaks): tou= d' [sc. tei/xeos] e)pilh/sontai, to\ e)gw\ kai\ *foi=bos *)apo/llwn | h(/rw| *laome/donti poli/ssamen a)qlh/sante.
eu)rume/dwn: Poseidon is also eu)rubi/as (O. 6.58) and eu)rusqenh/s (O. 13.80), and *eu)ru/pulos is his son (P. 4.33).
me/llontes e)pi\ ... teu=cai (= e)piteu=cai): The aor. after me/llw, as O. 7.61; P. 9.57. The pres., O. 8.64. P. does not use the normal future.
ste/fanon: “Battlement.” Compare P. 2.58: eu)stefa/nwn a)guia=n.
h)=n o(/ti: Not a harsh hyperbaton.
nin = ste/fanon. If a mortal had not joined in the work, the city could never have been taken (Schol.).
la/bron ... kapno/n: Cf. P. 3.40: se/las la/bron *(afai/stou. la/bros in Homer is used of wind and wave, river and rain; in P. the sphere is different.

div3.head: Epode 2
div3.p:
dra/kontes ... oi( du/o me\n ... ei(=s de/: Distributive apposition, much more vivid than the genitive use. glaukoi/ is
glossed by fobero/fqalmoi. For the basilisk glare, see P. 4.249: glaukw=pa ... o)/fin, O. 6.45: glaukw=pes dra/kontes.
ne/on = newsti/.
e)sallo/menoi: The conative present is translated by the Schol. boulo/menoi ei)selqei=n.
ka/peton = kate/peson. We should have expected ka/ppeton. The two who fell were Achilles and Aias; the one who entered was Neoptolemos, son of Achilles (Schol.).
au)=qi: “On the spot.”
a)tuzome/nw: Hardly seems applicable to the representatives of Achilles and Aias. The Scholiast feels this, for we find in the paraphrase e)n a)/t h| e)ge/nonto: a)pe/qanon ga/r.
yuxa\s ba/lon: Contrast the choked serpents of N. 1.46: a)gxome/nois de\ xro/nos | yuxa\s a)pe/pneusen mele/wn a)fa/twn.
boa/sais: “With a cry” (of victory). Mythical serpents may make mythical outcry. The aor. part. is not prior to the leading verb. Cf. O. 9.15.
a)nti/on: “Adverse,” with te/ras (Schol.).

o(rmai/nwn = dialogizo/menos, dianoou/menos (Schol.). Not satisfactory. The Scholia give also o(rw=n, qeasa/menos pointing to a corruption in o(rmai/nwn. A possible translation is “Apollo straight came rushing on and openly (a)nti/on) declared the prodigy.” Compare Od. 17. 529: e)/rxeo, deu=ro ka/lesson, i(/n' a)nti/on au)to\s e)ni/sph|.

a)mfi\ teai=s ... e)rgasi/ais: “About (and by reason of) the works of thy hands.” “Where thou hast wrought.” The weak point is indicated Il. 6. 433: par' e)rineo/n, e)/nqa ma/lista | a)/mbato/s e)sti po/lis kai\ e)pi/dromon e)/pleto tei=xos.
a(li/sketai: Praesens propheticum.
pemfqe\n ... *dio/s: The construction is lightened by fa/sma *kroni/da, K. being the subjective genitive.

div3.head: Strophe 3
div3.p: a)/rcetai: Acc. to the Schol. a). = a)rxh\n lh/yetai. “The capture will begin with the first generation and (end) with the fourth.” Better a)/rcetai, “will be swayed.” So Hdt. 3, 83, a)rxqh/somai, like so many -qh/somai futures, being late. Bergk conjectures r(h/cetai. r(a/cetai, though lacking early proof, has a vigorous ring.

tetra/tois: These numbers have given trouble, so that it has been proposed to read with Ahrens and Bergk terta/tois (Aeol.) = trita/tois (Meister, Gr. Dial. 1, 43). The genealogy is this:
Aiakos
Telamon
Aias
Peleus
Achilles
Neoptolemos
Phokos
Panopeus
Epeios

The Schol. remarks that Aiakos is excluded in prw/tois and included in tetra/tois. Epeios was the builder of the famous wooden horse. Telamon aided Herakles and Iolaos in the first capture of Troy. N. 3.36: *laome/donta d' eu)rusqenh\s | *telamw\n *)io/la| parasta/tas e)w\n e)/persen.
sa/fa: Apollo is usu. *loci/as. Cf. note on O. 6.61.

*ca/nqon: The prepos. is often suspended in P. See O. 9.94; P. 1.14; P. 4.130, and elsewhere. *ca/nqos, the divine name of the *ska/mandros. Il. 20. 74: o(\n *ca/nqon kale/ousi qeoi/, a)/ndres de\ *ska/mandron.
h)/peig' h)/: The codices have h)/peige or h)/peigen.
*)amazo/nas: The friends of Artemis, who lived on the Thermodon. Apollo goes from river to river. Cf. O. 6.58: *)alfew=| kataba\s e)ka/lesse ... tocofo/ron *da/lou qeodma/tas skopo/n.
*)/istron: O. 3.14.
*)orsotri/aina: So also P. 2.12; N. 4.86.
e)p' *)isqmw=| ... ta/nuen: Cf. O. 2.99: e)pi/ toi *)akra/ganti tanu/sais. For the gender, O. 7.81.
a)pope/mpwn: “Bringing home.”
deu=ro: To Greece from Troy and so to Aigina.
a)n' i(/ppois xruse/ais: so O. 1.41: xruse/aisin a)n' i(/ppois.

div3.head: Antistrophe 3
div3.p: deira/da: The Isthmus or “neck” of land (Schol.).
daitikluta/n: “Feast-famed.” So Bergk for dai=ta kluta/n, formed like qemiple/ktois, N. 9.52.

terpno\n ... ou)de/n: The contrast is between the life of the gods and the life of men. Apollo is happy in three places, Poseidon in two. But human beings are not equally happy everywhere. Timosthenes was victorious at Nemea, Alkimedon at Olympia. An Athenian would not be at home in Aigina, nor an Aiginetan at Athens. This commonplace prepares, after a fashion, the way for the inevitable mention of Melesias.
*melhsi/a: An Attic trainer. See N. 4 and 6, end. No favorite in Aigina, as we may gather from P.'s cautious tone.
e)c a)genei/wn ku=dos: See note on O. 1.2: nukti\ pu=r. “Glory from training beardless youths.”

a)ne/dramon u(/mnw|: A bold equivalent of a)nu/mnhsa. Compare the use of diecie/nai, diecelqei=n, and Simon. Amorg. 10: ti/ tau=ta makrw=n dia\ lo/gwn a)ne/dramon; “If I have traversed in song to its full height the glory of Melesias.” This is the objection of the cavillers, dramatically put in the aor., and not in the fut. P. uses the fut. only once certainly (fr. VII. 4, 15) in the protasis of a conditional sentence, and ei) with aor. subj. is generic. See O. 6.11.
mh\ bale/tw: The 3 p. aor. imper. with mh/ is much more common than it is sometimes repre sented to be.

kai\ ... xa/rin: The whole passage is much disputed. The sense seems to be: Do not envy the glory of Melesias
gained from his teaching art; he hath practised what he taught. If he taught boys to win, he himself won as a boy a wrestling-match; nay, won afterwards, as a man, the pankration. To train is easier for him that knows himself what struggle means. Foolish it is not to learn in advance, for giddier are those that have not tried. So he, as teacher and as athlete, could better tell what the prizers should do. By emphasizing Melesias' own achievements, P. justifies Alkimedon in employing him, and tries to salve the wounded feelings of the Aiginetans.
*neme/a| ... xa/rin: Compare v. 83: ko/smon *)olumpi/a|.
e)re/w: The old modal use of the future = e)/xw ei)pei=n.
tau/tan = toiau/tan, the same kind of honor that Alkimedon gained — a victory in wrestling.
a)ndrw=n ma/xan: Leop. Schmidt calls this a metaphor, as m. cannot be used literally of a game. Still eu)quma/xan (O. 7.15) is used of a boxer.

div3.head: Epode 3
div3.p: to\ dida/casqai: Only a more intense dida/cai, “To get one's men into training.” The two articular infinitives are noteworthy, as the construction is somewhat rare in P. The demonstrative sense is still perceptible. “This thing of teaching.”
kei=na ... e)/rga: The pa/lh, the pagkra/tion.
kei=nos: Melesias. 63. tro/pos: “Training.”
*)alkime/dwn ... e(lw/n: In prose usu. to\ *)alkime/donta e(lei=n. See P. 2.23.

ni/kan triakosta/n: Mezger thinks that the apparently disproportionate space allotted to Melesias is to be accounted for partly by this round number. It was a professional jubilee for the old a)lei/pths. See Introd.

div3.head: Strophe 4
div3.p: tu/xa| ... dai/monos: So P. 8.53: tu/xa| qew=n, N. 4.7: su\n *xari/twn tu/xa|, N. 6.27: su\n qeou= de\ tu/xa|.
ou)k a)mplakw/n: Neg. expression of tuxw/n. a). often in tragic poets = a(martw/n. — 68.

te/trasin: The most simple way of fulfilling the conditions is to suppose sixteen contestants, eight pairs, four bouts, the victors in each bout wrestling off the ties. Alkimedon, as the final victor, would then have thrown his four boys. If an e)/fedros, or “odd man,” is assumed at any point in the match, the calculation is more complicated, and the number may be as low as nine. With nine contestants (four pairs and an e)/fedros), the fourth bout would have been wrestled by the victor and the e)/fedros of the third. In this way Alkimedon might have thrown four boys, provided he was not himself an e)/fedros, which is an unnecessary inference drawn by some commentators from v. 67: tu/xa| me\n dai/monos.
The e)/fedros was considered lucky because he came with fresh strength to contend with a wearied victor, but if Alkimedon was to be an e)/fedros at all and defeat four boys personally and not by proxy, there must have been at least five bouts. In any case, the e)/fedros seems to have drawn lots with the others at the end of each bout, so that the same person was not necessarily e)/fedros throughout. The “reasonable plans” vary according to the editors. See P. 8.81.
a)peqh/kato: “Put off from himself” as something hateful. Compare O. 10 (11), 43: nei=kos de\ kresso/nwn | a)poqe/sq' a)/poron.

gui/ois: Emphasis on the important element, as in e)/tla kai\ *dana/as ... de/mas (Soph.); sqe/nos h(mio/nwn (O. 6.22), gui=a being the main thing in wrestling. So N. 7.73: ai)/qwni pri\n a(li/w| gui=on e)mpesei=n (of a pentathlete saved from wrestling). Compare Il. 23. 726: ko/y' o)/piqen kw/lhpa tuxw/n, u(pe/luse de\ gui=a. — 69.

no/ston , kte(.: n. is the return to the town, a)timote/ran glw=ssan refers to the jibes and jeers of enemies in the gate, e)pi/krufon oi)=mon to the slinking to the mother's house by the back way. Compare the parallel passage, P. 8.81: te/trasi d' e)/mpetes u(yo/qen | swma/tessi kaka\ frone/wn | toi=s ou)/te no/stos o(mw=s | e)/palpnos e)n *puqia/di kri/qh | ou)de\ molo/ntwn pa\r mate/r' a)mfi\ ge/lws gluku\s | w)=rsen xa/rin: kata\ lau/ras d' e)xqrw=n a)pa/oroi | ptw/ssonti, sumfora=| dedagme/noi. There is a savagely boyish note of exultation in both passages.
a)nti/palon: “That wrestles with.”
a)/rmena pra/cais = eu)= pra/cas, as P. 8.52: a)nti/a pra/cei = kakw=s pra/cei.

div3.head: Antistrophe 4
div3.p: a)ll' e)me/: The a)lei/pths teaches, the poet sings, the victor, being a boy, gets only a boy's share.

xeirw=n a)/wton ... e)pi/nikon: “The victorious prime of their hands,” “the fruit of their victorious hands,” karpo
 o(
 ai( xei=res au)tw=n h)/negkan. Compare P. 10.23: xersi
 h)\ podw=n a)reta=| krath/sais. Melesias is praised, N. 9, end: delfi=ni/ ken | ta/xos di' a(/lmas ei)ka/zoimi *melhsi/an | xeirw=n te kai\ i)sxu/os a(ni/oxon.
*bleyia/dais: The dative emphasizes the gain.
fullofo/rwn: Cf. P. 9.133: polla\ me\n kei=noi | di/kon fu/ll' e)/pi kai\ stefa/nous.
ka/n = kata/.

e)rdome/nwn: The MSS. have e)rdo/menon, which is harsh. The expression kata\ no/mon e)/rdein is sacrificial. So Hes. Theog. 416: kai\ ga\r nu=n o(/te pou/ tis e)pixqoni/wn a)nqrw/pwn | e)/rdwn i(era\ kala\ kata\ no/mon i(la/skhtai. ta\ no/mima, iusta, often of funeral rites.
ou) ko/nis: On the free position of the neg., see O. 1.81.

suggo/nwn kedna\n xa/rin: The dust does not hide (from the dead) the noble grace of (their living) kinsmen. As the dead are not insensible of rites paid in
their honor, so they are not blind to the glory gained by their kindred.

div3.head: Epode 4
div3.p: *(erma=: Hermes is yuxopompo/s, and has a right to an extemporized daughter *)aggeli/a, who plays the same part as the well - established *)hxw/ does, O. 14.21.
*)ifi/wn . . . *kallima/xw|: Iphion is supposed to be the father, and Kallimachos the uncle, of Alkimedon.
ko/smon *)olumpi/a|: Cf. v. 56.
sfi . . . ge/nei: ge/nei is not epexegesis to sfi. sfi depends on the combination ge/nei w)/pasen, “made a family gift to them.” See O. 2.16.
e)sla\ d' e)p' e)sloi=s: e)pi/ is = “heaped on.” See O. 2.12; 11 (10), 13.
eu)/xomai: Asyndeton, as often in prayers. Zeus is invoked. Cf. O. 1.115.
a)mfi\ kalw=n moi/ra|: The dat. of the thing at stake, as peri/ with dat.

dixo/boulon: “Of divided mind.” Zeus is not to make (qe/men) Nemesis double-minded. She is not to waver; she is to be a steady friend. P. 10.20: mh\ fqonerai=s e)k qew=n | metatropi/ais e)piku/rsaien, N. 10.89: ou) gnw/ma| diplo/an qe/to [*zeu\s] boulh/n. It must be remembered that matters were e)pi\ curou= a)kmh=s in Aigina. Others, “Of different mind,” “hostile.” dix. ne/mesin q., “to rouse factious discontent” is too colorless.
a)/gwn=e)pa/gwn. Compare O. 2.41: ou(/tw . . . *moi=ra. . . e)pi/ ti kai\ ph=m' a)/gei.
au)tou/s=tou\s *bleyia/das.

div2.p: The date of this ode is uncertain, and the Scholiasts are at variance. According to Böckh the victory was won Ol. 81 (456 B.C.), shortly after a Pythian victory, Ol. 80, 3 (458 B.C.), which is celebrated in this ode together with the Olympian one (v. 13). Leopold Schmidt finds that Böckh's computation agrees with his theory of P.'s poetical decline. Fennell puts the date Pyth. 30 (468 B.C.), acc. to one Scholiast, on the ground that at the later date (456) the Lokrian oligarchy was threatened, if not overthrown, by the Athenians. Cf. Thuk. 1, 108. Besides his many local successes, Epharmostos had been victorious in all the great national games, and was, consequently, a periodoni/khs. Pindar tells us all we know of him — his noble personal appearance (v. 119), his ancient stock (v. 58), his intimacy with Lampromachos, also a friend of Pindar's (v. 90).

The song was sung in Opus at a festival of Aias Oiliades. The assumption of a banquet gives more point to v. 52. The Lokrians are better known to us through the Epizephyrian representatives of the stock than by the members of the family that remained in Central Greece, and for us Opuntian Lokris is more lighted up by this ode of Pindar's (v. 24) than by the rude inscriptions, which doubtless give a false impression of the people (Hicks, Hist. Inscr. No. 63). Writing may be rude, and song, for which the Lokrians were famous, refined. The position of woman among the Lokrians seems to have been exceptionally influential, and even one who knew nothing of Lokris and the Lokrians could hardly fail to be struck by the predominance of woman in this ode. Pindar is a manner of “Frauenlob,” at any rate, but here “das Ewig-Weibliche” is paramount. Archilochos does not suffice; we must have the Muses (v. 5). Lydian Pelops is mentioned for the sake of the dowry of his bride, Hippodameia (v. 10). Themis and Eunomia (v. 15) are the patronesses of the renowned city, mother of the Lokrians (v. 22).
The city is the city of Protogeneia (v. 44). Opus, son of Zeus and an Epeian heroine (v. 62), bore the name of his mother's father (v. 67). When Menoitios is mentioned, his mother is not forgotten (v. 75); Achilles is only Thetis's son (v. 82).

The fundamental thought is to\ de\ fua=| kra/tiston a(/pan (v. 107). It matters not that in the previous song P. had sung: a)/gnwmon de\ to\ mh\ promaqei=n (O. 8.60). Here no Melesias is to be praised. The fua/ comes from God; hence P. sings, a)/neu de\ qeou= sesigame/non ou) skaio/teron xrh=m' e(/kaston (v. 111). The poem is full of the strange dealings, the wonderful workings of the deities, of the Supreme, culminating in the story of Protogeneia and her son. The fortune of Lydian Pelops (v. 10) reminds us of Poseidon. The dowry of Hippodameia was a gift of God, as Pindar's garden of song was allotted him by Fate (v. 28). The Charites are the bestowers of all that is pleasant. Men are good and wise according to the will of Heaven (v. 30). If Herakles withstood the gods themselves (v. 32), it is clear that there was a greater god within him. That god was Zeus, and P., after deprecating impiety toward the gods, tells of the marvels Zeus hath wrought. Behold the miracle of the stones raised up as seed to Deukalion and Pyrrha. That is the decree of Zeus, ai)olobro/nta *dio\s ai)/sa| (v. 45). Behold the deluge abated. That is the device of Zeus, *zhno\s te/xnais (v. 56). Protogeneia is caught up (v. 62). Zeus interferes again to give life to the dying house (v. 64).

Epharmostos has been singularly favored by nature and fortune. Nature and fortune mean God, and the narrative of his successes closes the poem with a recognition of the divine decree that made him quick of hand, ready of limb, and valorous of eye.
The Lokrian or Aiolian (logaoedic) rhythms are light and festive. They whirr like arrows (v. 12), they flame (v. 24), they speed faster than mettlesome horse or winged ship (v. 25).

The first triad contains the introduction. The myth, the story of the heroine who made Opus what it was, is announced in the first epode, the theme of which is continued in the second triad. After unfolding his moral (a)gaqoi\ de\ kai\ sofoi\ kata\ dai/mon' a)/ndres e)ge/nonto), P. resumes the myth, v. 44, tells of Deukalion and Pyrrha and the stone-folk, and the union of Zeus and the ancestress of Opus and the Opuntian nobles. About the city thus founded gathered nobles of different Grecian lands, chief of them Menoitios, father of Patroklos. From this story, which shows what
God can do, P. passes, at the close of the third triad, to the achievements of the descendants of this favored stock, and, in the last triad, recounts the exploits of Epharmostos.

div3.head: Strophe 1
div3.p: *)arxilo/xou me/los: The Schol. has preserved two lines of this famous hymn to Herakles: w)= kalli/nike xai=r' a)/nac *(hra/klees | au)to/s te kai\ *)io/laos, ai)xmhta\ du/o. The hymn was called simply kalli/nikos, the burden being kalli/nike, and in the absence of music th/nella, an imitative word, represented the lyre. Compare Ar. Ach. 1227. It was the “See the conquering hero comes” of the Greek, and was sung in honor of the Olympian victors at the evening procession, unless a special poem was ordered.
fwna=en: Has the effect of a participle, O. 2.93.
o( triplo/os: The burden was repeated three times.
kexladw/s: One of the onomatopoetic perfects which denote intense, not completed, action. “With its full ringing burden,” “with its note thrice swelling.”
a(gemoneu=sai: Acc. to the Schol., one of the companions of the victor struck up in the absence of a musician. In Ar. l. c. Dikaiopolis himself chants the kalli/nikos without reserve.
e(katabo/lwn: P. Keeps up this figure unusually long, as it is especially familiar. See O. 1.112; 13, 93; P. 1.12, and elsewhere.
foinikostero/pan: The words swell with the theme. We, too, speak of the “red levin,” Hor. rubente | dextera sacras iaculatus arces.

e)pi/neimai: Only here in P. It has an artillery sound, “sweep,” “rake” (compare e)pifle/gwn, v. 24), and is used chiefly of destructive agency. So of fire, Hdt. 5, 101; Pol. 14, 5, 7; Diod. Sic. 14, 51; of plague, Thuk. 2, 54; Diod. Sic. 12, 12; of foes, Plut. Caes. 19; Pomp. 25. P. delights in the oxymoron. Compare O. 6.46: a)memfei= i)w=|, and gluku\n o)isto/n, v. 12. e)., then, is not “aim at,” but “send arrow after arrow at,” “sweep with hurtling flight.”
a)krwth/rion: Kronion.
*(ippodamei/as: Recalls O. 1.70. The Schol. notes that e(/dnon is not used in the regular Homeric sense, as P. 3.94, but as fernh/, “dowry.”

div3.head: Antistrophe 1
div3.p: gluku\n . . . o)isto/n: Homer's pikro\s o)isto/s, Il. 23. 867, or “biting arrow,” was to P. as to us a “bitter arrow.” Hence the antithesis gluku/n.
*puqw=na/de: Epharmostos had won a victory at Pytho also, Pyth. 33 = Ol. 80, 3 (458 B.C.), acc. to one Schol. One arrow for Pytho, a shower of bolts for Olympia.
xamaipete/wn: Here with reference to arrows that fall to the ground without reaching their mark.

a)mfi\ palai/smasin:
See P. 2.62.
fo/rmigg' e)leli/zwn: The fo/rmigc takes the place of the bio/s. e)leli/zwn is properly used of the fo/rmigc, P. 1.4.

kleina=s e)c *)opo/entos: On the gender, compare O. 3.2: kleina\n *)akra/ganta. Pindar shows a special interest in the Lokrians (v. 23), and this has given rise to many historical fancies on the part of scholars.
ai)nh/sais: Aor., the result, as e)leli/zwn, pres., is the process. Dissen puts a full stop after *)opo/entos, and makes ai)nh/sais an opt. unnecessarily.
*qe/mis: The family-tree of such abstractions often gets its branches twisted, but P. consistently makes *eu)nomi/a daughter to *qe/mis, O. 13.8.
quga/thr . . . oi(: “She that is daughter to her” — not “her daughter.” N. 7.22 is not a parallel (Erdmann).
le/logxen: The sing., v. 89.

stefa/nwn a)/wtoi: Cf. O. 5.1: stefa/nwn a)/wton gluku/n. The distributive plural is genuinely Greek. Compare I. 3 (4), 48: tw=n a)peira/twn ga\r a)/gnwstoi siwpai/. Yet a)/wtoi occurs only here and N. 8.9: h(rw/wn a)/wtoi.
kluta/n: “To renown” (predicative).

div3.head: Epode 1
div3.p: fi/lan po/lin: Compare v. 89.
malerai=s e)pifle/gwn a)oidai=s: malero/s is painfully dazzling. So. O.R. 190: *)/area/ te to\n malero/n, o(\s nu=n fle/gei me.

m. a). is almost an oxymoron. P. 5.45: se\ . . . fle/gonti *xa/rites, N. 10.2: fle/getai d' a)retai=s muri/ais, I. 6 (7), 23: fle/getai d' i)oplo/koisi *moi/sais, P. 11.45: tw=n eu)frosu/na te kai\ do/c' e)pifle/gei. See note on v. 7.

u(popte/rou: Is the ship a winged thing (a bird) or a finny thing (a fish)? Od. 11. 125: e)retma/, ta/ te ptera\ nhusi\ pe/lontai. u(po/ proves nothing in favor of oars, because u(po/pteros is alatus quocumque modo et quacumque corporis parte (Tafel). Transl. “Winged.”

ei) su/n tini moiridi/w| pala/ma|: The condition is merely formal. This is the key-note of Pindar's poetic claims. Here he is tilling the garden of the Charites. The flaming darts of song are changed into flowers (a)/nqea u(/mnwn, v. 52), with which the keeper of the garden of the Charites pelts his favorites (P. 9.133: polla\ me\n kei=noi di/kon fu/ll' e)/pi kai\ stefa/nous) as he showered arrows before. Compare P. 6.2: a)/rouran *xari/twn, N. 10.26: kai\ *)isqmoi= kai\ *neme/a| ste/fanon *moi/saisin e)/dwk' a)ro/sai. For the shift compare N. 6.31: a)po\ to/cou i(ei/s, v. 37: *pieri/dwn a)ro/tais.
a)gaqoi\ . . . kai\ sofoi/: The brave and the wise, the hero (Herakles) and the poet (Pindar). Compare P. 1.42: kai\ sofoi\ kai\ xersi\ biatai/.
kata\ dai/mona = kat' ai)=san.

div3.head: Strophe 2
div3.p: e)ge/nonto: Empiric aorist.

e)pei/: “Since” (were
this not so), “whereas,” “else.”
sku/talon=r(o/palon. Post Homeric. Peisandros of Rhodes first endowed Herakles with the Oriental and solar club.
xersi/n: See P. 3.57.

a(ni/ka: “What time.” P. 1.48. P. rolls three several fights into one — the fight of Herakles with Poseidon in Messenian Pylos, because the sea-god's son, Neleus, would not purge him of the bloodguiltiness of the murder of Iphitos; the fight with Hades in Eleian Pylos, because he had carried off Kerberos; the fight with Apollo, because he had stolen a tripod to avenge the refusal of an oracle. So the Scholiast.
h)/reide: “Pressed.”
polemi/zwn: pelemi/zwn (Thiersch and Bergk) is specious, but we should expect to/con. Homer does not use polemi/zein of single combat, but that is not conclusive.

r(a/bdon: Hades' wand is akin to the caduceus of Hermes, with its well-known miraculous power. Herakles could meet not only two, but three — could match his sku/talon against Poseidon's jagged trident, Apollo's clangent bow, and Hades' magic wand, because he was supported by his sire. Genius is a match for the divine, is divine. Herakles is a kata\ dai/mon' a)nh/r, as P. is a kata\ dai/mon' a)oido/s. Compare v. 28. Observe that P. only carries out the thesis a)gaqoi\ kata\ dai/mon' e)ge/nonto with Herakles as proof. The sofoi/ he leaves untouched, as savoring of presumption.
a)po\ . . . r(i=yon: P. is overcome by his own audacity. A little more and he had matched himself against all the gods and goddesses of song. Compare the sudden start of O. 1.52: a)fi/stamai.

to/ ge loidooh=sai . . . to\ kauxa=sqai: Both objectionable; a very common use of the articular infinitive. See O. 2.107. loidorh=sai involves taking sides. In tense, loidorh=sai matches r(i=yon. kauxa=sqai and lala/gei go together. ou) dei= loidorh=sai, therefore r(i=yon. dei= mh\ kauxa=sqai, therefore mh\ lala/gei. So P. leaves the divine warriors facing each other, and holds his peace about his own powers.

div3.head: Antistrophe 2
div3.p: mani/aisin u(pokre/kei: “Keeps in unison with the discordant notes of madness.”

po/lemon ma/xan te: The combination of two substantives with te is common enough in this poem, so vv. 16, 43, 46, 75, 89. It is very rare in model prose, and hence it may be noted as a curiosity that it is exceptionally common in Plato's Timaios — Timaios being an Epizephyrian Lokrian.
xwri\s a)qana/twn: x., “apart from,” “aside from.”
fe/rois: Imper. opt. “Lend.”

*prwtogenei/as: P. seems to have been very familiar with local myths of the Lokrians. The story as told by
Mezger, after Böckh and Bossler, is as follows: Deukalion and Pyrrha, grandchildren of Iapetos (compare Hor. Iapeti genus) escape the deluge by taking refuge on Parnasos. When the waters subsided, by the devices of Zeus (v. 56), they descended from the mountain (v. 46) to Opus, where, in consequence of an oracle of Zeus, they founded the first town (v. 47), and made the Stone people. To these belonged “the hundred mothers” from whom the Lokrian nobles were descended, as, indeed, the prominence of women among the Lokrians generally is a significant fact. The royal race to which Epharmostos is supposed to have belonged traced their descent from Deukalion and Pyrrha down to Lokros in the male line, and from his adopted son Opus in the female. Lokros was the last of his house, and the race was about to die out with him, but Zeus carried off Protogeneia, daughter of Opus of Elis, and granddaughter of Protogeneia, daughter of Deukalion and Pyrrha; was united to her in the Mainalian mountains, and brought her to the childless Lokros, her cousin, as his wife. Lokros called the offspring of the younger Protogeneia after her father Opus, and gave him the throne. The fame of Opus spread, and many settlers came to him, none dearer than Menoitios.
ai)olobro/nta *dio/s: A thunderbolt was the token on the coins of the Lokrians. *)opou=s is supposed to be connected with the “eye of God,” lightning.
o(mo/damon: They are of the same commonwealth, not of the same blood. Compare the Herakleidai and the Dorians.
sfin: Refers to *laoi/, “in their honor.”

oi)=mon ligu/n: oi)=mos is more frequently a figurative path. So Engl. “way” yields more and more to “road.” Compare O. 1.110: o(do\s lo/gwn, and Hymn. in Merc. 451: a)glao\s oi)=mos a)oidh=s (Hom. oi)/mh).

ai)/nei . . . newte/rwn: This is said by the Schol. to be an allusion to a sentence of Simonides, who, in blaming P.'s new version of a myth, said, fr. 75 (Bergk): e)cele/gxei o( ne/os oi)=nos ou)/pw (ou) to\, Schneidew.) pe/rusi dw=ron a)mpe/lou: o( de\ mu=qos o(/de keneo/frwn. P. retorts by insisting on the difference between wine and song. Men want old wine and new song, the former a universal, the latter an Homeric sentiment, Od. 1. 352: th\n ga\r a)oidh\n ma=llon e)piklei/ous' a)/nqrwpoi, | h(/ tis a)kouo/ntessi newta/th a)mqipe/lhtai. The story has so little warrant that it ought not to weigh, as it does with some, in fixing the date of the ode. Simonides died 456 B.C.

div3.head: Epode 2
div3.p:
le/gonti ma/n: ma/n with a note of defiance.
Cf. P. 3, 88: le/gontai ma/n , and especially P. 1.63. The challenge does not refer to the old tale of the deluge, but to the new version of the line of Opus. I renounce the examination of the spider-web speculations that have been spun about the relations of Elis and Opus.
a)/ntlon: “The flood,” which rises as the water that rises in the hold of a ship, the regular meaning of a)/ntlos. Cf. P. 8.12. The earth appears as a leaky vessel.
e(lei=n: “Drained.”
kei/nwn: The reference is much disputed. k.=*law=n (Dissen); k.= *deukali/wnos *pu/rras te (Böckh), which is the more likely by reason of the emphasis on *)iapetioni/dos fu/tlas.
u(me/teroi pro/gonoi: Refers to Epharmostos and his family.
*)iapetioni/dos: See O. 3.14.

kou=roi kora=n: Stress is laid again on the distaff side, and it is hard to resist the inference that the novelty of P.'s story consists in dissociating Protogeneia from the *laoi/, the child of Deukalion and Pyrrha from their stone offspring; hence a)rxa=qen.

kora=n . . . *kronida=n: Used by poetic extension for Protogeneia the younger and Zeus, the pl. for the sing., as in fr. IV. 3, 11: go/non u(pa/twn me\n pate/rwn melpe/men gunaikw=n te *kadmeia=n e)/molon (of Dionysos). Bornemann's ko/ras . . . ferta/tou is a purely arbitrary simplification.
e)gxw/rioi basilh=es: e)gxw/rioi is used in opposition to e)paktoi/. “A purely native line of kings until . . .”

div3.head: Strophe 3
div3.p: pri\n *)olu/mpios . . . e)/neiken: The Schol. makes a full stop at ai)ei/, and considers pri/n an adverb, with ga/r omitted =pro/teron ga/r. But pri/n requires a standard of reference and ai)ei/ forces a close combination. pri/n with the ind. always means “until,” which here marks the introduction of new blood.
e(/kalos: Acc. to Schol.=la/qra. Compare Il. 8. 512: mh\ ma\n a)spoudi/ ge new=n e)pibai=en e(/khloi, with reference to an escape under cover of the night (dia\ nu/kta).
mi/xqh: Cf. O. 6.29.
*mainali/aisin e)n deirai=s: In Arkadia.
*lokrw=|: Not merely pro\s *lokro/n. Cf. O. 1.46.
ai)w/n: “Time.”
e)fa/yais: As a weight of sorrow.
e)/xen=fe/ren. Compare P. 3.15: fe/rousa spe/rma qeou= kaqaro/n.
e)ka/lesse/ nin . . . e)/mmen: With the same fulness as O. 6.56: katefa/micen kalei=sqai.
po/lin w)/pasen: Acc. to another tradition (Eustath. on Il. 2. 531), Lokros had been forced to yield to Opus.

div3.head: Antistrophe 3
div3.p: a)fi/konto de/ voi: For the dat. see P. 4.124, where there is a gathering of heroes, as also N. 8.9.
*)/argeos: Then at the head of Greece.

*qhba=n: Pindar's home. Notice the te ... te here,
the de\ . . . de/ further on; significant change from parallelism to contrast.
*)arka/des: On account of the joyance *mainali/aisin e)n deirai=s.
*pisa=tai: By reason of the Olympian games.
ui(o\n d' *)/aktoros: Il. 11. 785: *menoi/tios, *)/aktoros ui(o/s.

*menoi/tion: Patroklos is tenderly treated in the Iliad, and often called by his patronymic. So *menoitia/dhs, Il. 1. 307; 9, 211; 11, 608; 16, 420; 17, 270; 18, 93; *menoiti/ou ui(o/s, Il. 11. 605; 16, 278. 307. 827; 18, 12.

*teu/qrantos pedi/on: Compare I. 7 (8), 49: o(\ [sc. *)axilleu\s] kai\ *mu/sion a)mpelo/en | ai(/mace *thle/fou me/lani r(ai/nwn fo/nw| pedi/on. Teuthras was adoptive father of Telephos and king of Mysia.
molw/n. Rarely, as here, with a simple acc. (N. 10.36).

dei=cai | maqei=n: Lit. “to show (so as) to (make one) perceive,” “to show beyond a doubt.” Compare N. 6.9: tekmai/rei . . . i)dei=n, So. O.R. 792: dhlw/soim' o(ra=n, So. El. 1458: ka)nadeiknu/nai . . . o(ra=n.
g' i)=nis: The MSS. have go/nos, unmetrical; Schneidewin *qetio/gnhtos, Bergk g' o)/zos, Mommsen vi/nnos, Bothe g' i)=nis, in which I have acquiesced, though g' is a poor piece of patchery, as often.

div3.head: Epode 3
div3.p: sfete/ras: Homer uses sfe/teros of pl. only. Of sing., “his,” O. 13.61; P. 4.83; I. 5 (6), 33; I. 7 (8), 55; of pl., “their,” I. 2, 27; P. 10.38. The Scholiast remarks how much more honorable Pindar makes the position of Patroklos than Homer does. This divergence from Homer in small matters is a sign of independence of spirit, not of ignorance. Which of the two, Achilles or Patroklos, was e)rasth/s, which e)rw/menos, which the older, which the younger, was much discussed. See Plato's Sympos. 180.

e)/hn: A sudden transition. Remember that prayer is always in order, and many asyndeta fall under this head, O. 1.115. A similar shift is found N. 7.50. P. suddenly remembers the heavy load he had to carry, the contract list of the victories of Epharmostos, and prays for more power. “May I find words.” Compare Homer's petition to the Muses, goddesses of Memory, before he begins the catalogue of the ships, Il. 2. 484.

a)nagei=sqai: “For my progress” through all the victories of Epharmostos. a)na/ gives the force of “all through.” In N. 10.19: braxu/ moi sto/m' a)nagh/sasqai, the figure is effaced; not necessarily so in I. 5 (6), 56: e)moi\ de\ makro\n pa/sas a)nagh/sasqai a)reta/s. Here e)n *moisa=n di/frw|, for which see O. 6.22, keeps the figure alive.

pro/sforos: The traditional “fit,” whether “fit” (for the Muses), “fit” (for the theme), “fit for (e)n) the
Muses' car,” “fit to rehearse” (a)nagei=sqai), gives neither satisfactory sense nor sharp image. If pro/sforos can be understood as prosfora\n prosfe/rwn (cf. v. 116), the passage is perfect. P. is “a bearer” of precious gifts. He would mount the Muses' chariot, passing through the long line of victories with a tribute of praise to each, and for his attendants he wishes poetic Daring and ample Power.
to/lma: Compare O. 13.11: to/lma te/ moi | eu)qei=a glw=ssan o)rnu/ei le/gein.
e(/spoito: In v. 16 the concord (le/logxen) is with the unit produced by te, here with the nearer. For the form e(/sp., see O. 8.11.

proceni/a|: According to the Schol. Lampromachos was a pro/cenos of the Thebans and a kinsman of Epharmostos. Pindar's coming is a tribute to affection and to achievement. The datives are = dia/ with acc.
h)=lqon: In song. Compare O. 7.13: kate/ban.
tima/oros: To claim the honor due.
mi/trais: The pendent woollen ribbons of the wreath; hence, by synecdoche, the garland itself.

div3.head: Strophe 4
div3.p: e)/rgon: Cognate acc., being = ni/khn. Compare P. 8.80.
e)n *kori/nqou pu/lais: Poetic variation for Isthmus.

xa/rmai: Not in the Homeric sense, but = xa/rmata. So also Professor Postgate (Am. Journ. of Phil. III., p. 337). The “horrid” (√ghar) xa/rmai for “contests” would not be endurable in P., who does not tolerate ma/xai of a)gw=nes, except in a figure (O. 8.58).
tai\ de/: “Some.”

*)/argei . . . e)n *)aqa/nais: The omission of the preposition with the first and the addition of it to the second word occurs sixteen times in P., according to Bossler's count, but, as Bossler himself admits, all the examples are not cogent, e. g. O. 7.12; P. 4.130 (cf. O. 1.2. 6). Clear are, e. g., P. 1.14; 2, 59; I. 1, 29. The principle seems to be the same as the omission of the first negative, for which see P. 3.30; 6, 48.
sulaqei\s a)genei/wn: Bold brachylogy. “Reft of the beardless,” of the privilege of contending with the beardless. Cf. O. 8.54.
a)mf' a)rguri/dessin: The prize consisted of silver goblets. On a)mfi/ with dat., see O. 7.80.
o)curepei= do/lw|: “With a quick sleight of shifting balance.” By this light read So. O.R. 961: smikra\ palaia\ sw/mat' eu)na/zei r(oph/.
a)ptw=ti: Many a trick ends in a fall for the trickster.
ku/klon: The ring of spectators.
o(/ssa| boa=|: Of applause. P. 4.241; O. 10 (11), 80.
w(rai=os: P. dwells on the personal beauty of the victors whenever he has an excuse. So O. 8.19; 10 (11), 114; N. 3.19.

div3.head: Antistrophe 4
div3.p: *parrasiw| stratw=|: At the Lykaia, in Arkadia, O. 13.108; N. 10.48.

yuxra=n . . . eu)diano\n fa/rmakon au)ra=n: The prize was a woollen garment (xlai=na). Compare Hipponax, fr. 19: xlai=nan | dasei=an e)n xeimw=ni fa/rmakon r(i/geus. The games were the Hermaia, and were held, according to the Schol., in winter.
o(po/te: Never generic in P. except with subj.
*pella/na|: In Achaia. Compare O. 7.86; 13, 109.
su/ndikos: Schol. marturei=. Compare O. 13.108: marturh/sei *lukai/ou bwmo/s.
*)iola/ou: The Iolaia were celebrated near Thebes. Compare I. 1, 16 foll. On the tomb of Iolaos, see P. 9.90. Amphitryon was buried there also.
*)eleusi/s: The Eleusinia, in honor of Demeter and Koré (tw\ qew/), are mentioned also O. 13.110; I. 1, 57.
a)glai+/aisin: The dat. au)tw=| still lingers in the mind. “Witness to him . . . and to his splendid achievements.”

to\ de\ fua=| kra/tiston a(/pan: The keynote of the poem. A natural reflection after the long list of victories due to native endowment in contrast with the fruitless efforts of those who have tried to gain glory by mere training — the yefennoi\ a)/ndres (compare N. 3.41), whose numberless ventures come to naught.

a)/neu de\ qeou= , kte(.: “Each ungodded thing — each thing wherein God hath no part — is none the worse (for) remaining quenched in silence.” A good specimen of P.'s terse participiality. See note on O. 3.6. to\ a)/neu qeou= is to\ mh\ fua=|. Deep silence is to bury the didaktai\ a)retai/, but loud proclamation (cf. o)/rqion w)/rusai) is to announce the heaven-sent valiance of this man.

e)nti\ ga\r a)/llai , kte(.: Each thing must have the blessing of God. Some roads lead further than others; not all of us can prosper in one path of work. The heights of skill are steep. Of one Epharmostos has reached the pinnacle. For this no silence, but loud heralding.

div3.head: Epode 4
div3.p: o(dw=n . . . mele/ta: The Schol. cites Il. 13. 730: a)/llw| me\n ga\r e)/dwke qeo\s polemh/ia e)/rga, | a)/llw| d' e)n sth/qessi tiqei= no/on eu)ruo/pa *zeu/s.
tou=to . . . a)/eqlon: The e)pini/kion. See v. 87.

w)/rusai: A howl of defiance, as if P. were a watch-dog. To us the word has a note of exaggeration. Hence Ahrens: a)/rusai=ga/rusai, but w)/. is not worse in its way than the dies diei eructat verbum of the Vulgate.
daimoni/a|: Adv., daimoni/a| moi/ra| (Schol.).
o(rw=nt' a)lka/n: “With valor in his eyes.” So pu=r dedorkw/s, fo/bon ble/pwn, Engl., “look daggers.”

*ai)a/nteio/n t' e)n daiti\ vilia/da: With Mommsen. “At the banquet
of Oïliades he crowned victorious the Aias-altar.” This seems better here than “At the banquet he crowned the altar of Aias Oïliades,” the genitive being in apposition with the adjective in -ios, as in *gorgei/h kefalh\ deinoi=o pelw/rou (Il. 5. 741), *nestore/h| para\ nhi\ *puloigene/os basilh=os (Il. 2. 54). vilia/da for *)oilia/da. Aias, son of Oïleus, was a Lokrian, Il. 2. 527: *lokrw=n d' h(gemo/neuen *)oilh=os taxu\s *ai)/as. His effigy is seen on the coins of Opus. The postscript -te comes in very well.
e)pestefa/nwse: “Crowned in commemoration (e)pi/).” So Fennell. Rather “heaped wreaths upon.”

div2.p: The victory celebrated in this ode was gained by Agesidamos, a boy boxer, son of Archestratos of Epizephyrian Lokris, Ol. 74 (484 B.C.). The following ode (11), composed on the same theme, and produced at Olympia immediately after the victory, was put after the longer ode in the MSS., because it was fancied to be the to/kos mentioned v. 11. This longer poem was sent to Lokris some time afterwards. There is nothing to measure the interval that elapsed, and the poet's expressions of contrition at the long delay must be construed poetically. Hermann and Mommsen assign it to the next Olympiad, De Jongh and Fennell, who see in v. 15 an allusion to Anaxilas of Rhegion (see Introd. O. 1), would put it Ol. 76.

Lübbert has written an elaborate essay (Kiel, 1881) to prove that Pindar gave this detailed account of the institution of the Olympian games by the Theban Herakles in distinct opposition to the traditions of the Eleian priests, who referred the establishment of the games to the Idaian Herakles, and the Dactyls, his brothers. See Paus. 8, 7, 6. Lobeck and others consider the Eleian legend a late invention, but Lübbert has proved the great antiquity of Idaian sites in the Peloponnesos, and this theory gives a more plausible explanation of the detail here presented than the gratuitous assumption that the poet went into all these particulars for the benefit of the Epizephyrian Lokrians, as if the Epizephyrians did not have traditions of their own. As a champion of the glory of the Theban Herakles against all comers. Pindar appears in a very natural light.

The words which form the key to the poem lock the third antistrophe and the third epode together, o(/ t' e)cele/gxwn mo/nos | a)la/qeian e)th/tumon | *xro/nos (v. 59). The poet begins by acknowledging a debt: Time shamed him. The truth of the first Olympian games was hidden: Time revealed it. The melody was
long suppressed: Time brought it at last, as welcome as the son with whom the wife rewards the long-expectant love of the aging sire. Time brings roses, Time crowns renewed effort. So Herakles suffers repulse. So Agesidamos has a hard struggle, but both succeed at last. *xro/nos ga\r eu)marh\s qeo/s (Soph.).

The poem was written in fulfilment of a promise, in payment of a debt which the poet poetically feigns that he has forgotten (v. 4). He calls on the bystanders to read the ledger of his heart and see where his creditor stands written; he calls on the Muse (Memory) and Truth, the daughter of Zeus, to keep from him the reproach of falsehood (v. 6). Time has brought the blush of shame to him for this heavy arrear of debt (v. 7), but usury can make good the failure of prompt payment (v. 11). The tide of song will wash away the pebble-counters into the depths of poesy, and the debt due to Agesidamos and to Lokris shall be settled, and favor gained besides with Faithfulness, who inhabits the city of the Zephyrian Lokrians, with Kalliope, who is dear to them, as also mail-clad Ares (v. 15). But the poet is not the only one in debt. Agesidamos would have failed, as Herakles failed in the fight with Kyknos, had not Ilas helped him (v. 19). So let him pay his debt of gratitude to Ilas as Patroklos his to Achilles. Native valor, training sharp, and God's favor can raise a mortal to great fame. Only some few reach joy without toil, light without darkness (v. 25). This tribute paid to Ilas for the training sharp, the decrees of Zeus urge the poet to pay another debt — the debt due to Herakles for the establishment of the games hard by the ancient tomb of Pelops — and the heart of the poem is occupied with a detailed account of the origin of the Olympian games and the first celebration (vv. 27-85). Herakles is not the Herakles of Peisandros (O. 9.32); he is not a lonely knight-errant, he is the leader of a host. The version here given bears on its face the impress of a strong local stamp. It is not the common story, that is evident; and the poet draws a sly parallel between his forgotten debts written on the tables of his heart, which Time reveals to his shame (xro/nos, v. 8) and the truth which Time has brought to light (*xro/nos, v. 61). The victors, so far as they can be traced, are all in the belt of the Peloponnesos with which the Lokris of the mother-country had affinity. Arkadia is prominent, Tegea is there (v. 73), and Mantineia (v. 77), and the conclusion bears the broad mark of the device of the Lokrians — the thunderbolt (vv. 86-91).

At the close, P. sings how welcome the song must be in coming, as a late child of one's old age; and well it may, for song alone gives immortality. And now he has fulfilled his promise. He has praised the Lokrians, he has praised the son of Archestratos, a vigorous prizer and a Ganymede for beauty (v. 115).

The debt is paid, as debts should be paid, with cheeriness, if not with promptness. The Aiolian (logaoedic) rhythms are gay, lilting. The poem ends fitly with *kuprogenei=. Mezger calls attention to the recurrence of xa/rin, vv. 14, 19, 86, 104.

Of the five triads, the first is occupied with the introduction, the fifth with the conclusion. The story of the Olympian games takes up the central three. There is a little overlapping, but not so much as usual.

div3.head: Strophe 1
div3.p: to\n *)olumpioni/kan: Prolepsis. Emphatic accusatives naturally seek the head of the sentence.

a)na/gnwte: Familiar reference to reading and writing, esp. common in Aischylos, e. g., P. V. 789: h(\n e)ggra/fou su\ mnh/mosin de/ltois frenw=n . Compare, further, Choeph. 450, Eum. 275, Suppl. 179; Soph. Triptol. fr. 8: qe\s d' e)n freno\s de/ltoisi tou\s e)mou\s lo/gous. We have here a humorous search in the poet's ledger.
e)pile/laqa=e)pile/lhsmai (Schol.).
*moi=sa: The eldest of the old three was *mnh/mh.

*)ala/qeia: With a touch of repentance for the e)pile/laqa. He had forgotten, and so had lied, or seemed to lie. Hence what follows: e)ru/keton yeude/wn e)nipa/n. Memory is to find the place, and Truth is to discharge the debt.
o)rqa=|=dikai/a| (Schol.). “Rectifying hand;” the hand that scores off the debt.
e)nipa\n a)lito/cenon: Is much more poetic than a)litoce/nwn with yeude/wn. For a like hypallage, compare P. 6.5: *puqio/nikos u(/mnwn qhsauro/s, P. 4.255: u(mete/ras a)kti=nos o)/lbou.

div3.head: Antistrophe 1
div3.p: o( me/llwn xro/nos: The morrow to which I had long postponed my payment has come at last, and has revealed to my shame my long arrear of debt.
katai/oxune: The aor. as a perfect. The shame is not in the debt — this, too, is a qeo/dmaton xre/os (O. 3.7) — but in the delay. Cf. P. 9.112.
baqu/. Compare O. 13.62: baqu\n kla=ron. The column of figures grows downward, deeper and deeper as interest is added to principal.
to/kos: Not a separate poem (see Introduction), but payment in full with usance added.

o(ra=t' w)=n: So Schneidewin for the unmetrical qnatw=n of the better, the a)ndrw=n of the inferior MSS.
Hermann writes o)na/twr, “beneficial;” in the mercantile sense, “a good round interest.” Mommsen, ge to/kos a)ndrw=n. So also Mezger. Fennell, who desiderates proof for w)=n with imper. in P., has o(ra/tw. One might be satisfied with Homer's ou)=n and imper.

ya=fon: The Schol. refers y. to e)pimomfa/n, “the accumulation of censure.” In view of the technical use of ya=fos as “a counter,” it seems more natural to refer it to the debt; but as the e)pimomfa/ consists in the accumulation of the baqu\ xre/os thus rolled up, there is no great divergency in the two views.
ku=ma: The tide of song, as N. 7.12; I. 6 (7), 19.

o(/pa te: This parallelism is characteristic of P. Compare O. 2.108. How the wave will wash away with its flow the rolling pebble, and how this new tide of song will pay my growing debt. “How and how”=“as . . . so.”
koino\n lo/gon: “The general account.” What is due to the victor and the victor's home. Thus only does ga/r get a clear reference.
fi/lan . . . e)s xa/rin: “As a loving favor,” and thus get thanks for blame.
ti/somen: Pindar not unaided by *moi=sa and *)ala/qeia.

div3.head: Epode 1
div3.p: *)atre/keia: Not the same with *)ala/qeia above. a)lh/qeia is truth, as “candor;” a)tre/keia, “truth,” as “straightforwardness,” “unswerving accuracy,” a business virtue. Fides iustitiaque (Dissen). In *)atre/keia there may be an allusion to the uprightness of Zaleukos, the Lokrian lawgiver. The Lokrians love honesty. I am honest. They love song. I sing. They are warlike. I will tell of war.
*kallio/pa: Afterwards especially the heroic Muse. Stesichoros, “who bore the weight of the epos on the lyre” (Quintilian), was of Lokrian origin.
xa/lkeos *)/arhs: See O. 11 (10), 19: strato\n ai)xmata/n.

*ku/kneia: The short a, as in *)odu/sseia (Aeolic). Kyknos was slain by Herakles in the grove of the Pagasaian Apollo because he had seized the victims destined for the Delphian shrine. So Stesichoros. The poem was doubtless familiar to the Lokrians. The nexus is not over-clear. It is tolerably evident, however, that the victory of Agesidamos was gained after a hard struggle. In the first encounter Kyknos was aided by his father, Ares, and Herakles fled acc. to the proverb, ou)de\ *(hraklh=s pro\s du/o. But our Lokrian Herakles, Agesidamos, found his one adversary too much for him, and he would have failed, had it not been for the help of his trainer, Ilas, whether that help was the training itself or encouragement during the struggle. The parallel of Patroklos
and Achilles with Agesidamos and Ilas gives reason to suspect that the adversary was an ingens Telephus of a boy (O. 9.76). De Jongh sees in this an allusion to the struggle between the Lokrians and Anaxilas of Rhegion.
*)/ila|: The mention of the trainer (a)lei/pths) is a part, often a large part, of the contract. See O. 8.54.
*)axilei= *pa/troklos: The Lokrians took an especial pride in Patroklos. See O. 9.75. Patroklos was almost universally considered the older of the two, after Homer, Il. 11. 787.
qh/cais: A trainer is called a *naci/a a)ko/na, I. 5 (6), 73. The same figure is used by Xenoph. Cyr. 1, 2, 10. 6, 41.

fu/nt' a)reta=|: “Born to achievement.” Cf. N. 7.7: a)reta=| kriqei/s. P.'s contempt of the didaktai\ a)retai/ (O. 9.108) is reconcilable with the value of training (doctrina sed vim promovet insitam).

div3.head: Strophe 2
div3.p: a)/ponon . . . pau=roi/ tines: Litotes for “no joy without toil.” An a)/ponon xa/rma would not be singable. Connect fa/os with xa/rma above, “a joy that is a supreme light to life.”
pro/: “Above.”
bio/tw| fa/os: Compare O. 2.62: a)ndri\ fe/ggos.
a)gw=na: The place, as in Homer, and not the contest.
qe/mites=qesmoi/, with *dio/s.
sa/mati: O. 1.93.

bwmw/n e(ca/riqmon: “Six-numbered of altars” (e(c. with a)gw=na), “with altars six in number.” a)nh/riqmos with the genitive is not parallel. Hypallage, as with yeude/wn e)nipa\n a)lito/cenon (v. 6), would be scarcely more harsh. On the six altars, see O. 5.5. The passage is corrupt.

*kte/aton: Kteatos and Eurytos, sons of Poseidon, had attacked Herakles and slain most of the army that he had brought from Tiryns, and so prevented him from exacting the pay due him from their uncle, Augeias. In requital, Herakles lay in ambush for them near Kleonai, as they were on their way from Elis to the Isthmus, slew them, marched against Augeias, and put him to death. With the booty thus acquired he established the Olympian games. See O. 2.3.
a)mu/mona: Physically. Such an a)mu/mwn was Absalom, 2 Sam. 14, 25: From the sole of his foot even to the crown of his head there was no blemish in him. Such an a)mu/mwn was Aigisthos, Od. 1. 29.

div3.head: Antistrophe 2
div3.p:
*au)ge/an la/trion . . . misqo\n u(pe/rbion: Chiastic position, especially effective at the end of the verse. la/trion=a)nti\ th=s latrei/as, the well-known menial service of cleansing the stalls. “That he might exact of Augeias, despite unwillingness and o'erweening might, the wage for his menial service.” Some combine
u(pe/rbion with misqo/n.
pra/ssoito: See O. 3.7.
u(po\ *klewna=n: In Argolis. Kleonai was on the crest of a hill. Hence u(po/.
kai\ kei/nous: kai/, “in his turn.”
*(hrakle/hs: The name of the subject kept back to the close of the period, as often in P., O. 6.9; 13, 17; P. 12.17; I. 5 (6), 30. 35. 40. Cf. also O. 1.26; 3, 20.
e)f' o(dw=|: An offset against the ambush of the Moliones.

div3.head: Epode 2
div3.p: *moli/ones: The Siamese twins of antique fable, no monsters, however, in Homer, who calls them, Il. 11. 750, *)aktori/wne *moli/one pai=de. The name M. came from the mother's side of the house.
u(perfi/aloi: Like uncle, like nephews, v. 31: *au)ge/an . . . u(pe/rbion.
kai\ ma/n: ma/n gives a solemn preparation for the doom of Augeias.
cenapa/tas: So Iason is called ceinapa/tas by Medeia, Eur. Med. 1392.
*)epeiw=n basileu/s: Augeias.
o)/piqen | ou) pollo/n = ou) polu\ u(/steron.
sterew=|: Almost personifies puri/. Transl. “pitiless.” Note also the vividness of the dat. (O. 6.35).
o)xeto/n: Fire and axe are not enough. The river-bank has yielded, and the doomed city settles into a deep channel of woe.
e(a\n po/lin: Effective position. If patri/da is treated as an adj. with po/lin, the color is lost.
a)poqe/sqai: Cf. O. 8.68.
u(/statos: “Last of the three,” and so “at last.”
qa/naton ai)pu/n: Homer's ai)pu\n o)/leqron. He fell into the same o)xeto/s with the city.

div3.head: Strophe 3
div3.p: e)/lsais: Orig. ve/lsais.
staqma=to: “Laid off.”
a)/lsos: Not yet a grove (O. 3.18), and not necessarily a grove (Schol.).
peri\ de\ pa/cais=perifra/cas (Schol.).
e)n kaqarw=|: “In the open.”
do/rpou lu/sin: “Resting-place for the evening meal” (Fennell).
tima/sais: Coincident action. Cf. O. 7.5.

div3.head: Antistrophe 3
div3.p: meta/: “Among.” One of the six double altars was consecrated to Artemis and Alpheios. See O. 5.5.
*kro/nou=*kro/nion. Cf. P. 3.67: h)/ tina *latoi+/da keklhme/non.
a(=s: Asiat. Aeol. and Dor. = e(/ws.
nifa/di: The snow of the old time is an offset against the sun of the time of Herakles. O. 3.24.
pare/stan: The Moirai were present to help, as at the birth of Iamos (O. 6.42).
a)/ra: “As was meet.”

a)la/qeian e)th/tumon: a)lh/qeia, orig. “candor,” needs the reinforcement of “reality.” to\ e)th/tumon is to\ o)/ntws o)/n. Truth
to impression is proved to be truth to reality. The broidered tales (O. 1.29) perish, but the true record prevails (a(me/rai d' e)pi/loipoi ma/rtures sofw/tatoi). Things will right themselves — nay, have righted themselves — and Time, the Recorder, is Time the Herald. Nothing can be more evident than P.'s championship of the Lokrians against false traditions.

div3.head: Epode 3
div3.p: *xro/nos: See v. 34.
kate/frasen: Fulness and accuracy are both implied in kata/ and in fra/zw.
a)kro/qina: For the word, see O. 2.4. The “firstlings” were Herakles' share, and this he separates from the lots of his companions.

su\n *)olumpia/di: The Schol. transl. by e)n *)o. This effaces su/n. To resort to e(\n dia\ duoi=n, “with the victories of the first Olympiad,” is a coarse expedient. “The first Olympiad” is “the first Olympic contest” (Bergk).
ti/s dh/: P. gets out of the tedious dependent form as soon as possible.
xei/ressi: Is satisfied by pa/la|, v. 73, and pugma=s, v. 74.
posi/n te kai\ a(/rmati: Closely joined by te kai/, on account of their kinship in speed; afterwards distributed into possi\ tre/xwn, v. 71, and a)n' i(/ppoisi, v. 76.

a)gw/nion e)n do/ca| qe/menos eu)=xos: Much disputed. The contrast between e)n do/ca| and e)/rgw| must be insisted on: do/ca, usually “glory,” is “opinion” P. 1.36, and N. 11.24: e)ma\n do/can. e)n do/ca| qe/menos=proqe/menos, “setting before his mind” the glory (eu)=xos) of the games. The Schol., however, makes e)n do/ca| q. eu)=xos = e)/ndocon nomi/sas to\ nikh=sai.
kaqelw/n: Cf. P. 5.21: eu)=xos e(lw/n.

div3.head: Strophe 4
div3.p: sta/dion . . . a)ri/steusen: Compare O. 4.22: nikw=n dro/mon.
eu)qu\n to/non: “A straight stretch” — not the di/aulos. So the Schol.
*liku/mnion: See O. 7.29.
*oi)wno/s: Nephew of Alkmene, first cousin of Herakles. According to Pausan. 3, 15, 4, he was killed in Sparta, h(liki/an meira/kion, not very consistent with Pindar's strato\n e)lau/nwn.
*mide/aqen: Midea was in Argolis. The name of Oionos's grandmother was Midea. See O. 7.29.
*)/exemos: Who afterwards killed Hyllos, the son of Herakles. Paus. 8, 5, 1.
*do/ruklos: Unknown.
e)/fere: Imperfect of vision, what Shilleto calls the panoramic imperf. Compare O. 8.49. ta/nuen.
te/los: “Prize.” P. 9.128; I. 1, 27.

div3.head: Antistrophe 4
div3.p: *sa=mos: Mentioned in the Choliambi of Diphilos: stre/yas de\ pw/lous w(s o( *mantineu\s *sh=mos | o(\s prw=tos a(/rmat' h)/lasen par' *)alfeiw=|.

w(liroqi/ou=o( *(alirroqi/ou. Halirrhothios, son of
Poseidon, and so an hereditary charioteer.
*fra/stwr: Unknown, as well as Nikeus below. P. is following local records.
ma=kos . . . e)/dike=makra\n e)/rriye r(i=yin (Schol.).
de\ *nikeu\s: So Ambros. for d' *)enikeu/s.
pe/trw|: In I. 1, 24, cited as a parallel for the dat., Christ reads ai)xmai/s=ai)xma/s.
xe/ra kuklw/sais: Od. 8. 189: to/n r(a (sc. di/skon) peristre/yas.
u(pe\r a(pa/ntwn: “Above”=“beyond.” So N. 9.54; I. 2, 36.
summaxi/a=su/mmaxoi.

parai/quce: Tr., “shot past;” the cheer flashed by. See P. 1.87, note. For the last two contests the pe/ntaqlon was afterwards substituted. See I. 1, 26: ou) ga\r h)=n pentae/qlion a)ll' e)f' e(ka/stw| | e(/rgmati kei=to te/los. P. sticks to his record. It would not be strange if this whole description was composed to save the neglected memory of Doryklos and Phrastor and Nikeus.

e)n d' e(/speron | e)/flecen: e)ne/flecen, “lighted up.” Compare O. 3.20. The full moon, hence eu)w/pidos sela/nas, was a necessary part of the institution. The light of the moon meets the shout of the army.

div3.head: Epode 4
div3.p: a)ei/deto: “Rang with song.” This use of the passive is not very common in Greek. Cf. Eur. I. T. 367: au)lei=tai pa=n me/laqron , Heraclid. 401: quhpolei=tai d' a)/stu.
to\n e)gkw/mion a)mfi\ tro/pon: “Like banquet music.” A curious use of a)mfi/, which makes the tune the centre of the song.
a)rxai=s . . . prote/rais: “The beginnings of yore,” the establishment of the games by Herakles.
e(po/menoi: Seems to hint at deviation on the part of others.

e)pwnumi/an xa/rin: “As a namesake grace of the proud victory, we will sing forth the thunder . . . of Zeus.” The victory is Olympian, let us sing, to grace it, Olympian thunder. Perikles the Olympian was Perikles the Thunderer. xa/rin is the result of keladhso/meqa bronta/n.
ni/kas: So P. 1.30: tou= e)pwnumi/an.
a)gerw/xou: See P. 1.50.
keladhso/meqa=ei)/pwmen (Schol.).
purpa/lamon be/los: “Bolt of the firehand.” Hor. Od. 1, 2, 2: rubente | dextera sacras iaculatus arces. The thunderbolt is figured on the coins of the Epizephyrian Lokrians.
e)n a(/panti kra/tei . . . a)raro/ta: “In every victory fit emblem.” Mezger, after Friese, makes it “in which dwells omnipotence.”
xlidw=sa: “Swelling.” O. 9.2: kexladw/s.

div3.head: Strophe 5
div3.p: ta\ . . . fa/nen: Neut. pl. with verb pl. gives more individuality and more life. We distinguish the strains. Cf. P. 1.13. For fa/nen of music, compare So. O. R. 186: paia\n de\ la/mpei.
w(=te: So Böckh for w(/ste.
neo/tatos to\ pa/lin: “The reverse of youth.” So O. 12.11: e)/mpalin te/ryios, P. 12.32: e)/mpalin gnw/mas.
poime/na: “Master.”
e)pakto\n a)llo/trion: One thinks of “this Eliezer of Damascus.”

qna/|skonti stugerw/tatos: Out of the almost epic fulness of this passage it has falsely, if not foolishly, been gathered that Agesidamos had become old while waiting for Pindar's song. In one sense, yes! oi( de\ poqeu=ntes e)n h)/mati ghra/skousin. The late song is as welcome as a child of one's old age. Nothing more hateful than to die and leave no heir of one's body. Nothing more hateful than to die and leave no memorial of one's hard-earned glory. As the child keeps up the name, so the lyre keeps up the fame. We have no right to assume that Agesidamos was on the brink of the grave. The poet simply declares that he is secure from any such disaster as oblivion.

div3.head: Antistrophe 5
div3.p: kenea\ pneu/sais: “Having spent his strength and breath in vain.” Cf. N. 3.41: a)/llot' a)/llo pne/wn, and P. 2.61: palaimonei= kenea/.
mo/xqw|: Semi - personification. “Procures for Toil naught but a little pleasure,” the fleeting glory of the unsung victory.
eu)ru/: Predicative. The fame is spread “abroad” by the fostering Muses.

div3.head: Epode 5
div3.p: e)gw\ de/: In contradistinction to the Muses.
sunefapto/menos: “Lending a helping hand.”
a)mfe/peson: “Embraced,” “took to my heart.” What was promise is performance.
katabre/xwn: Cf. I. 5, 21: r(aine/men eu)logi/ais, P. 8.57: *)alkma=na stefa/noisi ba/llw, r(ai/nw de\ kai\ u(/mnw|. Above a)napa/ssei suggests roses.
e)rato/n: The son of Archestratos is not old enough to have lost his bloom.
ei)=don: Here no figure. The poet promised when he saw him, and then forgot.
xero\s | a)lka=|: Cf. v. 68: xei/ressi.
kekrame/non: “Endued,” literally “blended;” see P. 10.41.
a)naide/a . . . mo/ron: Theogn. 207: qa/natos a)naidh/s. Death is a true la=as a)naidh/s, “unabashed,” “regardless,” “ruthless.”
su\n *kuprogenei=: With the favor of Aphrodite.

div2.p: For the occasion of this ode see the Introduction to the preceding one, where Böckh's view has been followed. Leop. Schmidt calls it a promissory note, while the old arrangers imagined it to be interest on deferred payment. This is the first Olympian victory celebrated by Pindar, and Schmidt thinks that P. shows great satisfaction at receiving the commission. This may be true, but Schmidt does not succeed in explaining why P. should have postponed the execution so long.

The thought of the poem is, “Song, God-given, is the true complement of God-given victory.” There is a time for all things; time for winds, for showers. The time of all for song is when success is achieved by help of toil; then 'tis a beginning of fame hereafter, a sworn warranty of great achievements. High above envy is dedicated this praise for Olympian victors. This glory my tongue would fain feed full, but 'tis God alone can give a heart of wisdom. This glory I can sing as an adornment over and above thy olive wreath and foster the name of the Lokrian stock. There revel, ye Muses, for I will be bound that it is an hospitable race, acquainted with beauty, wise to the highest point, and warlike. Nor fox nor lion changes nature.

The rhythms are Dorian (dactylo-epitrite). Leop. Schmidt remarks on the inferior impressiveness and majesty of the rhythms as compared with other poems. However that may be, the proportion of dactyls is unusually small, though about the same as in O. 12, which belongs to the period of full maturity. Böckh says: ad Lydiam declinat harmoniam.

The strophe sets forth the importance of the song, the antistrophe the divine calling of the poet, the epode the noble stock of the victor. Thus this brief poem contains all the elements of the e)pini/kion except the myth. To this effect, Mezger.

div3.head: Strophe
div3.p: e)/stin a)nqrw/pois , kte(.: Pindaric approach by parallels, of which the type is given O. 1 (init.). See also O. 3.42, and compare N. 3.6: diyh=| de\ pra=gos a)/llo me\n a)/llou, | a)qloniki/a de\ ma/list' a)oida\n filei=.
a)ne/mwn: The wind is not necessarily suggested by the voyage of Agesidamos, but wind suggests rain. In Greece navigation and agriculture go hand in hand. Hesiod puts agriculture first.
pai/dwn: A common personification; hence less felt, though not wholly effaced. See note on O. 8.1; N. 4.3; 9, 52.

pra/ssei: So with Christ for pra/ssoi. Schol., Hartung, Bergk have pra/ssh|, but P. prefers the pres. indic. in the generic condition. The opt. protasis with universal present in the apodosis occurs P. 1.81. 82; 8, 13. 14; I. 2, 33. 34, but the circumstances are somewhat different.

te/lletai: Cited as an example of the schema Pindaricum (agreement of a plural subject with a singular verb), of which there are very few examples in P. Here we read, with A, a)rxa/, and the example disappears. This syntactical figure gives no trouble when plural nouns are mixed with singulars or neuters — of course, disjunctives do not count, as P. 10.41, q. v. — nor much when the verb precedes, for the singular is the general and the plural the particular. Compare fr. IV. 3, 16. In P. 10.71 there is a various reading, kei=ntai for kei=tai, in P. 4.246, te/lesan for te/lesen. In Plat. Gorg. 500 D, for ei) e)/sti B has ei) e)stin, which points to e)sto/n (Hirschig). In Aischyl. Pers. 49 steu=tai rests on a correction of M; the other MSS. have steu=ntai.

pisto\n o(/rkion: “A certain pledge for mighty deeds of emprise.” Cf. N. 9.16: o(/rkion . . . pisto/n. These songs are to be the beginning of future renown and a witness to great achievements. They are called a pledge because they bind themselves to prove what has been done. On shifting genitive (lo/gwn) and dative (a)retai=s), see O. 6.5.

div3.head: Antistrophe
div3.p: a)fqo/nhtos: The gloss polufqo/nhtos shows that the word was a puzzle here. “Beyond the reach of envy,” Böckh after the Schol., who says that images may be taken down, but the hymn cannot be destroyed.
a)/gkeitai: The best MSS. have e)/gkeitai, but a)/gkeitai is established by the Schol. and the sense. The song is an a)na/qhma, O. 13.36; I. 4 (8), 17.
ta\ me/n: Schol.: tau=ta ta\ katorqw/mata kai\ ta\ e)gkw/mia tw=n e)n *)olumpi/a| nenikhko/twn. As often, me/n and de/ attack different members of the antithesis with chiastic effect, P. 1.21.
a(mete/ra: Plural of the chorus.

poimai/nein: “Tend,” “cherish,” “make our care.” Compare also
the use of boukolei=n. The figure is not to be pressed.
e)k qeou= de/: P. modestly acknowledges his dependence on God. Compare P. 1.41: e)k qew=n ga\r maxanai\ pa=sai brote/ais a)retai=s.

o(moi/ws: So von Leutsch, who has expiscated it out of the i)/sws kai\ au)tw=| tw=| tro/pw| (tw=| au)tw=| tr.) and o(moi/ws w(/sper kai\ su\ neni/khkas of the old Scholiasts. “We are fain to sing thy praise, but our success depends on God, as well as thine.” The old MSS. have o(mw=s w)=n, the interpolated e)saei/ after diapanto/s of the Schol. Mommsen reads: prapi/dessin: o(/mws w)=n i)/sqi, kte(.

div3.head: Epode
div3.p: e)pi\ stefa/nw|: “Over and above,” “topping.” So O. 3.6: xai/taisi . . . zeuxqe/ntes e)/pi ste/fanoi. Mommsen retains a)mfi/ of the Ambros.
xruse/as e)lai/as: xr. figurative. O. 8.1: xrusostefa/nwn a)e/qlwn, N. 1.17: fu/llois e)laia=n xruse/ois, P. 10.40: da/fna| xruse/a|.
a)le/gwn: “Caring for;” hence “praising,” u(mnw=n (Schol.).

u)/mmin: So Bergk and De Jongh after the Scholiasts, the MSS. mh/ min. The subject of a)fi/cesqai is “We,” “I and the Muses.” Compare Od. 12. 212: e)kfu/gomen kai/ pou tw=nde mnh/sesqai o)i/w (sc. h(ma=s). nin, in anticipation of strato/n, would be forced (in spite of O. 7.60); with reference to the return of Agesidamos to his home, unnatural.

mhde/: For the one neg., compare P. 10.41: no/soi d' ou)/te gh=ras. So. Phil. 771: e(ko/nta mh/t' a)/konta, Eur. Hec. 373: le/gousa mhde\ drw=sa . The neg. mh/, as after a verb of swearing (O. 2.102).

a)pei/raton kalw=n , kte(.: The Epizephyrian Lokrians well deserved this praise. For their poets — Xenokritos, Erasippos, Theano — see the classical dictionaries. The *lokrika\ a)/|smata reflected the passionate and erotic character of the people. The poems of Nossis, preserved in the Anthologia Palatina, are well worth study.
ai)xmata/n: Especially noted is their victory over the Krotoniates on the banks of the Sagra. Cf. O. 10 (11), 17.
to\ ga\r | e)mfue\s . . . vh=qos: The equable dactylo-epitrite rhythm allows this separation of article and substantive (Stein). Cf. O. 7.13 (?); 12, 5; P. 12.20.
a)lw/phc: This need not refer to a)kro/sofon. Perhaps only the lionpart holds. Still compare I. 3 (4), 65.

dialla/canto: “Change” (gnomic aor.). So with Lehrs, v. Wilamowitz-Moellendorff, Schröder (Am. Journ. of Phil. XII. p. 386). The MSS. dialla/cainto, “May change,” the so-called potential optative without a)/n. However, the examples commonly cited for this opt. in Pindar, N. 3.20; P. 11.50, cannot be considered stringent. O. 3.45, the opt. is imperative. In prose a)/n is necessary, and Hartung writes here: dialla/caint' a)\n h)=qos, which is forbidden by the digamma.

div2.p: Ergoteles of Himera, an exile from Knosos in Crete, won the do/lixos, Ol. 77 (472 B.C.). The do/lixos is variously estimated at seven, twelve, twenty, twenty-four stades, most accepting the last. Crete was famous for its runners ( Xen. An. 4, 8, 27: do/lixon de\ *krh=tes plei/ous h)\ e(ch/konta e)/qeon ), though the Cretans seldom took part in the Greek national games. After the victories mentioned in this ode (v. 17), Ergoteles won another Olympian (Ol. 78), and two Nemean contests (Paus. 6, 4, 11). The poem itself tells us that he had been driven from Crete by political faction, and as Sicily was the land of promise to the eastern Greeks, and especially those of Dorian stock, we may dispense with a closer investigation. From the Scholiast we learn that he arrived at Himera when a quarrel between Gelon and Hieron was at its height. Himera was hardly more quiet than his old home, but he succeeded in acquiring citizenship and the jealously guarded right of holding real estate.

The twelfth Olympian is a short occasional poem. It has no room for a myth, unless we consider the simile of the homefighting cock an equivalent (v. 14). The simple thought is the domination of Tyché. At the beck of Tyché ships are piloted on the deep, stormy wars and councils guided on land. Men's hopes are ships that roll through seas of idle plans, now high, now low. The future no god hath pledged, no man hath seen. The hoped-for pleasure is reversed, and from the battle with a sea of trouble men pass in a moment's space to joy profound (vv. 1-12).

So Philanor's son, like some home-fighting cock, would have had only homely fame, and the garland for the swiftness of his feet had shed its leaves unheralded, had no hostile faction bereft him of his Knosian fatherland. Now he hath gained a wreath at Olympia, two at Pytho, two on the Isthmus. Now he magnifies
the city of the Nymphs' hot baths. Now he dwells amid broad acres of his own (vv. 13-19).

The sea plays an important part in this ode, as might be expected for many reasons — the distance that separates Ergoteles from Olympia, the distance that separates his old home and his new. There is something symbolic of the vicissitudes of Fortune in the numerous antitheses. The poem rocks like a ship. The deep, the land — wars, councils — up, down — no pledge from God, no foresight of man — pleasure reversed, pain redeemed.
Himera and Ergoteles are paralleled. The city and the victor mirror each other. The fortune of Himera is the fortune of Ergoteles.

The rhythms are dactylo-epitrite. Böckh calls the mood a mixture of Dorian and Lydian. The parts of the triad are clearcut. The first deals with the domination of Tyché, the second reinforces the theme of the uncertainty of human plans, the third makes a practical and comforting application of these reflections to the case of Ergoteles.

div3.head: Strophe
div3.p: *zhno\s *)eleuqeri/ou: *zeu\s *)eleuqe/rios was honored in other Greek states, but esp. in Himera, on account of the great victory gained over the Carthaginians, and the new deliverance from the rule of Thrasydaios. See Introd. to O. 2.
eu)rusqene/a: Proleptic. Not used elsewhere in P. of a city.
a)mfipo/lei: “Keep thy sentry-round about.”

*sw/teira *tu/xa: Tyché, acc. to the Homeric Hymn in Cerer. 420 is a Nereid; acc. to Hesiod (Theog. 360), a daughter of Okeanos. Notice the sea atmosphere. Only acc. to Pindar himself (Paus. 7, 26, 8), T. is one of the *moi=rai.
ti/n: “At thy beck.” The dat. of interest is by implication the dat. of agency. Compare P. 1.73: a)rxw=| damasqe/ntes.

qoai/: qoo/s is used of actual speed, w)ku/s of inherent. “qoh\ nau=s, velox navis, a thing of life; w)kei=a nau=s, celeris navis, an expeditious conveyance.” Jebb, on Soph. Ai. 710. Ships refer to war and peace, then follows war (po/lemoi), then peace (a)gorai/). So the balance is prettily held.
po/lemoi: Seas of blood, through which Himera had passed.
ka)gorai\ . . . boulafo/roi: In public councils it was a formula to commence a)gaqh=| tu/xh| (Paley).
ai(/ ge me\n a)ndrw=n . . . e)lpi/des: Article and substantive are rhythmically near, though syntactically far removed. Cf. O. 11 (10), 19.
po/ll' a)/nw . . . ta\ de/: Adverbial, as N. 9.43. The lying world is ploughed by hopes as waves by ships.

metamw/nia=mete/wra kai\ ai)ro/mena (Schol.). The
waves of falsehood dash high and then fall back.
kuli/ndontai: Not kuli/ndonti=kuli/ndousi.

div3.head: Antistrophe
div3.p: su/mbolon: “Token,” “pledge.” The figure is not wholly dropped. We are now voyaging on a merchantman.
fradai/=gnw/seis. The plural in sympathy with tw=n mello/ntwn (= peri\ tw=n m.). See O. 9.21.
e)/pesen: Empiric aorist. The metaphor is from dice: a)ei\ ga\r eu)= pi/ptousin oi( *dio\s ku/boi. — 11.
e)/mpalin me\n te/ryios: Instead of the mechanical toi=s me/n. See v. 5. Compare O. 10 (11), 95: neo/tatos to\ pa/lin, P. 12.32: e)/mpalin gnw/mas=para\ gnw/man.
za/lais: Recurrence to the nautical figure.
baqu/: Cf. O. 7.53: kle/os baqu/, O. 13.62: baqu\n kla=ron. Familiar is baqu/ploutos. Still the adj. belongs to the sea sphere, proverbially rich. Cf. O. 2.32.
ph/matos: Genitive of price, “won joy for anguish.”
peda+/meiyan=meth/meiyan. peda/, Aeol. and Old Dor.= meta/. Etymological connection is denied.

div3.head: Epode
div3.p: e)ndoma/xas a(/t' a)le/ktwr: A breviloquence (= a(/t' e)ndoma/xou a)le/ktoros tima/) hardly noticeable in English. Villemain tells of a translator who agonized over the unpoetical coq, but be it remembered that the *persiko\s o)/rnis was really more poetical to the Greek than it can be made to us. Aischylos does not shun the comparison (Eum. 861). Cock-fights were popular in Greece. Pindar knew the cocks of Tanagra as well as he knew the poetess of Tanagra; the cock was sacred to Athena (Paus. 6, 26, 2), and Himera stamped her coin with a cock, acc. to some a pun on *(ime/oa (h(me/ra), acc. to others in honor of Asklepios.
a)kleh/s: Prolep tic.
katefulloro/hse: The tima/ thus becomes a flower. It has been noticed that P. draws few of his figures from the world of plants.
sta/sis a)ntia/neira: *a le/cis drimei=a according to Eustathios.
*knwsi/as: It has been inferred from this that the Knosians of that time did not take part in the Olympic games. Notice the sigmatism of the line.
stefanwsa/menos: O. 7.81.
di\s e)k: Mommsen writes die/k, as the Scholiasts know nothing of a second Pythian victory; but see Paus. 6, 4, 11.
qerma\ . . . loutra/: The glory of Himera, still there and called Termini.
basta/zeis=u(yoi=s. The figure is not fully felt, else it would be absurd. It is nothing more than e)paei/rein, O. 9.22. Compare I. 3 (4), 8: xrh\ de\ kwma/zont' a)ganai=s xaritessin basta/sai.
par' oi)kei/ais a)rou/rais: On para/ with dat., see O. 1.20, and compare further Od. 18. 383: ou(/neka pa\r pau/roisi kai\ ou)k a)gaqoi=sin o(milei=s. Characteristic is the stress laid on e)/gkthsis.

div2.p: The thirteenth Olympian commemorates the victory of Xenophon of Corinth in both stadion and pentathlon, Ol. 79 (464 B.C.). Xenophon's father, before him, had won a foot-race at Olympia, Ol. 69 (504 B.C.); hence trisolumpioni/kan oi)=kon (v. 1). Indeed, the whole house of the Oligaithidai, to which Xenophon belonged, was illustrious almost beyond compare in Greece for their successes at the different games. The wealth of the family is shown by Xenophon's vow to consecrate a hundred e(tai=rai as i(ero/douloi to Aphrodite, which liberality Pindar's e)rga/tis *moi=sa did not fail to glorify. See fr. IX. 1.
