The splendor and wealth of Corinth were proverbial, and as the seventh Olympian glitters with the light of the sun, so the thirteenth reflects the riches of a( o)lbi/a *ko/rinqos (v. 4). The first impression of the poem is that of a semi - Oriental bazaar. It seems to be profuse in the admired disorder of its wares. But there is, after all, a certain Greek symmetry. Victor and victor's city mirror each other as elsewhere (O. 12), and the hero of Corinth, Bellerophon, sums up the highest of both. For wealth and success, without wisdom, without courage, are vulgar. The sister spirits of Law, of Justice, of Peace, daughters of Right, are the guardians of Corinth's wealth (v. 7). The achievements of the games abroad are balanced by inventions at home (v. 17). The dithyramb first rose upon the air in Corinth. The bit that rules the horse was first planned in Corinth. The temple's summit first received the adornment of the king of birds in Corinth. Here are three great inventions matching Eunomia, Dika, and Eirena — matching the three Olympian victories of the Oligaithidai. The Muse with the sweet breath and Ares with his embattled hosts of youthful warriors are both at home in Corinth (v. 23).

If Corinth abounds in wealth, in art — if Corinth claims the
honor of invention, her sons prosper, too. Keep, O Zeus, the people unharmed, fill the sails of Xenophon with a favoring breeze. a(/pan d' eu(ro/ntos e)/rgon (v. 17) is true of him. He gained the pentathlon and the stadion in one day, which mortal man never attained before (v. 31). Then comes a long list of the victories of Xenophon and his house, until the poet finds himself in feud with many concerning the number of these honors, and swears that he cannot count the sands of the sea (v. 46). The time has come to put a bound, and so he returns to Corinth and tells the story of Bellerophon (vv. 63-92), forerunner of Xenophon — Bellerophon who mounted the height of heaven on a winged steed, so that it might have been said of him as of Xenophon: a)ntebo/lhsen | tw=n a)nh\r qnato\s ou)/pw tis pro/teron (v. 31).

The myth concluded, the poet again tries to sum up the achievements of the Oligaithidai in a few words, but the line stretches beyond his sight, ma/sson' h)\ w(s i)de/men (v. 113). Swim out of this sea of glory with nimble feet. In highest fortune, as in trembling suspense (O. 8), there is but one resource, and that is prayer. Zeus, Perfecter, give reverence with enjoyment (v. 115).
So the spirit of control regulates both the end and the beginning of the ode. The dominant thought is e(/petai d' e)n e(ka/stw| | me/tron (v. 47).
The measures are logaoedic.

The distribution of the five triads is not the common one. The first triad is devoted to Corinth, the second to Xenophon, the third and fourth to Bellerophon and his ancestors, the fifth to the Oligaithidai. Mezger calls attention to the fact that the subjects fall strictly within each triad. P. was evidently deepladen with his commission, which must have come from the whole house, whose praises he distributes as best he may. The later successes, Xenophon's and his father's, are put first; the earlier, those of the Oligaithidai generally, are put last.

div3.head: Strophe 1
div3.p: trisolumpioni/kan: Notice the pomp of the beginning. So also O. 10 (11), 1: to\n *)olumpioni/kan a)na/gnwte/ moi. Compare O. 2.1: a)nacifo/rmigges u(/mnoi, another grand opening. The opulent word suits the opulent (o)lbi/a) Corinth. Xenophon was victorious twice (v. 30), his father once (v. 35).

a)stoi=s: Cf. P. 3.70: basileu\s | prau+\s a)stoi=s, ou) fqone/wn a)gaqoi=s, cei/nois de\ qaumasto\s path/r. a). is more common than poli/ths in P., because a). is less technical and has to do
with the natural rather than the political position. The difference is briefly expressed in [Dem.] 59, 107: h(\n ou)/te oi( pro/gonoi a)sth\n kate/lipon ou)/q' o( dh=mos poli=tin e)poih/sato. It would not be safe to make a)stoi=s “the humbler citizens” here, although it would include them.
qera/ponta: A word involving kindly service. See P. 4.287.

gnw/somai: Disputed. The Schol. ei)s gnw=sin a)/cw, “I will make known,” for which gnw=nai (O. 6.89) is cited, but in vain. “I will learn to know Corinth,” means “I will visit Corinth.” So De Jongh. This is the language of one who had never seen Corinth and is to make the acquaintance of the city on this happy errand of praise. Of course this is figurative, as is kate/ban (O. 7.13).
o)lbi/an: Noted from Homel on, Il. 2. 570: a)fneio/n te *ko/rinqon.
pro/quron: As one comes from Olympia, Corinth is the entrance of the Isthmus. Bakchyl. says of Corinth: *pe/lopos lipara=s na/sou qeo/dmatoi qu/rai.
*poteida=nos: Compare N. 6.46: *poseida/nion te/menos (of the Isthmian games). The form *pot. is Corinthian (Fennell). See Cauer,^{2} No. 81.
a)glao/kouron: Refers only to men, and not to the polu/cenai nea/nides, a)mfi/poloi | *peiqou=s e)n a)fneiw=| *kori/nqw| of the famous skolion.

*eu)nomi/a . . . *di/ka . . . *ei)rh/na: The same genealogy is given in Hesiod, Theog. 901: deu/teron h)ga/geto (SC. *zeu\s) liparh\n *qe/min, h(\ te/ken *(/wras, | *eu)nomi/hn te *di/khn te kai\ *ei)rh/nhn teqalui=an. The seasons are distributed thus: Eunomia is preparation (seedtime); Dika, decision (harvest); Eirena, enjoyment (festival). The Horai preside over everything that needs timing (O. 4.1); they are the regulators of wealth, and prevent the growth of u(/bris, which owes its origin to the wedlock of baseness and prosperity. On the chryselephantine statues of Themis (standing) and the Horai (sitting) at Olympia, see Paus. 5, 17, 1.
kasignh/ta: Sing., not dual, as is shown by the apposition; see O. 6.45.
o(mo/trofos: With v. l. o(mo/tropos, “of like character.” This seems to require the MS. a)sfalh/s above. Much tamer than the reading given here.
tami/ai a)ndra/si: Slur-ai a)/n- into one. Mommsen writes ta/miai for the fem. (O. 14.9).
xru/seai: See O. 11 (10), 13.

div3.head: Antistrophe 1
div3.p: e)qe/lonti: Of a fixed purpose, P. 1.62; O. 11 (10), 9, and so of a wont.

*(/ubrin, *ko/rou mate/ra: Full personification to match the other. Theognis reverses the genealogy, v. 153: ti/ktei toi ko/ros u(/brin o(/tan kakw=| o)/lbos e(/phtai, but that makes little difference, as, according to Greek custom, grandmother and granddaughter often bore the same name. It is a
mere matter of u(/bris — ko/ros — u(/bris.

eu)qei=a: “Straightforward.” eu). with tolma, not acc. pl., as Mommsen says, with le/gein. to/lma is semi-personification, and the figure is not unlike that of O. 9.88, where to/lma is one of the two attendants P. desires to have on his progress. I have hosts of fair things to tell, and I must go straight to my errand. Such is my nature. The poet apologizes for plunging into the thick of his praises.
moi: Ethic dative.
u)/mmin de/: I am the singer, you and yours the recipients of the favors of the Horai.
*)ala/ta: Aletes was a Herakleid king of Corinth.
polla\ me\n, ... polla\ i(e/: Both are adverbial = polla/kis. Symmetry keeps the second polla/ from going with sofi/smata (v. 17).

u(perelqo/ntwn: The genitive absolute without a subject is denied for Homer. In P. the construction is to be watched. Undoubted, however, seem to be P. 8.43: w(=d' ei)=pe marname/nwn, and P. 4.232 (= N. 10.89): w(\s a)/r' au)da/santos. Here the shift from the dative to the genitive is easy, easier than making u(perelqo/ntwn depend on a)glai+/an.
i(eroi=s e)n a)e/qlois: O. 8.64: e)c i(erw=n a)e/qlwn.

div3.head: Epode 1
div3.p: a)rxai=a: “From the beginning.”

a(/pan d' eu(ro/ntos e)/rgon: This has a proverbial ring. “All the work belongs to the inventor” (i. e. the credit for it all). Often quoted. Best commented by an epigram on Thespis: muri/os ai)w\n polla\ proseurh/sei xa)/tera: ta)ma\ d' e)ma/ (Schneidewin).
tai\ *diwnu/sou ... xa/rites: Explained by the Schol. as ai( e(ortai\ ai( to\ e)pagwgo\n e)/xousai.

bohla/ta|: Refers to the prize of the victor in the dithyramb. Some think of the symbolical identification of Dionysos with the bull. See Hdt. 1, 23, for the history of the dithyramb, first performed in Corinth by Arion of Methymna during the reign of Periander. The Bacchic joyance is the main thing, and we must not hold P. to a strict account when he attributes the origin of the dithyramb, as he does elsewhere, acc. to the Schol., now to Naxos and now to Thebes.
ti/s ga/r: P. 4.70: ti/s ga\r a)rxa\, kte(.

i(ppei/ois e)n e)/ntessin me/tra : m. here is “check,” and so “bit,” as the Schol. explains: ta\ i(/ppeia me/tra tou= xalinou=. The myth turns on the praise of *)aqhna= *xalini=tis, who had a temple in Corinth, Paus. 2, 4, 5. The selection of the word points to a more perfect control gained by the Corinthian bit, not the out-and-out invention of it.

naoi=sin ... di/dumon: The words would seem to mean naturally that two eagles were
placed as a)krwth/ria, or “finials,” on the temples, one on either gable. The pediment was called a)eto/s, a)e/twma, and the Scholiast supposes that the name was due to the eagle here mentioned. Another explanation is that the Corinthians filled the pediments, naked before, with the figure of an eagle, which subsequently gave way to groups of statuary. The name a)eto/s for the gablefield is commonly referred to the resemblance of the pediment to an eagle with extended wings. Bekker, Anecd. p. 348, 3: a)etou= mimei=tai sxh=ma a)potetako/tos ta\ ptera/. See Aristoph. Av. 1110, and the passages there collected by Blaydes.
e)n de/: With a)nqei=, “And there.”
*moi=s' a(du/pnoos: We have no right to refer this with Dissen to the older poets and musicians of Corinth exclusively.
*)/arhs: The Corinthian helmet (Hdt. 4, 180), the Corinthian trireme (Thuk. 1, 13), are well known, and the story of Periander, the history of Corinth in the Persian war, may be read in Herodotos.

div3.head: Strophe 2
div3.p: u(/pate: With *)olumpi/as (Fennell). Compare Aisch. Ag. 509: u(/pato/s te xw/ras *zeu/s.
a)fqo/nhtos: Active, as neg. compounds of verbals in -to/s often are. Cf. O. 6.67: yeude/wn a)/gnwston.
a)fqo/nhtos ge/noio = mh\ nemesh/sh|s (Schol.). Hdt. 1, 32: to\ qei=on pa=n e)sti fqonero/n.
eu)/qune: Natural metaphor for a nautical Corinthian, O. 7.95.
dai/monos: The dai/mwn here is the dai/mwn gene/qlios (v. 105). See P. 5.122: *dio)s toi no/os me/gas kuberna=| | dai/mon' a)ndrw=n fi/lwn.

de/cai te/ voi: The dat. is used with de/casqai because the giver is interested as well as the receiver. When the giver is a god, he is waiting to be gracious. When he is a man, the acceptance of the present is an honor. See the Pindaric passages P. 4.23; P. 8.5; 12, 5; I. 5 (6), 4. Cf. Il. 2. 186: de/cato/ oi( skh=ptron.
e)gkw/mion teqmo/n: Cf. O. 7.88: teqmo\n *)olumpioni/kan.
a)/gei: The processional notion of the kw=mos comes out. This teqmo/s is also a polu/filos e(pe/tas (P. 5.4).

pentae/qlw|: The memorial verses of Simonides run: *)/isqmia kai\ *puqoi= *diofw=n o( *fi/lwnos e)ni/ka | (1) a(/lma, (2) podwkei/hn, (3) di/skon, (4) a)/konta, (5) pa/lhn. See a long discussion of the pe/ntaqlon in Fennell's ed. of the Nemean and Isthmian odes IX.-XX.
tw=n: See O. 2.25. The hyperbaton is easy with the demonstrative relative tw=n = w(=n.

div3.head: Antistrophe 2
div3.p:
seli/nwn: The Isthmian wreaths were at first made of pine, then of parsley (I. 2, 16; N. 4.88), then pine was restored.
The parsley of the Isthmian games was dry, of the Nemean green. Parsley had a funereal as well as a hymeneal significance.
ou)k a)nticoei=: Lit. “does not go against the grain,” ou)k e)nantiou=tai (Schol.).
*qessa/loio: Homer does not elide the o in -oio = ou. Cf. P. 1.39; N. 9.55; I. 1, 16.
ai)/gla podw=n: Cf. O. 12.15: tima\ podw=n. With ai)/gla compare P. 3.73: kw=mo/n t' a)e/qlwn *puqi/wn ai)/glan stefa/nois.
a)na/keitai: Cf. O. 11 (10), 8.
stadi/ou: Six hundred Olympic feet.
diau/lou: The double stadion, round the turning - post and back.
a)eli/w| a)mf' e(ni/: “Within the circuit of a single sun.” Here a)mfi/ has the peculiar inside use O. 2.33, “with only one sun about it.”
kranaai=s e)n *)a.: See O. 7.82.
e)/rga: “Victories,” “crowns of victory.”
podarkh\s | a(me/ra: The day sympathizes with the victor. Compare the Homeric dou/lion h)=mar.

div3.head: Epode 2
div3.p: *(ellw/tia: Depends on the general notion of gaining. If the exact verb of the previous sentence were to be supplied, we should have e(pta/. Athena Hellotis was honored in Corinth by a torch-race.
a)mfia/loisi *p. teqmoi=sin: The Isthmian games.
makro/terai , kte(.: “Too long would be the songs that shall keep up with the victories of,” etc. Similar self-checks are found P. 4.247; N. 10.45; I. 4 (5), 51.

*teryi/a|: Acc. to the Scholia, Terpsias was the brother of Ptoiodoros and so uncle of Thessalos (v. 35), Eritimos was son or grandson of Terpsias. To judge by Pindar, Ptoiodoros was father of Terpsias and Eritimos. The Scholia give two names not in P., but it is hardly worth while to attempt to reconcile the two accounts, or to explain the divergence.

xo/rtois e)n le/ontos: The Nemean games. Cf. N. 6.47: bota/na ... le/ontos. A dash, rather than a comma, after le/ontos would give the feeling of the passage: “As for all your achievements — I am ready to contend with many.” No matter how many come against me, I can always match them, as your victories are like the sands of the sea for multitude.
pontia=n ya/fwn a)riqmo/n: Compare O. 2.108: ya/mmos a)riqmo\n peripe/feugen.

div3.head: Strophe 3
div3.p: e(/petai: Used absolutely = e(po/meno/n e)stin, “is meet.” There is a limit to everything. The poet puts a bit in his own mouth. Compare v. 20. Enough of the house, now of the state.

noh=sai: Sc. to\ me/tron. So the Schol.: tou=to de\ au)to\ noh=sai to\ th=s summetri/as eu)/kairo/n te/ e)sti kai\ a)/riston. The central thought of the poem. Cf. Hes. O. et. D. 694: me/tra fula/ssesqai: kairo\s d' e)pi\ pa=sin a)/ristos .

vi/dios e)n koinw=| stalei/s: The metaphor is nautical; P. 2.62; 4, 3; N. 6.37: i)/dia naustole/ontes e)pikw/mia. In the fleet of the common joy, P. is an i)dio/stolos nau=s — one that is independent of the rest; he sails his own course of poetry (Kayser). His mission is to celebrate the victor's family, but he is to learn to know Corinth, he is to praise Corinth, he is to forget for a while the i)/dion in the koino/n.

mh=ti/n te ... po/lemo/n t': Afterwards distributed into *si/sufon me\n ... ta\ de/ pot' e)n a)lka=|. Compare Pindar's praise of Sparta, fr. XI. 62, 1: e)/nqa boulai\ gero/ntwn kai\ new=n a)nd\rw=n a)risteu/oisin ai)xmai/.
a)mfi\ *kori/nqw|: In prose peri\ *kori/nqou.

*si/sufon: Both Sisyphos (the Archwise) and Medeia (the Deviser) were held in higher esteem in Corinth than in most parts of Greece. *s. depends not so much on garu/wn as on the echo of it. See v. 40.
w(s qeo/n: The popular and false etymology of *si/sufos derived the name from sio/s = qeo/s and sufo/s = sofo/s, hence = qeo/sofos.

au)ta=|: ipsi, not au(ta=|, sibi. There is no compound reflexive in Pindar, as there is none in Homer. The middle and the emphatic pronoun show the unnaturalness of the action from the Greek point of view. The story of Medeia is told P. 4.218 foll.

div3.head: Antistrophe 3
div3.p: ta\ de\ kai/: Adverbial, compare O. 9.102. Two examples of wisdom are followed by a double line of martial deeds.
e)n a)lka=|: “In the fight,” closely connected with pro\ *darda/nou teixe/wn.

e)p' a)mfo/tera: There was Corinthian blood on both sides. The Trojan side, represented by Glaukos, grandson of Bellerophon (see note on v. 67), happened to be the more satisfactory, and hence P. turns that outward, according to his rule, P. 3.83.
maxa=n ta/mnein te/los: “Decide the issue of battles.”

to\n me\n ... *)atre/os: The Corinthians were vassals of Agamemnon, Il. 2. 570. Their leaders were not especially distinguished. Euchenor, the son of Polyidos, the Corinthian seer, chose death in battle rather than by disease, and fell by the hand of Paris, Il. 13. 663.
komi/zontes ... ei)/rgontes: Conative.

*glau=kon: Glaukos appears often enough in the ranks of the Trojans — a brave, but flighty fellow, Il. 6. 119 foll. (where he makes himself immortal by exchanging armor with Diomed, v. 236: xru/sea xalkei/wn, e(kato/mboi) e)nneaboi/wn); 7, 13; 12, 102 (summoned by Sarpedon to help him), 309; 14, 426; 16, 492; 17, 140.
*peira/nas: Peirene, a famous fountain in Akrokorinthos.
sfete/rou: See P. 4.83.
patro/s: “Ancestor.”
baqu/n: “Rich.” Compare baqu/ploutos.

div3.head: Epode 3
div3.p: *pa/gason: Homer says nothing of the Pegasos myth. P. follows local legends, which he seems everywhere to have studied carefully. Compare N. 7.105, *dio\s *ko/rinqos, with the commentators.
pri/n ge: “Until,” which the conjunction pri/n always means with the indic. O. 9.61.
xrusa/mpuka: Of the whole headstall.
e)c o)nei/rou d' au)ti/ka h)=n u(/par: “Out of a dream there was forth with reality,” the sober certainty of waking fact.
*ai)oli/da: The genealogy is Aiolos-Sisyphos-GlaukosBellerophon-Hippolochos-Glaukos. P. drops, or seems to drop, Hippolochos. See Il. 6. 144.
fi/ltron: So v. 85: fa/rmakon. Transl. “charm.”
*damai/w| ... patri/: “Tamer-father,” Poseidon, of whom Glaukos is the double.
nin: Anticipates tau=ron (rare in Pindar). See N. 5.38.

a)rga/enta: Black bulls are generally sacrificed to Poseidon, and the Scholiast is puzzled into explaining a)rga/enta as eu)qalh= kai\ me/gan, but in P. 4.205 red bulls are sacrificed to the same god, and P. was doubtless following local usage.

div3.head: Strophe 4
div3.p: knw/ssonti: Of sleep at once sweet and deep. The word is used of Penelope's slumber (Od. 4. 809), when she sees the vision of Athena, disguised as her sister, who addresses her: *eu(/deis, *phnelo/peia ...; just as Athena addresses Bellerophon.
a)na\ d' e)/palto = a)ne/palto: Sudden change of subject.
o)rqw=| podi/: Dat. of manner, though we tr. “to his feet, erect.”
*koirani/da|: Polyidos the seer; see note on v. 58.
a)po\ kei/nou xrh/sios: “At his bidding,” viz. that of Polyidos.

div3.head: Antistrophe 4
div3.p: kelh/sato: Sc. *polu/idos.
o(/tan: Repraesentatio (mood of the original speech), common in repeating laws, oracles, and the like.
kartai/poda: A Delphic word for bull (Schol.). Oracles had a vocabulary of their own, which was wide open to parody.
*gaiao/xw|: Compare O. 1.25: megasqenh\s gaia/oxos *poseida=n.
kou/fan: Predicative, “as a light (little) thing” = w(s kou=fo/n ti.
kti/sin: Here = e)/rgon, just as kti/sai is often = poih=sai.
kai\ o( kartero/s: Even the strong Bellerophon had failed, and now was glad to use the mild remedy.
fa/rmakon prau+/: A variation of fi/ltron, v. 68.
ge/nui: Dissyllabic.

div3.head: Epode 4
div3.p: e)no/plia ... e)/paizen: “He played the weaponplay.” So N. 3.44: a)/qure mega/la e)/rga.

*)amazoni/dwn: Comp O. 8.47: *)amazo/nas eu)i/ppous, where they are represented as favorites
of Apollo.
ai)qe/ros yuxra=s: On the gender compare O. 1.7: e)rh/mas di' ai)qe/ros. “Chill,” on account of the height.
ko/lpwn: “Bosom of the ether,” with as much right as the “deep bosom of the ocean.” Shakespeare's “bosom of the air,” R. and J. ii. 2 (Cookesley).
e)rh/mwn: So with Hermann for e)rh/mou.

*xi/mairan: In Homer (Il. 6. 179 foll.) the order is different. The king of Lykia bids him slay the Chimaira first (h( d' a)/r' e)/hn qei=on ge/nos ou)d' a)nqrw/pwn: | pro/sqe le/wn, o)/piqen de\ dra/kwn, me/ssh de\ xi/maira), then he attacked the Solymoi, and finally slew (kate/pefnen) the Amazons. Purposeful variation.
pu=r pne/oisan: Il. 6. 182: deino\n a)popnei/ousa puro\s me/nos ai)qome/noio.
*solu/mous: Not an anticlimax. The name of this mountain-folk of Lykia was enough, according to Homer, Il. 6. 185: karti/sthn dh\ th/n ge ma/xhn fa/to du/menai a)ndrw=n.
diaswpa/somai : swp-for siwp- (Aeolic).
voi: Dependent on the verbal element in mo/ron.

mo/ron: He fell from his winged steed when attempting to fly to heaven, and was crippled. Homer says of him simply, Il. 6. 201: h)= toi o( ka\p pedi/on to\ *)alh/ion oi)=os a)la=to | o(\n qumo\n kate/dwn, pa/ton a)nqrw/pwn a)leei/nwn.
de/kontai: Not historical present, “are his shelter.”

div3.head: Strophe 5
div3.p: e)me\ d' eu)qu\n a)ko/ntwn, kte(.: The poet checks himself again. He has darts enough (cf. O. 2.91: polla/ moi u(p' a)gkw=nos be/lh), but he has a definite aim (O. 2.98: e)/pexe nu=n skopw=| to/con), and would not speed too many darts beside the mark (P. 1.44: a)gw=nos e)/cw). The figures grow out of toco/tan ... strato/n.
ta\ polla\ b.: “These many,” “all these.”

kartu/nein xeroi=n: “To speed with all the vigor of my two hands.” Notice the dual noun xeroi=n, so rare in P. See O. 6.45. But such duals crop out even in post-classic Greek, where the dual is practically dead.

ga/r: Accounts for ta\ polla\ be/lea. P. was evidently embarrassed by the instructions he had received, and took care to distribute the masses by taking up the victor in the first part and the victor's fratri/a, the Oligaithidai, in the third.
e)/ban: O. 9.89: h)=lqon | tima/oros, N. 4.74: ka=ruc e(toi=mos e)/ban.

*)isqmoi=: The poet is often spoken of as being present at the scene of the victory, so that it is unnecessary to supply ta/ from what follows. N. 9.43; P. 1.79. So Mezger, with whom I read pau/rw| g' e)/pei.
a)qro/a: He cannot go into details.
e)/corkos: “Under oath.” e)/. is a peculiar word (e)/corkos i)di/ws, says the old Schol.), but that is no reason for changing it into e(/corkos (“six-times sworn”) with Christ ap. Mezger.
e)pe/ssetai: “Will add confirmation.”

e(chkonta/ki: With a(du/glwssos, which involves speaking, “with its sixty-fold sweet messages.” They had overcome sixty times, thirty times in each of the two places, unless e(c. is merely a round number.
a(du/glwssos: Notice the short u before gl.

div3.head: Antistrophe 5
div3.p: h)/dh pa/roiqe: The only Olympian victories scored were those mentioned in the beginning.
to/te: When the time comes.
dai/mwn gene/qlios: See v. 28.
e(/rpoi: We should say “have free course.” On the opt. see O. 1.115.
*)enuali/w|: Supposed to refer to a family cult. A mere guess.

a)na/|sswn: Looks very much like a)na/sswn, a gloss to a)/nac. Bergk reads *)arka/si (ba/ssais). Still we may compare Homer's a)nade/drome pe/trh. This king-altar might look as if it were leaping into the air, on account of its commanding position on Mt. Lykaion, from which almost all the Peloponnesos was visible. See Paus. 8, 38, 5.
*lukai/ou: Sc. *dio/s.

div3.head: Epode 5
div3.p: *pe/llana: In Achaia, O. 7.86.
*sikuw/n: N. 9.1.
*me/gara: O. 7.86.
*ai)akida=n ... a)/lsos: Aigina, O. 7.86.
*)eleusi/s: O. 9.106.
lipara\ *maraqw/n: O. 9.95.
tai/ q' u(p' *ai)/tnas: At Aitna and Syracuse.

*eu)/boia: The names of the games at the different localities are given as follows: At Argos, Heraia or Hekatombaia; at Thebes, Herakleia and Iolaia; at Pellene, Diia, Hermaia, Theoxenia; at Sikyon, Pythia; at Megara, Diokleia, Pythia, Nemea, and Alkathooia; in Aigina, Aiakeia, Heraia, Delphinia, or Hydrophoria; at Eleusis, Eleusinia, Demetria; at Marathon, Herakleia; at Aitna, Nemea; at Syracuse, Isthmia, as at Corinth; in Euboia, Geraistia (in honor of Poseidon), Amarynthia (in honor of Artemis), Basileia.
ma/sson' h)\ w(s i)de/men: First appearance of this construction. “Stretching beyond the reach of sight.”
a)/na = a)ll' a)/ge: “Up!” The poet addresses himself.
e)kneu=sai: Imperative infin. “Swim out” of this sea of victories, which is to P. a sea of troubles, even if they are sweet troubles (O. 1.19).
*zeu= te/leie: Compare P. 1.67: *zeu= te/lei'. The special cult is supposed to have been brought from Corinth to her daughter, Syracuse, and thence to Aitna.

ai)dw= di/doi: Moderation is needed in this flood of prosperity. The poem closes with a wish for singer and for victor, as does O. 1. The poet wishes for himself a happy discharge of his perplexing task (e)kneu=sai), for the victor the enjoyment of the fruits of his victory, which can only be assured by ai)dw/s.

div2.p: Orchomenos, in Boeotia, was a very ancient city, the home of the famous Minyai (v. 4), where the Charites were worshipped from the earliest times. The poem, as we have it, contains scarcely more than an invocation and exaltation of the Charites, and an announcement of the Olympian victory of the boy Asopichos, who won the single-dash foot-race, Ol. 76 (476 B.C.). This victory Echo is bidden report to the father of Asopichos, who is now in the abode of Persephone. While the poem closes well, the massive structure of the strophe gives the piece the effect of a torso.
The song is supposed to have been sung in a procession (kou=fa bibw=nta, v. 17) to the temple of the Charites for the dedication of the wreath.

The metres are logaoedic. The mood is said by the poet himself to be Lydian (v. 17). The soft Lydian measure was especially suited to boys' voices (pre/pei th=| tw=n pai/dwn h(liki/a|, Aristot. Pol., end, p. 1342 b 32), and was in favorite use for prayers and plaints, and consequently well adapted to the close of the poem, in which the dead father of the victor is mentioned.
Poets have admired the ode greatly — while editors have complained of its difficulties.

div3.head: Strophe 1
div3.p: *kafisi/wn: On this Kephisos, see Strabo 405. 407. It was a common river-name, and is found in Attika, Salamis, Sikyon, Skyros, Argolis.

laxoi=sai ai(/te: Bergk writes tai/te for ai(/te of the MSS., which Mommsen defends, -ai in laxoi=sai being shortened, as often in dactylic poetry. The Pindaric passages cited by Mommsen (P. 5.72, and 8, 96) have been emended, the latter with good warrant. Böckh reads laxoi=san. On the lot (la/xos), compare O. 7.58.

kalli/pwlon: On account of the pasturage. Compare the praise of the Attic Kephisos in Sophokles,
O. C. 668: eu)i/ppou, ce/ne, kte(. , and 677: eu)/ippon, eu)/pwlon .

lipara=s : l. is used of Thebes, P. 2.3. Elsewhere of Athens, N. 4.17; I. 2, 20; and in the famous fragment IV. 4: w)= tai\ liparai\ kai\ i)oste/fanoi kai\ a)oi/dimoi, | *(ella/dos e)/reisma, kleinai\ *)aqa=nai, daimo/nion ptoli/eqron.
*)orxomenou=: Mommsen has *)erxomenou=, the local form, after Cavedoni. The change is advocated by van Herwerden also.
*minua=n: Minyas was the son of Poseidon and Kallirrhoë. His descendants, the Minyans, were the Vikings of Greek legend.

ta/ te terpna\ kai\ | ta\ gluke/a: te ... kai/ is usually employed to couple opposites or complements, as Mommsen notes. If to\ terpno/n is the transient diversion (Schmidt, Synonym.), and to\ gluku/ the immanent sweetness, there would be enough difference to justify the combination.
a)/netai: So Kayser for gi/netai.
brotoi=s: “For,” only incidentally “by.” The Schol. correctly gi/netai kai\ sumbai/nei.
sofo/s: “Skilled in song.” See O. 1.9. 116.
a)glao/s: Of victory, which is often represented as sheen (compare O. 13.5: a)glao/kouron, 14: a)glai+/an), and Aglaïa is one of the Graces.

a(gna=n: So Kayser, to save the metre; the MSS. semna=n: cf. fr. VI. 1: semna=n *xari/twn me/lhma terpno/n, and Eur. Hel. 134: semnai\ *xa/rites . For a(gna=n, see Sappho, fr. 65 (Bgk.): a)/gnai *xa/rites, and Alkaios, fr. 62 (Bgk.).
*xari/twn a)/ter: See P. 2.42.
ou)de\ ... koirane/oisin x. = ou)de\ koirane/oisin ou)/te xorou\s ou)/te dai=tas. The first neg. omitted. See O. 11 (10), 17. k. = diakosmou=si (Schol.), “consent to be the lords” (kosmh/tores).

tami/ai: Mommsen inclines to ta/miai, a theoretical fem. form. Cf. O. 13.7: *di/ka kai\ o(mo/trofos *ei)rh/na tami/ai plou/tou, and Eur. Med. 1415: pollw=n tami/as *zeu\s e)n *)olu/mpw| . Even in prose, Isok. 11, 13: tw=n o)/mbrwn kai\ tw=n au)xmw=n o( *zeu\s tami/as e)sti/n.
qe/menai ... qro/nous: Leop. Schmidt suspects the statement of the Schol. that the thrones of the Muses were placed at the right hand of Apollo in Delphi.
a)e/naon ... tima/n: a). is more poetic as a proleptic adj. than as an adverb. *kafi/sia u(/data calls up the image of u(/data a)ena/onta. The honor of Zeus is “as a river.”

div3.head: Strophe 2
div3.p: po/tni) *)aglai+/a: Aglaïa was especially the mistress of victory (see v. 7), as Thaleia presided especially over feasts (kw=moi). The three Graces were first fixed by Hesiod, Theog. 909: *)aglai+/hn te kai\ *eu)frosu/nhn *qali/hn t' e)rateinh/n.
filhsi/molpe ... e)rasi/molpe: As one might shift from filei=n to e)ra=n, the weaker to the stronger. Toying with synonyms was not impossible for P.

qew=n krati/stou: Zeus was the father, Eurynome,
an Okeanid, the mother, acc. to Hesiod (Theog. 907).

e)pakooi=te nu=n: So Bergk and Mommsen (for e)pa/kooi nu=n of the MSS.) from a supposed e)phkoe/w, not an attractive formation. Other conjectures are: e)pa/kooi tanu=n, Herm., Dissen, but we must have imperative or optative; e)pa/koos geneu=, Herm., Böckh, Schneidewin.
kou=fa bibw=nta: So Hom. Il. 13. 158: kou=fa posi\ probiba/s.
*)asw/pixon: Diminutive from *)aswpo/s.

*ludw=| ... e)n tro/pw|: Mommsen recognizes a kind of e(\n dia\ duoi=n, to which figure P., indeed, comes nearer than does any other Greek poet, but tro/pw| is “the tune,” and mele/tais is the verse. “With Lydian tune and meditated lays.” e)n, of the flute, O. 5.19; 7, 12; N. 3.79; of the cithern, P. 2.69; I. 4 (5), 27.
e)/molon: See O. 7.13: kate/ban.
*minu/eia: Aeolic accentuation, as in *ku/kneia, O. 10 (11), 17. Orchomenos is so called to distinguish it from the Arkadian city of the same name.
seu= ve/kati: Thaleia, not because she is korufai/a generally, but because this is the kw=mos, of which she has special charge.

e)lqe/, vaxoi=: Ahrens writes e)/luq', metri causa. With the passage compare O. 8.81, where *)alleli/a, a daughter of Hermes, is supposed to discharge the same office. Echo belongs to the Orchomenian sphere, by reason of her passion for Narkissos, son of Kephisos.
*kleo/damon: Father of Asopichos.
o)/fr' i)doi=sa: v lost.
ui(o\n ... o(/ti: Prolepsis for o(/ti ... ui(o/s. Compare P. 9.121.
ko/lpois par' eu)do/cois: So Bergk for eu)do/coio. On para/, see O. 1.20.
e)stefa/nwse: The middle (O. 7.15), though natural, is not necessary. xai/tan represents e(\ au)to/n. So P. 10.40: ko/mas a)nadh/santes.
pteroi=si: Cf. P. 9.135: polla\ de\ pro/sqen ptera\ de/cato *ni/kas. Wreaths are wings, because they bear the champion aloft, e)paei/ronti (O. 9.23).

div2.p: The victory commemorated in this poem was gained Pyth. 29, i. e. Ol. 76, 3 (474 B.C.). Hieron had himself proclaimed as a citizen of Aitna in order to please the city founded by him, Ol. 76, 1 (476 B.C.), to take the place of Katana. In the same year he had gained a victory over the Etruscans off Cumae, thus crowning the glory of the battle of Himera. The great eruption of Aitna, which began Ol. 75, 2 (479 B.C.), and continued several years, figures largely in this poem, which has been much admired and often imitated, notably by Gray in his “Progress of Poesy.”

Pindar's poems are constellations. There are figures as in the heavens, a belt, a plough, a chair, a serpent, a flight of doves, but around them clusters much else. The Phorminx is the name of the constellation called the first Pythian. In the first part of the poem the lyre is the organ of harmony, in the second the organ of praise. In the first part everything is plain. Apollo and the Muses are to the Greek the authors of all harmony, artistic, political, social, spiritual. The lyre, as the instrument of Apollo, is the symbol of the reign of harmony over the wide domain of Zeus. Everything that owes allegiance to Zeus obeys his son Apollo, obeys the quivering of the lyre's strings. So the footstep of the dancer, the voice of the singer. Even the thunderbolt, the weapon of Zeus, is quenched, the bird of Zeus slumbers, the wild son of Zeus, violent Ares, sleeps a deep sleep. This is the art of the son of Leto and the deep-bosomed Muses (vv. 1-12).

All those that Zeus hath claimed as his own are ruled by harmony. Not so those that he loves not. When they hear the sound of the Pierides, they strive to flee along the solid earth and the restless main. So he who now lies in dread Tartaros, enemy of the gods, Typhon, reared in the famed Kilikian cave. His hairy breasts are pinched by the high sea-shores of Kymé
and Sicily, and Aitna's heaven-mounting column pinions him — Aitna, nurse of keen snow, from whose inmost recesses belch purest streams of unapproachable fire, rivers that roll sparkling smoke by day, while purple flame by night bears in its whirl masses of stone down to the surface of the deep, plashing. These jets of fire are upflung by yon monster. Terrible are they — a marvel to behold, a marvel even to hear from those that have beheld. Such a creature is that which lies bound by peak and plain, while his back is goaded by his craggy couch (vv. 13-28).

May we not be of those thou lovest not, may we find favor in thy sight, O Zeus, lord of Aitna's mount — the forehead of this fruitful land, whose namesake neighbor city the famed founder glorified when the herald proclaimed her in the Pythian course by reason of Hieron's noble victory with the chariot. As men who go on shipboard count as the first blessing a favoring wind, an omen of a happy return, so we count from this concurrence that the city will henceforth be renowned for wreaths of victory and chariots, her name be named mid banquet-songs. Lykian and Delian lord, thou that lovest the Kastalian fount of Parnasos, make this purpose good, make the land a land of men (vv. 2940).

So far Apollo and the Muses dominate — dominate as the interpreters of Zeus. Now Zeus himself comes forward. Apollo is mentioned no more, but the prayer to him, v. 40, is matched by a prayer to the Muse in v. 58.

Zeus, Apollo, the Muses, have now led us up to the praise of Hieron. The achievements of mortals are all due to the gods. Men are bards; are valiant and eloquent through them (v. 41); and so, through them, Hieron has the virtues of his high position, and all the so-called counsels addressed to him are merely indications of what he is, or thinks he is, or tries to be. In praising his hero Pindar picks out first the quality that had recently distinguished him, and this success was won qew=n pala/mais (v. 48). The future lacks nothing but forgetfulness of toils and pains. Greater prosperity, greater wealth, it cannot give. It can only administer (ou(/tw, v. 46). When the forgetfulness of the bitter past comes, then the memory of all the glorious achievements of war, with all its proud wealth, will return. May our hero, like Philoktetes of old (v. 50), have a god to be his friend and benefactor. But the song is not for Hieron alone. His son, Deinomenes (v. 58), shares the joy in the victory of his sire; his son is
king of the city Aitna, which Hieron built for him, founding it with god-sent freedom in the laws of Doric stock, after the principles of Doric harmony (v. 65). May this harmony between people and princes abide, and may father pass to son the keynote of concordant peace (v. 79) — peace within and peace from barbaric foes without. Zeus keep the Phoenician and the Tyrrhenian battle-shouts at home, now that they have seen the fell destruction of their ships, the punishment of their insolence, before Kymé — that weight that rests upon Typhon's breast. For what Salamis to Athens, what Plataia to Sparta, that to the sons of Deinomenes is the day of Himera (v. 80).

But brevity is best. Twist the strands tight. Less, then, will be the blame, for surfeit dulleth the edge of expectation. Others' blessings and advantages are a hateful hearing; yet envy is better than pity. Hold, Hieron, to thy high career. Still guide the people with a just helm. Still be thy word forged on the anvil of truth. No sparkle of dross that flieth past is without its weight, coming from thee. Steward of many things thou art. Faithful witnesses there are many for right and wrong. Firm abide in generous temper. Wax not weary in expenditure. Let thy sail belly to the wind. Let no juggling gains lure thee. After mortals liveth fame alone as it revealeth the lives of the departed to speakers and to singers. Kroisos' generous kindliness perisheth not. The cruel soul of Phalaris — brazen-bull-burner — is whelmed by hating bruit; no harps beneath the roof-tree receive him to soft fellowship with warbling boys. Good fortune is first; then good fame. Whoso hath chanced on both and made both his own hath received the highest crown (vv. 81-100).
The mood is Dorian, the rhythms dactylo-epitrite.

Of the five triads, the first two deal with harmony; the third and the fourth have to do with Hieron's work as a founder, his work as a warrior, with the sweet music of a concordant state, the sweet silence from the barbaric cry, have to do with Aitna and Himera. The last triad avoids the weariness of praise by disguising it under sage counsel, with the intimation that Hieron has not only been prosperous, but has gained the fair voices of the world.

div3.head: Strophe 1
div3.p: xruse/a fo/rmigc: Cf. Hes. Scut. Hercl. 202: i(mero/en kiqa/rize *dio\s kai\ *dhtou=s ui(o\s | xrusei/h| fo/rmiggi, N. 5.24: fo/rmigg' *)apo/llwn e(pta/glwsson xruse/w| pla/ktrw| diw/kwn.
i)oploka/mwn: Cf. O. 6.30: pai=da vio/plokon. Our violet is the i)/on me/lan of the Greeks, and “black” is the nearest translation of io-.
su/ndikon ... kte/anon: “Joint possession.”
ba/sis: The dancer's foot listens and obeys the throb of the cithern.
a)oidoi/: The singers of the chorus.
prooimi/wn: “Preludes.”
a)mbola\s teu/xh|s = a)nabola\s poih=|, a)naba/llh|. Cf. Od. 1. 155: h)/ toi o( formi/zwn a)neba/lleto kalo\n a)ei/dein.
e)lelizome/na: “Quivering.” O. 9.14: fo/rmigg' e)leli/zwn.
ai)xmata\n kerauno/n : ai). better as a subst. than as an adjective. k. is personified, “spearwielder Thunderbolt.”
a)ena/ou puro/s: So a)/nqema xrusou= (O. 2.79).
a)na\ ska/ptw| *dio/s: The eagle on the sceptre of Zeus is a familiar figure. Compare So. fr. 766: o( skhptoba/mwn ai)eto\s ku/wn *dio/s.
w)kei=an: Of the inherent quality. See note on O. 12.3. Contrasting epithet to heighten xala/cais.

div3.head: Antistrophe 1
div3.p: a)rxo\s oi)wnw=n: Cf. O. 13.21: oi)wnw=n basile/a.
a)gku/lw| krati/: Od. 19. 538: ai)eto\s a)gkuloxei/lhs.
knw/sswn: This is a deep sleep with fair visions. See O. 13.71.
u(gro\n nw=ton: The feathers rise and fall like waves on the back of the sleeping bird in response to his breathing.
r(ipai=si : r(. often of winds and waves. So P. 4.195: kuma/twn r(ipa\s a)ne/mwn te.
katasxo/menos = katexo/menos. There is no aor. feeling. Cf. Od. 11. 334: khlhqmw=| d' e)/sxonto, and Thompson's notes on Plat. Phaidr. 238 D, 244 E.
biata\s *)/arhs: To match ai)xmata\n kerauno/n above.
i)ai/nei: With qumo/n, O. 7.43. “Lets his heart (himself) dissolve in deep repose.”
kh=la: Compare O. 1.112; 2, 91; 9, 5-12; I. 4 (5), 46 for the same metaphor.
a)mfi/: With the peculiar poetic use, rather adverbial than prepositional. “With the environment of art,” “by virtue of.” So P. 8.34: e)ma=| a)mfi\ maxana=|.
baquko/lpwn: Like baqu/zwnos, of stately and modest beauty. The deep girdle and the deep folds might be due to amplitude or to dignity, or both. baqu/kolpos of Mother Earth, P. 9.101.

div3.head: Epode 1
div3.p: pefi/lhke: Emotional perfect = pres., though on the theory that fi/los means “own,” p. = “hath made his own.”
a)tu/zontai: On the concord, see O. 2.92; O. 10 (11), 93. The neuter o(/ssa conjures up strange shapes.
boa/n: Of music. O. 3.8; P. 10.39; N. 5.38.

ga=n: a)maima/keton with po/nton throws up as a complementary color sterea/n, “solid,” with ga=n. For
a)maima/keton, “furious,” “restless,” see Il. 6. 179, where it is used of the Chimaira. The sea is the favorite haunt of monsters.
kata/: On k. with the second member, see O. 9.94.
ai)na/| *tarta/rw|: So *)isqmo/s is fem. in P. O. 8.48; N. 5.37; I. 1, 32.

*tufw/s: See Il. 2. 782, where his bed is said to be ei)n *)ari/mois, which is in Kilikia. Cf. Aisch. P. V. 351: to\n ghgenh= te *kiliki/wn oi)kh/tora ... e(katogka/ranon ... *tufw=na . In this passage, too long to quote entire, Prometheus prophesies the eruption in language that seems to be a reflex of Pindar's description.
*kili/kion ... a)/ntron: P. 8.16: *tufw\s *ki/lic.
poluw/numon = poluqru/lhton.

u(pe\r *ku/mas: Behind and above — not immediately over. The whole region is volcanic. Ischia, the ancient Pithekussa, where Hieron established a colony, was rudely shaken by an earthquake in 1880, almost destroyed in 1883.
ki/wn ... ou)rani/a: Aisch. P. V. 349: ki/on' ou)ranou= te kai\ xqono\s | w)/moin e)rei/dwn.
pa/netes ... tiqh/na: t. is adjective enough to take an adverb.
tiqh/na: Kithairon is xionotro/fos, Eur. Phoen. 803.

div3.head: Strophe 2
div3.p: e)reu/gontai me\n ... potamoi\ de/: Aisch. P. V. 367: e)kragh/sontai/ pote | potamoi\ puro/s.
a(gno/tatai: The commentators see in this epithet Pythagorean reverence of fire. The reverence of fire is Indo-European. For me\n ... de/, see O. 11 (10), 8.
pagai/: potamoi/ ... krounou/s: All carefully used. pagai/, “well up,” potamoi/, “roll,” krounoi/ are “shot up” in jets.
a(me/raisin ... e)n o)/rfnaisin: Cf. O. 1.2: nukti\ ... e)n a(me/ra|.
baqei=an: Measured from the top of the mountain. “Far below.”
su\n pata/gw|: Effective position.
*(afai/stoio: This personification was not so vivid to the Greek as it is to us. See note on P. 3.39.
te/ras ... qauma/sion proside/sqai: For the inf., compare I. 3 (4), 68: o)noto\s me\n i)de/sqai. qau=ma i)de/sqai is a common Homeric phrase.

qau=ma de\ kai\ pareo/ntwn a)kou=sai: kai/ is naturally “even,” and goes with a)kou=sai. “It is a marvel of marvels to see, a marvel even to hear.” This makes proside/sqai refer to the flo/c, the a)kou=sai to the su\n pata/gw|. So Schneidewin. pareo/ntwn (for which we have the variant pario/ntwn) is genitive absolute without a subject, “when men are present.” P. uses the construction somewhat charily (see note on O. 13.15), and Cobet's par' i)do/ntwn, “to hear of from those who have seen,” would be seductive in prose. P. does not happen to use para/ thus.

div3.head: Antistrophe 2
div3.p: oi(=on: Exclamatory, O. 1.16.

strwmna/: The
bed of the monster is ai)na\ *ta/rtaros, v. 15.
ei)/h, *zeu=, ti\n ei)/h: Asyndeton is common and natural in prayers (see O. 1.115), and so is the suppression of the dative (h(mi=n).

me/twpon: The mountain rises from the plain as the forehead from the face. The transfer of the designations of parts of the body to objects in nature is so common as not to need illustration. Whatever original personifying power this transfer may have had seems to have faded out in Greek poetry (Hense, Adolf Gerber).
tou= ... e)pwnumi/an: Cf. O. 10 (11), 86: e)pwnumi/an xa/rin | ni/kas a)gerw/xou.
*puqia/dos d' e)n dro/mw|: Dissen compares O. 1.94: ta=n *)olumpia/dwn e)n dro/mois, but there ta=n *)o. depends on kle/os.
a)ne/eipe: “Proclaimed.”
u(pe/r: “By reason of.”
kallini/kou | a(/rmasi: P. 11.46: e)n a(/rmasi kalli/nikoi.

div3.head: Epode 2
div3.p: nausiforh/tois: “Seafaring.” P. refers to a belief of the craft. In this case a good beginning makes a good ending.
e)s plo/on ... ou)=ron: Connected by the rhythm.
e)oiko/ta: “Likelihoods” for “likelihood” Cf. O. 1.52: a)/pora, P. 2.81: a)du/nata, P. 4.247: makra/.

tuxei=n: In Thukyd. also the regular construction of ei)ko/s is the aor. inf., never the fut. 1, 81, 6: ei)ko\s *)aqhnai/ous ... mh/te ... douleu=sai mh/te kataplagh=nai . So 1, 121, 2; 2, 11, 8; 3, 10, 6, al.
o( de\ lo/gos: “This (faithful) saying.”
tau/tais e)pi\ cuntuxi/ais: “With this good fortune to rest on.”
do/can: “Belief.”
loipo/n: So loipo\n ai)ei/, P. 4.256. — nin = po/lin.
su\n eu)fw/nois q.: “'Mid tuneful revels.”
*lu/kie: So Hor. Od. 3, 4, 61: Delius et Patareus Apollo , Patara being in Lykia. In solemn invocations the gods are appealed to by names which remind them of their favorite abodes.
*da/loi' a)na/sswn: The participle here and in file/wn is almost substantive. For the elision of *da/loi', see O. 13.35.

e)qelh/sais: “Deign.” P. uses bou/lomai but once (fr. VIII. 1). Attic distinctions do not always apply to the earlier period, but be it noted that e)qe/lw or qe/lw is the higher word; hence regularly qeou= qe/lontos.
tau=ta: The implied wishes and hopes.
no/w|: Local dative, the range of which is narrower even in poetry than is commonly supposed.
eu)/andron: tiqe/men must be understood with this as well as with no/w|. A slight zeugma, t. being there “put” or “take,” and here “make.” Herm. reads eu)androu=n.

div3.head: Strophe 3
div3.p: maxanai/: Sc. ei)si, “ways and means.”
a)retai=s: “Achievements.”

sofoi/: Specifically of poets. Cf. O. 1.9;
P. 1.12; N. 7.23. P. is thinking of his class in sofoi/, the biatai\ and peri/glwssoi being put in another by the force of te.
peri/glwssoi: Supposed to refer to the rhetorical school of Korax, who began his career under Hieron. See O. 2.96.
e)/fu^n: Gnomic aorist. P. identifies fu/sis with qeo/s. See O. 9.107. 111.

mh\ ... balei=n: e)/lpomai takes mh/ as involving wish; balei=n may be fut. (cf. P. 10.55) or aor. (N. 4.92). The negative favors the aor. (mh\ ba/loimi). P. 4.243 the neg. ou)ke/ti indicates the reading pra/cesqai.

xalkopa/ra|on: N. 7.71: a)pomnu/w mh\ te/rma proba\s a)/konq' w(=te xalkopa/ra|on o)/rsai qoa\n glw=ssan. The tongue, which P. handles boldly, is the missile here also. Being a javelin, it is forged, v. 86. See O. 6.82.
w(sei/te: The ellipsis (w(sei/ tis ba/loi) is hardly felt. Cf. O. 6.2: w(s o(/te.
a)gw=nos ... e)/cw: “Outside of the lists,” so as not to count.
pala/ma|: See P. 3.57.
a)meu/sasq(ai): “Surpass.” Cf. P. 6, end.
a)nti/ous: Supposed to refer to Simonides and Bakchylides. It is conjectured that there was to be a contest of poets.
ei) ga\r ... eu)qu/noi: A wish that runs over into a condition. See O. 1.108.
o( pa=s xro/nos: All time to come, O. 6.56; N. 1.69.
ou(/tw: “As heretofore.”
eu)qu/noi: Cf. N. 2.7: eu)qupompo\s ai)w/n. The nautical image was still in the poet's eye. Cf. v. 34 and O. 13.28: *cenofw=ntos eu)/qune dai/monos ou)=ron.
kama/twn d' e)pi/lasin: Victory brings serenity (O. 1.98); breathing space (O. 8.7); tranquillity (N. 9.44). Hieron suffered with the stone.
para/sxoi: See O. 1.39.

div3.head: Antistrophe 3
div3.p: a(ni/x': “What time.” P.'s usage does not militate against the rule, h(ni/ka: o(/te :: kairo/s: xro/nos. See O. 7.35; 9, 33.

eu(ri/skonto: “Gained” in the usu. sense of the middle of this verb. So P. 3.111. The active “find” can be used in similar connections (so P. 2.64, and elsewhere), and, in fact, the active being the general, is often used where the particular middl might be expected. The plural of Hieron and his brothers.
tima/n: timh/ is something practical, and does not correspond to “honor” pure and simple.
dre/pei: Active, O. 1.13; P. 1.49; P. 4.130; P. 6.48; fr. XI. 72, Middle, N. 2.9; fr. IX. 1, 6; fr. IX. 2, 1. The active is colder.

a)ge/rwxon: O. 10 (11), 87: ni/kas a)gerw/xon. a). only of persons in Homer, who does not use it in the same sense acc. to the lexicographers. To P. the word must have carried with it the ge/ras notion denied to it by modern etymologists. The booty gained at Himera was immense.
nu=n ge ma/n: A statement that defies contradiction. Cf. v. 63.

*filokth/tao: The type of a suffering hero. See the Philoktetes of Sophokles. “At that very time Syracuse contained the famous statue of the limping Philoktetes by Pythagoras of Rhegion, of which Pliny says that those who looked at it seemed to feel the pain (xxxiv. 59). Even if we hesitate to believe that the sculptor intended an allusion to Hieron, we may well suppose that Pindar's comparison was suggested by the work of Pythagoras” (Jebb).
ta\n ... di/kan: Notice the rare article with di/kan, “wise.”
e)strateu/qh: An aor. pass., where the middle would seem more natural. Cf. e)poreu/qh. We can understand the passive of Philoktetes “who was won to the war,” not so well of Hieron.
su\n d' a)na/gka|: “Under the pressure of necessity.” The comitative, personal character of su/n makes it a favorite preposition in poetry, keeps it out of model prose.
fi/lon: Predicate, “fawned him into a friend.” Rauchenstein's mh\ fi/lon is not Pindaric.

kai/ tis e)w\n megala/nwr: tis is referred to the proud citizens of Kymé (Cumae), who were forced to beg help from the tyrant. According to Euripides, Odysseus and Diomed, according to Sophokles, Odysseus and Neoptolemos, were sent for Philoktetes. Odysseus was evidently not a favorite with P. (N. 7.21; 8, 26), and megala/nwr may be a sneer.

metaba/sontas: So Kayser for the MS. metala/sontas or metalla/ssontas. Compare O. 1.42: metaba=sai. Böckh gives metamei/bontas (Hesych., Suid., Zonaras); but while the present is admissible on general grounds (O. 13.59; P. 4.106), we should not emend it into a text. metameu/sontas would be nearer, but it has even less warrant than Wakefield's metana/ssontas, a future formed on the aorist of nai/w (P. 5.70: e)n *)/argei e)/nassen *(hrakle/os e)kgo/nous).

div3.head: Epode 3
div3.p: toco/tan: The bow of Philoktetes, being the chief thing, could not be left out. We are not to look for any correspondence to this in the history of Hieron.
*pria/moio po/lin ... po/nous *danaoi=s: Chiastic not only in position, but also in sense. For the shifting stress on *pria/moio and po/nous, see O. 6.5.
a)sqenei= me\n xrwti\ bai/nwn, a)lla\ moiri/dion h)=n: On the shift from participle to finite verb, see O. 1.13.

qeo/s: As one short syllable, possibly as qe/s. Compare *qe/mnastos, *qe/dwros in Megaric inscriptions (Cauer ^{2} 104, and G. Meyer, Gr. Gr. § 119). Schneidewin suggests qeo\s swth/r. o)rqwth/r does not occur elsewhere. Compare N. 1.14: *zeu\s ... kate/neusen ... *sikeli/an ... o)rqw/sein.
xro/non ... kairo/n: With the usu. differentiation of “time” and “season.” “To give the season” is “to give in season.”
*deinome/nei: Hieron had appointed his son, Deinomenes, regent of Aitna (v. 60).
keladh=sai: O. 1.9.
poina/n: “Reward.” So in a good sense N. 1.70; Aisch. Suppl. 626. The reward is the ke/lados.

*ai)/tnas basilei=: In Greek one is king of the Aitnaians, rather than king of Aitna. The genitive of the place has something of the iure divino stamp. So of the old house of the Battiads, P. 4.2: basilh=i *kura/nas. Cf. N. 8.7.

div3.head: Strophe 4
div3.p: tw=|: “For whom.” Deinomenes was succeeded by Chromios. See N. 9.
po/lin kei/nan: k. seems to prove that the ode was sung, not at Aitna, but at Syracuse.
qeodma/tw| su\n e)leuqeri/a|: See O. 3.7.

*(ulli/dos sta/qmas: There were three Doric tribes *(ullei=s, *pa/mfuloi, and *duma=nes. The *pa/mfuloi and *duma=nes were the descendants of Pamphylos and Dyman, sons of Aigimios. The Herakleidai did not belong to the Doric stock proper, and so are distinguished from the descendants of Aigimios, P. 5.72: *(hrakle/os e)/kgonoi *ai)gimiou= te. Compare also fr. I. 1, 3: *(/gllou te kai\ *ai)gimiou=. So *(ulli\s sta/qma and *ai)gimiou= teqmoi/ cover the ground of the Dorians, official and actual.
e)n no/mois: Cf. O. 2.83: boulai=s e)n o)rqai=si *(padama/nquos.

kai\ ma/n: “Ay, and I dare swear.” A clear intimation, if such were needed, that the Herakleidai were not real Dorians. This does not make it necessary to change the MS. *dwriei=s, v. 65, to *dwri/ois. They all belonged to the *dwrieu\s strato/s, fr. I. 1, 4.
nai/ontes: Though they dwell far from the old home of Aigimios, they are still a *dwri\s a)poiki/a, I. 6 (7), 12.
teqmoi=sin: See O. 6.69.

e)/sxon: “They gat” (O. 2.10). The occupation of Amyklai was a memorable event in Doric annals. I. 6 (7), 14: e(/lon d' *)amu/klas *ai)gei=dai. We must not forget nor yet exaggerate Pindar's personal interest in all this as an Aigeid.

leukopw/lwn: The Dioskuroi were buried at Therapnai, on the left bank of the Eurotas. The white color of the steeds of the Dioskuroi is fixed by the myth. So Cic. N. D. 3, 5, 11: Tyndaridas ... cantheriis albis ... obviam venisse existimas? White horses belonged to royalty, P. 4.117. White was not a favorite color for horses in Vergil's time (Georg. 3, 82), but that does not concern us here. Even in the Apocalypse (19, 11) the KING OF KINGS is mounted on a white horse.

div3.head: Antistrophe 4
div3.p: *zeu= te/leie: Zeus, God of the Accomplishment, in whose hands are the issues of things. Compare O. 13.115.

ai)ei\ de/: On de/, after the vocative, see O. 1.36. The infinitive may be used in wish and entreaty, but di/doi toi/an for de\ toiau/tan would be more natural. Mommsen's do\s toi/an for toiau/tan is based on the Scholiast's para/sxou. toiau/tan ai)=san refers to the first line of the strophe, qeodma/tw| su\n e)leuqeri/a|. “Grant that the judgment of the world may with truth assign such a lot to citizens and kings.”
*)ame/na: Amenas, or Amenanos, “the unsteady” (mod. Giudicello), a stream of varying volume, which flowed through the city of Aitna.
diakri/nein: Is used of legal decision, O. 8.24; of marking off by metes and bounds, O. 10 (11), 51.
lo/gon: See O. 1.28, where o( a)laqh\s lo/gos is kept apart from brotw=n fa/tis and dedaidalme/noi mu=qoi.
su/n toi ti/n: “With thy blessing.”

ui(w=| t' e)pitello/menos: The position favors the close connection with su\n ti/n, “and with a son to whom he gives commands.” The regent who receives Hieron's behests, being a son, may be expected to carry them out in his spirit.
gerai/rwn: A significant concession to the new city, which at once becomes something heroic and divine; “by paying honor due.”
li/ssomai neu=son: Asyndeton in prayer.
a(/meron: Proleptic. “In peace and quiet.”
o)/fra ... e)/xh|, instead of e)/xein, the temporal final sense of o)/fra being hardly felt. e)/xh| is intr.
kat' oi)=kon: Hdt. 6, 39: ei)=xe kat' oi)/kous.
o( *foi=nic = Poenus, Carthaginian.

o( *tursanw=n t' a)lalato/s: This forcible form of expression, which is built on the same lines as bi/a *(hrakle/os, sqe/nos h(mio/nwn, is made still bolder by the participle i)dw/n, as if o( a)lala/zwn *tursano/s had been written.

nausi/stonon ... pro\ *ku/mas: Best explained o(/ti h( u(/bris h( pro\ *ku/mhs nausi/stonos e)ge/neto. There is no Pindaric warrant for the use of u(/bris as “loss,” “damage.” The reflection that their overweening insolence off Cumae had brought groans and lamentations to the ships (cf. P. 2.28) would silence their savage yell and keep them quiet at home. The Etruscans must have been especially prominent in this famous engagement: Diodoros does not mention the Phoenicians (Carthaginians) in his account (11, 51).
pro\ *ku/mas: Brings up the image of the u(bristh/s already depicted (v. 18). Typhon symbolizes every form of violence, domestic (*sikeli/a) or foreign (*ku/mh).

div3.head: Epode 4
div3.p: oi(=a: See O. 1.16.

a)rxw=|: Hieron. The dat. with
the aor. partic. is easy, as the aor. is the shorthand of the perf.
ba/leq': The middle is peculiar, as if the a(liki/a were an a)/gkura, as I. 5 (6), 13: ba/llet' a)/gkuran.
*(ella/d': Where Greek was spoken there was *(ella/s. Here Magna Graecia is specially meant.
e)ce/lkwn: The image of the sea-fight is half kept up.

a)re/omai, kte(.: “From Salamis I shall try to get for my reward the favor of the Athenians,” i. e., when I desire reward from the Athenians I shall seek it by praising Salamis. P. climbs up to Himera by parallels, as is his wont. See O. 1, init.
e)re/w: For the shift, see v. 55. Böckh's e)re/wn lightens the construction if we take it as a present, denied for classic times; but compare Theogn. 492; Soph. O. C. 596.
pro\ *kiqairw=nos ma/xan: Knit together. pro/, “in front of,” “at the foot of.” The battle of Plataia is meant, where the Lacedaemonians distinguished themselves especially.
tai=si: Refers to *salami=nos (= th=s e)n *salami=ni ma/xhs) and pro\ *kiqairw=nos ma/xan. Not simply “where,” but “in and by which.”
eu)/udron a)kta/n: Cf. O. 12.19. para\ de\ sa\n eu)/udron a)kta/n, *(ime/ra, would not be unpoetic nor un-Pindaric.
*(ime/ra: Genitive of *(ime/ras, the river.
a)mf' a)reta=|: v. 12.
kamo/ntwn: Rather strange, so soon after ka/mon, in view of P.'s poikili/a, though the Greeks have not our dread of repetition. See P. 9.123.

div3.head: Strophe 5
div3.p: kairo/n: Adverbial. “If thy utterance prove in season.”
fqe/gcaio: The poet to himself with a wish (O. 1.108).
pei/rata suntanu/sais: “Twisting the strands of many things into a brief compass.” The contrast is e)ktei/nein lo/gon, tei/nein, a)potei/nein, e)ktei/nein, makra/n. See Intr. Ess. p. xliii (note).
e(/petai: “Is sure to follow.” Indic. apodosis, as I. 2, 33; 4 (5), 14.

mw=mos: O. 6.74. In moralizing passages the metaphors follow in rapid succession — not so much mixing as overlapping. A defence of P. in this regard that should flatten his language out so as to make the metaphor disappear would be worse than a confession of the worst.

a)po\ ... e)lpi/das: “Satiety with its gruesomeness dulls quick hopes.” ai)anh/s, of doubtful etymology, is used of ko/ros again *i. 3 (4), 2. The hopes speed to the end; the poet, by lingering, wearies, and not only so, but rouses resentment at the blessings of those whom he praises. This prepares the return to the praise of Hieron, which is couched in imperatives, a rhetorical form strangely misunderstood to convey a real sermon.

a)stw=n d' a)koa/: “What citizens
hear.” Citizens are naturally envious (O. 6.7), and the good fortune of others is an ill-hearing, and oppresses their soul in secret. “What is heard from citizens” has in its favor P. 11.28: kakolo/goi de\ poli=tai.
kre/sswn ... oi)ktirmou= fqo/nos: Proverbial. Hdt. 3, 52: fqone/esqai kre/sson e)sti\ h)\ oi)kti/resqai.
mh\ pari/ei kala/: “Hold to thy noble course.” pari/ei possibly suggested the following metaphor. Notice the large number of present imperatives, as in the parai/nesis of Isokrates ad Demonicum (1).
nw/ma ... strato/n: P. 8.98: e)leuqe/rw| sto/lw| | po/lin ta/nde ko/mize. On str. see O. 11 (10), 17.

a)yeudei= de\ pro\s a)/kmoni xa/lkeue glw=ssan: This is counted as one of P.'s harsher metaphors, in spite of Cic. de Orat. 3, 30, 121: non enim solum acuenda nobis neque procudenda lingua est. P. might have continued the figure just given, for the tongue may be considered a rudder (compare P. 11.42 with James 3, 4), but the vibrating tongue is to Pindar a javelin (compare kh=la, v. 12), and in N. 7.71 he has a)/konq' w(=te xalkopa/ra|on o)/rsai | qoa\n glw=ssan. xa/lkeue grows out of nw/ma. The “true anvil” refers in all likelihood to the shaping of the arrow or javelin on a part of the anvil designed for that purpose. The figure is reflected in the next sentence.

div3.head: Antistrophe 5
div3.p: ei)/ ti kai\ f.: kai/, “never so.”

paraiqu/ssei: P. is thinking of the sparks that fly from the anvil, sheer dross it may be (flau=ron), but “surely you must know, coming from you, it rushes as a mighty mass.” If the figure is pressed, the moral is “Hammer as little as possible,” but the figure is not to be pressed. fe/retai, “is reported,” the common rendering, is too faint after paraiqu/ssei.
tami/as: A higher word than “steward,” in Engl. Compare O. 14.9.
a)mfote/rois: Is “good and bad,” as qa/teron is “worse.”
eu)anqei= ... parme/nwn: “Abide in the full flower of thy spirit.” Contrast to Phalaris.
ei)/per ti filei=s, kte(.: Arguing on a basis of conceded facts.
a(koa\n a(dei=an ... klu/ein: A good explanation of the idiom eu)= a)kou/ein.

mh\ ka/mne li/an dapa/nais: The Christian exhortation, “Be not weary in welldoing,” is addressed to well-doers, and Hieron's expenditure was doubtless liberal enough. It does not follow that he hoarded because he was fila/rguros. Of the virtue of generosity Kroisos was the model soon to be adduced.
i(sti/on a)nemo/en: The sail (so as to be) breezeful, (so as) to belly with the breeze. Cf. I. 2, 39: ou)de/ pote ceni/an | ou)=ros e)mpneu/sais u(pe/steil' i(sti/on a)mfi\ tra/pezan.

mh\ dolwqh=|s ... ke/rdess(in): Referred by some to “courtier
arts,” but it is better to keep the generosity side uppermost until we come to Kroisos. Tr. “juggling gains.” No mean saving on the one hand, no grasping at unworthy gains on the other. The positive exhortation stands between the two negatives.
fi/los: The commentators note P.'s familiarity. What other word was possible for a Greek gentleman?
o)piqo/mbroton: Sensitive as Hieron is to the voice of the world about him, he is far from deaf to the acclaim of posterity.

div3.head: Epode 5
div3.p: a)poixome/nwn ... a)oidoi=s: Cf. N. 6.33: a)poixome/nwn ga\r a)ne/rwn | a)oidai\ kai\ lo/goi ta\ kala/ sfin e)/rg' e)ko/misan.
di/aitan = bi/oton, which is the parallel, O. 2.69.
manu/ei = a)pagge/llei.

logi/ois: Usually interpreted of prose-writers, the early logographers; but it may refer to panegyrists. Compare not only N. 6.33, just quoted, but the same ode, v. 51: platei=ai pa/ntoqen logi/oisin e)nti\ pro/sodoi | na=son eu)kle/a ta/nde kosmei=n.

*kroi/sou: A romantic figure, if one may say so, in Greek history, though, perhaps, Lydian influence has not been sufficiently emphasized. That a Greek with such close relations to Delphi as Pindar bore should have given a niche to Kroisos is not strange.
a)reta/: “Generosity,” as often.
to\n de\ tau/rw| xalke/w| kauth=ra: k. takes the dative of instrument by virtue of its transparently verbal nature.
no/on: Acc. of specification to nhle/a. The prose laws of position are not to be pressed. to\n de/ may well be “the other,” and the rest in apposition.
tau/rw| xalke/w|: A survival or revival of Moloch worship.
*fa/larin: See Introd. O. 2.
kate/xei: Evil report weighs upon the memory of Phalaris as Aitna upon the body of Typhon, though kate/xei may be used of a weight of glory, O. 7.10; o( d' o)/lbios o(\n fa=mai kate/xont' a)gaqai/.

nin ... koinwni/an ... de/kontai: k. is construed after the analogy of de/cin de/xontai, which we have Eur. I. A. 1181:
e)f' h(=| [sc. profa/sei] s' e)gw\ kai\ pai=des ai( leleimme/nai
deco/meqa de/cin h(/n se de/casqai xrew/n.
o)a/roisi: Depends on koinwni/an.
to\ de\ paqei=n eu)=: We might expect the present, but the notion of achievement will serve. N. 1.32: eu)= te paqei=n kai\ a)kou=sai.

deute/ra moi=ra: So So. O. C. 145 speaks of prw/ths moi/ras. With the sentiment compare I. 4, 12: du/o de/ toi zwa=s a)/wton mou=na poimai/nonti to
 a)/lpniston eu)anqei= su
 o)/lbw| | ei)/ tis eu)= pa/sxwn lo/gon e)slo
 a)kou/sh|.
e)gku/rsh| kai\ e(/lh| (a)mfo/tera). The two verbs show a combination of luck and will.

div2.p: This victory, gained not at the Pythian games, but at the Theban Iolaia or Herakleia, is probably to be assigned to Ol. 75, 4 (477 B.C.), in which year Hieron had, by his interposition, saved the Epizephyrian Lokrians from a bloody war with Anaxilas, tyrant of Rhegion. The poem, with its dissonances, echoes the discord of the times. Hieron was just then at enmity with his brother, Polyzelos, who had taken refuge with his connection, Theron, the friend of Pindar, and a war was impending. The strain makes itself felt amid all the congratulation.
It is a strange poem, one in which divination and sympathy can accomplish little. Only we must hold fast to the commonsense view that Pindar did not undertake to lecture Hieron.

“Great Syracuse,” the poet says, “rearer of men and horses, I bring this lay from Thebes in honor of Hieron's victory with the four-horse chariot, gained not without the favor of Artemis, goddess of Ortygia, thus wreathed with glory. For Artemis and Hermes, god of games, aid Hieron when he yokes his horses and calls on the God of the Trident. Other lords have other minstrels, other praises. Let Kinyras be praised by Kyprian voices, Kinyras beloved of Apollo, and minion of Aphrodite. Thou, Hieron, beloved of Hermes and minion of Artemis, art praised by the voice of the virgin of Epizephyrian Lokris, to whose eye thy power hath given confidence. Grateful is she. Well hath she learned the lesson of Ixion, whose punishment, as he revolves on the winged wheel, says: Reward thy benefactor with kind requitals.”
So far the opening (vv. 1-24).

In P. 1 we had one form of u(/bris, sheer rebellion, typified by Typhon. Here we have another typified by Ixion, base ingratitude. Typhon belonged from the beginning to those o(/sa mh\ pefi/lhke *zeu/s (P. 1.13). Ixion was one of those who eu)mene/ssi pa\r *kroni/dais gluku\n ei(=lon bi/oton (v. 25). Ixion was another,
but a worse, Tantalos. Tantalos sinned by making the celestial meat and drink common (O. 1.61). Ixion sinned by trying to pollute the celestial bed (v. 34). Each was punished in the way in which he had sinned. Tantalos was reft of food and drink (note on O. 1.60). Ixion was whirled on his own wheel, became his own iynx (compare v. 40 with P. 4.214). Ixion's sin was of a deeper dye, and so, while the son of Tantalos came to great honor (O. 1.90), the son of Ixion became the parent of a monstrous brood.
This is the myth (vv. 25-48).

It is, indeed, not a little remarkable that in every Hieronic ode there is a dark background — a Tantalos (O. 1), a Typhon (P. 1), an Ixion (P. 2), a Koronis (P. 3) — and the commentators are not wrong in the Fight-with-the-Dragon attitude in which they have put Hieron. Who is aimed at under the figure of Ixion no one can tell. The guesses and the combinations of the commentators are all idle. Hieron is a manner of Zeus. He was the Olympian of Sicily as Perikles was afterwards the Olympian of Athens, and the doom of Tantalos, the wheel of Ixion, the crushing load of Typhon, the swift destruction of Koronis, the lightning death of Asklepios were in store for his enemies. The Hieronic odes are Rembrandts, and we shall never know more.

Passing over to the praise of Hieron, the poet emphasizes with unmistakable reduplication the power of God. “God decides the fate of hopes, God overtakes winged eagle and swift dolphin, humbles the proud, to others gives glory that waxes not old (v. 52). This be my lay instead of the evil tales that Archilochos told of the Ixions of his time. Wealth paired with wisdom, under the blessing of Fortune — this is the highest theme of song” (v. 56). The key of the poem lies in this double qeo/s. God is all-powerful to punish and to bless, and Hieron is his vicegerent.

The praise of Hieron follows, his wealth, his honor. His champion, Pindar, denies that he has ever had his superior in Greece, and boards the herald-ship all dight with flowers to proclaim his achievements — now in war, now in council; now on horse, and now afoot (vv. 57-66). But as we gaze, the herald-ship becomes a merchant-ship (v. 67), and the song is the freight — a new song, which forms the stranger afterpiece of a poem already strange enough. This afterpiece is an exhortation to straightforwardness. The Archilochian vein, against which Pindar protested
semi-humorously before (v. 55), stands out. The ape (v. 72), the fox (v. 78), the wolf (v. 84), are contrasts dramatically introduced, dramatically dismissed. “Let there be no pretentiousness, no slyness, no roundabout hate. Straight-tonguedness is best in the rule of the one man, of the many, of the wise. Follow God's leading, bear his yoke. Kick not against the pricks. There lies the only safety. May such men admit me to their friendship” (v. 96).

The difficulty of the last part lies in the dramatic shiftings — the same difficulty that we encounter in comedy, and especially in satire. If there are not two persons, there are two voices. The poet pits the *di/kaios *lo/gos and the *)/adikos *lo/gos against each other in the forum of his own conscience. The *di/kaios *lo/gos speaks last and wins.
A. Show thyself as thou art (v. 72).
B. But the monkey, which is ever playing different parts, is a fair creature, ever a fair creature, in the eyes of children (v. 72).
A. Yes, in the eyes of children, but not in the judgment of a Rhadamanthys, whose soul hath no delight in tricks (vv. 73-75).
B. If the monkey finds no acceptance, what of foxy slanderers? They are an evil, but an evil that cannot be mastered (vv. 76, 77).
A. But what good comes of it to Mistress Vixen? (v. 78).
B. “Why,” says Mistress Vixen, “I swim like a cork, I always fall on my feet” (vv. 79, 80).
A. But the citizen that hath the craft of a fox can have no weight in the state. He is as light as his cork. He cannot utter a word of power among the noble (vv. 81, 82).
B. Ay, but he wheedles and worms his way through. Flattery works on all (v. 82).
A. I don't share the confidence of your crafty models (v. 82).
B. My own creed is: Love your friends. An enemy circumvent on crooked paths, like a wolf (vv. 83, 84).

A. Nay, nay. No monkey, no fox, no wolf. Straight speech is best in monarchy, democracy, or aristocracy. A straight course is best because it is in harmony with God, and there is no contending against God. Success
does not come from cunning or overreaching, from envious cabals. Bear God's yoke. Kick not against the pricks. Men who are good, men with views like these, such are they whom I desire to live withal as friend with friend (vv. 86-96).
The rhythms are Aiolian (logaoedic). The introduction occupies one triad, the myth one, the praise of Hieron one, the afterplay one.

div3.head: Strophe 1
div3.p: megalopo/lies w)= *sura/kosai: A similar position, O. 8.1: ma=ter w)= xrusostefa/nwn a)e/qlwn *)olumpi/a, P. 8.2: *di/kas w)= megisto/poli qu/gater. Athens is called ai( megalopo/lies *)aqa=nai (P. 7.1). The epithet is especially appropriate in the case of Syracuse, which, even in Hieron's time, had a vast extent.
baqupole/mou: “That haunteth the thick of war.” The martial character of Syracuse is emphasized on account of the military movements then on foot.
a)ndrw=n i(/ppwn te: See O. 1.62.

sidaroxarma=n: “Fighting in iron-mail.” Here we seem to have xa/rmh in the Homeric sense. So I. 5 (6), 27: xalkoxa/rman e)s po/lemon, where the notion of rejoicing would not be so tolerable as in P. 5.82: xalkoxa/rmai ce/noi. i(ppoxa/rmas (O. 1.23) is doubtful. See O. 9.92.

lipara=n: Orig. “gleaming,” then vaguely “bright,” “brilliant,” “famous.” P. uses it of Thebes (fr. XI. 58), Athens (N. 4.18; I. 2, 20; fr. IV. 4), Orchomenos (O. 14.4), Egypt (fr. IV. 9), Marathon (O. 13.110). The wideness of its application takes away its force.
e)leli/xqonos: Used P. 6.50 of Poseidon; in Sophokles of Bakchos (Antig. 153).
e)n a(=| krate/wn: Compare P. 11.46: e)n a(/rmasi kalli/nikoi.
thlauge/sin: The wreaths send their light afar, like the pro/swpon thlauge/s of O. 6.4. Only the light is figurative, as the gold is figurative, O. 8.1. Compare O. 1.23 and 94.
*)ortugi/an: See O. 6.92.

potami/as ... *)arte/midos: Artemis, among her numerous functions, is a river-goddess, and in the Peloponnesos her worship is connected especially with the Kladeos and the Alpheios (*)/artemis *)alfeiw/|a). She has charge of rivers not only as a huntress, but as the representative of the Oriental Artemis. Pursued by Alpheios, she fled under the waters of the Ionian sea, and found rest by the fountain of Arethusa in Ortygia, where a temple was raised in her honor. Of course, Arethusa and Artemis
are one (compare Telesilla, fr. 1: a(/d' *)/artemis, w)= ko/rai, | feu/goisa to\n *)alfeo/n), but when Alpheios and Arethusa were united, Artemis, the virgin, and Arethusa were separated. Similar is the case of Kallisto. Compare with this whole passage N. 1.1: a)/mpneuma semno\n *)alfeou=, | kleina=n *surakossa=n qa/los *)ortugi/a, | de/mnion *)arte/midos, | *da/lou kasignh/ta. Note also that the brother of Artemis appears in the corresponding sweep of the antistrophe.

a(=s ou)k a)/ter: O. 3.26: *latou=s i(pposo/a quga/thr, fr. V. 2, 2: i(/ppwn e)la/teiran. Hieron has a trinity of helpers, *)/artemis potami/a, *(ermh=s e)nagw/nios, and kluto/pwlos *poseida/wn (fr. XI. 33, 2), whose enmity was so fatal to Hippolytos, favorite though he was of Artemis.
kei/nas: The preference for mares comes out distinctly in the famous description, So. El. 702. 734.
e)n xersi/: Plastic. N. 1.52: e)n xeri\ ... tina/sswn, instead of xeri\ tina/sswn (instrum.).
poikilani/ous: “With broidered reins.”

div3.head: Antistrophe 1
div3.p: e)pi/: With ti/qhsi. For sing. compare O. 9.16.
i^oxe/aira: In Homer i_oxe/aira. The word occurs only here in Pindar.

xeri\ didu/ma|: Variously interpreted. As we say, “with both hands,” to show readiness. According to others the reference is to Artemis and Hermes, x. d. being an anticipation, like the plural in the schema Alcmanicum.

e)nagw/nios *(ermh=s: Familiar function of Hermes. Hor. Od. 1, 10:
qui feros cultus hominum recentum
voce formasti catus et decorae
more palaestrae.
See O. 6.78: e)dw/rhsan qew=n ka/ruka litai=s qusi/ais | polla\ dh\ pollai=sin *(erma=n eu)sebe/ws, o(\s a)gw=nas e)/xei moi=ra/n t' a)e/qlwn.
ai)gla/enta ... ko/smon: k. “reins and trappings.” Compare h(ni/a sigalo/enta.

e)n: So for e)s in the Aeolic poems. Cf. v. 86; P. 5.38; N. 7.31. e)n, like Lat. in, originally took the acc., as well as the locative-dative. *e)ns (ei)s) was formed after the analogy of e)c, with which it was constantly associated in contrasts. By that time the -s of e)c had lost its abl. force. Compare uls like cis, ka/tw like a)/nw, o)/pisqen like pro/sqen, e)mpodw/n like e)kpodw/n (Brugmann). On the preposition with the second member, see O. 9.94.
peisixa/lina: “Obedient to the bit.” Only here, as if the chariot were the horses. In the few other compounds peisi- is active.
kataceugnuh|: Hieron.
sqe/nos i(/ppeion: Cf. O. 6.22: sqe/nos h(mio/nwn.
eu)rubi/an: O. 6.58.
kale/wn qeo/n: Compare the story of Pelops, O. 1.72: a)/puen baru/ktupon *eu)tri/ainan.

a)/llois de/ tis, kte(.: Pindar now passes to the praise of Hieron's services
to the Lokrians. As is his manner, Kinyras is introduced to balance. “I have praised Hieron, favorite of Artemis and of Hermes, for his victory with the chariot. The Kyprians praise Kinyras, the favorite of Apollo and Aphrodite, for his royal and priestly work. The Lokrian virgin praises Hieron for his successful championship.”
e)te/lessen: Gnomic aorist. “Pays,” as a tribute.
eu)axe/a ... u(/mnon: “The meed of a melodious song.”
a)/poin' a)reta=s: Contrast this clear accus. with the fading xa/rin, the faded di/khn, which needs the article to vivify it (P. 1.50). See O. 7.16.
kelade/onti: O. 1.9.

a)mfi\ *kinu/ran: Kinyras was a fabulous king of Kypros, priest and favorite of Aphrodite. He was a great inventor, a kind of Jubal and Tubal Cain in one — a Semitic figure, it would seem — the man of the harp, with whom we may compare Anchises, another favorite of Aphrodite, of whom it is said, Hymn. in Ven. 80: pwlei=t' e)/nqa kai\ e)/nqa diapru/sion kiqari/zwn. The introduction of Kinyras, lord of the eastern island of Kypros, as a balance to Hieron, lord of the western island of Sicily, leads the poet to mention Apollo in this non-Pythian ode (see Introd.) as a balance to Artemis. A genealogical connection is the merest fancy.
e)fi/lhse: If fi/los is “own,” “made his own,” “marked him for his own.” See P. 1.13.
*)apo/llwn: Aphrodite and Apollo are often associated. So esp. in P. 9.10, where Aphrodite receives the spouse of Apollo.

div3.head: Epode 1
div3.p: kti/lon: Lit. “Tame pet.” “Minion,” “favorite,” “cherished.”
a)/gei: Without an object. “Is in the van,” “leads,” or neg. “cannot be kept back.” So N. 7.23: sofi/a de\ kle/ptei para/goisa mu/qois. Compare also O. 1.108.
poi/nimos: a)meiptikh/ (Schol.). Echo of a)/poin' a)reta=s. For poinh/, in a good sense, see P. 1.59.
o)pizome/na: “In reverential regard.” Cf. O. 2.6: o)/pin.
*deinome/neie pai=: Cf. O. 2.13: w)= *kro/nie pai=, P. 8.19: *cena/rkeion ui(o/n. Hieron was the son of Deinomenes, and his son, after the Greek fashion, was also called Deinomenes. See P. 1.58.

*zefuri/a ... parqe/nos: The Lokrian women held an exceptional position in Greece. Lokrian nobility followed the distaff side (compare O. 9.60) and Lokrian poetesses were famous. But here we have simply an expression of popular joy, such as virgins especially would feel, and Lokrian virgins would freely express

pro\ do/mwn: Why pro\ do/mwn? Why “haven under the
hill?” Why anything that gives a picture? P. 3.78: *matri/, ta
 kou=rai par' e)mo
 pro/quron su
 *pani\ me/lpontai qama/.

drakei=s' a)sfale/s: We might expect the pres., but the aor. of attainment is here the aor. of recovery, “having gained the right to fearless glance.” For fear as expressed by the eye, compare So. Ai. 139: pefo/bhmai | pthnh=s w(s o)/mma pelei/as, O. R. 1221: a)ne/pneusa/ t' e)k se/qen kai\ katekoi/mhsa tou)mo\n o)/mma. The inner obj., with verbs of seeing, is familiar. So drimu\ ble/pein, deino\n de/rkesqai. Pindar has o(rw=nt' a)lka/n (O. 9.119).
e)fetmai=s: “Behests,” usu. of exalted personages.

*)ici/ona: The story of Ixion and his wheel has often been told. So in a famous (corrupt) passage of So. Phil. 676: lo/gw| me\n e)ch/kous' o)/pwpa d' ou) ma/la | to\n pela/tan le/ktrwn pote\ tw=n *dio\s | *)ici/ona (?) kat' a)/mpuka (a)/ntuga?) dh\ droma/da de/smion w(s e)/laben (others e)/balen) o( pagkrath\s *kro/nou pai=s. The only important points that Pindar's narrative suppresses are the purification of Ixion from bloodguiltiness by *zeu\s kaqa/rsios himself, and the intimacy of Zeus with the wife of Ixion. The former would not have been altogether consistent with v. 31, and the latter would have given a sinister meaning to a)ganai=s a)moibai=s (v. 24).
tau=ta: Namely, to\n eu)erge/tan ... ti/nesqai.
le/gein: “Teaches.”
panta=|: Here “round and round.”
kulindo/menon: Instead of the more prosaic inf. See O. 3.6.
a)moibai=s e)poixome/nous ti/nesqai: Notice the fulness of the injunction. e)poixome/nous, “visiting,” “frequenting.” “To requite the benefactor with ever-recurring tokens of warm gratitude.”

div3.head: Strophe 2
div3.p: para\ *kroni/dais: Zeus and Hera.
makro/n: “Great,” as P. 11.52: makrote/rw| (?) .. o)/lgbw|.
e)ra/ssato: P., like Homer, has no h)ra/sqh.
ta\n ... la/xon: Compare O. 1.53.
eu)nai/: The pl. of the joys of love. Cf. P. 9.13: e)pi\ glukerai=s eu)nai=s, fr. IX. 1, 7: e)rateinai=s e)n eu)nai=s, P. 11.25: e)/nnuxoi pa/ragon koi=tai.
a+/va+/tan = a)/tan. See P. 3.24.
a)nh/r: He had presumed as if he were a god.
e)cai/reton: Elsewhere in a good sense. There is a bitterness in the position, and in e(/le also, as it recalls v. 26: gluku\n e(lw\n bi/oton.
tele/qonti: Not historical pres. He is still in hell.
to\ me\n ... o(/ti .., o(/ti te: A double shift. On me/n ... te, see O. 4.13.
e)mfu/lion ai(=ma: He slew his father-inlaw, Deïoneus.
prw/tistos: Aisch. Eum. 718: prwtokto/noisi prostropai=s *)ici/onos.

ou)k a)/ter te/xnas: He filled a trench with live coals, covered it slightly, and enticed Deïoneus into it when he
came after the e(/dna.
e)pe/mice qnatoi=s: e). = intulit (ignem fraude mala gentibus intulit), but livelier, “Brought the stain of kindred blood upon mortals,” “imbrued them with kindred blood.”

div3.head: Antistrophe 2
div3.p: megalokeuqe/essin ... qala/mois: Stately plural. So O. 7.29; P. 4.160.
e)peira=to: Active more usual in this sense (N. 5.30).

kat' au)to/n, kte(.: Not kaq' au(to/n. P. does not use the compound reflexive. See O. 13.53; P. 4.250. “To measure everything by one's self,” i. e. “to take one's own measure in every plan of life.” This is only another form of the homely advice of Pittakos to one about to wed above his rank: ta\n kata\ sauto\n e)/la. P., like many other poets, has a genius for glorifying the commonplace. Compare Aisch. Prom. 892 on unequal matches.

eu)nai\ de\ para/tropoi ... pote kai\ to\n e(lo/nta: The MSS. have pote kai\ to\n i(/kont'. The quantity of i(/_kont' will not fit, an aorist i(^ko/nt' rests on Il. 9. 414, the sense of i(ke/thn is marred by kai/. Böckh's poti\ koi=ton i)o/nt' is ingenious, but coarse; e(ko/nt' is feeble. Schneidewin's e(lo/nt' is not bad, in view of P.'s harping on the word (vv. 26 and 30). The aor. is gnomic, and e)pei/ gives the special application. “Unlawful couchings have many a time plunged into whelming trouble even him that had won them.” Compare the case of Koronis and Ischys (P. 3.25).
