pre/pen: “Was like unto.” Only here in P. with this sense.
a(/nte: The reinforcing relative, “her, whom.” P.'s use of o(/ste does not give ground for any supersubtle distinctions.
*zhno\s pala/mai: More delicate than the other story that Hera played the trick on him. Schol. Eur. Phoen. 1185.
kalo\n ph=ma: P. perhaps had in mind Hes. Theog. 585: kalo\n kako/n (of Pandora).

tetra/knamon ... desmo/n: “The four-spoked bond” is the “four-spoked wheel.” The magic iynx (“wry-neck”), used in love-incantations, was bound to just such a wheel. Cf. P. 4.214: poiki/lan i)/ugga tetra/knamon *ou)lumpo/qen | e)n a)lu/tw| zeu/caisa ku/klw| | maina/d' o)/rnin *kuproge/neia fe/ren | prw=ton a)nqrw/poisi. It was poetic justice to bind Ixion to his own iynx wheel. Endless are the references to this symbol of mad love. See Theokritos' Pharmakeutriai.
e)/prace: “Effected,” “brought about,” and not e)pra/cato, I. 4 (5), 8. See note on dre/pwn, O. 1.13.

div3.head: Epode 2
div3.p:
e(o\n o)/leqron o(/g': A renewal of the close of the last line of the antistrophe with effective position. The breath is naturally
held at desmo/n. On the position of o(/g', see P. 11.22.
a)nde/cat': He received the message and delivered it, not in words, but by whirling on the wheel (v. 23). Mitscherlich's a)ndei/cat' has found much favor.
a)/neu . . . *xari/twn=a)/xarin, “Unblessed by the Graces.” Cf. a)/neu qeou=, O. 9.111.
mo/na kai\ mo/non : kai/ unusual in such juxtapositions, and hence impressive. No mother like her; so, too, no offspring like this.
a)ndra/si=a)nqrw/pois.
gerasfo/ron=ti/mion. Without part or lot among men or gods.
no/mois=toi=s nomizome/nois.
tra/foisa: Dor. for tre/foisa. So P. 4.115; I. 1, 48; 7 (8), 41.
*ke/ntauron: This name, of obscure origin, was applied to his descendants, properly *(ippoke/ntauroi.
*magnhti/dessin: P. 3.45: *ma/gnhti . . . *kentau/rw|.
sfuroi=s: With a like figure we say “spurs.” See P. 1.30.
strato/s: Is in apposition to the subject of e)ge/nonto. “Out they came — a host marvellous to behold.”

ta\ matro/qen me\n ka/tw, ta\ d' u(/perqe patro/s: “The dam's side down, the upper side the sire's.” Chiasm is as natural to the Greek as mother's milk; not so to us. matro/qen is often used parallel with mhtro/s.

div3.head: Strophe 3
div3.p: qeo\s . . . a)nu/etai: “God accomplishes for himself every aim according to his desires.” velpi/s, “pleasure,” “wish,” shows here its kinship to volup. e)pi/ as in e)p' eu)xa=|, P. 9.96. The wish is crowned by fulfilment. The middle a)nu/etai is rare.
qeo/s: The emphatic repetition gives the key to the poem. See introd.

ki/xe . . . paramei/betai . . . e)/kamye . . . pare/dwke: The gnomic aorist often varies with the present. Many examples in Solon, fr. XIII. (Bergk). See also Tyrtaios, fr. XII. (Bergk). In the absence of an aoristic present, the Greek often uses an aor. for concentrated action in the present with a conscious contrast to the durative. See Plat. Phaidr. 247 B. So here ki/xe, e)/kamye, pare/dwk(e) are finalities, paramei/betai is process.
ptero/enta = tanu/pteron. Cf. P. 5.111: tanu/pteros ai)eto/s.
ai)eto/n: N. 3.80: ai)eto\s w)ku\s e)n potanoi=s.
delfi=na: Also proverbial. N. 6.72: delfi=ni/ ken | ta/xos di' a(/lmas | ei)ka/zoimi *melhsi/an.
tina: “Many a one,” tel. So P. 4.86.
e)me\ de\ xrew/n: For the connection, see introduction.
da/kos=dh=gma (Etym. Mag.).
a)dino/n: “Excessive,” “I must avoid the reputation of a biting calumniator.”
e(ka\s e)w/n: P. was two hundred years later than Archilochos.

yogero\n *)arxi/loxon: A. is a synonym for a virulent and ill-starred satirist. From such casual mention we should not imagine that the ancients placed
A. only lower than Homer.

piaino/menon: Not to be taken ironically. There is nothing unhealthier than unhealthy fat, and there is no necessity of an oxymoron. Compare Shakesp. M. of V. i. 3, 48: I will feed fat the ancient grudge I bear him. Archilochos is a fat and venomous toad that lives upon the vapor of a dungeon. A reference to Bakchylides is suspected, but the name does not fit the metre here.

to\ ploutei=n . . . a)/riston: The Schol. interprets to\ de\ e)pitugxa/nein plou/tou meta\ sofi/as a)/riston, and so Aristarchos: eu)potmo/tato/s e)stin o( ploutw=n kai\ sofi/as a(/ma tugxa/nwn, so that we combine tu/xa| with sofi/as and po/tmou with a)/riston. “Wealth, with the attainment of wisdom, is Fortune's best.” The position is bold, but not incredible. Others, with a disagreeable cumulation, su\n tu/xa| po/tmou sofi/as, “with the attainment of the lot of wisdom.” But the two genitives cited from P. 9.43: sofa=s *peiqou=s i(era=n filota/twn, are not at all parallel, the relation there being that of a simple possessive. If Archilochos were alone involved, sofi/as a(/riston might well mean is “the best part of the poetic art,” as “discretion is the better part of valor,” but sofi/as here must be applicable to Hieron as well.

div3.head: Antistrophe 3
div3.p: nin e)/xeis: Sc. to\ ploutei=n meta\ sofi/as, nin may be neut. sing. Aisch. Choeph. 542, or pl. P. V. 55; So. El. 436. 624.
peparei=n=e)ndei=cai, shmh=nai (Hesych.), “for showing them with free soul,” “so that thou canst freely show them.” Others read peporei=n = dou=nai, which would make nin refer to to\ ploutei=n alone.
pru/tani: “Prince.” Used of Zeus P. 6.24: keraunw=n . . . pru/tanin.
eu)stefa/nwn: “Battlemented.” This is an early use of ste/fanos. Compare O. 8.32.
stratou=: Sc. pollou= stratou=.

peri\ tima=|: p. with the dat. of the stake, as, to some extent, even in prose, “when wealth and honor are at stake.” So with dhri/omai, O. 13.45; ma/rnatai, N. 5.47; a(milla=tai, N. 10.31; moxqi/zei, fr. IX. 2, 6. On the preposition with the second member, see O. 9.94.
xau/na| prapi/di palaimonei= kenea/: “(With) flabby soul, his wrestlings are all in vain.”
eu)an|qe/a: The ship of the victor is wreathed with flowers.
sto/lon: Cogn. acc. to a)naba/somai (Dissen). st. as “prow” is more poetical.
a)mf' a)reta=|: O. 9.14: a)mfi\ palai/smasin fo/rmigg' e)leli/zwn.
kelade/wn: O. 2.2.
neo/tati me\n, kte(.: Contrast chiastic, v. 65: boulai\ de\ presbu/terai.
qra/sos . . . pole/mwn: “Boldness in.” Cf. N. 7.59: to/lman kalw=n.
eu(rei=n: See O. 7.89, and compare P. 1.49.

div3.head: Epode 3
div3.p: i(pposo/aisin a)/ndressi: i(., O. 3.26, of Artemis, I. 4 (5), 32, of Iolaos. These achievements refer mainly to Himera.

boulai\ de\ presbu/terai: Sc. h)\ kata\ th
 neo/thta, or, as the Schol. says, u(pe th
 neo/thta bouleu/h. “Elder than thy years.” P. 4.282: kei=nos ga e)n paisi
 ne/os, e)n de\ boulai=s pre/sbus e)gku/rsais e(katontaetei= biota=|, P. 5.109. 110: kre/ssona me
 a(liki/as | no/on fe/rbetai.

a)ki/ndunon e)moi\ ve/pos: “Thy counsels, riper than thy age, furnish me with an utterance that runs no risk of challenge to praise thee in full view of the whole account,” through the whole count. The two exhaustive excellences are qra/sos and eu)bouli/a. If he is wise as well as brave, he has all the virtues. Compare I. 4 (5), 12: du/o de/ toi zwa=s a)/wton mou=na poimai/nonti to
 a)/lpniston eu)anqei= su
 o)/lbw|, | ei)/ tis eu)= pa/sxwn lo/gon e)slo
 a)kou/sh| . . . pa/nt' e)/xeis, | ei)/ se tou/twn moi=r' e)fi/koito kalw=n.
xai=re: So N. 3.76: xai=re, fi/los, where we have, as here, praise of the victor, farewell, and commendation of the poet's song.

to/de me/n: This would seem to indicate that the me/los here sent was different from the *kasto/reion, but P.'s handling of me/n and de/ is so peculiar, not to say tricky, that Böckh has a right to set up the antithesis pe/mpetai me\n to/de me/los, a)/qrhson de\ to\ *kasto/reion.
kata\ *foi/nissan e)mpola/n: k., “like.” Phoenician ware was costly, being brought from afar.

to\ *kasto/reion: Compare I. 1, 16: h)\ *kastorei/w| h)\ *)iola/oi) e)narmo/cai nin u(/mnw|. The *kasto/reion was an old Spartan battle-song, the rhythm anapaestic, like the e)mbath/ria, the mood Doric, the accompaniment the flute. P. uses it as a i(/ppeios no/mos, in honor of victory with horse and chariot (Castor gaudet equis); the mood is Aiolian, and the accompaniment the fo/rmigc. Some suppose that the K. was another poem to be sent at a later time, hence a)/qrhson, as if the prince were bidden descry it coming in the distance: others that the K. is the last part of the poem, which P. made a present of to Hieron, together with a batch of good advice. The figure of the Phoenician cargo runs into the antithesis. The Doric king might have expected a Doric lay, but this Kastoreion, with its Aiolian mood, is to be viewed kindly (qe/lwn a)/qrhson) for the sake of the Doric fo/rmigc — Apollo's own instrument. Compare O. 1.100: e)me\ de\ stefanw=sai | kei=non i(ppei/w| no/mw| | *ai)olh(i+/di molpa=|, and yet 1, 17: *dwri/an a)po\ fo/rmigga passa/lou la/mban(e).
xa/rin: Before its genitive only here in P.
e(ptaktu/pou: The old Terpandrian heptachord. N. 5.24: fo/rmigg' *)apo/llwn e(pta/glwsson xruse/w| pla/ktrw| diw/kwn.

a)nto/menos: Absolute.
“Coming to meet it, receive it” — the Phoenician ware again. Pindar's power of parenthesis is great. The farewell (v. 67) suggested the commendation, or, if need be, the justification of his poem, and he now returns to the characteristic of his hero. An unprepared break at v. 72 is not likely.

ge/noi' oi(=os e)ssi\ maqw/n: The necessity of connection makes maqw/n refer to the praise of the victor. “Show thyself who thou art, for I have taught it thee.” Some take maqw/n as part of the wish or command. ge/noio . . . maqw/n=ma/qois has no satisfactory analogy in Pindaric grammar, nor does it give any satisfactory transition. P.'s contempt of mere mechanical learning, as shown O. 2.95: maqo/ntes de\ la/broi . . . a)/kranta garu/eton has suggested a combination with pi/qwn (Bergk), in which the learned ape is contrasted with Rhadamanthys, who is doubtless polla\ ei)dw\s fua=| (O. 2.94), but the position of toi in maqw\n kalo/s toi is hardly credible, to say nothing of the quotation by Galen below.
pi/qwn. A young ape.

para\ paisi/n: “In the judgment of children.” The ape was a favorite in the nursery then as he is now. Galen, de Usu Part. 1, 22: kalo/s toi pi/qhkos para\ paisi\n ai)ei/, fhsi/ tis tw=n palaiw=n, a)namimnh/skwn u(ma=s w(s e)/stin a)/qurma geloi=on paizo/ntwn pai/dwn tou=to to\ zw=|on. Instead of para\ de\ *(radama/nqui, P. changes the form of the antithesis.

div3.head: Strophe 4
div3.p: kalo/s: Child-like and lover-like repetition. The ape is said to have been introduced into Greek fable by Archilochos, and the mention of the ape here may have called up the image of the fox below without any inner nexus. An allusion to the Archilochian fable of “the Ape and the Fox” seems to be out of the question. “Show thyself thyself. Care naught for the judgment of those that be mere children in understanding. Thy judge is Rhadamanthys.”

eu)= pe/pragen: Rhadamanthys owes his good fortune to his judicial temper. Compare O. 2.83: boulai=s e)n o)rqai=si *(radama/nquos | o(\n path\r e)/xei [*kro/nos] e(toi=mon au)tw=| pa/redron. Of the three judges in Hades, Aiakos — usually the first met by the new-comer — is in P. only the great Aeginetan hero, except in I. 7 (8), 24, where he is represented as a judge over the dai/mones. Minos does not appear.
frenw=n . . . karpo/n: So N. 10.12. Famous in Aischylos' description of Amphiaraos is the line S. c. Th. 593: baqei=an a)/loka dia\ freno\s karpou/menos .
e)/ndoqen: The wiles of the deceivers do not penetrate the deep soil.

oi(=a: See O. 1.16. Half exclamatory. If with the
MSS., brotw=n, “Such things (a)pa/tai) always sort with the acts of whisperers!” So e(/petai, O. 2.24. If with Heindorf, brotw=|, “Such things always haunt a man by the devices of whisperers!”
brotw=n: Used like a)ndrw=n, so that yi/quroi brotoi/ = yiquristai/, but b. is hardly so colorless in P.
a)mfote/rois: “To both parties,” the prince and his slandered friends, tw=| diaballome/nw| kai\ tw=| pro\s o(\n diaba/lletai (Schol.).
u(pofa/ties: Böckh has u(pofau/ties, Bothe u(pofa/tores. “Secret speakings of calumnies” for “secret calumniators” does not satisfy. We want a masc. subst. Some MSS. have u(pofa/nties from fai/nw.
o)rgai=s: See P. 1.89.

a)tene/s=pantelw=s. P. has proudly compared himself to the *dio\s o)/rnis qei=os, O. 2.97, and it may be well to remember that the eagle and the fox were not friends, acc. to the fabulist Archilochos, and that the eagle was the “totem” of the Aiakidai and of Aias, Pindar's favorite, a straightforward hero (N. 8.23 foll.).

The usual interpretation gives the whole passage to one voice. “But what good does this do to the fox (the whisperer). I, Pindar, am a cork not to be sunk by his arts. I know it is impossible for a crafty citizen to utter a word of power among the good, and, though by his fawning he makes his way, I do not share his confidence. My plan is: love thy friend and cheat thine enemy — the enemy alone is fair game. The man of straightforward speech hath the vantage-ground everywhere, under every form of government.” In the introduction I have suggested two voices.

kerdoi=: To me convincing emendation of Huschke for ke/rdei. kerdw/ is a popular name for fox, Ar. Eq. 1068. First Voice: “But what doth Master Reynard gain by his game?” The pun in kerdoi= . . . ke/rdessi is obvious. The proverb a)lw/phc dwrodokei=tai is taken from Kratinos' parody (2, 87 Mein.) of Solon's celebrated characteristic of the Athenians, fr. 11, 5 (Bergk): u(me/wn ei(=s me\n e(/kastos a)lw/pekos i)/xnesi bai/nel.

a(/te ga\r . . . a(/lmas: Second Voice: “His gain is to be an a)/maxon kako/n (v. 76). He can say: I am a cork that is always atop, though all the rest be under water. I am a cat, and always fall on my feet.” Fennell, who, like the others, understands the poet to speak of himself, allegorizes thus: “The net is the band of contemporary poets; the heavy parts are those of poor and precarious repute, who try to drag down the cork, Pindar.”
ei)na/lion po/non: Toil of the sea. So Theokr. 21, 39: deilino\n w(s kate/darqon e)n ei)nali/oisi po/noisi.

skeua=s e(te/ras: The a)mfo/teroi above mentioned — the whole world outside of the
slanderer.

fello\s w(/s: The comparison is not so homely in Greek as in English. “Cork” could hardly be used with us in elevated poetry, but Aisch. Choëph. 505:
pai=des ga\r a)ndri\ klh|do/nes swth/rioi
qano/nti: felloi\ d' w(\s a)/gousi di/ktuon
to\n e)k buqou= klwsth=ra sw/|zontes li/nou.
“Our withers are unwrung” might be as impossible for an un-English poet.
a(/lmas: With a)ba/ptistos.

div3.head: Antistrophe 4
div3.p: First Voice: “But you are, after all, a mere cork. You have no weight. A deceitful man cannot utter a word of power among the good (the conservatives).”
a)du/nata: So O. 1.52: a)/pora, P. 1.34: e)oiko/ta.
a)sto/n: a). is much more frequently used by P. than poli/ths, as he prefers strato/s to da=mos. See O. 6.7. — Second Voice: “Well, what of that? The deceitful man fawns and makes his way thus.”
ma/n: Often used to meet objections. Cf. P. 1.63.
sai/nwn: Specifically of the dog. See P. 1.52.

a)_ga/n. The MS. a)/gan has the first syllable short. a)gh/, “bend,” is not the doubling of the fox, but the peculiar fawning way in which the dog makes an arc of himself. J. H. H. Schmidt reads au)da/n and compare for diaple/kei P. 12.8: ou)/lion qrh=non diaple/kei.
diaple/kei: Commentators compare Aischin. 3, 28: a)ntidiaple/kei pro\s tou=to eu)qu/s, but there the metaphor is from the twists and turns of wrestlers. Here we are still with the dog.
ou)/ voi mete/xw qra/seos: First Voice: “I do not share his confidence.” qra/sos in a good sense, v. 63.

fi/lon ei)/h filei=n, kte(.: Second Voice: “I do not deny the claims of friendship; it is only mine adversary that I seek to circumvent.” Others think this perfectly consistent with the antique morality of a man like Pindar. Compare I. 3 (4), 66: xrh\ de\ pa=n e)/rdonta maurw=sai to
 e)xqro/n, Archiloch. fr. 65 (Bergk): e(
 d' e)pi/stamai me/ga | to
 kakw=s me drw=nta deinoi=s a)ntamei/besqai kakoi=s. P. is supposed to say: “Let my adversary play the monkey, the fox, the dog; I can play the wolf.” Requital in full is antique; crooked ways of requital are not Pindaric.
u(poqeu/somai: Incursionem faciam, Dissen. It is more than that; it involves overtaking. The persistency and surprise of the wolf's pursuit are the points of comparison.
a)/lla: Adverbial.
e)n=e)s: See v. 11. The First Voice closing the debate.
no/mon: “Constitution,” “form of the state.”
eu)qu/glwssos: In opposition to the o(doi\ skoliai/, skoliai\ a)pa/tai (fr. XI. 76, 2).
profe/rei: “Comes to the front.”
para\ turanni/di: As if para\ tura/nnois.
o( la/bros strato/s: Milton's “fierce democratie.”
oi( sofoi/: The aristocracy.

xrh\ de\ pro\s qeo\n ou)k e)ri/zein:
The neg. ou)k, as if he were about to say a)lla\ fe/rein e)lafrw=s e)pauxe/nion zugo/n. As it stands, it looks like a licentious ou)k with the inf., of which there are very few. The connection is shown in the introduction. Though the straightforward man has the lead in every form of state, yet his enemies have sometimes the upper hand, and we must not quarrel with God for this. But the envious do not wish him to have anything at all, and so they overreach themselves, and come to harm.

div3.head: Epode 4
div3.p: a)ne/xei: As in So. O. C. 680: kisso\n a)ne/xousa , “upholding,” “holding high.”
ta\ kei/nwn: The fortunes of the whisperers.
e)/dwken: As there is no metrical reason for not using di/dwsin, we may accept a contrast between continued and concentrated action. See v. 50.

sta/qmas: sta/qmh is grammh/, N. 6.8. The Schol. thinks of a measuring-line. The measuring-line has two sharp pegs. The measurer fastens one in the ground and pulls the cord tight, in order to stretch it over more space than it ought to cover (perissa=s). In so doing he runs the peg into his own heart. Hermann finds an allusion to the play dielkusti/nda, still played everywhere. This would make e(lko/menoi reciprocal, “one another,” and sta/qmas a whence-case, but for perissa=s we should have to read perissw=s. On the other interpretation, sta/qmas is the genitive of the hold, as in P. 9.132: parqe/non kedna\n xeri\ xeiro\s e(lw/n. Schneidewin has noticed the play on e(lko/menoi and e(/lkos.
e(a=| . . . kardi/a|: As if “one's heart” for “their heart.”
o(/sa . . . tuxei=n: tugxa/nw often takes a pronominal neut. acc.
fronti/di mhti/ontai: “Are planning with anxious thought.”

fe/rein . . . zugo/n: Yet another animal. This whole fabulistic passage seems to point to court pasquinades. A reference to Hieron's secret police of w)takoustai/, “eavesdroppers,” and potagwgi/des (-dai), “tale-bearers,” Aristot. Pol. 5, 11, is to me incredible.
poti\ ke/ntron . . . laktize/men: A homely proverb familiar to us from Acts [9, 5] 26, 14. Doubtless of immemorial antiquity in Greece, Aisch. P.V. 323; Ag. 1624; Eur. Bacch. 795.
a)do/nta = a(do/nta. Cf. O. 3.1; 7, 17.

div2.p: This poem, which is not so much an e)pini/kion as a Consolatio ad Hieronem, is classed with the e)pini/kia because it celebrates the victories that Hieron gained with his race-horse *fere/nikos (v. 74) at Delphi, Pyth. 26 and 27 (Ol. 73, 3, and 74, 3, 486 and 482 B.C.). According to Böckh, the composition of the poem belongs to a much later period, Ol. 76, 3 (474 B.C.). Earlier than Ol. 76, 1 (476 B.C.) it cannot be, for Hieron is called *ai)tnai=os (v. 69), and Aitna was founded in that year. Later than Ol. 76, 3 it cannot well be, for in that year Hieron won a chariot-race at Delphi, of which no mention is made in this poem. Böckh thinks that the ode was composed shortly before P. 1, probably to celebrate the recurrent date of the previous victories. Hieron was suffering (compare P. 1.50), and hence the blending of congratulation and consolation. The “historical” allusions to scandals in Hieron's family and to the quarrels of the court physicians are all due to the fancy of the commentators.

The drift of P. 3 seems to be plain enough. Hieron is victorious, but suffering, and he must learn that the gods give two pains for one pleasure, and be content to have only one against one. To expect more is to reach out to what is not and cannot be. To this lesson the poet leads up step by step. So in the very beginning of this ode he himself sets an example of the impatient yearning he condemns. “Would that the old Centaur, the master of Asklepios, the great healer, were alive!” A poet, Pindar longs for the control of leechcraft, and does not recognize his own ambition until other examples of disappointment pass before his eyes. Such an example is Koronis, mother of Asklepios. This was her sin: she had one love, she wanted yet another (v. 25). Asklepios himself comes next. He was a leech of wide renown — a benefactor to his kind — but he was a slave to gain (v. 54). This was his sin, and, like his mother, he perished
(v. 57). And now the poet draws the moral. “Mortals must seek what is meet for mortals, and recognize where they stand, what is their fate.” The wish is renewed, but this time with a sigh. The poet is not satisfied with paying Hieron his homage in music, he yearns to bring him the master of healing and gain a double share of favor. It must not be; he cannot cross the water with this double joy (v. 72). He must be content to stay at home and make vows to the goddess at his door (v. 77). This lesson Hieron and Hieron's poet must divide: e(\n par' e)slo\n ph/mata su/nduo dai/ontai brotoi=s | a)qa/natoi (v. 81). That is the rule. Make the best of it. Look at Peleus. Look at Kadmos (vv. 87, 88). They heard the Muses, as Hieron heard Pindar's songs. One married Harmonia, one Thetis (vv. 91, 92). Both saw the sons of Kronos banqueting with them, both received bridal gifts of the gods. But three daughters brought threefold sorrow to Kadmos. True, one daughter's couch was shared by Zeus (v. 99), yet this is only one joy to three sorrows. Against the bridal of Thetis set the death of Achilles (v. 100), an only son, and so more than a double sorrow. “Enjoy, then, what thou mayest while thou mayest in the changing breezes of fortune, in the ticklish balance of prosperity. This be our creed. Fit thy will to God's will. Pray for wealth. Hope for fame. Fame rests on song. Nestor and Sarpedon — the one who lost his noble son, the other lost to a divine sire — live on in lays. Few achieve this” (vv. 102115). And so the poem ends with the tacit pledge that Hieron shall live on in P.'s song as they in Homer's.
The rhythms are dactylo-epitrite (Dorian).

The distribution of the elements is different from that of an ordinary e)pini/kion. The myth, with a slight introduction, takes up nearly half the poem. Indeed, the whole ode is a picturegallery of mythic troubles. We have at full length Koronis and Asklepios, who were guilty; with less detail Kadmos and Peleus, who were innocent; and, in mere outline, Nestor and Sarpedon — Nestor, who was lord among the third generation but to see Antilochos die; Sarpedon, who was mourned by Zeus himself. But all this sorrow is lost in the light of poetry.

div3.head: Strophe 1
div3.p:
*xei/rwna: Cheiron was the great mythical healer and teacher; he gave Machaon healing drugs (Il. 4. 219), and taught Achilles medicine (Il. 11. 832). The *xei/rwnes of Kratinos
was a plea for a return to the old training, of which Achilles was the mythical example. See N. 3.43, foll.
*filuri/dan: So the Centaur is called, P. 9.32. Compare N. 3.43: *filu/ras e)n do/mois.

a(mete/ras a)po\ glw/ssas: Contrast to koino\n ve/pos. Something more was expected of the poet than such an every-day utterance. P. apologizes, as it were, on the ground of the naturalness of the wish. It was on everybody's tongue then. P. 5.107: a)/ndra kei=non e)paine/onti sunetoi/: lego/menon e)re/w.
go/non . . . kro/nou: Cf. N. 3.47: *kroni/dan *ke/ntauron.
*pali/ou: His cave was on Pelion (P. 9.30), a mountain full of medicinal herbs.
*fh=ra = qh=r(a): “Centaur.” So called Il. 1. 268; 2, 743; as well as P. 4.119.
a)gro/teron: “Upland,” as in Chapman's Homer, with the same note of ruggedness
a)ndrw=n fi/lon=fila/nqrwpon: A contrast to his name, *fh/r. Cheiron was dikaio/tatos *kentau/rwn (Il. 11. 832).
qre/yen . . . te/ktona: qr. like e)di/dacen, “bred.”
guiarke/o_s: The o must be lengthened to save the metre. Compare O. 6.103: ponto/medo_n, P. 4.184: po/qo_n, 11, 38: triodo_n.
h(/rw^a: So h(/rw^as, P. 1.53.

div3.head: Antistrophe 1
div3.p: *flegu/a: The myth was taken from the *)hoi=ai of Hesiod, a kata/logos gunaikw=n, or list of heroines to whom the gods had condescended. The story of Koronis is an especially good exemplification of the difference between epic and lyric narrative. Epic narrative is developed step by step. “The lyric poet gives the main result briefly in advance, and follows it up by a series of pictures, each of which throws light on the preceding” (Mezger).

pri\n tele/ssai: “Before having brought to term,” “before she had borne him the full time.” Eur. Bacch. 100:
e)/teken d' a(ni/ka *moi=rai
te/lesan tauro/kerwn qeo/n.
xruse/ois: P. 1.1.
*)arte/midos: A. kills women, Apollo men.

e)n qala/mw|: With damei=sa, an additional touch of color. The MSS. have ei)s *)ai/da(o) do/mon e)n qala/mw| kate/ba, which would give a quibbling tone, “went to Hades without leaving her chamber;” nor is a lingering death implied by e)n qala/mw|. Artemis is expected to kill queens e)n mega/roisi (Od. 11. 198); Artemis smites Aribas' daughter, who stole Eumaios, by hurling her into the hold of the pirate vessel (Od. 15. 479); and it was meet that the wanton Koronis should be slain e)n qala/mw| — not in her chamber, but in the bed of Ischys.
gi/netai: “Proves.”
a)poflauri/caisa/ nin: Sc. to\n xo/lon.

a)mplaki/aisi: Homeric
                                    plural, not common in Pindar. a)nore/ais (P. 8.91;
                                        N. 3.20; I. 3 [4], 29) is 
 not exactly parallel.
ai)/nhsen ga/mon: Cf. Eur. Or. 1092: h(=s le/xos g' e)ph/|nesa (Dind. pot' h)/|nesa), and 1672: kai\ le/ktr' e)ph/|nesa.
a)keireko/ma|: So the best MS., and not a)kerseko/ma|. Compare Ov. Trist. 3, 1, 60: intonsi candida templa dei , and the description of Iason, P. 4.82. A. is ever young.

div3.head: Epode 1
div3.p: spe/rma . . . kaqaro/n: k., because divine.
e)/mein' e)lqei=n: Subj. of e)lqei=n is tra/pezan.
tra/pezan numfi/an: Koronis should have waited until the birth of the son of Apollo, and then have married. The gods were tolerant of human successors.

pamfw/nwn i)axa\n u(menai/wn: P. 12.19: au)lw=n pa/mfwnon me/los. On the shield of Achilles, Il. 18. 493: polu\s d' u(me/naios o)rw/rei: | kou=roi d' o)rxhsth=res e)di/neon, e)n d' a)/ra toi=sin | au)loi\ fo/rmigge/s te boh\n e)/xon.
oi(=a: Loose reference to u(menai/wn. Cf. P. 1.73.

u(pokouri/zesq(ai): “Such petting, playful strains as girlmates love to utter in even-songs.” In the even-songs of the bridal the maids were wont to use the pet name, “baby name” (u(poko/risma), of the bride, while they indulged in playful allusions to her new life.

h)/rato tw=n a)peo/ntwn: Nikias warns the Athenians against this duse/rwtas ei)=nai tw=n a)po/ntwn (Thuk. 6, 13) . Lys. 12, 78: tw=n a)po/ntwn e)piqumw=n . Theokr. 10, 8: ou)dama/ toi sune/ba poqe/sai tina\ tw=n a)peo/ntwn.

oi(=a kai\ polloi\ pa/qon, kte(.: Pindar unfolds a moral as Homer unfolds a comparison. A reference to Hieron and foreign physicians (a)peo/ntwn), which Hermann suggests, is altogether unlikely, not to say absurd.
fu=lon . . . o(/stis: A common shift, as in “kind who;” only we follow with the plural.
ai)sxu/nwn: “Putting shame on.”
paptai/nei ta\ po/rsw: O. 1.114: mhke/ti pa/ptaine po/rsion.
metamw/nia: P. multiplies synonyms to show the bootlessness of the quest. The seekers are “futile,” the object is “unsubstantial,” the hopes “unachievable.” Cf. O. 1.82, and 14, 6.
qhreu/wn. Cf. N. 11.47: kerde/wn de\ xrh\ me/tron qhreue/men.

div3.head: Strophe 2
div3.p: e)/sxe: “Caught.” On the ingressiveness, see O. 2.10.
toiau/tan mega/lan: Keep the words separate.
a+/va+/tan = a)/tan. P. 2.28. Note the quantity.

lh=ma *korwni/dos: “Wilful Koronis.” Cf. O. 6.22: sqe/nos h(mio/nwn, 1, 88: *oi)noma/ou bi/an, and note on 8, 68. It may be of some significance that she was the sister of the wilful hero Ixion, who came to his bad end by eu)nai\ para/tropoi (P. 2.35).
ce/nou: Ischys, as we are told below (v. 31).

skopo/n: Used of the gods (O. 1.54), but esp.
of Apollo. O. 6.59: tocofo/ron *da/lou qeodma/tas skopo/n.

mhlodo/kw|: See Eur. Ion, 228:
e)pi\ d' a)sfa/ktoisi
mh/loisi mh\ pa/rit' e)s muxo/n.
to/ssais (Aeolic) = tuxw/n. Compare to/con.
*aoci/as: There is, perhaps, a play on loco/s and eu)qu/tatos, “crooked” and “straight.”

koina=ni (Dor.) = koinw=ni = mhnuth=|. Hesiod says (fr. 90) that a raven told it to Apollo. Pindar delights to depart from the popular version in little points that affect the honor of the gods; hence the emphasis laid on the pa/nta vi/santi no/w|.
para\ ... no/w|: As it were “in the courts of.” He did not go out of himself. The Schol. dulls the expression by para\ tou= no/ou puqo/menon.

gnw/man piqw/n: For the MS. gnw/ma| pepiqw/n. piqw/n= pei/sas. The acc. gnw/man gives the finer sense. Apollo forced conviction on his will, his heart. So also Mezger, who cites for this use of gn. O. 3.41; 4, 16; P. 4.84. Fennell prefers “judgment” to “heart.”
vi/santi = ei)do/ti. Cf. P. 4.248: oi)=mon i)/sami braxu/n.
yeude/wn d' ou)x a(/ptetai: Neither deceiving nor deceived. Cf. P. 9.46: se/, to\n ou) qemito\n yeu/dei qigei=n.
e)/rgois ou)/te boulai=s: On the omission of the former negative, compare P. 10.29. 41.

div3.head: Antistrophe 2
div3.p: *ei)lati/da: Ischys, son of Elatos, seems to have been a brother of Aipytos (O. 6.36), who was an Arkadian lord.
ceini/an koi/tan = koi/tan ce/nou. “Couching with a stranger.”
a)maimake/tw|: Homer's a)maima/ketos suits all the Pindaric passages. See P. 1.14.
*lake/reian: In Thessaly. Van Herwerden has called attention to the resemblance between Koronis of Lakereia and Hesiod's lake/ruza korw/nh (O. et D. 745).
krhmnoi=sin: Specifically of “bluffs.” O. 3.22: krhmnoi=s *)alfeou=.
dai/mwn: Where we should blame her mad passion, her lh=ma.

e(/teros=o( kakopoio/s (Schol.). N. 8.3: to\n me\n a(me/rois a)na/gkas xersi\ basta/zeis, e(/teron d' e(te/rais. So often after P., ple/on qa/teron poiei=n, a)gaqa\ h)\ qa/tera. “The dai/mwn e(/teros is one of the notes by which Bentley detected the false Phalaris. See ‘Letters of Phalaris,’ p. 247 (Bohn and Wagner),” C. D. Morris.
a(ma=: See O. 3.21.
polla\n . . . u(/lan: Inevitable expansion of the moral. See v. 20. The sentence is proverbial, as in James 3, 5: i)dou/, o)li/gon pu=r h(li/khn u(/lhn a)na/ptei.
spe/rmatos: O. 7.48: spe/rma . . . flogo/s, Od. 5. 490: spe/rma puro\s sw/|zwn.

div3.head: Epode 2
div3.p: tei/xei . . . e)n culi/nw|: On the pyre.

se/las . . . *(afai/stou: P. 1.25: *(afai/stoio krounou/s. The person of Hephaistos
is little felt, but it can always be brought back as in *(hfai/stou ku/nes, “sparks,” Alexis, fr. 146 (3, 452 Mein.).
ou)ke/ti: Apollo has been struggling with himself. Cf. O. 1.5.
a+/mo/n = h(me/teron, but h(me/teron = e)mo/n, and does not refer to Koronis. “Our” would be a human touch. Here it is the selfish “my.” P. 4.27: a)moi=s = e)moi=s.
o)le/ssai: The MSS. o)le/sai. o)le/sqai would not be so good. He had killed the mother, and so was about to kill the child.
matro\s barei/a| su\n pa/qa|: The same principle as lh=ma *korwni/dos (v. 25). The ill-fate of the mother = the ill-fated mother.

ba/mati d' e)n prw/tw|: An exaggeration of trita/tw|, which Aristarchos preferred, after Il. 13. 20: tri\s me\n o)re/cat' i)w\n (*poseidw=n), to\ de\ te/traton i(/keto te/kmwr (Schol.). Bergk suggests te/rtw| (Aeol.) = tri/tw|. See note on O. 8.46.
nekrou=: There is no good fem.

die/faine: Imperfect of vision, in an intercalated clause. So the best MS. die/fane would be an unusual intransitive, “flamed apart,” literally “shone apart,” “opened a path of light.” The flames were harmless to him.
dida/cai: The old final infinitive.
a)nqrw/poisin: More sympathetic than a)nqrw/pwn.

div3.head: Strophe 3
div3.p: au)tofu/twn: In contradistinction to wounds.
cuna/ones: The sphere of partnership and companionship is wider in Greek than in English. We usu. make the disease, not the sufferer, the companion. See Lexx. under su/neimi, sunoikw=, sunnai/w.
qerinw=| puri/: Sunstroke. Perh. “Summer fever.”
e)/cagen: “Brought out,” still used by the profession.
tou\s me/n: Resumes the division indicated, v. 47.

malakai=s e)paoidai=s: Incantations were a regular part of physic among the Greek medicine-men. The order is the order of severity. So. Aias, 581:
ou) pro\s i)atrou= sofou=
qroei=n e)pw|da\s pro\s tomw=nti ph/mati.
a)mfe/pwn . . . pi/nontas . . . pera/ptwn: P. breaks what seems to him the hateful uniformity by putting pi/nontas instead of a causative, such as pipi/skwn, or an abstract, such as potoi=s.
prosane/a: “Soothing potions.”
pera/ptwn . . . fa/rmaka: “Swathing with simples.” Plasters and poultices are conspicuous in early leechcraft. pera/ptwn (Aeolic) = peria/ptwn. So N. 11.40: pero/dois.

tomai=s e)/stasen o)rqou/s: tomh/ is the regular surgical word for our “knife,” and the pl. gives the temporal effect of te/mnwn. P. makes in e)/stasen a sudden and effective change to the finite verb, so as to be done with it. Compare O. 1.14; P. 1.55. i(sta/s would be feeble. To punctuate at e)/cagen: and make tou\s me\n ... tou\s de\ prosane/a
depend on e)/stasen is to efface the growth of the sentence and the rhythm. The methods are in the durative tenses, the results in the complexive (aorist).

div3.head: Antistrophe 3
div3.p: de/detai: “Is a thrall,” “is in bondage.” dei=tai would mean “lets itself be enthralled by.” The instr. dative is the regular construction.
e)/trapen . . . komi/sai: P. 9.47: e)/trape . . . parfa/men. The prose protre/pein has lost its color.

a)ga/nori: Cf. P. 10.18: a)ga/nora plou=ton, and O. 1.2: mega/noros . . . plou/tou. One cannot help thinking of xrh/mata xrh/mat' a)nh/r (I. 2, 11). See Plato's criticism of this passage, Resp. 3, 408 B. C.
a)/ndra: Hippolytos, son of Theseus, acc. to the Schol. Compare Verg. Aen. 7, 765-774.
komi/sai: N. 8.44: tea\n yuxa\n komi/cai | ou)/ moi dunato/n.
a(lwko/ta: Sc. qana/tw|.
xersi/: O. 9.32: sku/talon ti/nace xersi/n. The addition of “hand” does not give the same vigor in English.
a)mfoi=n: The Hesiodic fragment tells only of the death of Asklepios (Athenag. Leg. p. 134).
e)ne/skimyen: “Brought crashing down.”
qnatai=s frasi/n: Depends on e)oiko/ta, and is not dat. of manner (Dissen) to masteue/men, modesta mente. Cf. I. 4 (5), 16: qnata\ qnatoi=si pre/pei.
to\ pa\r podo/s: P. 10.62: fronti/da ta\n pa\r podo/s (I. 7, 13: to\ . . . pro\ podo/s), “that which stretches from the place of the foot,” “our nearest business.”
oi(/as ei)me\n ai)/sas: As Archilochos says: gi/gnwske d' oi(=os r(usmo\s a)nqrw/pous e)/xei. ai)/sas: Genitive of the owner.

div3.head: Epode 3
div3.p: fi/la yuxa/: P. is addressing himself and swinging back to his theme. “Asklepios sought to rescue a man fordone. We must seek only what is meet, see what is before us, what are the limits of our fate. Seek not the life of the immortals, my soul; do the work of the day, play thy humble part to the end. And yet, would that I could bring the double delight of health and poesy; would that my song had power to charm Cheiron! Then the unreal would be achieved by the real, health which I cannot bring by poesy which I do.” fi/la yuxa/ of Hieron would be too sweet. It is more likely that P. is taking a lesson to himself.
bi/on a)qa/naton = to\ e)comoiou=sqai toi=s qeoi=s (Schol.).
ta\n d' e)/mprakton a)/ntlei maxana/n: “Exhaust all practicable means,” “drain each resource.”
ei) de\ . . . e)/naie: Wish felt in the condition.
meliga/rues u(/mnoi: So O. 11 (10), 4; N. 3.4.
a)ndra/sin: The plural is part of the shyness with which the poet alludes to Hieron's disorder.
qerma=n no/swn: “Fevers.”
h)/ tina *latoi+/da , kte(.: “Some one called (the son) of Latoides, or son of the Sire;” Asklepios or Apollo, son of the great Sire Zeus. Bergk suggests h)\ pate/ra=*)apo/llw.
kai/ ken . . . mo/lon: This shows that the poem was composed in Greece, and not in Sicily.
*)ioni/an . . . qa/lassan: Elsewhere (N. 4.53) called *)io/nion po/ron.
*)are/qousan: The famous fountain of Ortygia (P. 2.6), called N. 1.1: a)/mpneuma semno\n *)alfeou=.
*ai)tnai=on ce/non: See P. 1.

div3.head: Strophe 4
div3.p: ne/mei: “Rules” without an object.
a)stoi=s: Seems to mean here the rank and file of the citizens (O. 13.2).
a)gaqoi=s: The optimates, doubtless, for they are “the good” to a Dorian.
xa/ritas = xa/rmata.
u(gi/eian . . . xruse/an: See P. 1.1; and for the praise of health, compare Lucian's De lapsu inter salutandum.
kw=mo/n te: On the effect of te in twinning the two xa/rites, see O. 1.62.
a)e/qlwn *puqi/wn: Depends on stefa/nois. So N. 5.5: pagkrati/ou ste/fanon.

ai)/glan stefa/nois: Cf. O. 1.14: a)glai+/cetai de\ kai\ mousika=s e)n a)w/tw|, and O. 11 (10), 13: ko/smon e)pi\ stefa/nw| . . . a(dumelh= keladh/sw. The song lends additional lustre to the lustrous crowns. The plur. on account of the victories of Pherenikos.
*fere/nikos: O. 1.18.
e)n *ki/rra| pote/: Kirrha was the Delphian hippodrome. The victory was won at least eight years before.
fami/: Out of construction. Elsewhere in P. with acc. and inf.
fa/os: Acc. to J. H. H. Schmidt, fa/os is the light of joy (O. 10 [11], 25; I. 2, 17), fe/ggos, for which we here have ai)/glan, is the light of glory (O. 2.62; P. 9.98; N. 3.64; 9, 42).

div3.head: Antistrophe 4
div3.p: a)lla/: “Well,” since that may not be.
e)peu/casqai: “Offer a vow to,” not simply “pray.”
e)qe/lw: See P. 1.62.

*matri/: Magna Mater or Rhea (Kybele is not mentioned in Pindar). The worship of this Phrygian goddess was hereditary in the flute-playing family of P. (see P. 12), and he had a chapel in front of his house dedicated to the joint service of Rhea and Pan. Among the kou=rai, who sang parqe/nia by night to the two deities, are said to have been P.'s daughters, Eumetis and Protomache. The Scholiasts tell us that Magna Mater was tw=n no/swn au)chtikh\ kai\ meiwtikh/. Welcker takes kou=rai with *pani/, and considers them to be nymphs. But there is an evident connection between the molph/ and the e)peuxh/.
su\n *pani/: Cf. fr. VI. 1: w)= *pa/n, . . . semnw=n a)du/twn fu/lac, *matro\s mega/las o)pade/.
lo/gwn . . . korufa/n: “The right point (the lesson) of sayings.”

manqa/nwn:
“Learning.” The lesson is ever before him. It is a proverb.
e(\n par' e)slo\n, kte(.: One and two are typical. So we have not to do with avoirdupois or apothecaries' weight in Spenser's “a dram of sweete is worth a pound of soure” (F. Q. III. 30).
ko/smw| =kosmi/ws.
ta\ kala\ tre/yantes e)/cw: Another proverbial locution; “turning the fair part outward” (of clothes), as we might say, “putting the best foot foremost” (of shoes).

div3.head: Epode 4
div3.p: ti\n de\ . . . e(/petai: Thy e(\n e)slo/n is great.
de/rketai: As the Biblical “look upon” (with favor). Compare O. 7.11: a)/llote d' a)/llon e)popteu/ei *xa/ris. “The eyes of the Lord are upon the righteous.”
ei)/ tin' a)nqr.: Compare O. 1.54.
o( me/gas po/tmos: N. 4.42: po/tmos a)/nac.
a)sfalh/s=a)/ptaistos.
e)/gento = e)ge/neto: Aor. with neg.
*phlei= . . . *ka/dmw|: Proverbial examples of high fortune and noble character, O. 2.86.
oi(/ = ou(=toi.
sxei=n: O. 2.10.
xrusampu/kwn . . . *moisa=n: The Muses so styled again, I. 2, 1.

e)n o)/rei: Pelion. Cf. N. 5.22: pro/frwn de\ kai\ kei=nos a)/eid' e)n *pali/w| | *moisa=n o( ka/llistos xoro/s. The marriage of Peleus and Thetis was a favorite theme with the poets. See N. 4.65, quoted below. Catullus makes the Fates sing at the wedding (64, 322).
o(po/q': The indic. of a single occasion. With the indic. o(po/te has very much the sense of h(ni/ka. Compare O. 1.37; 9, 104; P. 8.41; 11, 19; I. 6 (7), 6; fr. V. 1, 6.

*nhre/os: The sea-gods were oracular. So Poseidon (O. 6.58). So Proteus and Glaukos. For Nereus as a prophet, the commentators. cite Hesiod, Theog. 233, Eur. Hel. 15, Hor. Od. 1, 15, 5. See also P. 9.102.

div3.head: Strophe 5
div3.p: *kro/nou pai=das . . . i)/don , kte(.: N. 4.66: ei)=den d' eu)/kuklon e(/dran, ta=s ou)ranou= basilh=es po/ntou t' e)fezo/menoi, kte(.
*dio\s . . . xa/rin: Here “thanks to Zeus.”
e)/stasan o)rqa\n kardi/an: “Raised their hearts again,” “raised their sunken hearts,” o)rqa/n being proleptic, “erect.”
me/ros: e)rh/mwsan, with two acc., as a)fairei=sqai in prose.
ai( trei=s: Ino, Agaue, Autonoë. Cf. O. 2.25.
*quw/na| = *seme/la|.

div3.head: Antistrophe 5
div3.p: ti/kten: P. uses the imperf. seven times (nearly all in dactylo-epitrites), the aorist nine times. See note on O. 6.41.
to/cois: Il. 22. 359: h)/mati tw=| o(/te ke/n se *pa/ris kai\ *foi=bos *)apo/llwn | e)sqlo\n e)o/nt' o)le/swsin e)ni\ *skaih=|si pu/lh|si.
kaio/menos: See O. 3.6.

tugxa/nont' eu)= pasxe/men = eu)tuxou=nt' eu)= pasxe/men.
Compare O. 2.56: to\ de\ tuxei=n, “success,” and N. 1.32: a)ll' e)o/ntwn eu)= paqei=n, kte(.
a)/llote d' a)lloi=ai , kte(.: O. 7.95: a)/llot' a)lloi=ai diaiqu/ssoisin au)=rai.
pa/mpolus: So Dissen for o(\s polu/s. Others a)/pletos. p. with e)pibri/sais, “in all its fulness.”
e)pibri/sais: “Coming down with weight.”

div3.head: Epode 5
div3.p: smikro\s e)n smikroi=s , kte(.: smikroi=s is neut. “I will be small when my fortunes are small, great when they are great.” P. puts himself in Hieron's place. See O. 3.45.

to\n a)mfe/pont' ai)ei\ . . . dai/mona: “My shifting fortune.” Though prosperity is a polu/filos e(pe/tas, excessive prosperity is dangerous, and the wise man must be prepared to do homage to the fortunes that attend him from time to time.
frasi/n: “Heartily.”
a)skh/sw: So a)skei=tai *qe/mis, O. 8.22; N. 11.8. a). of honor and homage, while qerapeu/wn is used of service.
kat' e)ma\n . . . maxana/n: “To the extent of my power,” “with all my might.” Cf. v. 62: ta\n e)/mprakton a)/ntlei maxana/n.
ei) de/ moi . . . o)re/cai: Hieron might be expected to say w)/recen. P. looks upon such fortune as a dream. See note on O. 6.4.
eu(re/sqai: “Gain.” P. 1.48.

pro/sw: With a solemn indefiniteness, that is yet made sufficiently plain by the mention of Nestor and Sarpedon. The pro/sw is “among them that shall call this time ancient” (Dante), where songs shall make thee what N. and S. are to us.
*ne/stora: A model prince, though mentioned by P. only here and P. 6.35, *messani/ou ge/rontos.

*sarphdo/na: Lykian Sarpedon balances (Pylian) Nestor. One shining light is taken out of each camp. Sarpedon, we are reminded, was the grandson of Bellerophon, B. was from Corinth, and Corinth was the metropolis of Syracuse. But P. is thinking of Homer and the looming figures of Nestor on the Greek, Sarpedon on the Trojan side. Some quiet mischief in this, perhaps (N. 7.21).
a)nqrw/pwn fa/tis: fa/ti_s = fa/tias, hominum fabulas, compare “the talk of the town” — “whose names are in every mouth.”
te/ktones: So Kratinos (Schol., Ar. Eq. 527): te/ktones eu)pala/mwn u(/mnwn.
a(/rmosan: “Framed.” So Lat. pangere.
xroni/a tele/qei: Cf. N. 4.6: r(h=ma d' e(rgma/twn xroniw/teron bioteu/ei.
pra/casq(ai) = eu(re/sqai (v. 111).

div2.p: ArkesilasDoric form of Arkesilaos. IV., son of Battos IV., king of Kyrene, won a Pythian victory with the chariot, P. 3.1 (Ol. 78, 3 = 466 B.C.). This victory is commemorated in the fourth and fifth Pythian odes. P. 5 was composed to celebrate the return of the victorious pomph/, which took place, as has been conjectured, at the time of the *ka/rneia, a festival which fell about the same time as the Pythian. The fourth ode was doubtless composed to be sung at a banquet in the royal palace, and seems to have been prepared at the urgent request of one Damophilos, who had been exiled by Arkesilas for participating in an aristocratic rebellion. That he was related to Arkesilas, that he was akin to Pindar, is little more than conjecture. “Urgent request” means in Pindar's case a lordly recompense. The poem was a grand peace-offering, and the reconciliation had doubtless been quietly arranged in advance.

Not only in size, but also in many other respects, the fourth Pythian is Pindar's greatest poem — a prime favorite with all Pindaric scholars. The obscurities are few in proportion to the bulk, the diction is noble and brilliant. The aesthetic value is great, for in this poem we have a whole incorporated theory of the lyric treatment of epic themes, the Argonautic expedition in points of light.

After a brief invocation of the Muse, Pindar tells how the priestess of Apollo bade Battos leave his sacred island, Thera, and found a city on a shimmering hill in Libya, and thus bring to honor the prophecy of Medeia (vv. 1-9).

In the Prophecy of Medeia, we learn the story of the wonderful clod that a deity delivered to the Argonaut Euphamos where the Libyan lake Tritonis empties into the sea. Washed overboard, this symbol of sovereignty followed the wet main to
Thera, whence the descendants of Euphamos should, at the bidding of Apollo, go forth and possess the land promised to their ancestor (vv. 10-56).

Such is the prophecy that was fulfilled by Battos, the founder of Kyrene, and it is to the descendant of this Battos in the eighth generation that Apollo has given the glory of the victory in the chariot-race, the theme of Pindar's song (vv. 57-69).
So far the overture. Then follows the Quest of the Golden Fleece, or the Voyage of the Argonauts, which constitutes the bulk of the poem (vv. 70-256).

On their return voyage the Argonauts had shared the couches of Lemnian heroines. From such a union came the stock of Euphamos, which went first to Lakedaimon, thence to Thera, and from Thera to Kyrene (v. 261).

Here the poem seems to pause. A stop at *kura/nas (v. 261) would satisfy mind and ear. But P. continues with an afterthought participle, which emphasizes the importance of right counsel, and prepares the message that he has to deliver. The message is one that needs delicate handling, and, like the wise woman of Tekoah, P. clothes it in a parable — the Apologue of the Lopped Oak (vv. 263-268).

The answer is not given at once. The king is a healer that knows well the art of the soothing hand. The king is one that, under the guidance of God, can put the shaken city on its true foundation. He has only to will and it is done. Let him then take counsel, and consider what Homer said, that a fair messenger makes fair tidings. Such a fair messenger is the poet's Muse (vv. 270-279).

The way being thus prepared, the name of Damophilos is mentioned for the first time, and the praise of the banished nobleman is blended with an appeal for such forgiveness as Zeus accorded the Titans. “Let him see his home again; let him take his delight in banquets by Apollo's fountain. Let him make melody on the harp. Let his days be days of quietness, himself all harmless, by the world unharmed. Then he can tell what a wellspring of song he found for Arkesilas at Thebes” (vv. 281-299).

As the fourth Pythian is thrown out of line with the other odes by its size, and as this characteristic determines the handling of the poem, the distribution of the masses becomes a matter of leading importance and cannot be relegated, as has been
done elsewhere, to a mere summary. Pindar nowhere else goes beyond five triads. Here he has the relatively vast structure of thirteen. If the introduction bore any proportion to the myth, or to the introductions of the other poems, we should have a large porch of song. What do we find? The poet seems to enter upon the theme at once, as if he were composing an epic and not a lyric. The ringing relative that so often introduces the myth makes itself heard almost immediately after the invocation of the Muse (v. 4). We slip out of port in a moment, and find ourselves in the midst of the returning Argonauts. But the introduction is longer than it seems. The first three triads constitute an introductory epyllion — the Prophecy of Medeia — which bears a just proportion to the rest. Only if the usual measure were observed the myth would occupy seven triads and the conclusion three (3+7+3), but the story runs over into the eleventh triad, when the poet chides himself as having lingered too long (v. 247), and the slow imperfects give way to the rapid aorists. He calls on Arkesilas (v. 250) in order to show that he is hasting to Kyrene, and the emphasis laid on the guidance of Apollo prepares the conclusion. Notice that the story of the Argonauts makes the same returning sweep to Arkesilas and Apollo as the Prophecy of Medeia (vv. 65, 66). Apollo is an oracular god, and speaks in riddles. “So read me,” the poet says, “the riddle of Oidipus” (v. 263). After this riddle is given, “fulfil the word of Homer” (v. 277). Both Oidipus and Homer, be it noted, are Apollinic. The answer to the riddle is — Damophilos (v. 281); but it is not until the poet has claimed the good messenger's credit, according to the word of Homer, that he brings forth the name. The poem closes with a commendation of the banished nobleman, and with the evident intimation that this song was made at his desire (v. 299).

The myth itself (vv. 70-256) is natural enough. It is natural enough that in celebrating the victory of Arkesilas, Pindar should sing of the founding of Kyrene; and the introduction of the Argonautic expedition may be justified on general grounds; but this is not the only time that Pindar has sung Kyrene. In P. 5 Battos and the Aigeidai come to honor, in P. 9, the heroine Kyrene, but there is no such overwhelming excess of the myth. In the length of the myth nothing more is to be seen than the costliness of the offering. If the poem was to be long, the myth must needs be long.

There are those who see in Pindar's Argonautic expedition a parable. Damophilos is Iason. Then Arkesilas must be Pelias — which is incredible. Damophilos is anybody else, anything else. Sooner the soul of Phrixos (v. 159), sooner the mystic clod that Euphamos received (v. 21). The tarrying of the soul of Phrixos, the drifting of the clod, the long voyage of the Argonauts, may be symbolical of the banishment of Damophilos. He could not rest save in Kyrene (v. 294). The true keynote, then, is the sweetness of return, the sweetness of the fulfilment of prophecy and of the fruition of hope long deferred. The ancient prophecy came to pass, and Battos founded Kyrene (vv. 6, 260). The word of Medeia was brought to honor in the seventeenth generation (v. 10). The ships should one day be exchanged for chariots (v. 18). The clod, following the watery main, was borne to Thera, not to Tainaros (v. 42), and yet the pledge failed not. Iason came back to his native land (v. 78). Everybody comes back, not Iason alone, else the moral were too pointed. Let Damophilos come back. Let there be one Kyrenaian more.
The measures are dactylo-epitrite (Dorian), and the grave, oracular tone is heard in rhythm as well as in diction.

“As this poem, among all the Pindaric odes, approaches the epos most closely, so the rhythmical composition reminds one of the simplicity of an hexametrical hymn. Four times in succession we have precisely the same pentapody,
3 u | - - | - u u | - u u | - ^
the close of which reminds us of the hexameter, which, like it, prefers the trisyllabic bar towards the close. Another example of this will be sought in vain throughout Pindar. These five pentapodies are followed by nine tetrapodies, interrupted only by a dipody in the middle of the strophe, where there is usually most movement” (J. H. H. Schmidt).

div3.head: Strophe 1
div3.p: sa/meron . . . sta=men: So N. 1.19: e)/stan d' e)p' au)lei/ais qu/rais . P. “floats double.” The Muse is his shadow. sta=men =sth=nai. So ba=men (v. 39)=bh=nai.
a)ndri\ fi/lw|: See on P. 1.92.
eu)i/ppou: Compare v. 17.
*kura/nas: See on P. 1.60.
*)arkesi/la|: The position gives zest to the postponed proper name. Compare P. 8.42.

*latoi/daisin: Compare N. 6.42: a)dw\n e)/rnesi *latou=s (of a victory at the Pythian games); 9, 4: mate/ri kai\ didu/mois pai/dessin . . . *puqw=nos ai)peina=s o(mokla/rois e)po/ptais. Apollo and Artemis, together with their mother, presided over the Pythian
games. Hence o)feilo/menon. — au)/ch|s: “Freshen the gale of songs” (Fennell).

ou)=ron u(/mnwn: N. 6.31: ou)=ron . . . e)pe/wn. P. makes much use of nautical metaphors and similes, but as the Battiads were originally Minyans, a manner of Vikings (O. 14.4), there is a special Argonautical propriety in this use of ou)=ron.

xruse/wn . . . ai)htw=n: There were two golden eagles on the o)mfalo/s at Delphi, the white stone navel, at which two eagles, sent from east and west, had met, and so determined the centre of the earth. ai)htw=n in one MS.

ou)k a)poda/mou . . . tuxo/ntos: When the god was present in person the oracle was so much more potent. Cf. P. 3.27: e)n d' a)/ra mhlodo/kw| *puqw=ni to/ssais. Apollo was a migratory god, now in Lykia, now in Delos (P. 1.39). For Apollo's sojourn among the Hyperboreans, see P. 10.30 foll.
i(/rea, an Aeolic form = i(e/reia, which Christ gives. Böckh and others, i(re/a.
xrh=sen oi)kisth=ra *ba/tton: “Appointed by an oracle Battos (as) colonizer.” Compare O. 7.32: plo/on ei)=pe, where the verbal element is felt, as here.
karpofo/rou *libu/as: P. 9.63 ou)/te pagka/rpwn futw=n nh/poinon.
i(era\n | va=son: Thera (Santorini = Saint Eirene).

w(s . . . kti/sseien = kti/sai. As xrh=sen is here a verb of will, w(s is hardly so purely final as in O. 10 (11), 31; N. 8.36. It is used rather as o)/fra, P. 1.72. Compare Il. 1. 558: th=| s' o)i/w kataneu=sai e)th/tumon w(s *)axilh=a | timh/sh|s, o)le/sh|s de\ pole/as e)pi\ nhusi\n *)axaiw=n, and L. and S. ed. 7, S. V. o(/pws, end.

a)rgino/enti mastw=|: “A shimmering hill,” an Albion Mamelon. P. 9.59: o)/xqon . . . a)mfi/pedon. Kyrene was built on a chalk cliff. For description and recent researches, see F. B. Goddard in Am. Journ. of Philology, V. 31 foll.

div3.head: Antistrophe 1
div3.p: a)gkomi/sai: “Bring back safe,” “redeem,” “fulfil.” Cf. “my word shall not return unto me void.” The MSS. have a)gkomi/sai q', of which the editors have made a)gkomi/saiq'. P. nowhere uses the middle of komi/zw, nor is it necessary here.

e(bdo/ma| kai\ su
 deka/ta|: As this is not equivalent to su
 e(bdo/ma| kai\ su
 deka/ta|, P. 1.14 is not a parallel. Cf. O. 13.58: ge/nei fi/lw| su
 *)atre/os. It is idle to count these seventeen generations.
*qh/raion: “Uttered in Thera,” the a(li/plaktos ga= of v. 14.

zamenh/s: Animosa. Others think of non sine dis animosa, and consider Medea “inspired.” It is simply “bold,” “brave,” “highspirited,” as suits such a heroine. There is no such curious adaptation of epithet to circumstance as we find in the hivework of Horace (apis Matinae | more modoque).

*ke/klute: The
speech ends, v. 56.

*)epa/foio ko/ran: Epaphos, son of Zeus and Io. The Scholiasts notice the blending of nymph and country, which is very easy here, as r(i/zan and futeu/sesqai are often used of persons. N. 5.7: e)k de\ *kro/nou kai\ *zhno\s h(/rwas ai)xmata\s futeuqe/ntas ta=sde ga=s.
a)ste/wn r(i/zan: This root, which is to spring up out of Libya, is Kyrene, metropolis of Apollonia, Hesperides, Barka, etc.
futeu/sesqai: “Shall have planted in her” (Fennell), as one should say “shall conceive and bring forth.” P. has no fut. pass. apart from the fut. middle.
melhsi/mbroton: Only here in Greek. Compare Od. 12. 70: *)argw\ pa=si me/lousa.
e)n *)/ammwnos qeme/qlois: The whole region was sacred to Zeus Ammon (Schol.).

div3.head: Epode 1
div3.p: a)nti\ delfi/nwn, kte(.: The dolphins were to the Greeks the horses of the sea, and we must not spoil poetry by introducing the notions of “fisheries” and “studs,” as some have done. On the speed of the dolphin, see P. 2.50: qeo\s . . . qalassai=on paramei/betai | delfi=na, and N. 6.72: delfi=ni/ ken | ta/xos di' a(/lmas ei)ka/zoimi *melhsi/an.

a(ni/a t' a)nt' e)retmw=n di/frous te: e(\n dia\ duoi=n, in the extreme form assumed here, can hardly be proved for Greek, and a(ni/a di/frous te is not a(ni/a di/frwn. The correspondence between “oar” and “rein” is not to be pressed, the “rein” being rather “the rudder” (phda/lion). The two spheres of ship and chariot have much in common, and borrow much from each other.
nwma/soisin: nwma=n of ships, P. 1.86: nw/ma dikai/w| phdali/w| strato/n, of reins, as here, I. 1, 15: a(ni/a . . . nwma/sant(a). Subject “they,” i. e., “men.”
a)ello/podas: For the metonymy, compare P. 2.11: a(/rmata peisixa/lina, and O. 5.3: a)kamanto/podos a)ph/nas.

kei=nos o)/rnis: “That token,” the clod of earth (v. 21). o)/rnis and oi)wno/s are familiarly used without too lively a sense of the bird meaning. See Ar. Av. 719: o)/rnin de\ nomi/zete pa/nq' o(/saper peri\ mantei/as diakri/nei , and Professor Postgate in Amer. Journ. of Phil. IV. 70.

*tritwni/dos e)n proxoai=s: The geography of the Argonautic expedition will always be misty, and the mistiness is essential to its poetry. On their return from Kolchoi, the Argonauts passed by the Phasis into Okeanos, thence to the Red Sea, carried their ship overland twelve days, reached Lake Tritonis, in Libya, and found an outlet from Lake Tritonis to the Mediterranean. The Okeanos is not our Ocean, the Red Sea is not our Red Sea, the Lake Tritonis that we know is inland, and Pindar is poetry.

qew=| a)ne/ri veidome/nw|: “A god taking to himself the likeness of man.” No ambiguity to a Greek. qew=| depends on de/cato (v. 22), which takes the dat. of interest (see O. 13.29), just as pri/asqai, “buy,” and so “take off one's hands.” Ar. Ach. 812: po/sou pri/wmai/ soi ta\ xoiri/dia; le/ge . A gift blesseth both. The god is supposed to be Triton. Poseidon was masking as his own son and speaking to his own son (v. 45).
gai=an: An immemorial symbolism. “With our Saxon ancestors the delivery of turf was a necessary solemnity to establish the conveyance of land.”
prw/|raqen: Because he was prw|reu/s.

ai)/sion . . . e)/klagce bronta/n: “As a sign of favor he sounded a thunder peal.” Compare v. 197: e)k nefe/wn de/ voi a)nta/use bronta=s ai)/sion fqe/gma. Bergk reads brontai/s, Aeolic participle, fr. bro/ntaimi = brontw=.

div3.head: Strophe 2
div3.p: a)/gkuran: In Homer's time there were no a)/gkurai, only eu)nai/.
poti/: With krhmna/ntwn.
xalko/genun: The flukes bite; hence “jaws” of an anchor, which is itself a bit. Compare Lat. dens ancorae.

krhmna/ntwn: Commonly considered a genitive absolute with au)tw=n, or the like, understood. Not an Homeric construction, and sparingly used in P. See O. 13.15, and below, v. 232: w(\s a)/r' au)da/santos. e)pe/tosse takes the acc. P. 10.33, but it is hard to see why it cannot be construed with the genitive here, as e)pe/tuxe in prose.
e)pe/tosse=e)pe/tuxe: Sc. qeo\s a)ne/ri ei)do/menos. On the change of subject, see O. 3.22.

dw/deka . . . fe/romen: f. is imperfect. Definite numbers usu. take the aor., but the imperfect is used when the action is checked, usu. by the aor., sometimes by the imperf. There are numberless passages from Homer on, Od. 2. 106: w(\s tri/etes me\n e)/lhqe . . . a)ll' o(/te te/traton h)=lqen e)/tos. Cf. Il. 1. 53. 54; 9, 470. 474; Od. 3. 118. 119. 304. 306, al.
nw/twn . . . e)rh/mou: Cf. v. 228: nw=ton ga=s, and Homer's eu)re/a nw=ta qala/sshs. Here we have a desert sea of sand.
ei)na/lion do/ru: Consecrated oracular language.
mh/desin: Medeia was not above an allusion to her name.
a)nspa/ssantes: Usu. “drawing ashore.” Mezger tr. “shouldering.”
a)moi=s = h(mete/rois = e)moi=s, P. 3.41.
oi)opo/los: An Homeric word, Il. 13. 473; Od. 11. 574.
dai/mwn: The god of v. 21.
per' o)/yin qhka/menos: So Bergk, after the Schol., for pro/soyin qhka/menos. per(i) qhka/menos, “having put on.” In resuming the story P. amplifies it.
a(/te: “As,” “such as those in which.”
eu)erge/tai: “The hospitable.” I. 5 (6), 70: ce/nwn eu)ergesi/ais a)gapa=tai.
dei=pn' e)pagge/llonti: The model words are found in Od. 4. 60, where Menelaos: si/tou q' a(/ptesqon kai\ xai/reton.

div3.head: Antistrophe 2
div3.p: a)lla\ ga/r: “But it might not be for.” Cf. O. 1.55.
pro/fasis: Is an assigned reason, true or false.
*eu)ru/pulos: Son of Poseidon and Kelaino, and king of Libya (Schol.). Poseidon (Triton) assumes a name like one of his own attributes. eu)rubi/as (O. 6.58), eu)rume/dwn (O. 8.31).
*)ennosi/da: So v. 173. In Homer e)nnosi/gaios, e)nosi/xqwn.
a)rou/ras: Is not felt as dependent on protuxo/n, which comes in as an after-thought, but as a partitive on a(rpa/cais.
protuxo/n: “What presented itself,” “what came to hand.”

ou)d' a)pi/qhse/ nin: “Nor did he fail to persuade him.” Herm. ou)d' a)pi/qhse/ vin (dat.), “nor did he disobey him,” the subject coming up emphatically in the second clause — the h(/rws (Euphemos) being set off against the god (Eurypylos).
voi: The position speaks for dependence on xei=r' a)nterei/sais. See O. 2.16.
bw/laka: More special and technical than gai=an (v. 21).
daimoni/an: “Fateful.”

e)nali/an ba=men: So Thiersch for e)nali/a| ba=men su\n a(/lma|. The adj. (esp. in -ios) for the prepos. and subst. So u(pai/qrios (O. 6.61). Compare peda/rsioi nai/ousi, Aisch. Prom. 710 ; qurai=on oi)xnei=n, So. El. 313. The e)nali/a bw=lac would thus match the ei)na/lion do/ru and take its own course.
ba=men = bh=nai. See v. 1.
su\n a(/lma|: Comitative-instrumental use of su/n. See P. 12.21. The clod went with the spray by which it was washed into the sea.

div3.head: Epode 2
div3.p: e(spe/ras: When men wax tired and careless.
spome/nan: Coincident with ba=men.
h)= ma/n: Protest.
w)/trunon: “I, Medeia.” w)/t. with dat., like keleu/w in poetry.
lusipo/nois: “Who relieve their masters of their toils.” So also Schol. Il. 24. 734. “Reliefs,” “relays,” would be to us a natural translation.
pri\n w(/ras: First and extremely rare use of pri/n as a preposition.
ei) ga\r oi)/koi nin ba/le: Wish passing over into condition.
*)/aida sto/ma: This was one of the most famous entrances to Hades.
vi(o\s i(ppa/rxou *poseida/wnos: A half-brother of Eurypylos on the Triton theory. This Poseidonian origin accounts for the Battiadai's love of horses.
ti/kte: See O. 6.41.
*kafisou= par' o)/xqais: A Minyan of Orchomenos (see O. 14), and so an interesting figure to a Boeotian poet. par' o)/xqais as para\ krhmnoi=sin, P. 3.34.

div3.head: Strophe 3
div3.p:
tetra/twn pai/dwn . . . ai(=ma: The blood (offspring, N. 3.65) of the fourth generation (t. p. e)pigeinome/nwn need not be genitive absolute) is the fifth generation, the time of the Dorian migration,
or the return of the Herakleidai.
su\n *danaoi=s: The Danaoi (or Achaians) were the old inhabitants of the Peloponnesos, who were driven out by the general unsettling known as the Dorian conquest.
ke ... la/be: One of P.'s few unreal conditions. See O. 12.13.
e)cani/stantai: Prophetic present, as O. 8.42.
*lakedai/monos , kte(.: The order is the line of invasion, though such coincidences are not to be pressed.
nu=n ge: Regularly nu=n de/. “As it is.”
a)llodapa=n . . . gunaikw=n: The prophecy fulfilled, v. 252: mi/gen . . . *lamnia=n . . . e)/qnei gunaikw=n a)ndrofo/nwn. These murderous brides are often mentioned in classic poetry. See O. 4.17.
eu(rh/sei: See P. 2.64. Subject is *eu)/famos.

ta/nde . . . na=son: P.'s range of the terminal acc. is not wide. For e)lqei=n with do/mon, see O. 14.20; with me/garon, P. 4.134; with pedi/on, P. 5.52; with *libu/an, I. 3 (4), 71; with a person, I. 2, 48. For molei=n, see O. 9.76; N. 10.36. i(/keo (P. 9.55; *n. 3, 3), i(/konti (O. 10 [11], 95), a)fi/keto (P. 5.29), a)fi/cetai (P. 8.54), e)ci/keto (P. 11.35) hardly count, as these verbs are felt as transitives, “reach.”

oi(/ ken . . . te/kwntai: The plural agrees with the sense of ge/nos. ken, with the subj., as a more exact future, where in prose the future indic. would be employed; an Homeric construction, nowhere else in P.
su\n tima=| qew=n: q., subjective genitive, “favor of the gods.” Cf. v. 260.
fw=ta: Battos (Aristoteles), who is glorified in the next ode.
kelainefe/wn: Kyrene had rain, the rest of Libya none. Hence k. by contrast rather than absolutely.
poluxru/sw|: So. O.R. 151: ta=s poluxru/sou | *pnqw=nos. The presence of Phoibos is emphasized, as v. 5.
a)mna/sei = a)namna/sei.
qe/missin: “Oracles.” Pl. as a)ggeli/ais, O. 3.28.

div3.head: Antistrophe 3
div3.p: kataba/nta: The threshold is much higher than the floor (Od. 22. 2: a)=lto d' e)pi\ me/gan ou)=don); hence, kat' ou)/dou ba/nta, Od. 4. 680.
xro/nw| | u(ste/rw|: With kataba/nta.
a)gage/n: Doric = a)gagei=n (see O. 1.3).

*nei/loio pro\s . . . te/menos *kroni/da: “To the Nile precinct of Kronides” (Zeus Ammon). With *nei/loio te/menos, compare O. 2.10: oi)/khma potamou= = oi)/k. pota/mion. The Schol. combines N. *kroni/da, and considers it equivalent to *dio\s *nei/lou, but there is no *zeu\s *nei=los in the sense meant.
h)= r(a: The Homeric asseveration (Il. 16. 750; Od. 12. 280) is well suited to the solemn, oracular passage.
e)pe/wn sti/xes: “Rows of words,” “oracular, verses.” On the absence of ei)si, see O. 1.1.

e)/ptacan: Only here in P. Not the usual tone of the word, which is ordinarily
“to cower,” as in So. Ai. 171: sigh=| pth/ceian a)/fwnoi. The attitude here assumed is that of brooding thought.
ui(e\ *polumna/stou: Aristoteles - Battos (v. 52).
e)n tou/tw| lo/gw|: “In consonance with this word” (of prophecy).
w)/rqwsen: “Exalted,” “glorified.”
meli/ssas: “The bee” is the Pythia. Honey is holy food. Cf. O. 6.47.
au)toma/tw| kela/dw|: “Unprompted cry.” He had only asked a remedy for his stuttering tongue.
e)s tri/s: The consecrated number.

au)da/saisa: The original sense of au)da=n is not lost, as is shown by kela/dw|, “loudly bade thee Hail!” The oracle is given by Herodotos, 4, 155: *ba/tt' e)pi\ fwnh\n h)=lqes: a)/nac de/ se *foi=bos *)apo/llwn | e)s *libu/hn pe/mpei mhlotro/fon oi)kisth=ra.

div3.head: Epode 3
div3.p: dusqro/ou fwna=s: “Slowness of speech.” *ba/ttos means “stutterer.” Cf. battari/zw. His real name was *)aristote/lhs. Herodotos (l. c.) says that B. was the Libyan word for “king.”
poina/: a)moibh\ h)\ lu/sis (Schol.).
h)= ma/la dh/: Nowhere else in P. Od. 9. 507: h)= ma/la dh/ me palai/fata qe/sfaq' i(ka/nei. There of a painful revelation, here of a joyous vision.
meta/: Adverbial.
w(=te=w(s.
foinikanqe/mou h)=ros: I. 3, 36: foinike/oisin a)/nqhsen r(o/dois. The rose is the flower by excellence. Arkesilas was in the flower, the rosy flush of his youth.

paisi\ tou/tois , kte(.: “These children” are the descendants of Battos, to whom A. is the eighth bloom. “Eighth in the line of these descendants blooms Arkesilas.” Battos is counted in after the Greek fashion.
me/ros: P. 12.11: tri/ton kasignhta=n me/ros.
*)apo/llwn a(/ te *puqw/: A complex; hence e)/poren. Compare O. 5.15.
ku=dos . . . i(ppodromi/as: “Glory in chariot-racing.” Others make a)mfiktio/nwn depend on i(ppodromi/as.

e)c a)mfiktio/nwn: e)c is “over,” O. 8.54. a)mfiktio/nwn, not *)amfiktuo/nwn, “the surrounding inhabitants.” This is understood of those who lived around Delphi, but it would apply with more force to the Libyan rivals of Arkesilas. So. El. 702: du/o | *li/bues zugwtw=n a(rma/twn e)pista/tai.

a)po\ . . . dw/sw: “I will assign him to the Muses” as a fit theme for song. The meetness lies in a)po/, often used of that which is due. Cf. I. 7 (8), 59: e)/doc' a)=ra kai\ a)qana/tois, | e)slo/n ge fw=ta kai\ fqi/menon u(/mnois qea=n dido/men.
au)to/n: Ipsum. Euphamos in contrast to tw=| me/n, his descendant, Arkesilas, the de/ shifting, as often in P. See O. 11 (10), 8.
sfisin: The house of Euphamos.
fu/teuqen: I. 5, 12: dai/mwn futeu/ei do/can e)ph/raton. qa/llei, v. 65, shimmers through.

div3.head: Strophe 4
div3.p: de/cato: Without an object, as a)/gei, P. 2.17. Bergk reads a)rxh )kde/cato.
ki/ndunos: The dangerous quest, the nautili/a.

krateroi=s . . . a(/lois: The Argonauts were riveted to their enterprise as the planks were riveted to the Argo, which may have suggested the figure, but we must not forget that Hera inspired them (v. 184), and so may be said to have driven the nails. The passages cited certatim by the editors do not really help, such as Aisch. P. V. 64, and Hor. Od. 1, 35, 17. These are not the nails of necessity, but the nails of passion — the nails that fastened the i)=ugc to her wheel, just as the proverb h(=lon h(/lw|, clavum clavo pellere can be used “of the expulsive power of a new affection.”
a)da/mantos: On the genitive see O. 2.79. a). iron of special hardness.
e)c a)gauw=n *ai).: e)c of the source, not of the agent. So Thuc. 1, 20.

*ai)olida=n: Here is the genealogy of Iason that seems to be followed:
Aiolos
Enarea
Kretheus
Salmoneus
Athamas
Aison
Pheres
Amuthan
Tyro
Poseidon
Phrixos
IASON
Admetos
Melampos
Pelias
Neleus
Nestor
Periklumenos
a)ka/mptois: Pelias perished by the latter means. a)., “inflexible,” “invincible.”
h)=lqe de/ voi . . . qumw=|: On the double dative, see O. 2.16. voi depends on qumw=| kruo/en. The relation is not that of apposition. Cf. P. 1.7: voi . . . krati/, and above, v. 37.
kruo/en: “Blood-curdling.”
pukinw=| . . . qumw=|: O. 13.52: *si/sufon me\n pukno/taton pala/mais w(s qeo/n. Pelias is not only “wary,” but “crafty.” Compare v. 138: ba/lleto krhpi=da sofw=n e)pe/wn.
me/son o)mfalo/n: See note on v. 4.

eu)de/ndroio . . . mate/ros: Gaia was the first tenant of the oracle. Aisch. Eum. 1, 2:
prw=ton me
 eu)xh=| th=|de presbeu/w qew=n
th
 prwto/mantin *gai=an,
and the o)mfalo/s was a reminder of her. N. 7.33: para\ me/gan o)mfalo
 eu)ruko/lpou | molw
 xqono/s. Cf. P. 6.3; 8, 59; 11, 10.
ai)peinw=n a)po\ staqmw=n: On Pelion, where he was brought up by Cheiron. st. is used in its special Homeric sense.

eu)dei/elon: The Homeric signification “far-seen” suits Kronion after a fashion (*o. 1, 111), but not Iolkos, whereas “sunny,” an old interpretation, suits Kronion perfectly (O. 3.24), and is not inapt for Iolkos, as opposed to the forest shade of Pelion and the cave of the Centaur. P. was not always clear himself as to the traditional vocabulary.

div3.head: Antistrophe 4
div3.p: cei=nos ai)/t' w)=n a)sto/s: Only passage where ai)/te is used = ei)/te. Even in prose the first ei)/te is sometimes omitted. Iason was both.
ai)xmai=sin didu/maisin: As Homer's heroes. Od. 1. 256: e)/xwn . . . du/o dou=re.
a(/ te . . . a)mfi\ de/: te . . . de/, again P. 11.29, the reverse of the common shift, me\n . . . te (O. 4.13).
*magnh/twn e)pixw/rios: A close-fitting dress was necessary for hunters in a dense forest.

pardale/a|: So Paris, Il. 3. 17: pardale/hn w)/moisin e)/xwn kai\ kampu/la to/ca | kai\ ci/fos: au)ta\r o( dou=re du/w kekoruqme/na xalkw=| | pa/llwn. But Paris was brought up on Mt. Ida, not on Mt. Pelion, and P. has blended his colors. Philostratos II. (Imagg. c. 7) gives Iason a lion-skin, which is a symbol of the Sun, who was Medeia's grandsire, patro\s *(/hlios path/r, Eur. Med. 1321.

fri/ssontas o)/mbrous = fri/ssein poiou=ntas (Schol.). “Shivering showers” = “shivery showers.” But as o)/mbros is a strato\s a)mei/lixos (P. 6.12), “bristling showers” may well represent bristling spears. Compare Il. 7. 62: sti/xes . . . e)/gxesi pefrikui=ai.

ou)de\ koma=n . . . kerqe/ntes: He was still a boy, and had not shorn his locks off — for Greek youths were wont to dedicate their first hair to the river-gods (Schol.). Hence Pelias' sneer at him, v. 98. Others think of the ka/rh komo/wntes *)axaioi/, and the vindication of his Achaian origin, despite his strange attire.

a(/pan nw=ton katai/qusson: For acc. compare P. 5.11: kataiqu/ssei . . . ma/kairan e(sti/an. As P. seems to associate ai)qu/ssw with ai)/qw (P. 1.87; 5, 11), “flared all down his back.” Compare a)glaoi/ above.
sfete/ras = e(a=s. See O. 9.78.

a)tarba/ktoio (not in L. & S.) = a)tarba/toio. Herm. reads a)tarmu/ktoio after Hesych. tarmu/casqai: fobhqh=nai. I. makes trial of his unaffrighted soul — his soul that cannot be affrighted — just as, on one interpretation, Kyrene makes trial of her unmeasured strength (P. 9.38).
e)n a)gora=| plh/qontos o)/xlou: In prose, plhqou/shs a)gora=s, from 10 o'clock in the morning. Genitive of time, from which the genitive absolute, with present participle, springs.

div3.head: Epode 4
div3.p: o)pizome/nwn: Not genitive absolute. “Of the awed beholders.”
e)/mpas: “For all that,” though they knew not that he was the heir.
tis . . . kai\ to/de: “Many a one (w(=de de/ tis ei)/peske, Hom.), among other things this.”
*ou)/ ti/ pou: Half-question, half-statement. “It can't be, although it ought to be.” Compare Ar. Ran. 522, and the famous skolion of Kallistratos: *fi/ltaq' *(armo/di', ou)/ ti/ pou te/qnhkas.

ou)de\ ma/n: Swearing often indicates a doubt which one desires to remove (P. 1.63). Apollo's hair is the first thing suggested by the plo/kamoi . . . a)glaoi/ (v. 82). Ares is next (e)/kpaglos, v. 79) — but not so beautiful as Apollo, though Aphrodite's lord — then the demigods.
po/sis | *)afrodi/tas: Ares, for Hephaistos is not recognized by Pindar as the husband of Aphrodite; nor is he by Homer in the Iliad, and the episode of Od. 8. 266 was discredited in antiquity.
e)n de/: And yet who else can it be, for Otos and Ephialtes are dead?
*na/cw|: The Aloeidai were buried in Naxos and had a cult there.

*)=wton . . . *)efia/lta: Homer calls them polu\ kalli/stous meta/ ge kluto\n *)wri/wna (Od. 11. 310). According to him the brothers were slain by Apollo for threatening the immortals with war. According to another account, they slew each other by the device of Artemis. The comparisons are taken from the Artemis cycle, as Iason is clearly a hunter.

*)efia/lta: For the voc. compare v. 175; P. 11.62. The voc. naturally gives special prominence and interest, but it must not be pressed too much, as has been done with *patro/kleis i(ppeu= and *eu)/maie subw=ta. Metre and variety have much to do with such shifts.

*tituo/n: T. was slain by Artemis. Od. 11. 580: *lhtw\ ga\r h(/lkhse *dio\s kudrh\n para/koitin | *puqw/d' e)rxome/nhn dia\ kallixo/ron *panoph=os. Those who wish to moralize P.'s song see in these figures warning examples. It would be as fair to say that Tityos was introduced as a compliment to Arkesilas, whose ancestor he was (v. 46).
o)/fra . . . e)/ratai: e)/ra_tai is subj. A bit of obbligato reflection without any personal application. The Greek moralizes as Shakespeare quibbles.
ta=n e)n dunatw=| filota/twn: See P. 2.34.

div3.head: Strophe 5
div3.p: ga/ruon: The lower range of this word, as O. 2.96.
a)na\ d' h(mio/nois: Compare O. 8.51: a)n' i(/ppois.

h(mio/nois cesta=| t' a)ph/na|: Greek seldom comes nearer than this to e(\n dia\ duoi=n (v. 18). Mules were a favorite team among the Thessalians as well
as among the Sicilians.
deciterw=|: Iason had lost his left shoe in crossing the Anauros. See v. 75.
kle/ptwn = kalu/ptwn. Cf. O. 6.36. The Greek associated the dissociate radicals of these words.

*poi/an gai=an: There is something disrespectful about poi/an, and gai=an is not especially courteous. The Homeric formula (Od. 1. 170) is: ti/s po/qen e)ss' a)ndrw=n; po/qi toi po/lis h)de\ tokh=es; Pelias had come protropa/dan, looking neither to the right nor to the left of him, his eye riveted on the unsandalled foot, and seeing nothing of the o)/pis on the face of the multitude.
a)nqrw/pwn . . . xamaigene/wn: “Groundling wenches.”

polia=s . . . gastro/s: No father is mentioned (contrast Homer's tokh=es), and the mother is an old drab, by whom Iason was “ditch-delivered.” The insinuation that she petted her child is not impossible, though to less prejudiced eyes Iason could not have suggested a mamma/kuqos.
e)canh=ken: “Sent forth,” “spewed forth,” “spawned.”
katamia/nais: Ironical.

div3.head: Antistrophe 5
div3.p: qarsh/sais a)ganoi=si go/gois: Both lesson, that Iason had learned from Cheiron — boldness of action, gentleness of speech.
a)mei/fqh: This form, only here in P., becomes common in later times; perhaps “was moved to answer.” Cf. e)strateu/qh (P. 1.51).

oi)/sein: May be an undifferentiated fut., equiv. to a present. But the future = me/llein oi)/sein is defensible, “that I am going to show myself the bearer of Cheiron's training.” Cheiron's great lesson, reverence for Zeus, and reverence for one's parents (P. 6.23), is the very lesson which Iason is about to carry out. In restoring Aison he is obeying Zeus.
*xariklou=s: Chariklo was the wife and Philyra the mother of Cheiron (P. 3.1).
kou=rai . . . a(gnai/: Repels the pogia\ gasth/r, the old drab who is supposed to have spoiled him.
ve/rgon . . . ei)pw/n: Zeugma for poih/sas.

eu)tra/pelon: The reading of the old codices, e)ntra/pegon, might mean “to cause concern, shame, anxiety.” eu)tra/pegon (Cod. Perus.) would mean “shifty,” “deceitful.” “I have never said nor done aught that was not straightforward.” e)ktra/pelon (Schol.), “out of the way,” “insolent.”

a)rxa\n a)gkomi/zwn: So with Bergk after the grammarian Chairis for the MS. a)rxai/an komi/zwn. a)gkomi/zwn: “To get back,” pres. part. for fut. (a)g)komi/zwn has been suggested, but is unnecessary. The conative present will serve. See O. 13.59. If a)rxai/an is read, notice how far the adjective carries in the equable dactylo-epitrites. Cf. O. 11 (10), 19.
patro/s: Pelias had asked for his mother, Iason proudly speaks of his father.

div3.head: Epode 5
div3.p: nin: Sc. tima/n.

leukai=s piqh/santa frasi/n: leukai=s is variously interpreted. “White,” i.e. “envious.” Others compare leugale/os (Il. 9. 119: fresi\ leugale/h|si piqh/sas), lugro/s, Fennell lu/ssa (lukya), “yielding to his mad desires.”
a)rxedika=n: “Lords by primal right,” “lawful lords.”
ka=dos . . . qhka/menoi: “Having made lamentation.”
mi/ga kwkutw=|: So mi/gda with dat., Il. 8. 437.
pe/mpon: With the imperf. the thoughts follow the motion. See note on O. 2.23.
sparga/nois e)n porfure/ois: The spa/rgana are also krokwta/, N. 1.38.
nukti\ koina/santes o(do/n: “Having made night privy to the journey.” Time is often considered a companion (O. 2.11).
tra/fen = tre/fein: The inf. as O. 6.33: h(/rwi porsai/nein do/men *ei)lati/da| bre/fos.

div3.head: Strophe 6
div3.p: leuki/ppwn: White horses were princely. See P. 1.66: leukopw/lwn *tundarida=n.

ou) cei/nan i(koi/man . . . a)/llwn: The MSS. have i(ko/man, which is unmetrical. ou) cei/nan i^(/koim' a)/n (=a)figme/nos a)\n ei)/hn), “I can't have come to a strange land” would be easy, and an aorist i(/koimi is supported by i(/kwmi, Il. 9. 414, and by P. 2.36, where the codices have i^(ko/nt'. The pure opt. might stand here as a half-wish, a thought begotten of a wish, “I hope it will turn out that I have come to no strange land,” ou) being adhaerescent. Bergk has written ou) ma\n cei=nos i(/kw gai=an a)/llwn, which does not explain the corruption. ou) ma/n does not occur in P., though ou)de\ ma/n does.
a)/llwn = a)llotri/an. Cumulative,
*fh/r = qh/r. Only of the Centaurs. P. 3.4.
e)/gnon = e)/gnwsan.
pomfo/lucan: For the plur. see P. 1.13. The dualistic neut. plur. often retains the plur. verb, and there are two streams of tears here.
a(\n peri\ yuxa/n: “All round (through) his soul” — kata\ th\n e(autou= yuxh/n (Schol.).

div3.head: Antistrophe 6
div3.p: kasi/gnhtoi: Aison's brothers. See v. 72.
sfisin: O. 3.39: *)emmeni/dais *qh/rwni/ t' e)lqei=n ku=dos. The brothers were an accession.
kata\ kle/os: “At the report,” “close on the report.” Compare kata\ po/das, “at the heel of,” “following.”
*fe/rhs: See v. 72. Most memorable to us for his part in the Alkestis of Euripides, where he declines to die for his son Admetos: xai/reis o(rw=n fw=s, pate/ra d' ou) xai/rein dokei=s;
*uperh=|da: A fountain in the ancient Pherai, near Iolkos, Hypereia. See commentators on Il. 2. 734; 6, 457.
e)k de\ *messa/nas: Messene was distant, hence an implied antithesis to e)ggu\s me/n.
*)amuqa/n = *)amuqa/wn, as *)alkma/n for *a)lkmai/wn (P. 8.46).
