*me/lampos: A famous seer, son of Amythan. Od. 11. 259; 15, 225.

a)neyio/n: Must depend on i(=ken — cf. P. 11.35: *stro/fion e)ci/keto — but it would be easier to have i(=kon (suggested by Bergk), and a)neyioi/ (Hartung). i(=kon would then be in the schema Alcmanicum. See v. 179. It is wholly inconceivable that a)neyio/n should depend on eu)mene/ontes = file/ontes.
e)n daito\s . . . moi/ra|: At a shared, i. e. common, banquet.
a(rmo/zonta: Compare N. 1.21: a(rmo/dion dei=pnon. The Thessalians lived well, as we know from Euripides' Alkestis, Plato's Kriton, and other familiar passages.
pa=san . . . ta/nuen: “Stretched joy to its full extent,” “kept it up to its full height.”
drapw/n: N. 2.8: dre/pesqai ka/lliston a)/wton. The aor., on account of the definite number (v. 26). Otherwise we should have expected the present part., as the action is coincident with ta/nuen.

div3.head: Epode 6
div3.p: pa/nta: Acc. pl. with parekoina=to. In contradistinction to v. 116: kefa/laia lo/gwn.
qe/menos = poihsa/menos. “Speaking in sober earnest.”
spoudai=on: Before v. 129 it was all eu)frosu/na.
e)pe/sponto: Figuratively. “They took sides with him.”
h)=lqon . . . me/garon: v. 51.
*turou=s e)rasiploka/mou: See v. 72, and note the contrast to polia=s . . . gastro/s, both at the time of bearing.
prau+\n . . . o)/aron: Cf. v. 101. prau+/s, “gentle” by nature; h(/meros, by culture (J. H. H. Schmidt).
potista/zwn: Compare the Biblical “distil” (Deut. 32, 2), and Homer's r(e/en au)dh/.
ba/lleto krhpi=da: P. 7.3: krhpi=d' a)oida=n bale/sqai. The metaphor shifts rapidly, but the notion of drink - offering is not foreign to that of laying the foundation.
*pai= *p.: Stately genealogical address, with effective position of vocative.
*petrai/ou: Poseidon was worshipped in Thessaly as the Cleaver of the Rock, because he had opened a way through the rock for the Peneios. On the p's, see v. 150.

div3.head: Strophe 7
div3.p: w)ku/terai: “Are but too swift.” N. 11.48: a)prosi/ktwn d' e)rw/twn o)cu/terai mani/ai.
e)/pibdan: “Day after the feast,” the next morning with all its horrors, next day's reckoning.
qemissame/nous o)rga/s: “Having ruled our tempers by the law of right (qe/mis).”
u(fai/nein: Cf. v. 275.

mi/a bou=s: Not common, yet not surprising after the frequent use of heifer (“Samson's heifer”) everywhere for a girl or young married woman. Cf. Aisch. Ag. 1126 (Kassandra speaks): a)/pexe th=s boo\s to\n tau=ron.

qrasumh/dei+ *salmwnei=: See v. 72. S. imitated
Zeus's thunder and lightning, and was struck by lightning for his pains.
kei/nwn futeuqe/ntes: v. 256: *eu)fa/mou futeuqe/n.
sqe/nos a)eli/ou: The sun rejoiceth as a strong man to run a race.
xru^se/ou: u_ in Homer, u common in P.

*moi=rai d' a)fi/stant(ai), kte(.: “The Fates withdraw . . . to hide their blush” (Dissen). This has a modern sound, but is better than Rauchenstein's, “The Fates avert their faces, if enmity among the members of a family obscures reverence (die heilige Scheu).” Hermann reads ai)doi=, and makes the Fates revolt against concealment.

div3.head: Antistrophe 7
div3.p: a)ko/ntessin: The historical Thessalians were famous a)kontistai/. X. Hell. 6, 1, 9.
canqa/s: “dun.”
a)pou/rais | a(mete/rwn toke/wn , kte(.: This is hardly prau+\s o)/aros, according to modern ideas, but Iason warms as he goes on. Compare v. 109 with v. 101.
plou=ton piai/nwn: “Feeding fat thy wealth.” P. has an especial fancy for p- alliteration.
ponei=: “Irks,” a rare transitive use.
tau=ta porsu/nonta = o(/ti tau=ta porsu/nei.
kai\ ska=pton mo/narxon kai\ qro/nos: The verb of tau=ta is not exhausted, and there is no need of a nominativus pendens.
*krhqei+/das: Aison.
i(ppo/tais . . . laoi=s: The Thessalian cavalry was famous.
eu)/qune . . . di/kas: Solon, fr. IV. 37: eu)qu/nei de\ di/kas skolia/s.
ta\ me/n: Notice the lordly indifference to ta\ de/, which had already been disposed of — flocks and fields.

div3.head: Epode 7
div3.p: a)nasth/h|: To which the a)nasth/sh|, a)nasth/sh|s, of the MSS. points. a)nastai/h, the opt., is a rare sequence and cannot be paralleled in P. As there is no touch of a past element, a)nastai/h would be a wish, and detach itself from lu=son. See Am. Journ. of Phil. IV. p. 425.
new/teron, itself threatening, is reinforced by kako/n.
*)/esomai | toi=os: “I will be such” as thou wishest me to be, will do everything thou wishest. Compare the phrase pantoi=on gene/sqai.

ghraio\n me/ros: Yet Pelias belonged to the same generation with Iason, acc. to Pindar (see v. 72), although not acc. to Homer, who makes Aison and Pelias half-brothers (Od. 11. 254 foll.). This makes the fraud transparent. Notice also his vigorous entrance (v. 94). It is true that his daughters cut him up, in order to restore his youth, but that does not prove that he was as old a man as Aison.
so\n d' a)/nqos h(/bas kumai/nei: k. “is swelling,” “is bourgeoning.” ku=ma is not only the “wave,” but also the “swelling bud.” (J. H. H. Schmidt).

komi/cai: This refers to the ceremony of a)na/klhsis,
by which the ghosts of those who had died and been buried in foreign parts were summoned to return home and rest in their cenotaph. So we might translate k., “lay.”
e)lqo/ntas: We should expect e)lqo/nta, sc. tina/. But there is a h(ma=s in Pelias' conscience.

div3.head: Strophe 8

div3.p: ei) meta/llato/n ti: “Whether there is aught to be followed up.” Dreams might be false, for they come through the gate of ivory as well as through the gate of horn, Od. 19. 562.
o)tru/nei: Sc. *)apo/llwn, a very natural ellipsis whenever oracles are mentioned.
nai+\ pompa/n: Almost as one word, “a ship-home-bringing.” pompa/n: Od. 6. 290; 10, 18.
te/leson . . . proh/sein = e)a\n tele/sh|s . . . proh/sw.
monarxei=n | kai\ basileue/men: Compare v. 152: kai\ ska=pton mo/narxon kai\ qro/nos.
*zeu\s o( gene/qlios: Cf. O. 8.16. Z. was the father of their common ancestor, Aiolos.
kri/qen = diekri/qhsan.

div3.head: Antistrophe 8
div3.p: e)o/nta plo/on = o(/ti o)/ntws e)/stin.
faine/men: Compare the use of froura\n fai/nein among the Spartans, Xen. Hell. 3, 2, 23. 5, 6. There may be an allusion to fire-signals
trei=s: Herakles, Kastor, Polydeukes.
e(likoblefa/rou: Of Aphrodite, fr. IX. 2, 5: *)afrodi/tas e(likoblefa/rou. Cf. Hesiod. Theog. 16; Hymn. Hom. V. 19.

*)ennosi/da: Of the sons of Poseidon (v. 33), Euphamos, ancestor of Arkesilas, is from Tainaros (v. 44); Periklymenos, grandson of Poseidon, brother of Nestor (Od. 11. 286), is from Pylos. Notice the chiasm. They are all Minyans.

ai)desqe/ntes a)lka/n: In modern parlance, “from self-respect,” a)lka/n being an equiv. of “self,” as xai/tan (O. 14.24), as ko/mas (P. 10.40). a)lka/n is “repute for valor,” a brachylogy made sufficiently plain by kle/os below. ai)dw/s and ai)sxu/nh are often used in the sense of military honor. Il. 15. 561: w)= fi/loi, a)ne/res e)/ste, kai\ ai)dw= qe/sq' e)ni\ qumw=|. See also v. 185.

u(yixai=tai: Hardly a reference to the top-knot. Poseidon's sons were all tall (the unit of measurement being the fathom), and if they were tall, so was their hair. Cf. oi)o/zwnos (So. O.R. 846), e(katompo/dwn (O. C. 717) .
*periklu/mene: Compare v. 89. P. has no special interest in Periklymenos.
e)c *)apo/llwnos: Orpheus is the son of Oiagros (fr. X. 8, 10; hence e)c *)a. may be taken as ‘sent by.’ Cf. Hes. Theog. 94.
a)oida=n path/r: Even in prose the speech-master at a symposium is a path\r lo/gou (Plat. Sympos. 177 D).
*)orfeu/s: First mentioned by Ibykos of Rhegion, assigned to the Argonautic expedition by Simonides of Keos.

div3.head: Epode 8
div3.p: pe/mpe; See v. 114.
xruso/rapis: xruso/rrapis is an Homeric epithet of Hermes.
*)exi/ona . . . *)/eruton: Hold-fast and Pull-hard, sons of Hermes and Antianeira.

kexla/dontas: A peculiar Doric perfect participle with present signification (compare pefri/kontas, v. 183). The Schol. makes it = plhqu/ontas, “full to overflowing with youth.” The anticipation of the plural is called sxh=ma *)alkmaniko/n. See note on v. 126. Il. 5. 774; 20, 138; Od. 10. 513: ei)s *)axe/ronta *puriflege/qwn te r(e/ousin | *kwkuto/s q' o(\s dh\ *stugo\s u(/dato/s e)stin a)porrw/c. The figure becomes much easier if we remember how distinctly the plural ending of the verb carries its “they,” and here kexla/dontas recalls ui(ou/s.
taxe/es: So the better MSS. for taxe/ws. Cf. P. 11.48: qoa\n a)kti=na.
*paggai/ou: On the borders of Thrace and Macedon.
naieta/ontes: “Dwelling, as they did,” far to the north, while Euphamos dwelt in the far south. Cf. P. 1.64.
qumw=| gelanei=: Compare O. 5.2: kardi/a| gelanei=. Notice the cumulation.
e)/ntuen: O. 3.28: e)/ntu) a)na/gka.
pefri/kontas: See v. 179.
po/qon e)/ndaien *(/hra: Hera favored the expedition, as appears from other sources. Od. 12. 72: *(/hrh pare/pemyen, e)pei\ fi/los h)=en *)ih/swn.

div3.head: Strophe 9
div3.p: ta\n a)ki/ndunon . . . ai)w=na: ai)w/n is fem. P. 5.7; N. 9.44. The article has a contemptuous fling. So. Ai. 473: ai)sxro\n ga\r a)/ndra tou= makrou= xrh/|zein bi/ou, “your.”
para\ matri/: Compare the slur cast on Iason (v. 98), and P. 8.85: molo/ntwn pa\r mate/ra.
pe/ssonta: O. 1.83.
e)pi\ kai\ qana/tw|: Even if death were to be the meed (like e)pi\ misqw=|).

fa/rmakon . . . e(a=s a)reta=s: fa/rmako/n tinos is either “a remedy for” or “a means to.” Here it is the latter. It is not “a solace for their valorous toil,” but an “elixir of valor,” as we say the “elixir of youth.”
le/cato: “Reviewed.”
e)painh/sais: Coincident action.
*mo/yos: A famous soothsayer.
e)mbo/lou: The e)/mbolon was more modern, but P. had in mind the famous talking-plank in the ship Argo.
a)gku/ras: The same mild anachronism as above, v. 24. The anchors were suspended at the prow, v. 22 and P. 10.52. On the two anchors, see O. 6.101.

div3.head: Antistrophe 9
div3.p: fia/lan: Compare the famous scene in Thuk. 6, 32.
e)gxeike/raunon: So O. 13.77: *zhno\s e)gxeikerau/nou.
w)kupo/rous: Proleptic. So eu)/frona and fili/an, v. 196.

kuma/twn r(ipa\s a)ne/mwn te: a)ne/mwn r(ipai/ is common enough everywhere. So in our author, P. 9.52; N. 3.59; fr. V. 1, 6; So. Antig. 137. r(. not so common of the waves. Fr. XI. 83: po/ntou r(ipai/.
e)ka/lei: He called on Zeus, and then on the other things that he feared or desired. Nothing is more characteristic of the heathen mind than this meticulous prevision. Zeus answered for all.
fqe/gma . . . a)kti=nes: No u(/steron pro/teron. The lightning was secondary.

a)mpnoa\n . . . e)/stasan: i(sta/nai is used in poetry to form periphrases with abstract nouns (Böckh), very much as poiei=sqai is used in prose. a). e)/st.=a)ne/pneusan, for which see So. O.R. 1221: a)ne/pneusa/ t' e)k se/qen | kai\ katekoi/mhsa tou)mo\n o)/mma. “They drew a free breath again.”

div3.head: Epode 9
div3.p: e)ni/ptwn: Not the Homeric e)ni/ptw, but a new present formation from e)/nnepe (Curtius).
a)/koros: Gives life to the dipping oar, that cannot get its fill.
*)acei/nou: The *)/aceinos, afterwards *eu)/ceinos.
e(/ssanto = kaqi/drusan. Cf. P. 5.42: kaqe/ssanto (MSS.), where, however, we read ka/qessan.
foi/nissa . . . a)ge/la tau/rwn: Cf. v. 149: bow=n canqa\s a)ge/las. For the sacrifice, see O. 13.69. 81.

*qrhiki/wn: Hieron, the seat of the altar, was on the Asiatic shore and in Bithynia. The Bithynians were Thracians (Hdt. 7, 75), but Thracian had a nobler sound, such as Norse has to us, a sound of the sea. So. O.R. 196: to\n a)po/cenon o(/rmon *qrh/|kion klu/dwna, Antig. 588: duspno/ois o(/tan *qrh/|ssaisin e)/rebos u(/falon e)pidra/mh| pnoai=s .
neo/ktiston: Built by the sons of Phrixos.
li/qwn: The best MSS. have li/qinon, which is a gloss. This shows that the old readers connected it with qe/nar.

qe/nar: I. 3 (4), 74: baqukrh/mnou polia=s a(lo\s e)ceurw\n qe/nar, where it means the hollow (depth) of the sea, as it elsewhere means the hollow of the hand. Acc. to the Schol. to\ koi/lwma tou= bwmou= to\ u(podexo/menon ta\ qu/mata.
despo/tan . . . naw=n: Poseidon.

div3.head: Strophe 10
div3.p: sundro/mwn . . . petra=n: The famous Symplegades.
a)maima/keton: See P. 1.14.
sti/xes: The winds come like files of armed men. Contrast P. 6.12.
teleuta/n: “Death.”
*fa=sin: Long a notable demarcation for the Greeks.
kelainw/pessi: See Hdt. 2, 104, on the dark skin of the Kolchians.
bi/an | mi=can = “Joined battle,” “fought hand to hand with.”
para/: “In the realm of.”
au)tw=|: Contrast to their previous adventures.
po/tnia . . . bele/wn: Aphrodite. Cf. Il. 21. 470: po/tnia qhrw=n (Artemis).
poiki/lan i)/ugga: See P. 2.40, and add N. 4.35: i)/uggi d' e(/lkomai h)=tor, and Plaut. Cistell. 2, 1, 4: versor in amoris rota miser.

div3.head: Antistrophe 10
div3.p: maina/da: “Maddening.”
lita/s: “Supplicatory,” “the litany of incantations.” Cf. O. 6.78: litai=s qusi/ais. Some prefer to consider lita/s as a substantive in apposition.
e)kdida/skhsen sofo/n: Sc. ei)=nai. So tou/tous i(ppe/as e)di/dacen, to\n vi(o\n i(ppe/a e)dida/cato, au)tou\s gennai/ous e)cedi/dacas.
poqelna\ . . . *(ella/s = poqoume/nh *(ella/s = po/qos *(ella/dos.

kaiome/nan: The metaphor of the a)/lutos ku/klos lingers. She is a wheel of fire, lashed by Peitho, who is Aphrodite's first maid of dishonor. So Aisch. Ag. 385 (of an unholy love): bia=tai d' a( ta/laina *peiqw/.
pei/rat' a)e/qlwn: “The achievements of (the means of achieving) the labors.”
a)nti/toma: Magic herbs were shredded (te/mnein), as in Aisch. Ag. 17: u(/pnou to/d' a)nti/molpon e)nte/mnwn a)/kos.
katai/nhsan: They pledged (themselves). Desponderunt. “They vowed sweet union in mutual wedlock.”
mi=cai: A promise, as a vow, takes the aor. of the future. Od. 4. 252: w)/mosa . . . mh\ . . . a)nafh=nai. With mi=cai cf. P. 9.13: cuno\n ga/mon mixqe/nta. On e)n with mignu/nai, O. 1.90.

div3.head: Epode 10
div3.p: a)dama/ntinon: So Apoll. Rhod. 3, 1285: a)da/mantos a)/rotron.
ski/myato: “Pressed hard.” L. & S. transl. “alleged!” Applies strictly to a)/rotron alone, not to the oxen, which would require e)/sthsen. Transl. kai/, “with.”
canqa=n: See v. 149: bow=n canqa\s a)ge/las.
genu/wn = genu/=wn: u is semi - vocalic (consonantal). See G. Meyer, Gr. Gr. § 147.
pne/on: Monosyllabic. Sometimes written pneu=n. See G. Meyer, Gr. Gr. § 117.
pe/lassen: Apoll. Rhod. 3, 1307: ei(=lken e)pikrate/ws panti\ sqe/nei o)/fra pela/ssh| | zeu/glh| xalkei/h|.
o)rqa\s d' au)/lakas , kte(.: “Straight stretched he the furrows as he was driving.” The process and the result side by side.
a)na/: With sxi/ze. a)n' o)ro/guian would mean “a fathom at a time,” not “fathom high.”
basileu/s, | o(/stis a)/rxei nao/s: He disdains to turn to Iason.
strwmna/n: “Coverlet.”

div3.head: Strophe 11
div3.p: qusa/nw|: “Flocks.”

au)da/santos: Genitive absolute
of participle without a subject. See v. 25.
kroko/en: A royal color, as well as purple. See N. 1.38: krokwto\n spa/rganon.
e)o/lei = e)vo/lei. Plupf. of ei)/lw. Compare e)/orga and the rest.
e)fetmai=s: P. suppresses the details. So he does not say that Medeia bade Iason not plough against the wind. Even here we have to do only with the kefa/laia lo/gwn. For the pl., see O. 3.28.

a)na/gkas | e)/ntesin: So N. 8.3: xersi\n a)na/gkas. Compare Hor. Od. 1, 35, 17:
saeva Necessitas
clavos trabales et cuneos manu
gestans aena.
ai)ane/s: P. 1.83.
i)/ucen: His anguish was inarticulate (a)fwnh/tw| . . . a)/xei), but his amazement forced from him the whistling i)u/ of astonishment.

div3.head: Antistrophe 11
div3.p: poi/as: Cf. P. 8.20: poi/a| *parnasi/di.
e)/repton = h)/refon (I. 3, 72: e)re/fonta). Homer has only an aor. e)/reya.
*)aeli/ou qaumasto\s ui(o/s: Od. 10. 136: *ki/rkh e)uplo/kamos, deinh\ qeo\s au)dh/essa, | au)tokasignh/th o)loo/fronos *ai)h/tao: | a)mfw\ d' e)kgega/thn faesimbro/tou *)heli/oio.
de/rma . . . e)/nnepen, e)/nqa: Prolepsis.
e)kta/nusan: Poetical condensation. Phrixos had slain the ram with his sacrificial knife in honor of *zeu\s *lafu/stios, flayed him, and stretched the skin.

h)/lpeto . . . pra/cesqai: As e)/lpomai contains an element of wish it may take the aor. pra/casqai (with the MSS.) instead of the future, but P. uses the first aor. only here, and the neg. ou) favors pra/cesqai (P. 1.43), unless we write kei=no/n ke. Compare P. 3.43. The subject of pra/c. is *)ia/sona. Easier pra/c. as fut. pass. (note on v. 15) with oi( = *)ia/soni. Perh. pepra/cesqai.
lo/xma|: The grove of Ares.
ei)/xeto . . . genu/wn: “Was sticking to the jaws.” The dragon guarded it thus when he saw Iason approaching.
nau=n kra/tei: The absence of the article does not exclude the Argo, which is never lost sight of (pa=si me/lousa). The antecedent of the relative does not require the article.
te/lesan a(\n . . . sida/rou: Picturesque addition. The finishing of the ship was the beginning, the finishing of the dragon the achievement, and there the main story ends.

div3.head: Epode 11
div3.p: makra/: For the plur. O. 1.52; P. 1.34; N. 4.71. From this point to the end of the story proper (v. 256), P. has nothing but aorists, whereas the statistics of the myth show the proportion of imperf. to aor. to be 1: 1.78, which is unusually high. See Am. Journ. of Phil. IV. p. 162.

kat' a)macito/n: The point of this is heightened by the existence of grooves in the
Greek highways, “in the old groove.”
w(/ra . . . suna/ptei: “Time presses.” kairo\s ga/r m' e)pei/gei (Schol.).
a(/ghmai = h(gemw/n ei)mi.
sofi/as: “Poetic art” (O. 1.116). Poetry is a path (O. 9.51).
glaukw=pa: O. 6.45.
*)arkesi/la: The poem is soon to become more personal.
su\n au)ta=|: “With her own help.” Cf. O. 13.53.

fo/non: We expect fono/n like trofo/n, but compare Eur. I. A. 794: ta\n ku/knou dolixau/xenos go/non . “Her . . . the death of Pelias” seems violent. In the story of the return, the passage through Africa is presupposed on account of the overture (v. 26).
e)n . . . mi/gen: “They (the Argonauts) entered the stretches of Ocean.”
*lamnia=n . . . a)ndrofo/nwn: O. 4.20: *lamnia/dwn gunaikw=n.
a)e/qlois: Funeral games in honor of Thoas, father of Hypsipyle. See O. 4.23. — vi=n': So Kayser for kri/sin, on the strength of the Schol.'s a)ndrei/an. I. 7 (8), 53: i)=nas e)ktamw\n dori/.
e)sqa=tos a)mfi/s: “About (for) raiment.” Such a prize is mentioned O. 9.104. This does not exclude the wreath mentioned O. 4.24. Note a)mfi/s = a)mfi/ only here.

div3.head: Strophe 12
div3.p: e)n a)llodapai=s . . . a)rou/rais: Familiar symbolism. So in the marriage formula e)pi\ pai/dwn gnhsi/wn a)ro/tw|. Eur. Phoen. 18: mh\ spei=re te/knwn a)/loka daimo/nwn bi/a| . The fulfilment echoes the prophecy. Cf. v. 50: a)llodapa=n . . . gunaikw=n | e)n le/xesin.
touta/kis = to/te. P. 9.15.
u(mete/ras a)kti=nos o)/lbou: Run together (so-called hypallage). “Your radiant prosperity.” a)kti=nos is due to Hermann. The MSS. have a)kti=nas.

moiri/dion: The rhythm connects it with spe/rm(a), and m. spe/rma is as easily understood as mo/rimos ui(o/s (O. 2.42). But the standing phrase mo/rsimon h)=mar forces the other combination with a)=mar.
h)\ nu/ktes: “Or, shall I say? night.” The plur., as often of “nightwatches.”
mixqe/ntes: See v. 251.
h)/qesin: “Abode.” See P. 5.74: o(/qen (Sparta) gegenname/noi | i(/konto *qh/rande fw=tes *ai)gei+/dai.
*kalli/stan = *qh/ran.
*latoi/das: The next ode emphasizes the agency of Apollo.
*libu/as pedi/on: Cf. v. 52: kelainefe/wn pedi/wn.
su\n qew=n timai=s: Cf. v. 51: su\n tima=| qew=n.
ka)/stu xrusoqro/nou . . . *kura/nas: ka)/stu for a)/stu with Hartung. More about Kyrene in P. 9.

div3.head: Antistrophe 12
div3.p:
o)rqo/boulon . . . e)feurome/nois: An after-thought participle (P. 6.46) which recalls u)/mmi, balances su\n qew=n timai=s, and, like su\n qew=i/ timai=s, gives at once the cause and condition
of success in administration, “by the devising of right counsel.” These words link the conclusion to the myth, and o)rqo/boulon mh=tin prepares the way for the wisdom of Oidipus and the saying of Homer. The Battiadai are a wise race; they can read riddles and apply proverbs that bear on the management of the state. Neither text nor interpretation is settled. A full discussion is impossible in the limits assigned to this edition. I give first a close rendering of Christ's text, which I have followed: “Learn to know now the wisdom of Oidipus. For if a man with a keenedged axe hew off the branches of a great oak and put shame on its comely seeming, e'en though its fruit fail, it puts a vote concerning itself, if at any time into the wintry fire it comes at last, or together with upright columns of lordliness being stayed it performs a wretched toil in alien walls, having left desolate its own place.”

gnw=qi . . . sofi/an: Twisted by the interpreters to mean “show thyself as wise as Oidipus.” ta\n *oi)dipo/da sofi/an is as definite as tw=n d' *(omh/rou kai\ to/de sunqe/menos. P., to whom all Theban lore was native, is repeating a parable of Oidipus, and, if I mistake not, a parable of Oidipus in exile.

e)cerei/yh| me/n: So Christ after Bergk, who has also changed ai)sxu/noi into ai)sxu/nh|. ei) ga/r with the opt. would not be consistent with P.'s handling of this form. On the other hand, ei) with the subj. is found in comparison O. 7.1.

didoi= ya=fon per' au)ta=s: The oak is on trial. dido/nai yh=fon is equiv. to e)piyhfi/zein. “It puts its own case to the vote.” “Enables one to judge of it” (Jebb), and so shows its quality. On per', see O. 6.38; on au)ta=s, P. 2.34.

ei)/ pote . . . loi/sqion: “If at last it comes into the wintry fire,” i. e., shows its good qualities by burning freely. Although it cannot bear fruit, it is good for burning, good for building. pote . . . loi/sqion like pote\ xro/nw| u(ste/rw| (vv. 53, 55), pote xro/nw| (v. 258).

su\n o)rqai=s . . . e)reidome/na: The great oak forms a beam, which, stayed by the help of the upright columns, bears up the weight of the building. According to some, the beam is horizontal; according to others, it, too, is an o)rqa\ ki/wn, and the ki/ones despo/sunai its fellows.
mo/xqon . . . du/stanon: The weight of the building.

a)/llois . . . tei/xesin: a)/llois = a)llotri/ois. t. cannot be the “walls of a house,” only the “walls of a city.” The oak is supposed to be the people, the o)/zoi the princes of the state of Kyrene, or the oak is the Kyrenaian nobility and the branches the members. But nothing seems clearer than that the oak is one. Who is the oak? Iason. But as Iason
would be the type of Damophilos, Arkesilas would be Pelias, which is monstrous. Are all these accessories of fire and column mere adornments? Or is “the fire insurrection and the master's house the Persian Empire?” Is this an Homeric comparison, or a Pindaric riddle? Why should not the ‘wisdom of Oidipus’ refer to the case of Oidipus himself? Oidipus is uttering a parable for the benefit of those to whom he had come as an exile. The parallel between the exiled Oidipus and the exiled Damophilos is one that would not insult Arkesilas, and the coincidences in detail between the oak and Oidipus are evident enough. Like the oak, Oidipus has lost his branches, his sons (o)/zous), who, according to one version of the legend, perished before their father, his comeliness has been marred (qahto\n ei)=dos), the place that knew him knows him no more (e(o\n e)rhmw/saisa xw=ron), and yet, though his fruit perish (kai\ fqino/karpos e)oi=sa), he can render services to an alien state, such services as are set forth in the Oidipus at Kolonos of Sophokles. By drawing a lesson from the mistaken course of his own people towards one of their great heroes, Pindar acquits himself of a delicate task delicately, and then, for fear of making the correspondence too close, breaks off. ‘But why this parable? Thou art a timely leech.’

div3.head: Epode 12
div3.p: e)ssi\ d' i)ath/r: In any case an interruption to a parable that is becoming awkward.
e)pikairo/tatos: “That knowest how best to meet the time.”
*paia/n: This is a Delphic victory, and the mention of the Healer is especially appropriate, as Apollo is the a)rxage/tas of the Battiadai, P. 5.60.

r(a/|dion . . . sei=sai: In such passages P. delights to change the figure. sei=sai and e)pi\ xw/ras suggest a building, kubernath/r forces us to think of a ship. The house suddenly floats. So. Ant. 162: ta\ me\n dh\ po/leos a)sfalw=s qeoi\ | pollw=| sa/lw| sei/santes w)/rqwsan pa/lin.
e)pi\ xw/ras e(/ssai = o)rqw=sai.
ti/n = soi/.
e)cufai/nontai: “For thee the web of these fair fortunes is weaving to the end.” The achievement of this restoration is at hand, is in thy reach.
tla=qi: The imper. instead of the conditional e)a\n tlh=|s, as v. 165.

div3.head: Strophe 13
div3.p: tw=n d' *(omh/rou: There is nothing exactly like it in our Homer, but we must remember that Homer was a wide term, and P. may have had a bad memory. The nearest, and that not near, approach is Il. 15. 207: e)sqlo\n kai\ to\ te/tuktai o(/t' a)/ggelos ai)/sima ei)dh=|.

sunqe/menos: Od. 17. 153: e)mei=o de\ su/nqeo mu=qon,
“take to heart.”
po/rsune: “Further,” “cherish.”
a)/ggelon e)slo/n: P. means himself.

a)ggeli/as o)rqa=s: “A successful message.” Everything points to a private understanding between P. and Arkesilas as to the restoration of Damophilos. D. paid for the ode, and one is reminded of the Delphic oracle and the banished Alkmaionidai. It would be very innocent to suppose that P. was really pleading for a man whose pardon was not assured.

e)pe/gnw: With prapi/dwn, “had knowledge of.” gignw/skw occurs with genitive in Homer. Il. 4. 357: gnw= xwome/noio, Od. 21. 36: gnw/thn a)llh/lwn, 23, 109: gnwso/meq' a)llh/lwn. So also Xen. Kyr. 7, 2, 18: e)/gnw kai\ ma/la a)/topa e)mou= poiou=ntos.

e)n paisi\n ne/os: Cf. N. 3.80: w)ku\s e)n potanoi=s, So. Phil. 685: i)/sos e)/n g' i)/sois a)nh/r. It does not necessarily follow from this statement of Damophilos' versatility that he was really young.
e)gku/rsais: Adjective use of the participle in predication. pre/sbus e)gk. e(. biota=| = pre/sbus e(katontaeth/s.
o)rfani/zei . . . o)po/s: He hushes the loud voice of the calumnious tongue.
u(bri/zonta: Above we have the word, here the deed.

div3.head: Antistrophe 13
div3.p: toi=s a)gaqoi=s: Doubtless in the conservative sense.
ou)de\ maku/nwn te/los ou)de/n: “Not postponing decisive action” — a hint, if one chooses, to Arkesilas, but on my theory Arkesilas had decided.
o( ga\r kairo\s pro\s a)nqrw/pwn: With Pindaric freedom = o( kairo\s o( pro\s a)nqrw/pwn. “The favorable season.”

qera/pwn de/ voi , kte(.: The Greeks conceive Time and man as companions (o( xro/nos sunw/n, Soph.). See O. 2.11. If, as Hesiod says, Day is sometimes a stepmother, sometimes a mother to a man (O. et D. 825), so a man may be a son or a stepson to Time — an attendant (qera/pwn), as Patroklos was on Achilles, or a mere drudge. A qera/pwn is one who has rights, who can avail himself of an opportunity without servility.
tou=t' a)niaro/taton: “A sorrow's crown of sorrow.”
e)kto\s e)/xein po/da: “To stand without,” e)kto\s kalw=n, as Aisch. P. V. 263: phma/twn e)/cw po/da | e)/xei.
kei=nos *)/atlas: “He, an Atlas,” “a second Atlas,” which recalls very prettily v. 267.
a)po/: “Far from, reft of.”
*tita=nas: The comparison shows that Damophilos has been at least indiscreet.

xro/nw|: In the introduction stress has been laid on the fulfilment of prophecy, long postponed, yet unfailing; and, if the catch-word theory is worth anything, it is at least to be noted that xro/nw| occurs four times, each time at the end of a verse (vv. 55, 78, 258, 291), where the position demands
stress. Whoever chooses to hear in it the sigh of Damophilos “at last” is welcome.

div3.head: Epode 13
div3.p: ou)lome/nan nou=son: no/sos is a common word for any misfortune.
kra/na|: The great fountain Kyré or “ring,” whence *kurh/nh.
e)kdo/sqai pro\s h(/ban: As he is e)n paisi\n ne/os, he can give himself up to the enjoyment of youthful pleasures.
h(suxi/a| qige/men: “To attain quiet.” For the dat. see P. 8.24; 9, 46.
mh/te ... a)paqh\s de/: Compare P. 8.83: ou)/te . . . ou)de/.
kai/ ke muqh/saiq' o(poi/an , kte(.: The real apodosis to the wish in v. 293: eu)/xetai = ei) ga/r.
eu(=re paga/n: This fountain that he had found in Thebes was the ode that P. composed for him in honor of Arkesilas, the ode we have before us.
pro/sfaton . . . cenwqei/s: Cf.P. 5.31. This does not seem to favor Böckh's hypothesis that Damophilos was an Aigeid and a connection of Pindar.

div2.p: The fifth Pythian celebrates the same victory as the fourth (Pyth. 31, Ol. 78, 3=466 B.C.), and was sung in the festal procession along the street of Apollo at Kyrene. The charioteer, who plays a conspicuous part in the ode, was Karrhotos (Alexibiades), brother of the king's wife.

For the legendary portion of the story of the Battiadai, Pindar himself, in these two odes, is our chief authority. Herodotos has given much space in his fourth book (c. 150, foll.) to the early history of the house.

The founder of Kyrene was Aristoteles, surnamed Battos, descendant of Euphemos, the Minyan, of Tainaros. From Tainaros the family went to Thera, and in the seventeenth generation fulfilled an ancient oracle by the occupation of Kyrene, which had been settled five hundred years before by the Trojan Antenoridai. Kyrene was founded Ol. 37 (632 B.C.), and the throne was filled by eight kings in succession, an Arkesilas succeeding a Battos to the end. The rule of the Battiadai seems to have been harsh; revolts were frequent; and the Arkesilas of this poem was the last of the kings, and fell in a popular tumult.
This ode seems to be the one ordered by the king; the preceding ode was a propitiatory present from a banished nobleman, Damophilos.

In the fifth Pythian the theme is stated in the very beginning. Wealth wedded to Honor and blessed by Fortune hath a wide sway (v. 1, foll.). The word o)/lbos is repeated with a marked persistency. So we read v. 14: polu\s o)/lbos a)mfine/metai, v. 55: o)/lbos e)/mpan ta\ kai\ ta\ ne/mwn, v. 102: sfo\n o)/lbon. As variants, we have ma/kairan e(sti/an (v. 11), ma/kar (v. 20), maka/rios (v. 46), ma/kar (v. 94). But Honor is not less loved. We have su\n eu)doci/a| (v. 8), ge/ras (vv. 18, 31, 124), lo/gwn ferta/twn mnamh=|on (v. 48), mega/lan a)reta/n (v. 98). There is a suggenh\s o)fqalmo/s (v. 17), an
o)/mma faenno/taton (v. 56). But above Wealth and Honor is the blessing of God. The power is given of God (v. 13). The glory must be ascribed to God (v. 25). The men who came to Thera came not without the gods (v. 76). God makes of potency performance (v. 117). The higher powers aid at every turn — Kastor of the golden chariot (v. 9); Apollo, god of the festal lay (v. 23); Apollo, leader of the colony (v. 60); and, to crown all, Zeus himself (v. 122). This iteration makes the dominant thought plain enough, and there seems to be no propriety in classing the poem “among the most difficult of the Pindaric odes.”

After an introduction, then, which has for its theme the power of prosperity paired with honor under the blessing of Fortune, as illustrated by Arkesilas' possession of ancestral dignity and his attainment of the Pythian prize (vv. 1-22), the poet is about to pass to the story of Battos, founder of Kyrene, in whose career are prefigured the fortunes of his race. But Pindar pauses perforce to pay a tribute to Karrhotos, the charioteer, before he tells the legend of Battos, just as in O. 8 he pauses perforce after the legend of Aiakos to praise Melesias, the trainer. Such details were doubtless nominated in the bond. This time the honor is paid to one who stands near the king, and it needs no apology. The trainer has but one sixth of O. 8, the charioteer has one fourth of P. 5. The transition is managed here with much greater art than in O. 8, which shows the jar of the times. Karrhotos represents the new blessing of the Pythian victory as Battos represents the old blessing of Apollo's leadership.

The story of Battos is briefly told, as is the story of Aiakos in O. 8. True, he put lions to flight (v. 58), but it was Apollo's doing, and Battos is as faint in the light of Apollo as Aiakos in the light of his divine partners. He was fortunate while he lived, and honored after his death (vv. 94, 95), but we are not allowed to forget the thought of the opening, v. 25: panti\ me\n qeo\n ai)/tion u(pertiqe/men, a thought which is reinforced by the close also.

The rhythms are logaoedic in the main, but the strophe has a long Paionian introduction of sixteen bars (I. II.). Compare the structure of O. 2,Details for both odes in J. H. H. Schmidt, Kunstformen, IV. 497-507. and see Introductory Essay, p. lxxiv.
The introduction proper (Arkesilas) occupies one triad, one is given to Karrhotos, one to Battos, the fourth returns to Arkesilas.

div3.head: Strophe 1
div3.p: o( plou=tos eu)rusqenh/s: On the union of plou=tos and a)reta/, see O. 2.58: o( ma\n plou=tos a)retai=s dedaidalme/nos | fe/rei tw=n te kai\ tw=n | kairo/n.
kekrame/non: Blended with=wedded to. See O. 1.22.

kaqara=|: As a)reta/ is “honor,” so kaqara/ is used of it as kaqaro/n is used of fe/ggos. P. 9.97: *xari/twn keladenna=n | mh/ me li/poi kaqaro\n fe/ggos, fr. XI. 3: kaqaro\n a(me/ras se/las. The poet strikes the keynote of the ode: “Wealth with Honor” as a gift of God, who appears here as po/tmos.
parado/ntos . . . a)na/gh|: There is a festal, bridal notion in both words. For a)na/gein, see Il. 3. 48; Od. 3. 272; 4, 534.
qeo/more: This string is harped on. So v. 13: qeo/sdoton, v. 25: panti\ me\n qeo\n ai)/tion u(pertiqe/men, v. 60: a)rxage/tas *)apo/llwn, v. 76: ou) qew=n a)/ter, v. 117: qeo/s
te/ voi . . . telei= du/nasin.
nin: “Wealth blent with Honor;” but nin may be plou=ton and su\n eu)doci/a| a variant of a)reta=|.

kluta=s | ai)w=nos a)kra=n baqmi/dwn a)/po: Life is represented as a flight of steps. a)p' a)rxh=s tou= bi/ou, says the Schol. The kluta\ ai)w/n is the lofty position to which Arkesilas is born. Kastor plays the part of po/tmos, and the king goes after the wealth that he is to bring home as a polu/filon e(pe/tan. For ai)w/n fem. see P. 4.186.

xrusarma/tou *ka/storos: The Dioskuroi, whose worship was brought from Thera to Kyrene, had a temple on the famous i(ppo/krotos skurwta\ o(do/s (v. 92). Castor gaudet equis, but the Dioskuroi were, and, in a sense, are still, sailor gods. The wealth of Kyrene was due to its commerce in silphium, its fame to its chariots (P. 4.18; 9, 4), and Kastor represents both commerce and chariots. This sailor element suggests the next figure.

eu)di/an: The special function of the Dioskuroi was to calm storms. Compare “the ship of Alexandria whose sign was Castor and Pollux” (Acts 28, 11), and Hor. Od. 1, 12, 25-32:
Dicam et Alciden puerosque Ledae,
hunc equis, illum superare pugnis
nobilem: quorum simul alba nautis
stella refulsit,
defluit saxis agitatus umor,
concidunt venti, fugiuntque nubes,
et minax, quod sic voluere, ponto
unda recumbit.
xeime/rion o)/mbron: Cf. v. 120: fqinopwri\s a)ne/mwn xeimeri/a . . . pnoa/. This is the storm of state in which Damophilos was banished. See introd. to P. 4.
kataiqu/ssei: kataiqu/ssein is used of Iason's hair that streamed down his back (P. 4.83), and is well suited to the meteoric Kastor, called by the sailors of to-day St. Elmo's fire.
ma/kairan e(sti/an: Cf. O. 1.11.

div3.head: Antistrophe 1
div3.p:
sofoi/: “The noble.” From P.'s point of view
wisdom is hereditary, the privilege of a noble caste. P. 2.88: xw)/tan po/lin oi( sofoi\ thre/wnti. Compare O. 7.91, foll., where Diagoras' straight course, despite his prosperity, is attributed to the hereditary balance of his soul.
e)rxo/menon: “Walking.” The first figure echoes still.
e)n di/ka|: O. 2.83.

e)/xei suggenh/s: I follow the MSS., though it is hard to frame a clear translation. o)fqalmo/s is used as O. 2.11; 6, 16, metaphorically. suggenh\s o)fqalmo/s is really = suggenh\s po/tmos (I. 1, 39). It is the blessing that comes from exalted birth. “Born fortune hath this (to\ basile/a ei)=nai) as its meed most fit for reverence when wedded to a soul like thine.” Compare O. 8.11: so\n ge/ras, “a privilege like thine.” One cannot be born to higher fortune than to have thy rank and thy nature. Hermann's e)pei\ suggene/s is easier. “Since this born meed of reverence wedded to a soul like thine is a light of life.” To be born a king, and to be of kingly mould, is a real o)fqalmo/s, a true o)/lbos. J. H. H. Schmidt (Synon. 1, 376) maintains that o)fqalmo/s is clearly differentiated from o)/mma. “o)fqalmo/s is not the eye as a jewel, but the eye as a guiding star.” So O. 2.11; 6, 16 (cited above). Here he makes suggenh\s o)fqalmo/s to mean “native insight.”
mignu/menon: Cf. v. 2.
eu)=xos . . . e(lw/n: Compare O. 10 (11), 69: eu)=xos e)/rgw| kaqelw/n.

div3.head: Epode 1
div3.p: *)apollw/nion a)/qurma: So I. 3 (4), 57 a)qu/rein is used of the joy of poesy.
*kura/nan: So Bergk for *kura/na. K. depends on a)mfi/. Cf. P. 9.114: *)/irasa pro\s po/lin.
ka=pon *)afrodi/tas: As P. calls Libya (P. 9.57) *dio\s ka=pos, and Syracuse (P. 2.2) te/menos *)/areos. Kyrene, a luxurious place, was famed for its roses, flowers sacred to Aphrodite.

a)eido/menon: With se. This gives the necessary contrast, whereas with ka=pon it would only be a picturesque detail. “While thy praises are sung, do not forget what thou owest to God, what thou owest to Karrhotos.” According to Bergk, the inf. gives the contents of the song, and a)eido/menon is=o(/ti a)ei/detai. “Forget not that there is a song that resounds about Kyrene: Ascribe everything to God.” Cf. P. 2.23. This message is supposed to have been delivered to Kyrene by an oracle.
u(pertiqe/men: The sense is “to give the glory of everything to God.” The figure is that of setting up God, as the author, over the achievement, which is the pedestal.
*ka/rrwton: Arkesilas' wife's brother, who was the charioteer.

*)epimaqe/os: “After-thought,” the opposite of *promhqe/os
(Fore-thought). Compare O. 7.44: *promaqe/os *ai)dw/s.
a)/gwn: The figure of a procession, as v. 3: a)na/gh|. No lingering bride delayed his steps.
qugate/ra: See O. 8.1.

qemiskreo/ntwn: The word, which occurs only here, seems to refer to the oracular institution of the kingship. P. 4.53: to
 me
 . . . *foi=bos a)mna/sei qe/missin . . . polei=s a)gage
 *nei/loio pro\s pi=on te/menos *kroni/da.
u(/dati *kastali/as cenwqei/s: With reference to the usual lustration in the waters of Kastalia, and not merely a periphrasis for Pytho. Cf. P. 4.299: *qh/ba| cenwqei/s.

div3.head: Strophe 2
div3.p:
a)khra/tois a(ni/ais: Dative of circumstance. The reins which were passed round the body (see fig. p. 170) often got broken or tangled. Compare So. El. 746: su\n d' e(li/ssetai tmhtoi=s i(ma/si (t. i(.=h(ni/ais), and Eur. Hippol. 1236:
au)to\s d' o( tlh/mwn h(ni/aisin e)mplakei\s
desmo\n dusech/nuston e(/lketai deqei/s.

podarke/wn dw/deka dro/mwn te/menos: “Through the sacred space of the twelve swiftfooted courses.” te/menos is acc. of extent to the verbal idea in a)khra/tois. Bergk considers podarke/wn to be a participle=tre/xwn. Böckh writes potarke/wn=prosarke/wn, “holding out,” poti/=pro/s being elided as O. 7.90: pot' a)stw=n. On the number twelve, see O. 2.55; 3, 33; 6, 75. The hippodrome was sacred soil, hence the propriety of te/menos.
e)nte/wn sqe/nos: Compare O. 6.22: sqe/nos h(mio/nwn. “No part of the strong equipage.” e)/ntea embraces the whole outfit.
kre/matai: The change of subject is nothing to P. Cf. O. 3.22.

o(po/sa ... dai/dala: The chariots of Kyrene were famous (Antiphanes ap. Athen. 3, 100 f.). The o(po/sa gives the positive side of ou)de/n above, and dai/dala can only be referred to the chariots and their equipment (e)/ntea) which were hung up as a)naqh/mata at Delphi, a usage for which, however, we have no very safe warrant.
a)/gwn ... a)/meiyen: “Brought across.”
e)n = e)s: See P. 2.11.
tou=: Sc. *)apo/llwnos (Bergk). The MSS. to/, “therefore” (“wherefore”).

a)ndria/nti: Why the especial mention of this Cretan statue? Böckh thinks of a connection between the Cretans and the Battiadai. But the peculiar sanctity of the effigy is enough to account for the mention.
ka/qessan to/n: For kaqe/ssanto (unmetrical), with Hermann. Bergk, kaqe/ssanq' w(=|, w(=| being = sfete/rw| = *krhtw=n.
mono/dropon futo/n: “Grown in one piece.” Of a tree that had an accidental likeness to a human figure, which likeness had afterwards been brought out by Daidaleian art.

div3.head: Antistrophe 2
div3.p: to\n eu)erge/tan: Usu. referred to Karrhotos. L. Schmidt and Mezger make it apply to Apollo, and cite v. 25. The only thing that favors this is the bringing in of Alexibiades, as if some one else had been mentioned.
u(pantia/sai: “To requite.” The construction after the analogy of a)mei/yasqai. The subject se/ is implied as e)me/ (h(ma=s) is implied P. 1.29.
*)alecibia/da: The patronymic gives weight and honor.
se\ de/: See O. 1.36.
fle/gonti: “Illume.” Compare O. 9.24: fi/lan po/lin | malerai=s e)pifle/gwn a)oidai=s.
*xa/rites: See O. 7.11.
maka/rios, o(\s e)/xeis , kte(.: He might have had the ka/matos without the lo/goi. This furnishes the transition.
peda/=meta/ (Aiol.-Dor.). Cf.O. 12.12.
mnamh=|on (Aeolic) for mnhmei=on (Bergk). The MSS. mnamh/ion, Christ mnamh/i'.
tessara/konta: The number seems high. Il. 23. 287 there are but five competitors, So. El. 708 but ten.
peto/ntessin (Aeolic) = katapesou=si (Schol.).
a)tarbei= freni/: Cf. P. 9.33: a)tarbei= ... kefala=|. Karrhotos owed the victory to his coolness. So did Antilochos in the Iliad (23, 515): ke/rdesin ou)/ ti ta/xei ge parafqa/menos *mene/laon.
h)=lqes ... pedi/on: See P. 4.51.
a)glaw=n: So Moschopulos for a)gaqw=n. Mommsen reads a)gaqe/wn = h)gaqe/wn, “divine.”

div3.head: Epode 2
div3.p: po/nwn ... e)/setai: In another mood Pindar says, O. 10 (11), 24: a)/ponon d' e)/labon xa/rma pau=roi/ tines.

e)/mpan ta\ kai\ ta\ ve/mwn: “Despite its chequered course.” So I. 4 (5), 52: *zeu\s ta/ te kai\ ta\ ne/mei, and I. 3 (4), 51: tw=n te ga\r kai\ tw=n didoi=. Success and defeat, good and bad, glory and toil.

pu/rgos a)/steos ... ce/noisi: Compare P. 3.71: prau+\s a)stoi=s, ou) fqone/wn a)gaqoi=s, cei/nois de\ qaumasto\s path/r. Significant omission here of the a)gaqoi/. The conspiracy was among the upper classes.
o)/mma: See note on v. 17.
faenno/taton: See P. 3.75.

le/ontes ... fu/gon: P., according to his wont (cf. P. 3.83: ta\ kala\ tre/yantes e)/cw), turns the old tale about. Kyrene was infested by lions, like the rest of Africa (leonum arida nutrix), until the arrival of Battos. According to Pausanias, 10, 15, 7, Battos, the stammerer, was frightened by the sight of a lion into loud and clear utterance; P. makes this utterance frighten the lion and his kind into flight.

peri\ dei/mati: peri/ here takes the peculiar construction which is more frequently noticed with a)mfi/, “compassed by fear,” hence “from fear.” So Aisch. Pers. 696: peri\ ta/rbei, Choëph. 35: peri\ fo/bw|, Hymn. Cer. 429: peri\ xa/rmati.

e)/dwke ... fo/bw|: So N. 1.66: dw/sein mo/rw|, O. 2.90: qana/tw| po/ren,
O. 10 (11), 102: e)/pore mo/xqw|.
tami/a| *kura/nas: tami/as is a high word. See P. 1.88.
a)telh\s ... manteu/masin = yeudo/mantis. “One that effects naught by his prophecies.”

div3.head: Strophe 3
div3.p: bareia=n no/swn , kte(.: Apollo's various functions are enumerated, beginning with the physical and proceeding to the musical and the political, which had a natural nexus to the Greek. The development is perfectly normal.

a)ke/smata:) The Kyrenaians, next to the Krotoniates, were the best physicians of Greece, Hdt. 3, 131. The medical side is turned out v. 91: a)lecimbro/tois pompai=s. Compare P. 4.270. Silphium also had rare virtues.
po/ren te ki/qarin: Compare v. 107 and P. 4.295. The moral effect of the ki/qaris (compare the fo/rmigc in P. 1) prepares the way for a)po/lemon ... eu)nomi/an.
muxo/n t' a)mfe/pei | manth=|on: This is the crowning blessing. Kyrene owes her very existence to the oracle of Apollo, P. 4.53.
manth=|on = mantei=on.
w(=|: “Whereby.”

*lakedai/moni: The most important is put first and afterwards recalled, v. 73: a)po\ *spa/rtas. *l. is geographically central, with Argos and Pylos on either hand. On e)n with the second dat. see O. 9.94.
*ai)gimiou=: A Dorian, not a Herakleid. See P. 1.64.

to\ d' e)mo/n: Cf. I. 7 (8), 39: to\ me\n e)mo/n. The healing power, the gift of the Muse, the fair state, the settlement of the Peloponnese — all these wonderful things are due to Apollo — but mine it is to sing the glory of Sparta and the Aigeidai, who are bone of my bone and flesh of my flesh. By insisting on the ancient ties of kindred, P. gives a warmer tone to his narrative. Compare O. 6.84.
garu/en: So with Hermann and Bergk for garu/et' garu/ent' of the MSS.

div3.head: Antistrophe 3
div3.p: *qh/rande: Thera is called Kallista, P. 4.258.

e)moi\ pate/res: P. was an Aigeid of the Theban branch. If a)delfo/s may be stretched to mean “cousin,” pate/res may be stretched to mean “uncles.” According to Herodotos, 4, 149, the Aigeidai colonized Thera, and were preceded by Kadmeians, c. 147. On the Theban origin of the Aigeidai, see I. 6 (7), 15.

ou) qew=n a)/ter a)lla\ moi=ra/ tis a)/gen: Some editors punctuate after a)/ter and connect a)/gen with what follows, but the divorce of a)lla/ from ou) qew=n a)/ter and a)/gen from i(/konto is unnatural. Compare O. 8.45: ou)k a)/ter pai/dwn se/qen, a)ll' a(/ma prw/tois a)/rcetai. The leading of fate in the imperfect, the special case of Aristoteles-Battos in
the aor., v. 87.
e)/ranon: The Karneia was a sacred festival, to which each participant contributed. See O. 1.38.
e)/nqen: Cf. O. 2.9 on the trajection of the relative.
a)nadeca/menoi: Pindar identifies himself with the worshipping multitude at Kyrene. Hermann's a)nadecame/nan is unnecessary.
*karnh/ie: The Karneia, the great festival of Apollo Karneios, was transmitted from Sparta to Thera, from Thera to Kyrene.
e)/xonti: Not an historical present. The old stock of the Antenoridai is still there. If not, they still hold the land, as Aias holds Salamis. N. 4.48: *ai)/as *salami=n' e)/xei patrw/|an.
xalkoxa/rmai: See P. 2.2.
*trw=es *)antanori/dai: Lysimachos is cited by the Schol. as authority. A hill between Kyrene and the sea was called lo/fos *)anthnoridw=n.
kapnwqei=san ... vi/don: In prose the aor. part. is seldom used of actual perception, not unfrequently in poetry of vision. I. 7 (8), 37. Aor. part. with i)dei=n, P. 9.105; 10, 26.

div3.head: Epode 3
div3.p: e)la/sippon: As Trojans the Antenoridai were ke/ntores i(/ppwn (Il. 5. 102) and i(ppo/damoi (Il. 2. 230, etc.).
de/kontai: Not historical present. The Antenoridai are still worshipped by the descendants of the colony under Battos.
oi)xne/ontes: Cf. O. 3.40; P. 6.4.
*)aristote/lhs: Battos I. See P. 4.63.

eu)qu/tomon ... o(do/n: Bergk reads eu)qu/tonon, which is not so good. The road was hewn out of solid rock, the occasional breaks being filled in with small stones carefully fitted together; hence skurwta\n o(do/n. This road was evidently one of the sights of Kyrene, and the remains still stir the wonder of travellers.
a)lecimbro/tois: See note on v. 64.
pedia/da: “Level.” All care was taken to prevent ill-omened accidents in the processions.
di/xa kei=tai: Special honor is paid him as ktisth/s. So Pelops' tomb is by itself (Schol., Ol. 1, 92). Catull. 7, 6: Batti veteris sacrum sepulcrum.

div3.head: Strophe 4
div3.p: laosebh/s: The honors thus received are described O. 7.79, foll.
pro\ dwma/twn: On either side of the road. The monuments are still numbered by thousands; many of them are little temples.
laxo/ntes a)i/dan: P.'s poikili/a for qano/ntes.

mega/lan ... *)arkesi/la|: “They hear, sure, with soul beneath the earth great achievement besprent with soft dew 'neath the outpourings of songs — their happiness a joint glory with their son, and richly due to him, even to Arkesilas.” Another reading is megala=n a)reta=n r(anqeisa=n. Yet another, r(anqei=sin.
The codices have kw/mwn, for which Beck reads u(/mnwn to save the metre.
dro/sw| malqaka=|: A favorite figure. P. 8.57: r(ai/nw de\ kai\ u(/mnw|, I. 5 (6), 21: na=son r(aine/men eu)logi/ais.
r(anqei=san: The aor. part. is not very common even in poetry after verbs of hearing as actual perception. See v. 84.
u(po\ xeu/masin: Plastic. dro/sos malqaka/ forms the xeu/mata.
poi/ = pw/s. Compare O. 1.28: pou/. Böckh prefers toi/.
xqoni/a| freni/: xqonia| = u(po\ xqono/s. Fennell: “With such faculty as the dead possess.”
sfo/n = sfe/teron. Only here in P.

o)/lbon: The Scholiast refers this to the kw=mos. Grammatically it is in apposition to the whole preceding clause. to\ r(anqh=nai is the o)/lbos, the a)koh/ involved in a)kou/onti. The honor is common to them and their son (compare P. 6.15), but it is peculiarly due to Arkesilas; hence the neat division of ui(w=| and *)arkesi/la|, which should not be run together.
e)n a)oida=|: O. 5.19: *ludi/ois a)pu/wn e)n au)loi=s.
xrusa/ora: Hung with (the) gold(en fo/rmigc). Compare P. 1.1. The same epithet is applied to Orpheus, fr. X. 8, 10.

div3.head: Antistrophe 4
div3.p: e)/xonta: With to/n.
kalli/nikon luth/rion: Both adj
dapana=n: The inevitable other side, never forgotten by the thrifty Greek. Cf. O. 5.15: po/nos dapa/na te.
lego/menon e)re/w: I can only say what all the world says. See P. 3.2: koino\n ve/pos.
kre/ssona me\n a(liki/as: Compare the laudation of Damophilos P. 4.280.
fe/rbetai: Used like tre/fei.

e)n ... *moi/saisi: Not “in musical arts,” which were colorless. He flits among the Muses (P. 6.49), a winged soul from his mother's lap — not “taught by his mother dear,” but as an inheritance from her nature.
pe/fantai: Now. Not to be supplied with the other predicates.
sofo/s: See note on v. 51.

div3.head: Epode 4
div3.p: o(/sai t' ei)si\n ... teto/lmake: te sums up. The e)pixw/ria kala/ embrace all the forms of generous rivalry in Kyrene.
e)/sodoi: Cf. P. 6.50.
telei= du/nasin: “Maketh his potency performance.”
o(moi=a: So Hartung for MS. w)=, Moschopulos' w)= plei=sta. May the blessed Kronidai give him like fortune in deeds and counsels.
mh\ ... xro/non: Punctuate after e)/xein. Asyndeton presents no difficulty in wishes.
fqinopwri/s: The compound recalls fqino/karpos, P. 4.265. Compare v. 10.
kata\ pnoa/: So with Christ for katapnoa/, k. with damali/zoi.
damali/zoi: Bergk reads dnopali/zoi.

xro/non = bi/on (Schol.). “His lifetime,” as O. 1.115. Not satisfactory. qro/non (Hecker). xlo/an would
keep up the figure (Bergk).
dai/mona: “Fate.” Here it suits P. to make Zeus the pilot and the dai/mwn the oarsman.
tou=to ... ge/ras: It is not necessary to change to twu)to/, O. 8.57. The desired victory was gained Ol. 80.
e)/pi: “As a crowning mercy.” See O. 2.12; 9, 120.

div2.p: The victory here commemorated was gained P. 24 (Ol. 71, 3) 494 B.C., and was celebrated by Simonides also, acc. to the Schol. on I. 2. The victor, Xenokrates, was an Agrigentine, brother of Theron. Compare O. 2.54: *puqw=ni d' o(mo/klaron e)s a)delfeo\n | *)isqmoi= te koinai\ *xa/rites a)/nqea teqri/ppwn duwdekadro/mwn | a)/gagon. The charioteer was Thrasybulos, son of Xenokrates. Böckh thinks that the ode was sung at a banquet held at Delphi in honor of Thrasybulos.

The theme is the glory of filial devotion. As the man that hath dared and died for his father's life, so the man that hath wrought and spent for his father's honor hath a treasure of hymns that nothing shall destroy, laid up where neither rain nor wind doth corrupt.
The simplicity of the thought is not matched by the language, which is a trifle overwrought.

The poet's ploughshare is turning up a field of Aphrodite or the Charites as he draws nigh to the temple centre of the earth where lies a treasure for the Emmenidai, for Akragas, for Xenokrates (vv. 1-9).

A treasure which neither the fierce armament of wintry rain nor storm with its rout of rubble shall bear to the recesses of the sea — a treasure whose face, shining in clear light, shall announce a victory common to thy father, Thrasybulos, and to thy race, and glorious in the repute of mortals (vv. 10-18).

At thy right hand, upheld by thee, rideth the Law, once given in the mountains by the son of Philyra to Peleides when sundered from father and mother, first of all to reverence the Thunderer, then of such reverence never to deprive his parents in their allotted life (vv. 19-27).

There was another, Antilochos, man of might, that aforetime showed this spirit by dying for his father in his stand against Memnon. Nestor's chariot was tangled by his horse, stricken
of Paris' arrows, and Memnon plied his mighty spear. His soul awhirl the old man of Messene called: My son! (vv. 28-36).

Not to the ground fell his word. Stedfast the god-like man awaited the foe, bought with his life the rescue of his father, for his high deed loftiest example of the olden time to younger men, pattern of filial worth. These things are of the past. Of the time that now is Thrasybulos hath come nearest to the mark in duty to a father (vv. 37-45).

His father's brother he approaches in all manner of splendor. With wisdom he guides his wealth. The fruit of his youth is not injustice nor violence, but the pursuit of poesy in the haunts of the Pierides, and to thee, Poseidon, with thy passionate love of steeds, he clings, for with thee hath he found favor. Sweet also is the temper of his soul, and as a boon companion he outvies the cellè labor of the bees (vv. 46-54).

The poem is the second in time of Pindar's odes. Eight years separate it from P. 10, and Leop. Schmidt notices a decided advance, although he sees in it many traces of youthfulness. The parallel between Antilochos, son of Nestor, who died for his father, and Thrasybulos, son of Xenokrates, who drove for his, has evoked much criticism, and, while the danger of the chariot-race must not be overlooked, the step from Antilochos to Thrasybulos is too great for sober art.

The poem consists of six strophes, with slight overlapping once, where, however, the sense of the preceding strophe (v. 45) is complete, and the participle comes in as an after-thought (compare P. 4.262). Of these six strophes two describe the treasure, two tell the story of Antilochos, son of Nestor, prototype of filial self-sacrifice, the last two do honor to the victor's son.
The rhythm is logaoedic.

div3.head: Strophe 1
div3.p: a)kou/sate: A herald cry. So a)kou/ete lew/|, the “oyez” of the Greek courts.
e(likw/pidos: This adj. is used of Chryseïs, Il. 1. 98; variously interpreted. “Of the flashing eye” is a fair compromise.

*)afrodi/tas: Pindar goes a-ploughing, and finds in the field of Aphrodite, or of the Charites, treasure of song. Aphrodite is mentioned as the mistress of the Graces, who are the goddesses of victory. See O. 14.8 foll.
a)/rouran: Cf. O. 9.29: *xari/twn ... ka=pon, N. 6.37: *pieri/dwn a)ro/tais, 10, 26: *moi/saisin e)/dwk' a)ro/sai.

e)ribro/mou: Refers most naturally to the noise of the waterfall,
though the gorge was full of echoes, the roar of the wind, the rumble of thunder (v. 11), the rattling of chariots, the tumult of the people.
na/ion: The MSS. have nao/n, for which Hermann writes na/ion = naou=, “of the temple” (cf. v. 6), Bergk and many editors la/inon.
*)emmeni/dais: O. 3.38.
potami/a| ... *)akra/ganti: Cf. O. 2.10: oi)/khma potamou=. Akragas, the city, is blended with the nymph of the river Akragas. See P. 9.4; 12, 2.
kai\ ma/n: P. 4.90.
u(/mnwn | qhsauro/s: A store of victories is a treasure-house of hymns.
poluxru/sw|: P. 4.53: poluxru/sw| pot' e)n dw/mati.
tetei/xistai: The figure shifts from the field to the gorge, or rather the temple in the gorge, where the treasure is safely “guarded by walls.”

div3.head: Strophe 2
div3.p:
xeime/rios o)/mbros: The original of Hor. Od. 3, 30, 3. 4:
quod non imber edax, non Aquilo impotens
possit diruere.
e)pakto/s: The rain comes from an alien quarter. Compare the hatefulness of the poimh\n e)pakto\s a)llo/trios, O. 10 (11), 97.
e)ribro/mou: P., with all his poikili/a, is not afraid to repeat, as a modern poet would be. See P. 1.80.

strato/s: The figure is perfect. Rain comes across a plain, or across the water, exactly as the advance of an army. One sees the sti/xes a)ndrw=n. The wall protects the treasure against the hostile (e)pakto/s) advance.
a)mei/lixos: “Relentless,” “grim.”

a)/coisi: With the plur. compare Eur. Alc. 360: kai/ m' ou)/q' o( *plou/twnos ku/wn ou)/q' ou(pi\ kw/ph| yuxopompo\s a)\n *xa/rwn e)/sxon . Similar plurals are not uncommon with disjunctives in English. In Lat. compare Hor. Od. 1, 13, 5:
Tum nec mens mihi nec color
certa sede manent.

pamfo/rw| xera/dei: So, and not xera/di. The nominative is xe/rados, not xera/s. The Schol. says xera\s o( meta\ i)lu/os kai\ li/qwn surfeto/s. It seems to be rather loose stones, and may be transl. “rubble.”

tupto/menon: So Dawes for tupto/menos. Bergk's krupto/menon is not likely. The whirlwind drags the victim along while he is pounded by the storm-driven stones. The rain is an army (imber edax), the wind is a mob (Aquilo impotens).

pro/swpon: The pro/swpon is the pro/swpon thlauge/s of the treasure-house made luminous by joy (P. 3.75). Mezger: “thy countenance” (of Thrasybulos) after Leop. Schmidt. We should expect teo/n, and we need the tew=| that we have.
patri\ tew=| ... koina/n te genea=|: p. depends on koina/n, not on a)paggelei=.
lo/goisi qnatw=n ... a)paggelei=: “Will announce to the discourses of mortals,” will furnish a theme to them. Cf. P. 1.93: manu/ei kai\ logi/ois kai\ a)oidoi=s.
eu)/docon: Proleptic.
a(/rmati ni/kan | *krisai/ais e)n ptuxai=s: All run together, “a Pythian chariot-victory,” as I. 2, 13: *)isqmi/an i(/ppoisi ni/kan.

div3.head: Strophe 3
div3.p: sxe/qwn: Shall we write sxeqw/n aor. or sxe/qwn pres.? Most frequently aor., the form seems to be used as a present here.

toi ... nin: nin anticipates e)fhmosu/nan. See O. 7.59; 13, 69. Another view makes nin the father, who stands on the right of the son in the triumphal procession. Bergk writes nun, after the Schol. toi/nun.

e)pide/cia xeiro/s: Compare Od. 5. 277: th\n ... e)p' a)ristera\ xeiro\s e)/xonta. The commandment is personified. She is mounted on the chariot of Thrasybulos as a polu/filos e(pe/tis (cf. P. 5.4), and stands on his right hand because upheld by him. The word shall not fall to the ground. It is an o)rqo\n e)/pos. Cf. v. 37: xamaipete\s ... e)/pos ou)k a)pe/riyen.
ta/: Compare, for the shift, P. 2.75: oi(=a.
megalosqenh=: So with Bergk for megalosqenei=. The teacher is to be emphasized this time.

*filu/ras ui(o/n: Cheiron, P. 3.1. On Achilles' education in the abode of Cheiron, see N. 3.43. The *xei/rwnos u(poqh=kai were famous. The first two of them seem to have been identical with the first two of Euripides' three, Antiop. fr. 46: qeou/s te tima=n tou/s te qre/yantas gonei=s. Compare also P. 4.102.

o)rfanizome/nw|. Verbs of privation connote feeling, hence often in the present where we might expect the perfect. Compare ste/romai and e)ste/rhmai, privor and privatus sum. Achilles is parted from father and mother.
ma/lista me\n *kroni/dan: The meaning, conveyed in P.'s usual implicit manner, is: Zeus above all the gods, father and mother above all mankind.
baruo/pan: Immediately applicable to the keraunw=n pru/tanin, but steropa=n keraunw=n
te form a unit (O. 1.62).
tau/tas ... tima=s = tou= se/besqai.
gone/wn bi/on peprwme/non = tou\s gone/as e(/ws a)/n zw=sin.

div3.head: Strophe 4
div3.p: e)/gento: For e)ge/neto (as P. 3.87) = e)fa/nh, “showed himself.”
kai\ pro/teron: In times of yore as Thrasybulos now (kai/).
fe/rwn: With no/hma is almost an adjective, toiou=tos to\n nou=n.
e)nari/mbroton: Occurs again, I. 7 (8), 53: ma/xas e)narimbro/tou.
*ai)qio/pwn | *me/mnona: This version of the story is taken from the *ai)qiopi/s of Arktinos.
*nesto/reion: O. 2.13.

e)pe/da: Il. 8. 80: *ne/stwr oi)=os e)/mimne *gerh/nios ou)=ros *)axaiw=n | ou)/ ti e(kw/n, a)ll' i(/ppos e)tei/reto, to\n ba/len i)w=| | di=os *)ale/candros, *(ele/nhs po/sis h)uko/moio. In Homer it is Diomed that comes to the rescue.
Still the death of Antilochos by the hand of Memnon was known to the poet of the Odyssey, 4, 188.
dai+xqei/s: O. 3.6.
e)/fepen: “Plied,” “attacked him with.”
*messani/ou: Not from Triphylian, but from Messenian Pylos. See P. 4.126.
donhqei=sa frh/n: See P. 1.72.

div3.head: Strophe 5
div3.p: xamaipete/s = w(/ste xamaipete\s ei)=nai. Compare O. 9.13: ou)/toi xamaipete/wn lo/gwn e)fa/yeai.
au)tou=: “On the spot,” hence “unmoved,” “stedfast.”
tw=n pa/lai: tw=n depends on u(/patos.
genea=|: Cf. Il. 2. 707: o(plo/teros geneh=|.

o(plote/roisin: The position favors the combination, e)do/khsen -- o(plote/roisin -- u(/patos. Antilochos belonged to the o(plo/teroi, and the position accorded to him by them was the more honorable, as younger men are severer judges.
a)mfi\ tokeu=sin: Prose, peri\ tou\s toke/as.
ta\ me\n pari/kei: The parallel is strained, and it is hard to keep what follows from flatness, although we must never forget the personal risk of a chariot-race.
tw=n nu=n de/: Contrast to tw=n pa/lai.

patrw/|an ... pro\s sta/qman: “To the father-standard,” “to the standard of what is due to a father.” Not “to the standard set by our fathers.” Antilochos was and continued to be an unapproachable model. Xen. Kyneg. 1, 14: *)anti/loxos tou= patro\s u(perapoqanw\n tosau/ths e)/tuxen eu)klei/as w(/ste mo/nos filopa/twr para\ toi=s *(/ellhsin a)nagoreuqh=nai.

div3.head: Strophe 6
div3.p: pa/trw|: Theron.
no/w| de\ plou=ton a)/gei: Compare P. 5.2. 3: o(/tan tis ... [plou=ton] a)na/gh|. no/w|, “with judgment.”

a)/dikon ou)/q' u(pe/roplon: On the omission of the first ou)/te, see P. 10.29: nausi\ d' ou)/te pezo\s i)w/n. A similar omission of “neither” is common enough in English. So Shakespeare, “The shot of accident nor dart of chance,” “Thine nor none of thine,” “Word nor oath;” Byron, “Sigh nor word,” “Words nor deeds.” a)/dikon and u(pe/roplon are proleptic. The youth that he enjoys is not a youth of injustice or presumption.
h(/ban dre/pwn: Cf. O. 1.13.
sofi/an: O. 1.116.
*)ele/lixqon: Cf. P. 2.4.

o)rga=|s o(\s i(ppeia=n e)so/dwn: This is Christ's reading. “Who art passionate in thy love of chariot contests.” o)rga=|s construed like o)rou/eis (P. 10.61). The inferior MSS. have eu(=re/s q', the better o)rgai=s pa/sais, which is supposed to be a gloss to ma/la vado/nti no/w| = e(ko/nti no/w|, P. 5.43, but when did a(dw/n ever mean e(kw/n? ma/la vado/nti no/w| must mean that the spirit of
Thrasybulos had found favor in Poseidon's eyes. All the MSS. have i(ppei/an e)/sodon. i(/ppeiai e)/sodoi = i(ppikai\ a(/millai.
glukei=a de\ frh/n: Supply e)sti, which P. seldom uses. O. 1.1.

sumpo/taisin o(milei=n = e)n tai=s sumpotikai=s o(mili/ais. kai/ throws it into construction with a)mei/betai. To say that “a spirit that is sweet to associate even with one's boon companions surpasses the honey and the honeycomb” is a bit of sour philosophizing that does not suit the close of this excessively sugary poem.
trhto\n po/non: Has a finical, précieux, sound to us.

div2.p: The seventh Pythian is the only epinikion in honor of a citizen of Athens except N. 2. Megakles, whose victory is here celebrated, was a member of the aristocratic house of the Alkmaionidai, a grandson of that Megakles who married the daughter of Kleisthenes, tyrant of Sikyon (Hdt. 6, 127 foll.). Whether our Megakles was the son of Kleisthenes, the lawgiver, or of Hippokrates, brother of the lawgiver, does not appear. The latter is called simply suggenh/s by the Scholiast. The victory was gained Pyth. 25 (Ol. 72, 3), the year of the battle of Marathon. Whether the Pythian games were celebrated and the ode composed before the battle or not is a question that has led to elaborate discussion, which cannot be presented here even in summary. Pindar's patriotism, so dear to many, so doubtful to some, is thought to be at stake; but we have to do with Pindar the poet, rather than Pindar the patriot; and all that can be said in this place is, that even if the ode was composed and performed after the battle, there were reasons enough why the poet should not have referred distinctly to a victory, the greatness of which was not necessary to make Athens great enough for poetry; a victory which would not have been a pleasant theme for the Alkmaionidai, on account of the suspicions of treachery that attached to them (Hdt. 6, 115).

Athens is the fairest preface of song, the fairest foundation of a monument of praise to the Alkmaionidai for their victory in the chariot-race. No fatherland, no house, whose name is greater praise throughout Greece (vv. 1-6).

The story of the Erechtheidai haunts every city, for they made the temple of Apollo in divine Pytho a marvel to behold. That were enough, but I am led to further song by five Isthmian victories, one o'ertopping victory at Olympia, and two from Pytho (vv. 7-12).

These have been won by you that now are and by your forefathers. My heart is full of joy at this new good-fortune. What though noble acts have for their requital envy? Abiding happiness brings with it now this, now that (vv. 13-17).

Mezger sees in this ode a complete poem, not a fragment, as L. Schmidt does. No part of an epinikion, he says, is wanting. Praises of the victor, the victory, the family, the city, the god of the games, form the usual garland. In the heart of the poem stands the great act of piety, the building of the Delphic temple. The victories of the Alkmaionidai are a reward of their service to Apollo. The citizens are not all so grateful as the god, but their envy is only an assurance of abiding happiness.

So short a poem does not call for an elaborate analysis. Chiefly noteworthy is the way in which each member of the triad balances itself. The strophe has to do with Athens and the Alkmaionidai, the antistrophe with splendid generosity and brilliant success, the epode sums up new and old, and sets off abiding happiness against the envy which it costs. Compare the structure of O. 12.
The measures are logaoedic.

div3.head: Strophe
div3.p: ai( megalopo/lies *)aqa=nai: Cf. P. 2.1: megalopo/lies w)= *sura/kosai. As this is poetry, there is no need of scrutinizing the epithet closely with reference to the period. Solon calls Athens mega/lhn po/lin. Herodotos, writing of the end of the sixth century, says (5, 66): *)aqh=nai kai\ pri\n mega/lai to/te a)pallaxqei=sai tw=n tura/nnwn e)ge/nonto me/zones.
prooi/mion: Athens is the noblest opening for a song in honor of the Alkmaionidai. pr. is the prelude sung before the foundation is laid.

genea=| ... i(/ppoisi: The double dat. is not harsh if we connect, after Pindar's manner, a)oida=n with i(/ppoisi, “chariot-songs.” Cf. P. 6.17, and I. 1, 14: *(hrodo/tw| teu/xwn to\ me\n a(/rmati teqri/ppw| ge/ras.

krhpi=d' a)oida=n ... bale/sqai: Cf. P. 4.138: ba/lleto krhpi=da sofw=n e)pe/wn. The architectural image recalls the service that the Alkmaionidai had rendered the Delphian temple. bale/sqai: “For the laying.” P. is instructive for the old dat. conception of the inf.
pa/tran: Cannot be “clan” here. It must refer to Athens, as oi)=kon to the Alkmaionidai.

nai/ont': With ti/na. “Whom shall I name as inhabiting a fatherland, whom a house more illustrious of report in Greece?” (ti/s nai/ei e)pifaneste/ran me\n pa/tran, e)pifane/steron de\ oi)=kon;) P.'s usual way of changing the form of a proposition.
nai/wn is the reading of all the MSS. The Scholia read nai/ont', as they show by oi)kou=nta. No conjecture yet made commends itself irresistibly.
puqe/sqai: Epexegetic infinitive.

div3.head: Antistrophe
div3.p: lo/gos o(milei=: Semi-personification. o(. = a)nastre/fetai (Schol.). Cf. O. 12.19: o(mile/wn par' oi)kei/ais a)rou/rais. The story is at home, is familiar as household words.
*)erexqe/os a)stw=n: Indication of ancient descent. Compare O. 13.14: pai=des *ala/ta. P. includes Athens in the glory of the liberality.

teo/n ne do/mon: When the temple of Delphi, which had been burned Ol. 58, 1 = 548 B.C.), was rebuilt, the Alkmaionidai, then in exile, took the contract for the façade, and carried it out in an expensive marble instead of a cheap stone (Hdt. 5, 62).
qahto/n = w(/ste qahto\n ei)=nai. “Fashioned thy house in splendor.”
a)/gonti de/: P. is not allowed to linger on this theme. Other glories lead him to other praises.
e)kpreph/s: Cf. O. 1.1

div3.head: Epode
div3.p: u(mai/: By you of this generation.
xai/rw ti: A kind of lito/ths. “I have no little joy.”
to\ d' a)/xnumai: “But this is my grievance.”
fqo/non a)meibo/menon = o(/ti fqo/nos a)mei/betai. Instructive for the peculiar Attic construction with verbs of emotion, e. g. So. Ai. 136: se\ me\n eu)= pra/ssont' e)pixai/rw. a). “requiting.”

ge ma/n: “Howbeit.” ma/n meets an objection, made or to be made, ge limits the utterance to fanti/. Compare O. 13.104; P. 1.17; N. 8.50; I. 3 (4), 18. “Yet they say that thus prosperity that abideth in bloom for a man brings with it this and that” (good and bad), or, analyzed, ou(/tws a)\n paramo/nimos qa/lloi h( eu)daimoni/a e)a\n ta\ kai\ ta\ fe/rhtai. Ups and downs are necessary to abiding fortune. Perpetual success provokes more than envy of men, the Nemesis of God. We hear the old Polykrates note.
ta\ kai\ ta/: Here “good and bad.” as I. 3 (4). 51.

div2.p: Aristomenes of Aigina, the son of Xenarkes, belonged to the clan of the Midylidai, and had good examples to follow in his own family. One of his uncles, Theognetos, was victorious at Olympia, another, Kleitomachos, at the Isthmian games, both in wrestling, for which Aristomenes was to be distinguished. His victories at Megara, at Marathon, in Aigina, were crowned by success at the Pythian games. It is tolerably evident that at the time of this ode he was passing from the ranks of the boywrestlers (v. 78). No mention is made of the trainer, a character who occupies so much space in O. 8.

P. was, in all likelihood, present at the games (v. 59). The poem seems to have been composed for the celebration in Aigina — compare to/qi (v. 64), which points to distant Delphi, and note that Hesychia, and not Apollo, is invoked at the outset of the ode.

What is the date? According to the Schol., Pyth. 35 (Ol. 82, 3 = 450 B.C.), when Aigina had been six years under the yoke of Athens; but the supposed reference to foreign wars (v. 3), and the concluding verses, which imply the freedom of the island, led O. Müller and many others to give an earlier date to the victory, 458 B.C. Allusions to the battle of Kekryphaleia (Thuk. 1, 105) were also detected, but Kekryphaleia was a bad day for the Aiginetans, because the Athenian success was the forerunner of Aiginetan ruin (Diod. 11, 78), and a reference to it would have been incomprehensible. In any case, P. would hardly have represented the Athenians as the monstrous brood of giants (v. 12 foll.). Mezger, who adheres to the traditional date, sees in pole/mwn (v. 3) an allusion, not to foreign wars, but to domestic factions, such as naturally ensued when the Athenians changed the Aiginetan constitution to the detriment of the nobles (oi( paxei=s). Krüger gives the earlier date of Ol. 77, 3 (470 B.C.). or Ol. 78, 3 (466 B.C.). Hermann goes back as far as Ol. 75, 3 (478 B.C.), and sees in the ode allusions to the Persian war, Porphyrion
and Typhõeus being prefigurements of Xerxes — altogether unlikely. Fennell, who advocates 462 B.C., suggests the great victory of Eurymedon four years before “as having revived the memory of Salamis, while apprehensions of Athenian aggression were roused by the recent reduction of Thasos.”

If we accept the late date, the poem becomes of special importance as Pindar's last, just as P. 10 is of special importance as Pindar's earliest ode. Leopold Schmidt has made the most of the tokens of declining power. Mezger, on the other hand, emphasizes the steadiness of the technical execution, and the similarity of the tone. “In P. 10.20 we have mh\ fqonerai=s e)k qew=n metatropi/ais e)piku/rsaien, in P. 8.71: qew=n d' o)/pin a)/fqiton ai)te/w, *ce/narkes, u(mete/rais tu/xais, and in P. 10.62 we have as sharp a presentation of the transitoriness of human fortunes as in the famous passage P. 8.92.” But this comparison of commonplaces proves nothing. There is undoubtedly an accent of experience added in P. 8; and, according to Mezger's own interpretation, P. 8.71 is deeper than P. 10.20. Jean Paul says somewhere, “The youngest heart has the waves of the oldest; it only lacks the plummet that measures their depth.” In P. 8 Pindar has the plummet.

Hesychia is to Aigina what the lyre is to Syracuse; and the eighth Pythian, which begins with the invocation *filo/fron *(hsuxi/a, is not unrelated to the first Pythian, which begins with the invocation *xruse/a fo/rmigc. In the one, the lyre is the symbol of the harmony produced by the splendid sway of a central power, Hieron; in the other, the goddess Hesychia diffuses her influence through all the members of the commonwealth. In the one case, the balance is maintained by a strong hand; in the other, it depends on the nice adjustment of forces within the state. Typhõeus figures here (v. 16) as he figures in the first Pythian; but there the monster stretches from Cumae to Sicily, and represents the shock of foreign warfare as well as the volcanic powers of revolt (note on P. 1.72); here there is barely a hint, if a hint, of trouble from without. Here, too, Typhõeus is quelled by Zeus, and Porphyrion, king of the giants, by Apollo (vv. 1618); but we have no Aitna keeping down the monster, and a certain significance attaches to e)n xro/nw| of v. 15.

The opening, then, is a tribute to Hesychia, the goddess of domestic tranquillity, who holds the keys of wars and councils,
who knows the secret of true gentleness (vv. 1-7), who has strength to sink the rebellious crew of malcontents, such as Porphyrion and Typhõeus — the one quelled by the thunderbolt of Zeus, the other by the bow of Apollo — Apollo, who welcomed the son of Xenarkes home from Kirrha, crowned with Parnassian verdure and Dorian revel-song (vv. 8-20).

Then begins the praise of Aigina for her exploits in the games, and the praise of Aristomenes for keeping up the glory of his house and for exalting the clan of the Midylidai and earning the word that Amphiaraos spoke (vv. 21-40).

The short myth follows, the scene in which the soul of Amphiaraos, beholding the valor of his son and his son's comrades among the Epigonoi, uttered the words: *fua=| to\ gennai=on e)pipre/pei | e)k pate/rwn paisi\n lh=ma (v. 44). The young heroes have the spirit of their sires. “Blood will tell.” Adrastos, leader of the first adventure, is compassed by better omens now; true, he alone will lose his son, but he will bring back his people safe by the blessing of the gods (vv. 41-55).

O. 8, another Aiginetan ode, is prayerful. Prayer and oracle are signs of suspense; and the utterance of Amphiaraos carries with it the lesson that Aigina's only hope lay in the preservation of the spirit of her nobility. What the figure of Adrastos means is not so evident. It may signify: Whatever else perishes, may the state abide unharmed.

Such, then, were the words of Amphiaraos, whose praise of his son Alkmaion is echoed by Pindar — for Alkmaion is not only the prototype of Aristomenes, but he is also the neighbor of the poet, guardian of his treasures, and spoke to him in oracles (vv. 56-60).
Similar sudden shifts are common in the quicker rhythms (Aiolian), and the Aiginetan odes of P. presume an intimacy that we cannot follow in detail.

P. now turns with thanksgiving and prayer to Apollo — entreats his guidance, craves for the fortunes of the house of Xenarkes the boon of a right reverence of the gods. Success is not the test of merit. It is due to the will of Fortune, who makes men her playthings. “Therefore keep thee within bounds.”
Then follows the recital of the victories, with a vivid picture of the defeated contestants as they slink homeward (vv. 61-87).

“The bliss of glory lends wings and lifts the soul above riches. But delight waxeth in a little space. It falls to the ground, when shaken by adversity. We are creatures of a day. What are we?
what are we not? A dream of shadow is man. Yet all is not shadow. When God-given splendor comes there is a clear shining and a life of sweetness.”
“Aigina, mother dear, bring this city safely onward in her course of freedom, with the blessing of Zeus, Lord Aiakos, Peleus, and good Telamon and Achilles” (vv. 88-100).
Compare again the close of O. 8. This invocation of all the saints in the calendar is ominous.

To sum up: The first triad is occupied with the praise of Hesychia, ending in praise of the victor. The second triad begins with the praise of Aigina, and ends with the Midylidai, to whom the victor belongs. The third triad gives the story of Alkmaion, as an illustration of the persistency of noble blood. The fourth acknowledges the goodness of Apollo, and entreats his further guidance; for God is the sole source of these victories, which are now recounted. The fifth presents a striking contrast between vanquished and victor, and closes with an equally striking contrast between the nothingness of man and the power of God, which can make even the shadow of a dream to be full of light and glory. At the end is heard a fervent prayer for Aigina's welfare.

So we have two for introduction, one for myth, two for conclusion. It is evident that the circumstances are too absorbing for the free development of the mythic portion. We have here a tremulous poem with a melancholy note in the midst of joyousness.

The lesson, if there must be a lesson, is: In quietness and confidence shall be your strength. The only hope of Aigina, as was said above, is the persistence of the type of her nobility, but it is clear that it is hoping against hope.
The rhythms are Aiolian (logaoedic). The restlessness, in spite of Hesychia, forms a marked contrast to the majestic balance of P. 1.

div3.head: Strophe 1
div3.p:
filo/fron: “Kindly.” Ar. Av. 1321: to\ th=s a)gano/fronos *(hsuxi/as eu)h/meron pro/swpon.
eu)menh/s seems to be more personal. Compare v. 10.
*(hsuxi/a: A goddess. Compare *ai)dw/s, *fh/mh, *)/eleos, *(ormh/, at Athens (Paus. 1, 17, 1). The Romans carried this still further.

*di/kas . . . qu/gater : *ei)rh/nh (peace between state and state) is the sister of *di/kh (O. 13.7), but
*(hsuxi/a, domestic tranquillity, is eminently the daughter of right between man and man. Cf. P. 1.70: su/mfwnon h(suxi/an, and if “righteousness exalteth a nation” the daughter of righteousness may well be called megisto/polis.
w)=: For the position, compare O. 8.1.

pole/mwn: The Schol. understands this of factions (sta/seis). But when a state is at peace within itself, then it can regulate absolutely its policy at home and abroad, its councils and its armies. This is especially true of Greek history.
klai+=das u(perta/tas: Many were the bearers of the keys — *peiqw/ (P. 9.43), *)aqhna= (Aisch. Eum. 827, Ar. Thesm. 1142), *eu)molpi/dai (So. O. C. 1053) .
*puqio/nikon tima/n = kw=mon.
*)aristome/nei: On the dat. with de/keu, see O. 13.29; P. 4.23.
to\ malqako/n: “True (to/) gentleness.”

e)/rcai te kai\ paqei=n : paqei=n pushes the personification to a point where analysis loses its rights. There is no e)/rcai without paqei=n, hence the exhaustive symmetry. Hesychia knows how to give and how to receive, and so she teaches her people how to give and how to receive.
kairw=| su\n a)trekei= = eu)kai/rws (Schol.).

div3.head: Antistrophe 1
div3.p: a)mei/lixon . . . e)nela/oh: The figure is that of a nail. Whose heart? The Schol.: e)nqh=| th=| e(autou= kardi/a|, and that is the only natural construction of the Greek. Dissen and others think of the bitter hatred of the Athenians towards the Aiginetans. “Plants deep in his heart ruthless resentment.” If *(hsuxi/a were meant, we should expect tea=|.
traxei=a . . . u(pantia/caisa: “Meeting the might of embittered foes with roughness.” Tranquillity (conservatism) is harsh whenever it is endangered. No class more cruel than the repressive.
