tiqei=s . . . e)n a)/ntlw|: a)/ntlos is “bilgewater” (O. 9.57). a)/ntlon de/xesqai is “to spring a leak,” nau=s u(pe/rantlos is “a leaky, foundering ship.” e)n a)/ntlw| tiqe/nai is opposed to e)leuqe/rw| sto/lw| komi/zein (v. 98), hence = “to scuttle,” or, if that is unlyrical, “to sink.” The Schol., a)fani/zeis kai\ a)mauroi=s.
ta/n: Sc. *(hsuxi/an.

*porfuri/wn: Porphyrion, the basileu\s *giga/ntwn mentioned below, attempted to hurl Delos heavenward, and was shot by Apollo, who is, among other things, the god of social order. If there is any special political allusion, this would seem to refer to parties within rather than enemies without.
ma/qen = e)/gnw, Schol. pa/qen and la/qen are unnecessary conjectures.

ei)/ tis . . . fe/roi: We should expect ei)/ tis . . . fe/rei (see note on O. 6.11), but the opt. is used of the desirable course. Compare I. 4 (5), 15. One of Pindar's familiar foils.
There is no allusion that we can definitely fix.
e)k do/mwn: Adds color, as pro\ do/mwn, P. 2.18.

div3.head: Epode 1
div3.p: e)/sfalen: Gnomic aorist, which does not exclude the plumping effect of the tense. See P. 2.50.
*tufw\s *ki/lic: See P. 1.16: *tufw\s e(katontaka/ranos: to/n pote | *kili/kion qre/yen poluw/numon a)/ntron. — nin = *(hsuxi/an.
basileu\s *giga/ntwn: Porphyrion.
dma=qen de\ keraunw=|: Instead of the circumstantial dma=qen o( me\n keraunw=| o( de\ to/coisin *)apo/llwnos. Typhõeus was slain by Zeus.
eu)menei=: See v. 1.
*cena/rkeion . . . ui(o/n: Aristomenes. O. 2.13: w)= *kro/nie pai=, P. 2.18: w)= *deinome/neie pai=.
poi/a|: A wide term. Cf. P. 9.40.
*dwriei=: Always complimentary in Pindar (Mezger) — when he is addressing Dorians.

div3.head: Strophe 2
div3.p: e)/pese: The figure is like that of the lot (la/xos), O. 7.58.
*xari/twn: The goddesses of the hymn of victory. See O. 9.29.
dikaio/polis: According to the genealogy of *(hsuxi/a (v. 1).
a)retai=s: P. 4.296: h(suxi/a| qige/men, P. 9.46: yeu/dei qigei=n.
qigoi=sa: P. uses qigei=n as an aor., and I hesitate to follow the MS. accent qi/goisa. Aigina has attained.
polloi=si: With a)e/qlois.

div3.head: Antistrophe 2
div3.p: ta\ de/: “And then again,” with the shift de/ to another part of the antithesis, a Pindaric device instead of h(/rwas me\n . . . a)ndra/si de/. See O. 11 (10), 8. On the contrast, see O. 2.2. On ta\ de/, O. 13.55.
a)/sxolos: “I have no time” = “this is no time.”

a)naqe/men: To set up as an a)na/qhma. Cf. O. 5.7: ti\n de\ ku=dos a(bro\n | nika/sais a)ne/qhke, O. 11 (10), 7: a)fqo/nhtos d' ai)=nos *)olumpioni/kais | ou(=tos a)/gkeitai. The poet is thinking of the inscription of the votive offerings (O. 3.30).
lu/ra| . . . fqe/gmati: Cf. liquidam pater vocem cum cithara dedit.
mh\ . . . kni/sh|: mh/ sentences of fear are really paratactic, and are often added loosely. Compare note on P. 4.155. “I have no time” = “I say that I have no time.” kni/sh|: Lit., “nettle,” “irk.”

to\ . . . e)n posi/ moi tra/xon: A more forcible to\ pa\r podo/s (P. 3.60; 10, 62), to\ pro\ podo/s (I. 7 [8], 13). e)n posi/, “on my path,” as e)mpodw/n, “in my way.” tra/xon shows that the matter is urgent, “my immediate errand.” Dissen combines tra/xon i)/tw. But tra/xon is heightened by the poet to potano/n.
teo\n xre/os: Thy victory.

potano/n: Cf. P. 5.114: e)/n te *moi/saisi potano/s. He
calls his art potana\ maxana/ (N. 7.22).
a)mfi\ maxana=|: Cf. P. 1.12. a)mfi/te *aatoi/da sofi/a| baquko/lpwn te *moisa=n.

div3.head: Epode 2
div3.p: i)xneu/wn: “Following hard upon the track.” Echo of tra/xon. Notice eu=.
*)olumpi/a|: Pindaric brachylogy for *)olumpioni/kan.

*qeo/gnhton: Honored by an epigram of Simonides (149 Bgk., 206 Schndw.): *gnw=qi *qeo/gnhton prosidw
 to
 *)olu\mpioni/kan | pai=da, palaismosu/nhs decio
 a(ni/oxon, | ka/lliston me
 i)dei=n, a)qlei=n d' ou) xei/rona morfa=s, | o(\s pate/rwn a)gaqw=n e)stefa/nwse po/lin. See Paus. 6, 9, 1.

katele/gxeis: Cf. O. 8.19 and I. 3 (4), 14: a)reta
 | su/mfuton ou) katele/gxei, 7 (8), 65: to
 me
 ou) katele/gxei kritou= genea\ patradelfeou=.
qrasu/guion: See O. 8.68, for the propriety of the compound.
au)/cwn: O. 5.4.
pa/tran: “Clan.”
lo/gon: O. 2.24. Used as the Homeric e)/pos.
fe/reis: As a prize. “Thou earnest.”
*)oikle/os pai=s: Amphiaraos, the seer, the just man and wise among the seven against Thebes. See O. 6.13. His spirit speaks.
ai)ni/cato: “Uttered as a dark saying, in a riddle,” as became an oracular hero.

div3.head: Strophe 3
div3.p: o(po/te: See P. 3.91.
marname/nwn: Cf. O. 13.15.

*fua=| . . . lh=ma: “By nature stands forth the noble spirit that is transmitted from sires to sons.” This is nothing more than an oracular way of saying to\ de\ suggene\s e)mbe/baken i)/xnesin patro/s (P. 10.12). Amphiaraos recognizes the spirit of the warriors of his time in his son and his sons' comrades, hence the plural. Tafel gives fua=| the Homeric sense, “growth,” “stature.” The Epigonoi had shot up in the interval, and become stalwart men. So also Mezger. But how would this suit Aristomenes?
dra/konta: The device occurs on the shields of other warriors, but it is especially appropriate for Alkmaion — our *)alkma=na — the son of the seer Amphiaraos. The serpent is mantic. See O. 6.46.

div3.head: Antistrophe 3
div3.p: o( de\ kamw/n: Adrastos, who had failed in the first expedition, was the successful leader of the second.
prote/ra| pa/qa|: A breviloquence, such as we sometimes find with a)/llos and e(/teros: e(/teros neani/as, “another young man,” “a young man beside.” The prote/ra o(do/s was a pa/qa. Tr. “before.”
e)ne/xetai: Usu. in a bad sense. Here “is compassed.”
o)/rnixos: Omen. See P. 4.19.
to\ de\ voi/koqen: “As to his household.” to\ is acc.
a)nti/a pra/cei: “He shall fare contrariwise” (Fennell). Cf. O. 8.73: a)/rmena pra/cais a)nh/r.
qano/ntos . . . ui(ou=: Aigialeus.

div3.head: Epode 3
div3.p: *abantos: Abas, son of Hypermnestra and Lynkeus, king of Argos, not Abas, grandfather of Adrastos.
a)guia/s: On the acc. see P. 4.51.
kai\ au)to/s: As well as Amphiaraos.
stefa/noisi ba/llw: P. 9.133: polla\ me\n kei=noi di/kon | fu/ll' e)/pi kai\ stefa/nous.
r(ai/nw de\ kai\ u(/mnw|: Cf. P. 5.93; I. 5 (6), 21: r(aine/men eu)logi/ais, O. 10 (11), 109: po/lin katabre/xwn.
gei/twn o(/ti moi: Alkmaion must have had a shrine (h(rw=|on) in Pindar's neighborhood that served the poet as a safety-deposit for his valuables.
u(pa/ntasen: Figuratively, “offered himself as a guardian.”
i)o/nti: As it would seem on this occasion.

e)fa/yato: “Employed.” The dat., as with qigoi=sa, v. 24. The prophecy doubtless pertained to this victory of Aristomenes, which P. describes with all the detail of a spectator. His relations to the Aiginetans were very intimate. The prophecy leads to the mention of the fulfilment.
suggo/noisi: Alkmaion, through his father Amphiaraos, was a descendant of the great seer Melampus.

div3.head: Strophe 4
div3.p: pa/ndokon | nao/n: A temple, and not a simple h(rw=|on.
diane/mwn: P. 4.260: a)/stu . . . diane/mein.
a(rpale/an do/sin: “A gift to be eagerly seized.” Phil. 2, 6: ou)x a(rpagmo\n h(gh/sato to\ ei)=nai i)/sa tw=| qew=|.
e(ortai=s: The Delphinia in Aigina. See note on O. 13.112.
u(mai=s: Of Apollo and Artemis. See P. 4.3.
a)/nac, e(ko/nti de/: O. 1.36.

div3.head: Antistrophe 4
div3.p: kata\ ti\n a(rmoni/an: The MSS. have tin' ti/n = soi/ is De Pauw's conjecture, and is to be combined with the verbal subst. a(rmoni/an. Cf. O. 13.91.

ble/pein: With kata/. katable/pein (not elsewhere in the classic period), like kaqora=n. “It is my heart's desire to keep my eyes fixed on agreement with thee at every step of my whole path” (of song). The poet prays for accordance with the divine in his own case, as he afterwards asks (v. 71) that the successful house of the Midylidai may ever have reverential regard for the gods. Others take eu)/xomai as “I declare.” The passage has been much vexed.
e(/kaston o(/sa = e(/kaston tw=n poihma/twn o(/sa . . . e)pe/rxomai (Schol.).
ne/omai: Cf. a)nadramei=n (O. 8.54), dielqei=n (N. 4.72).

kw/mw| me\n . . . *di/ka pare/stake: P. is certain that Apollo stands by him as Justice does, but he looks forward to the future of the race: hence the
demand that the fortunes of the Midylidai should be guarded by reverence for the divine. On me\n . . . de/, O. 11 (10), 8. With pare/stake, compare O. 3.4: paresta/koi.
qew=n d' o)/pin: Usu. “favor of the gods,” but can the gods have o)/pis for men as they have tima/? (P. 4.51).
*ce/narkes: Father of Aristomenes (cf. v. 19), addressed as the head of the house, as the Amphiaraos of our Alkmaion.

ei) ga/r tis . . . maxanai=s: A mere foil to v. 76. “Easy success is not wisdom, as the vulgar think. 'Tis not in mortals to command success. Each man's weird determines now success, now failure. Have God in all your thoughts. Keep within bounds.”

ped' a)fro/nwn = e)n a)/frosi (Schol.). For this use of meta/, P. 5.94: ma/kar a)ndrw=n me/ta | e)/naien. “Wise amongst fools.” Success is the vulgar test of merit, of wisdom. See O. 5.16: h)u+\ d' e)/xontes sofoi\ kai\ poli/tais e)/docan e)/mmen. On peda/ see P. 5.47.

div3.head: Epode 4
div3.p: korusse/men: “To helmet,” where we should say “to panoply.” The head-piece was the crowning protection, pollw=n meq' o(/plwn su/n q' i(ppoko/mois koru/qessin (Soph.).
ta\ de/: Such success with its repute of wisdom. Compare P. 2.57: nin.
e)p' a)ndra/si kei=tai: Cf. the Homeric qew=n e)n gou/nasi kei=tai, and P. 10.71.
pari/sxei: “Is the one that giveth.” It is not necessary to supply anything.

u(/perqe ba/llwn . . . u(po\ xeirw=n: “Tossing high in the air . . . under the hands (where the hands can catch it).” Men are the balls of Fortune (dai/mwn). u(po/ with genitive instead of the accusative on account of the contrast with u(/perqe, which suggests the genitive. Bergk reads u(poxeirw=n, not found elsewhere.

me/trw| kata/baine: m. = metri/ws, litotes for mh\ kata/baine. “Seek no further contests.” Thou hast victories enough of this kind (v. 85 shows that his opponents were boys). Aristomenes was leaving the ranks of the pai=des palaistai/.
e)n *mega/rois: O. 7.86.
muxw=|: Marathon lies between Pentelikon and Parnes.
*maraqw=nos: O. 9.95.
*(/hras t' a)gw=n' e)pixw/rion: The Aiginetan Heraia were brought from Argos.
a)gw=na ... da/massas: An easy extension of the inner object — nika=n ste/fanon.
e)/rgw|: Emphasizes the exertion in contrast to the lucky man who achieves his fortune mh\ su\n makrw=| po/nw| (v. 73). Schol.: met' e)/rgou kai\ e)nergei/as pollh=s.

div3.head: Strophe 5
div3.p: te/trasi: See O. 8.68.
e)/mpetes = e)ne/peses.

swma/tessi: In the other description (O. 8.68) we have gui/ois,
which some consider an equiv. to sw/masi.
kaka\ frone/wn: Literally “meaning mischief.” “With fell intent” (Fennell). Cf. N. 4.95: malaka\ frone/wn.
ou)/te . . . ou)de/: So I. 2, 44: mh/te . . . mhde/.
o(mw=s: Like as to thee.
e)/palpnos = h(du/s, proshnh/s (Schol.).
molo/ntwn: Easier to us as genitive absolute than as dependent on a)mfi/. See note on O. 13.15.
lau/ras: “Lanes,” “back-streets.”
e)xqrw=n a)pa/oroi: “In suspense of their enemies” would be perfectly intelligible.
dedagme/noi: So with Bergk for dedaigme/noi = dedai+gme/noi.

div3.head: Antistrophe 5
div3.p: o( de\ . . . me/rimnan: “He that hath gained something new (a fresh victory) at the season, when luxury is great (rife), soars by reason of hope (at the impulse of Hope), borne up by winged achievements of manliness (by the wings of manly achievements), with his thought above wealth.” This is a description of the attitude of the returning victor in contrast to that of the vanquished. He seems to tread air. Hope, now changed to Pleasure (see P. 2.49), starts him on his flight, and his manly achievements lend him the wings of victory (P. 9.135: ptera\ *ni/kas). From this height he may well look down on wealth, high as wealth is (O. 1.2). Hermann, and many after him, read a(bro/tatos e)/pi, in disregard of the Scholiast (a)po\ mega/lhs a(bro/thtos kai\ eu)daimoni/as), and, which is more serious, in disregard of P.'s rules of position (see note on O. 1.37). Mezger considers a)nore/ais as dat. termini (for which he cites O. 6.58; 13, 62, neither of them cogent), and sees in e)lpi/dos and a)nore/ais the prophecy of future success among men. a(bro/tatos is not “the sweet spring-time of life,” but rather the time when there is every temptation to luxury, and when the young wrestler is called on to endure hardness.
u(popte/rois: Compare further O. 14.24: kudi/mwn a)e/qlwn pteroi=si.
to\ terpno/n: See note on O. 14.5.
ou(/tw: Sc. e)n o)li/gw|.
a)potro/pw| gnw/ma|: “Adverse doom.”

div3.head: Epode 5
div3.p: e)pa/meroi: Sc. e)sme/n. A rare and impressive ellipsis.

ti/ de/ tis; ti/ d' ou)/ tis; “What is man? what is he not?” Man continueth so short a time in one stay that it is not possible to tell what he is, what he is not. One Scholiast understands it as “What is a somebody? what a nobody?” which is a clearer way of putting it.

skia=s o)/nar: Life had often been called a shadow and a dream before P., but this famous combination
startles the Scholiast: eu)= th=| e)mfa/sei xrw/menos, w(s a)\n ei)/poi tis tou= a)sqenou=s to\ a)sqene/steron.
ai)/gla: Cf. O. 13.36: ai)/g|la podw=n. The dream may be lighted up by victory.

e)pestin a)ndrw=n: The Schol. e)/pesti kata\ tw=n a)nqrw/pwn. If the text is right, we must understand e)/pestin as e)sti\n e)pi/, “rests on.” Cf. e)pibai/nw. P.'s e)pi/, with genitive, is used of fixed position, O. 1.77; P. 4.273; 8, 46; N. 5.1.
fi/la ma=ter: P.'s love for Aigina and his interest in her fate are abundantly evident in his Aiginetan odes, nearly one fourth of the whole number. Here, of course, the heroine is meant.
e)leuqe/rw| sto/lw|: Nautical figure. “In the course of freedom.”
ko/mize: As always with the note of care.

*di\ . . . *)axillei=: i. e. su
 *di\ kai\ su
 *ai)akw=| — su
 *phlei= . . . su/n t' *)axillei=. See O. 9.94, and for this special case compare N. 10.53: *(erma=| kai\ su
 *(hraklei=, where god and hero are connected, as god and heroes are connected here, by kai/. The brothers of the first generation are coupled by te kai/, Achilles completes the line with te.

div2.p: The ninth Pythian was composed in honor of Telesikrates of Kyrene, son of Karneiades, who was successful as an o(plitoo\ro/mos, Pyth. 28 (Ol. 75, 3 = 478 B.C.). Telesikrates had previously distinguished himself at all the local games of Kyrene, had been victorious in Aigina, at Megara, and, after the race in armor, gained a foot-race at Delphi, Pyth. 30 (Ol. 77, 3 = 470 B.C.). P. tells of the former victory only, and the poem must have been composed at the earlier date. Böckh thinks that Telesikrates had not returned to Kyrene when the poem was sung; nor, on the other hand, is there any trace of a kw=mos at Delphi. Hence the inference that the performance was at Thebes. Unfortunately de/cetai (v. 79) proves nothing more than that the ode was not composed at Kyrene. Otfried Müller conjectures that Telesikrates belonged to the Aigeidai, and we have good reason to believe that Pindar was an Aigeid (P. 5.76). The name Karneiades points to the Karneia, a traditional festival among the Aigeidai.
The acknowledged difficulty of the poem will justify a detailed abstract.

I sing Telesikrates, crowning glory of Kyrene, whom Apollo brought on golden chariot from windy Pelion, and made the huntress-maiden queen of a fruitful continent (vv. 1-9). Silverfoot Aphrodite received the Delian guest and shed winsome shamefastness on the bridal couch of Apollo and the daughter of Hypseus, king of the Lapithai, to whom a Naiad bore her (vv. 10-18). Naught did this white-armed maiden reck of loom or dance or home-keeping with her playmates. With dart and falchion slew she the fierce beasts of prey and gave rest to her father's kine, scant slumber granting to eyelids on which sleep loves to press towards dawn (vv. 19-27).

He found her — he, God of the Wide Quiver — as she was
struggling alone, unarmed, with a furious lion. Out he called Cheiron from his cave to mark the woman's spirit, and to tell her parentage (vv. 28-36). Whate'er her lineage, the struggle shows boundless courage. “Is it right,” asks the god, “to lay hand on her and pluck the sweet flower of love?” The Centaur smiled and answered: “Secret are the keys of Suasion that unlock the sanctuary of love's delights; gods and men alike shun open union” (vv. 37-45). Thou didst but dissemble, thou who knowest everything, both end and way, the number of the leaves of spring, the number of the sands in sea and rivers, that which is to be and whence it is to come. But if I must measure myself with the Wise One — (vv. 46-54).

I will speak. Thou didst come to be wedded lord to her, and to bear her over sea to the garden of Zeus, where thou wilt make her queen of a city when thou shalt have gathered the islandfolk about the plain-compassed hill. Now Queen Libya shall receive her as a bride in golden palaces, lady of a land not tributeless of fruits nor ignorant of chase (vv. 55-62). There shall she bear a son, whom Hermes shall bring to the Horai and to Gaia, and they shall gaze in wonder at their lapling, and feed him with nectar and ambrosia, and make him an immortal Zeus and a pure Apollo, God of Fields, God of Pasture; to mortal men, Aristaios. So saying he made the god ready for the fulfilment of wedlock (vv. 63-72). Swift the achievement, short the paths of hastening gods. That day wrought all, and they were made one in the golden chamber of Libya, where she guards a fair, fair city, famed for contests. And now the son of Karneiades crowned her with the flower of fortune at Pytho, where he proclaimed Kyrene, who shall welcome him to his own country, land of fair women, with glory at his side (vv. 73-81).

Great achievements are aye full of stories. To broider well a few among so many — that is a hearing for the skilled. Of these the central height is Opportunity — Opportunity, which Iolaos did not slight, as seven-gated Thebes knew. Him, when he had shorn away Eurystheus' head, they buried in the tomb of Amphitryon, his father's father, who came to Thebes a guest (vv. 82-90). To this Amphitryon and to Zeus, Alkmena bare at one labor two mighty sons. A dullard is the man who does not lend his mouth to Alkmena's son, and does not alway remember the Dirkaian waters that reared him and his brother Iphikles. To whom, in payment of a vow for the requital of their grace to me
I will sing a revel song of praise. May not the clear light of the Muses of Victory forsake me, for I have already sung this city thrice in Aigina, at Megara (vv. 91-99), and escaped by achievement the charge of helpless dumbness. Hence be a man friend or be he foe, let him not break the commandment of old Nereus and hide the merit of a noble toil. He bade praise with heartiness and full justice him that worketh fair deeds. (So let all jealousy be silent. Well hast thou wrought.) At the games of Pallas mute the virgins desired thee as lord, (loud the mothers) thee as son, Telesikrates, when they saw the many victories thou didst win (vv. 100-108).

So at the Olympian games of Kyrene, so at the games of Gaia and at all the contests of the land. But while I am quenching the thirst of my songs, there is one that exacts a debt not paid, and I must awake the glory of thine old forefathers, how for the sake of a Libyan woman they went to Irasa — suitors for the daughter of Antaios. Many wooed her, kinsmen and strangers — for she was wondrous fair (vv. 109-117) — all eager to pluck the flower of youthful beauty. The father, planning a more famous wedding for his daughter, had heard how Danaos had found speedy bridal for his eight-and-forty virgins ere midday should overtake them, by ranging all that had come as suitors for his daughters, to decide who should have them by contests of swiftness (vv. 118-126). Like offer made the Libyan for wedding a bridegroom to his daughter. He placed her by the mark as the highest prize, and bade him lead her home who should first touch her robes. Then Alexidamos outstripped the rest in the whirlwind race, took the noble maid by the hand, and led her through the throng of the Nomad horsemen. Many leaves they threw on them and wreaths; many wings of Victory had he received before (vv. 127-135).

The ode, beautiful in details, has perplexed commentators both as to its plan and as to its drift. The limpid myth of Kyrene has been made to mirror lust and brutality. Telesikrates is supposed by one to have violated a Theban maiden, by another to be warned against deflouring his Theban betrothed until he is legally married to her. It is hard to resist the impression of a prothalamion as well as of an epinikion, but all conditions are satisfied by the stress laid on kairo/s, which Leopold Schmidt has made the pivot. Mezger happily calls the
ode “Das Hohelied vom *kairo/s,” “the Song of Songs, which is Season's.” The key is v. 84: o( de\ kairo\s o(moi/ws | panto\s e)/xei korufa/n. The poet, following his own canon — baia\ d' e)n makroi=si poiki/llein, | a)koa\ sofoi=s, v. 83 — has selected four examples to show that the laggard wins no prize. Witness how Apollo, no laggard in love, seized Kyrene (w)kei=a d' e)peigome/nwn h)/dh qew=n | pra=cis o(doi/ te braxei=ai, v. 73); how Iolaos, no dastard in war, shore off the head of Eurystheus (v. 87). Witness Antaios (v. 114), who caught from Danaos the lesson of speedy marriage for his daughter (w)ku/taton ga/mon). Witness Alexidamos (v. 131), who won the prize by his impetuous rush in the race (fu/ge laiyhro\n dro/mon). Mezger, who emphasizes the recurrence of au)ti/ka (vv. 31, 62, 124), shows, in perhaps unnecessary detail, that the poem breathes unwonted determination and energy, and thinks that it is intended to urge the victor to make quick use of his victory for pressing his suit to some eligible maiden. The poet is to be to Telesikrates what Cheiron was to Apollo. This view seems to me rather German than Greek, but it is not so unbearable as Dissen's rape and Böckh's caution against the anticipation of the lawful joys of marriage.

The poem has certain marked points of resemblance and contrast with P. 3. As in P. 3, the myth begins early; as in P. 3, the foremost figure is a heroine beloved of Apollo. There the god espies his faithless love — wanton Koronis — in the arms of Ischys. Here he finds the high-hearted Kyrene struggling, unarmed, with a lion. There Cheiron was charged with the rearing of the seed of the god. Here Cheiron is summoned to leave his cave and witness the courage of the heroine. The fruit of this love is not snatched from the body of the mother fordone, and borne in haste to the foster-father, but the child is taken by Hermes, in virtue of his office, is fed with nectar and ambrosia by the Horai and Gaia, and becomes, not an Asklepios, to perish in lightning flame, but an Aristaios.
In P. 9, as in P. 4, the myth comes to the front, the myth of Kyrene occupying three fifths of the ode. Iolaos dominates one fifth, Alexidamos the last.
The rhythms are Dorian (dactylo-epitrite). They are lighter than the norm (O. 3), and hence are supposed to be a mixture of Dorian and Lydian.

div3.head: Strophe 1
div3.p: e)qe/lw: “I am fain.”

xalkaspi/da: The o(plitodro/mos originally wore shield, helmet, and greaves (Paus. 6, 10, 4), and is so figured on a celebrated vase (Gerhard, A. V., IV.). Afterwards the shield only was worn, which, being the heaviest, is here made prominent. Compare Paus. 2, 11, 8: kai\ gumno\s kai\ meta\ th=s a)spi/dos.
baquzw/noisin: Cf. O. 3.35: baquzw/nou . . . *lh/das.
a)gge/llwn: See O. 7.21
*xari/tessi: Mistresses of the song of victory, as often: O. 4.8; 7, 11; P. 6.2.
gegwnei=n: Of the herald cry, as O. 2.5: *qh/rwna . . . gegwnhte/on.

diwci/ppou: Cf. P. 4.17. A further illustration of the subject is given by the description so often referred to, So. El. 680 foll., where two of the contestants are Libyans (v. 702) and their chariots Barkaian (v. 727).
stefa/nwma: The result of the gegwnei=n, rather than apposition to a)/ndra. See P. 1.50 and 12, 5.
ta/n: Change from city to heroine, P. 12.3.

o( xaita/eis . . . *latoi+/das: We can afford to wait for *latoi+/das, as the epithet is characteristic of Apollo, who is a)keireko/mas, P. 3.14 and I. 1, 7, and the ode is Pythian. Compare v. 28: eu)rufare/tras . . . *)apo/llwn, and O. 7.13.
xruse/w| p. a). d.: Notice the pretty chiasm.
a)grote/ran: P. 3.4: *fh=r' a)gro/teron. The myth, as many of P.'s heroine myths, is taken from the *)hoi=ai of Hesiod, a fragment of which opens the *)aspi\s *(hrakle/ous.
polumh/lou: See on O. 1.13. The Schol. here has distinctly poluproba/tou.

r(i/zan: The earth is conceived as a plant with three roots, Libya being one, Europe and Asia being the other two. The order from qh=ke to oi)kei=n is noteworthy — qh=ken (a), de/spoinan (b), xqono\s r(i/zan (c), a)pei/rou tri/tan eu)h/raton (c), qa/lloisan (b), oi)kei=n (a). So the Schol.

div3.head: Antistrophe 1
div3.p: a)rguro/peza: Aphrodite, as a sea-goddess, was specially honored in Libya. Compare P. 5.24. a)rg. refers to the sheen on the waves, the track of the moonlight. We have here the lunar side of the goddess.
qeodma/twn: The latter part of the compound is still felt here. See O. 3.7. Add to the instances there given fr. XI. 40: qeo/dmaton ke/ladon.
o)xe/wn: Depends on e)faptome/na. On the construction, see O. 1.86. Simply a natural bit of color. To make o)x. depend on u(pe/dekto as a whence - case is not happy.
xeri\ kou/fa|: Often taken as = xeri\ koufizou/sh|. Surely the young couple did not need bodily help so much as moral sympathy, and it is a pity to spoil Pindar's light touch as well as Aphrodite's.

e)pi\ . . . eu)nai=s: Dat.-locative of the result of the motion often with e)pi/ in Homer, regularly
with e)n and ti/qhmi in prose.
eu)nai=s: P. 2.27.

ba/len ai)dw=, kte(.: This ai)dw/s is the a(rmo/s that binds the pair in wedlock. The intimate union is emphasized by cuno/n, a(rmo/zoisa, mixqe/nta. qew=| and kou/ra| depend on cuno/n (compare P. 6.15), resumed and varied by mixqe/nta (compare P. 4.222), an anticipatory contrast to the light of love kei=rai meliade/a poi/an, that Apollo proposes (v. 40). For the complex, compare P. 5.102: sfo\n o)/lbon ui(w=| te koina\n xa/rin | e)/ndiko/n t' *)arkesi/la|. “And shed upon the pleasures of their couch the charm of shamefastness, uniting thus in bonds of mutual wedlock the god and the maiden-daughter of Hypseus.”
a(rmo/zoisa: Below, v. 127, a(rmo/zwn is used of a lawful marriage.
*lapiqa=n u(pero/plwn: The statues of the western pediment of the temple of Zeus at Olympia represent the combat between the Centaurs and the Lapithai. — touta/kis = to/te, P. 4. 255.
ge/nos: Acc. of limit to deu/teros.
e)/tikten: See O. 6.41.

div3.head: Epode 1
div3.p: *gai/as quga/thr: Not necessary to the sense. By putting the end of the sentence at the beginning of the epode (compare O. 1.23. 81; 2, 17; 3, 26 al.), antistrophe and epode are closely combined, and the mechanical (a) + (a) + (b) of strophe, antistrophe, and epode is avoided, and we have instead (a) + ((a) + (b)). So J. H. H. Schmidt.
leukw/lenon: So Lehrs (after the Schol., leuko/phxun) for the MS. eu)w/lenon.
qre/yato: O. 6.46.
palimba/mous . . . o(dou/s: The to and fro necessary with the upright loom.

dei/nwn te/ryias ou)/q' e(tara=n oi)kouri/an: The best MSS. have ou)/te dei/pnwn oi)kouria=n meq' e(taira=n te/ryias, for which the metre demands oi)koria=n, a form for which there seems to be no warrant. The Scholia show an old trouble. I have accepted Bergk's recasting of the passage — dei/nwn = di/nwn, “dances.” The monotonous to and fro of the loom would be well contrasted with the “whirl” of the dance. Maidens and banquets are disparate in Pindar. e(tara=n oi)kouri/an is = meq' e(tara=n oi)kouri/an, and this may help to account for the corruption of the text.
fasga/nw|: “Falchion.”
h)=: With a note of asseveration, as in h)= mh/n.
to\n de\ su/gkoiton gluku/n: “Him that as bed-fere (bedfellow) is so sweet.”
pau=ron . . . u(/pnon: Transposed with Mommsen. p. “scant,” litotes for “not at all.”
e)pi\ glefa/rois: Od. 2. 398: u(/pnos e)pi\ glefa/roisin e)/pipten. Cf. v. 13.
a)nali/skoisa: “Wasting sleep,” brachylogy for wasting time in sleep.

r(e/ponta pro\s a)w=: Sleep is sweetest and deepest before dawn (suadentque cadentia sidera somnum). Yet this is the time
when the huntress has no right to sleep. “This is the time,” as a naturalist says, “when savages always make their attacks.”

div3.head: Strophe 2
div3.p: le/onti: Whether there were lions in Greece at that time or at any time matters not. There were lions in Kyrene, P. 5.58.
o)bri/mw|: Used of the monster Typhõeus, O. 4.7.
a)/ter e)gxe/wn: Schol. a)/neu do/ratos.
au)ti/ka: See the introduction.
e)k mega/rwn: “From out his halls,” sc. Cheiron's. Called him out and said to him.
a)/ntron: Cf. P. 3.63: ei) de\ sw/frwn a)/ntron e)/nai) e)/ti *xei/rwn.
*filuri/da: Cf. P. 3.1.

a)tarbei= . . . kefala=|: A steady head is a compliment as well as a)tarbei= kradi/a|, which Schneidewin reads. Note the serenity of the heads of combatants in Greek plastic art. kradi/a| is unlikely with h)=tor to follow.

kexei/mantai fre/nas: The MSS. have fre/nes. Some recognize in this the sxh=ma *pindariko/n (O. 11.6). Mommsen suggests ou)k e)xei/manqen, others see in kexei/mantai a plural. Compare Curt. Gr. V. II.^{1} 223. I have no hesitation in following Bergk's suggestion, fre/nas.
a)pospasqei=sa: The lover cannot imagine such a maiden to have come into such surroundings except by accident.

div3.head: Antistrophe 2
div3.p: e)/xei: “Inhabits.”
geu/etai: “Tastes,” “makes trial of.”

a)lka=s: Doubtful whether the lion's or the maiden's, and, to add to the trouble, we have a)peira/ntou, “boundless,” and a)peira/tou, “untried.” Apollo has no fear for the heroine, and so, on the whole, it is better to understand “the boundless strength” of the maiden.

o(si/a: Especially hard to define. Plato's Euthyphron discusses to\ o(/sion. Grote translates o(sio/ths, “holiness;” Jowett, “piety.” Ammonios says: o(/sion kai\ i(ero\n diafe/rei: o(/sia me\n ga/r e)sti ta\ i)diwtika/, w(=n e)fi/etai kai\ e)/cesti prosa/yasqai: i(era\ de\ ta\ tw=n qew=n, w(=n ou)k e)/cesti prosa/yasqai. o(si/a, the human right, is also the divine right, as Eur. says, Bacch. 370:
*(osi/a po/tna qew=n
*(osi/a d' a(\ kata\ ga=n
xruse/an pte/ruga fe/reis.
Perhaps the use of the word here is another of those strokes that serve to show that this is no ordinary amour.
kluta\n xe/ra: With the same epic simplicity as Od. 9. 364: ei)rwta=|s m' o)/noma kluto/n.

h)= r(a; Not disjunctive, and best punctuated thus. Myers translates after Donaldson, who makes h)/ disjunctive, “or rather on a bridal bed,” lexe/wn being the lectus genialis spread dw/masin e)n xruse/ois (v. 60). Unfortunately for all this legality, the Centaur, despite his refined environment,
the kou=rai a(gnai/ of P. 4.103, understood lexe/wn to be nothing more than eu)na=s.
poi/an: P. 8.20. Here of the flower of love. Cf. v. 119: a)podre/yai karpo\n a)nqh/santa. The oracular god, who has been speaking in oracular phrase, winds up with an oracular hexameter.
zamenh/s: “Inspired” (Fennell). But see P. 4.10.

xlaro/n: The passage requires an equivalent of proshne\s kai\ gluku/ (Schol.), which is better satisfied by association with xliaro/n, “lukewarm,” than by derivation from the root of ke/xlada with Curtius. We have not here the “lively” horse-laugh of the other Centaurs; we have the half-smile of the great teacher.
klai+/des: See P. 8.4, and add Eur. Hippol. 538: *)/erwta . . . to\n ta=s *)afrodi/tas filta/twn qala/mwn klh|dou=xon.
*peiqou=s . . . filota/twn: Both genitives depend on klai+/des. “Secret are the keys that Suasion holds to the hallowed joys of love.” On Peitho, see P. 4.219.
tou=to . . . tuxei=n: This apposition serves to show the growth of the articular inf., sparingly used even in Pindar.
toprw=ton: tuxei=n toprw=ton eu)na=s: “To enter the bridal bed.” Not as if this applied only to the first time.

div3.head: Epode 2
div3.p: yeu/dei qigei=n: On the dat., see P. 4.296. For the thought, P. 3.29: yeude/wn ou)x a(/ptetai.
mei/lixos o)rga/: “Bland humor,” “pleasant mood.” Apollo is merely teasing the Centaur by pretending to ask his advice. Others, “soft desire,” “guiling passion.”
parfa/men: “To dissemble,” “utter in jest.” para/, “aside” (from what is meant).
o(po/qen: Sc. e)sti/.
ku/rion . . . te/los , kte(.: “The decisive end.” The final destiny, and the ways that lead thereto.
o(/ssa . . . klone/ontai: Oracle in Hdt. 1, 47: oi)=da d' e)gw\ ya/mmou t' a)riqmo\n kai\ me/tra qala/sshs.
fu/lla: Fits the woodland environment.
a)nape/mpei: The spring leaves are an army in rank and file, the sands are an army in rout (klone/ontai).
xw)/ ti me/llei: The te/los again (v. 48).
xw)po/qen | e)/ssetai = o(po/qen to\ me/llon e)/stai: The ke/leuqoi again.
kaqora=|s: From thy lofty height. Apollo is a skopo/s, and kata/ is not effaced.
kai\ pa\r sofo\n a)ntiferi/cai: kai\ sofw=| soi o)/nti e)ciswqh=nai (Schol.). “To match myself against the Wise One.”

div3.head: Strophe 3
div3.p: e)re/w: Effective position. The word is not necessary.
po/sis: Compare P. 4.87: po/sis | *)afrodi/tas, and contrast dative and genitive. Kyrene becomes Apollo's wife. As A. was unmarried it was easy to put the myth in this honorable form.

i(/keo ba=ssan:
O. 6.64: i(/konto pe/tran. See P. 4.51.
me/lleis . . . e)nei=kai: On the aor., O. 7.61; 8, 32.
*dio\s . . . poti\ ka=pon: See O. 3.24, for ka=pos. For *dio/s, P. 4.16: *dio\s e)n *)/ammwnos qeme/qlois.
e)pi\ . . . a)gei/rais = e\pagei/rais.
lao\n . . . nasiw/tan: See P. 4.17 foll. The island was Thera.
o)/xqon e)s a)mfi/pedon: Cf. P. 4.8: po/lin e)n a)rgino/enti mastw=|. Cheiron has the oracular tone in perfection. He parodies Apollo.
*libu/a: The nymph, daughter of Epaphos (P. 4.14).
dw/masin e)n xruse/ois: Where she will abide, not e)s, as N. 11.3: *)aristago/ran de/cai teo\n e)s qa/lamon.
i(/na: Always “where” in P.
ai=san: Share.
au)ti/ka: Cf. v. 31.

suntele/qein e)/nnomon: “To abide with her as hers in law,” “to be her lawful possession.” Paley tr. “To become an occupier of it together with herself.” Cf. Aisch. Suppl. 565: brotoi\ d' oi(\ ga=s to/t' h)=san e)/nnomoi. But see O. 7.84. The Schol., misled by nh/poinon, glosses suntele/qein by suntelei=n, “to contribute.”
nh/poinon: With the good sense of poinh/, P. 1.59; poi/nimos, P. 2.17, glossed as a)/moiron. “Not tributeless.”

div3.head: Antistrophe 3
div3.p: *(erma=s: Hermes was not only the patron of flocks and herds, but also the great gerulus of Olympos. The Hermes of Praxiteles, with the infant Dionysos, is one of many.

eu)qro/nois: A note of majestic beauty. So Kleio (N. 3.83) and the daughters of Kadmos (O. 2.24). Even Aphrodite as eu)/qronos (I. 2, 5) is more matronly than she is as poikilo/qronos (Sappho). On the images of the seated Horai at Delphi, see O. 13.8.

*(/wraisi: The Horai, as authors of a)rxai=a sofi/smata (O. 13.17), are well introduced here, but who would question the appropriateness of the Seasons and Mother Earth as the foster-mothers of a rural deity like Aristaios?
*gai/a|: Great-grandmother of Kyrene (v. 19), if the relation is to be insisted on.
u(po/: Vividly local, “from under,” “from his mother's womb.” See O. 6.43.
e)pigouni/dion = e)pi\ gona/twn. P. makes the very widest use of these adjj. in -ios. Combine e)pigouvi/dion with au)tai=s. au(tai=s is unknown to Pindar. See O. 13.53.
qahsa/menai: So Bergk for qhka/menai, qhsa/menai of the codices, for which Moschopulos katqhka/menai. qahs. = qauma/sasai (Schol.).
au)tai=s: Bergk reads au)gai=s.

qh/sontai: “Shall decree,” to which kalei=n is epexegetic. Eur. Phoen. 12:
kalou=si d' *)ioka/sthn me — tou=to ga\r path\r
e)/qeto kalei=n,
which shows that ti/qesqai and kalei=n are not necessarily synonymous, as Shilleto would make them here.

*zh=na: Aristaios, an ancient divinity of woodland life, of
flocks, herds, and fields, is a representative of *zeu\s *)/aristos (*)aristai=os), of *)apo/llwn *)agreu/s, *)a. *no/mios. Best known to modern readers by the passage in Verg. Georg. 4, 317 foll.
a(gno/n: Used of Helios, O. 7.60.
a)/gxiston: “Ever nigh.”
o)pa/ona: St. Anthony has taken his place.
kalei=n: Epexegetic inf. By insisting so much on the fruit of the union, the Centaur hallows it, and formally weds the two.
ga/mou . . . teleuta/n: Cf. O. 2.19: e)/rgwn te/los.

div3.head: Epode 3
div3.p: o(doi\ . . . braxei=ai: Cf. v. 49: oi)=sqa kai\ pa/sas keleu/qous.
diai/tasen: “Decided,” as an umpire decides, hence “accomplished.” diaita=n = dianu/ein (Hesych.).
qala/mw| d' e)n poluxru/sw|: Cf. v. 60: dw/masin e)n xruse/ois.
a)mfe/pei: City and heroine are blended, as P. 12.2.
nin: Kyrene, the city.
*karneia/da: A name of good omen, recalling *)apo/llwn *ka/rneios. See P. 5.80.
sune/mice: See O. 1.22.
a)ne/fane: By the voice of the heralds. Cf. N. 9.12: a)/mfaine kudai/nwn po/lin.
de/cetai: Shows that the ode was not composed at Kyrene.
kalligu/naiki pa/tra|: k. not a likely adjective on Dissen's theory. See introduction.

div3.head: Strophe 4
div3.p: a)retai\ . . . polu/muqoi, kte(.: “Great achievements aye bring with them many legends, but to adorn a few things is a hearing for the wise,” what the wise, the poets, those who understand the art, love to hear. P.'s art in his selections among the mass of themes will be appreciated by his fellows. In this transition we have the key to the poem, for in all P.'s chosen myths kairo/s is atop — the kairo/s of Kyrene and Apollo, the kairo/s of Iolaos, the kairo/s of Antaios, of Alexidamos.
a)koa\ sofoi=s: Cf. O. 2.93: fwna/enta sunetoi=sin.
panto\s e)/xei korufa/n: Cf. O. 7.4: korufa\n ktea/nwn.
e)/gnon = e)/gnwsan.

*)io/laon: The son of Iphikles and nephew of Herakles, trusty companion of the latter hero. See O. 9.105. This example of the headship of kairo/s may have been suggested by the training of Telesikrates in the gymnasium of Iolaos at Thebes, by the neighborhood of the celebration, by P.'s vow to Herakles and Iphikles (v. 96). Compare a similar introduction of Alkmaion, P. 8.57.
nin = to\n kairo/n.
*eu)rusqh=os: The taskmaster of Herakles. See O. 3.28.
*)amfitru/wnos | sa/mati: Before the Proitid gate, where there was a gymnasium of Iolaos (Paus. 9, 23, 1). See also O. 9.105 for the *)iola/ou tu/mbos.

patropa/twr: Amphitryon — Iphikles —
Iolaos.
voi: O. 9.16: quga/thr te) voi.
ce/nos: Amphitryon had been exiled from Tiryns by Sthenelos.
leuki/ppoisi: Cf. O. 6.85. Hypallage for leuki/ppwn.

div3.head: Antistrophe 4
div3.p: voi=: Amphitryon.

dai+/frwn: On the meaning and etymology of this word, see F. D. Allen in Am. Journ. Phil. I. pp. 133-135, who rejects both dah=nai and dai+/, “battle,” and looks to dai+/s, “torch” (√du, dav). From the “fiery-hearted” of the Iliad, it becomes, acc. to A., the “high-spirited” of the Odyssey. Mezger's “doppelsinnig,” as of one divided between her mortal and her immortal love, has no warrant.
didu/mwn: Iphikles and Herakles.
sqe/nos ui(w=n: See O. 6.22.
kwfo\s a)nh/r: P.'s characteristic way of whirling off from the subject in order to come back to it with more effect.
paraba/llei: “Lends.” Cf. paraba/llein kefalh/n, ou)=s, and O. 9.44: fe/rois . . . a)/stei glw=ssan.

qre/yanto: See v. 20. On the plur. see O. 10 (11), 93. The copiousness of the Dirkaian stream (*dirkai/wn r(ee/qrwn, Soph.) is emphasized by the plural. The name of Iolaos is heightened by this glorification of father and uncle, and the poet at the same time shows how he can avail himself of a kairo/s to fulfil his vow.

te/leion e)p' eu)xa=| kwma/somai: “I must needs sing a song to crown my vow with fulfilment,” te/leion kwma/somai = te/leion kw=mon a)/|somai. The kw=mos is to fulfil the obligation that rests upon the vow. A much-disputed passage. ti with te/leion is unsatisfactory, ti with e)slo/n may be made tolerable by litotes, “a great blessing.” See P. 7.14: xai/rw ti. Hermann makes the vow refer to mh/ me li/poi, whereas in that case we should have expected lipei=n. The great blessing may very well be the victory of Telesikrates.
kwma/somai: The modal future. “I must needs,” “I am fain.”
*xari/twn: See v. 3. Nothing suggests prayer like successful prayer. On the asyndeton, see O. 1.115.
kaqaro\n fe/ggos: To illumine the path of the victories of Telesikrates. On fe/ggos and fa/os, see note on P. 3.75.

*ai)gi/na| te . . . *ni/sou t' e)n lo/fw|: On the one e)n, compare O. 9.94. Nisos was a mythic king of Megara. The poet, as usual, transports himself to the scene where the victories were won. See P. 1.79.

*ai)gi/na| te ga/r, kte(.: P. has thrice already glorified the city in Aigina and Megara, and vindicated there his poetic art, of course, in the praise of the victories of Telesikrates in these places. Now he hopes that the light of the Charites will continue to illumine his poesy (compare O. 1.108: ei) de\ mh\ taxu\ li/poi), for he looks forward
to other themes.

ta/nde: Dissen has to/nde. The poet says that he has glorified this city (Thebes) by celebrating the victories of Telesikrates at the places mentioned. T. evidently had close ties with Thebes, a *spartw=n ce/nos, like Amphitryon. Others refer ta/nde to Kyrene.

div3.head: Epode 4
div3.p: sigalo\n a)maxani/an: “Dumb helplessness,” “silence from want of words.” Pindar is fighting his own battles as well as those of Telesikrates. Compare the passage O. 6.89: a)rxai=on o)/neidos a)laqe/sin | lo/gois ei) feu/gomen.
e)/rgw|: Must refer to Pindar, “by my work,” “by my song.” Beck's fugo/nt' would, of course, refer to Telesikrates.

tou)/neken, kte(.: “Wherefore,” as I have glorified the city, and Telesikrates has won his prize, let friend and foe alike respect good work done in the common interest (e)n cunw=|), for the common weal.
lo/gon: “Saying.”
bla/ptwn: “Violating.”
a(li/oio ge/rontos: Old men of the sea are always preternaturally wise. See P. 3.92. Here Nereus is meant, whom Homer calls a(/lion ge/ronta (Il. 18. 141).

krupte/tw: The word of Nereus is a light unto the path, and disobedience quenches it in silence. Cf. O. 2.107: kru/fon te qe/men e)slw=n kaloi=s e)/rgois, N. 9.7: mh\ xamai\ siga=| kalu/yai. See also O. 7.92: mh\ kru/pte koino\n | spe/rm' a)po\ *kallia/naktos.
kai\ to\n e)xqro/n: Would apply strictly only to ei)/ tis a)nta/eis, but ei) fi/los is there only to heighten ei)/ tis a)nta/eis.
su/n te di/ka|: So the MSS. and the Scholia. su/n ge di/ka| introduces a qualification that is not needed for kala/. The praise is to be hearty and fair. proqu/mws te kai\ dikai/ws (Schol.).
w(ri/ais: In their season.
*palla/dos: Armed Pallas (*tritoge/neia, *)obrimopa/trh) was worshipped at Kyrene, and weapon-races run in her honor.
parqenikai\ po/sin: The Doric maidens of Kyrene were present at the games. The wish, as the wish of Nausikaa, Od. 6. 244: ai)\ ga\r e)moi\ toio/sde po/sis keklhme/nos ei)/h.

h)\ ui(o\n eu)/xonto: “Or they (the mothers) wished as son.” The shift is sudden, and Hartung's ai( d' for h)/ is worth considering; not so Bergk's awkward parqenika=|, which destroys the color of a)/fwnoi, and does not allow us to supply the complementary fwna=| to the complementary mate/res, as Hartung's ai( d' would do.

div3.head: Strophe 5
div3.p: *)olumpi/oisi: A local game.
baquko/lpou: Especially appropriate to Mother Earth (v. 18). Compare P. 1.12.

a)oida=n di/yan: “The songs are athirst,” as “deed is athirst” (N. 3, 6),
but the poet finds that he is quenching the thirst of his Muse, and would fain pause, but Telesikrates (tis) reminds him that there is one more theme to call up — the glory of his ancestors.
e)gei=rai . . . do/can: A half-forgotten tale is roused from sleep, and this, too, is a kairo/s story.
kai\ tew=n: As well as the glory of the Thebans, Herakles and Iphikles.
progo/nwn: Plural, for though Alexidamos alone is meant, the whole line is involved.

*)/irasa: The choice part of the country, through which the Libyans led the new-comers by night for good reasons, acc. to the story of Herodotos, 4, 158. As P. would say *)/irasa pro\s po/lin more readily than pro\s po/lin *)/irasa, it is not fair to cite this passage as an example of e)/ban with acc. See P. 4.52.
*)antai/ou: The father of the maiden (Barké) bore the same name as the famous Libyan antagonist of Herakles.

div3.head: Antistrophe 5
div3.p: e)/pleto: Binds strophe and antistrophe together, and thus gives special prominence to the epode, which here contains the kairo/s-point.
xrusostefa/nou: O. 6.57: terpna=s d' e)pei\ xrusostefa/noio la/ben | karpo\n *(/hbas.
a)nqh/santa: Flower and fruit are one.
a)podre/yai: Cf. v. 40. On the active, see O. 1.13.
futeu/wn: Of a deep-laid plan. So N. 4.59: fu/teue/ voi qa/naton e)k lo/xou.
ga/mon: “Wedding,” not “wedlock.”
tessara/konta kai\ o)ktw/: One of the fifty Danaides (Hypermnestra) had saved her husband, N. 10.6; Hor. Od. 3, 11, 33; one (Amymone) had yielded to Poseidon.

pri\n me/son a)=mar e(lei=n = pri\n to\ me/son th=s h(me/ras gene/sqai (Schol.). “Before the oncoming of midday.” e(lei=n does not require an object any more than ai(rei= in the familiar phrase o( lo/gos ai(rei=.
ga/mon: No fear of repetition. See note on P. 1.80.
au)ti/ka: See v. 31.
a)gw=nos: “Lists,” as O. 10 (11), 26.
su\n d' a)e/qlois: Cf. O. 2.46. “With the help of,” instead of “by means of.”
sxh/soi: Opt. in or. obl. = ind. only with interrog. in P., as in Homer, except O. 6.49, which see. First occurrence of fut. opt.

div3.head: Epode 5
div3.p: e)di/dou: “Offered.”
*ai/bus: Antaios.
a(rmo/zwn: See v. 14.
te/los . . . a)/kron: Praemium summum (Dissen), “the great prize.”
a)pa/gesqai: Where we should expect a)pagage/sqai: but a)/gein often tricks expectation, and there is, besides, a note of triumph in the present. So a)=gen below, v. 133.

o(\s a)
 . . . yau/seie: The oratio recta would be o(\s a)
 . . . yau/sh, and o(\s a)
 . . . yau/seie would be a slight anakoluthon. This, however,
is doubtful for P. a)
 . . . qorw/n may possibly be=a)naqorw/n, but in all likelihood a)/n belongs to the opt. and gives the view of the principal subject, Antaios. Compare Hes. Theog. 392: o(\s a)
 ma/xoito, implying ma/xoit' a)/ntis. So here o(\s a)
 yau/seie implies yau/seien a)/ntis.
a)mfi/: With yau/seie.
voi: Does not depend on pe/plois, but on the whole complex.
pe/plois: The fluttering robe heightens the picture (v. 128: kosmh/sais). On the dat. see v. 46.
fu/ge laiyhro\n dro/mon = dro/mw| laiyhrw=s e)/fugen.
xepi\ xeiro/s: P. 4.37: xeiri/ voi xei=ra.
*noma/dwn: The scene is laid in Barka.
di' o(/milon: In prose we must say di' o(mi/lou. With the accus. we feel the throng.
di/kon . . . e)/pi: A similar scene in P. 4.240.
ptera\ . . . *ni/kas: O. 14.24: e)stefa/nwse kudi/mwn a)e/qlwn pteroi=si xai/tan. On the prothalamion theory we have a parallel with Telesikrates.

div2.p: A peculiar interest attaches to this poem as the earliest work of Pindar that we have, for, according to the common count, the poet was only twenty years old when he composed the tenth Pythian in honor of the victory of Hippokleas, pai=s diaulodro/mos, Pyth. 22 (Ol. 69, 3 = 502 B.C.). The Scholiast says that Hippokleas gained another victory the same day in the single-dash foot-race (stadi/w|), but no direct mention of it is made in this poem. The father of Hippokleas had overcome twice at Olympia as o(plitodro/mos, once at Pytho in an ordinary race. Pindar was employed for this performance not by the family of Hippokleas, but by the Aleuadai of Larisa. Dissen thinks that the ode was sung at Larisa, Böckh at Pelinna, the home of Hippokleas.

Always an aristocrat, at the time of P. 10 Pindar had not reached the years of balance in which even he could see some good in the la/bros strato/s. Here he simply repeats the cant of his class. He is what we may suppose the Kyrnos of Theognis to have been when he started life, and this poem is redolent of the young aristocracy to which P. belonged. The Persian war had not yet come with its revelation. “The Gods and the Good Men,” that is his motto, but the good men must be of his own choosing. He believed in God, he believed also in Blood. The praise of Hippokleas, as aristocratic as his name, was a congenial theme. “Rich is Lakedaimon, blessed is Thessaly; o'er both the seed of Herakles bears sway.” This is the high keynote of the poem — the name of Herakles, the pride of race. “Is this an untimely braggart song?” he asks. “Nay, I am summoned by Pytho and the Aleuadai, descendants of Herakles, to bring to Hippokleas a festal voice of minstrels” — Pytho and the Aleuadai, God and Blood (vv. 1-6). “For Hippokleas maketh trial of contests, and the Parnassian gorge hath proclaimed him foremost of boys in the double course. Apollo, achievement and
beginning wax sweet alike when God giveth the impulse, and it was by thy counsels that he accomplished this, but by inborn valor hath he trodden in the footsteps of his father.” Apollo gave the accomplishment, the father the native vigor — God and Blood again (vv. 7-13). “That father was twice victorious at Olympia, clad in the armor of Ares, and the field of contests 'neath the rock of Kirrha proclaimed him victor in the footrace. May fortune attend them in after-days also with flowers of wealth.” May Blood have the blessing of God (vv. 13-18).

Now follows the moral, not other for the youthful poet than for the gray-haired singer, and Pindar prays for Pelinna as he is afterwards to pray for Aigina (P. 8, end). “Having gained no small share of the pleasant things of Hellas, may they suffer no envious reverses from the gods. Granted that God's heart suffers no anguish, 'tis not so with men. A happy man is he in the eyes of the wise, and a theme for song, who by prowess of hand or foot gains the greatest prizes by daring and by strength (vv. 19-24), and in his lifetime sees his son obtain the Pythian wreath. Higher fortune there is none for him. The brazen heaven he cannot mount, he has sailed to the furthest bound. By ships nor by land canst thou find the marvellous road to the Hyperboreans” (vv. 25-30).

Then follows the brief story of Perseus' visit to the Hyperboreans, a land of feasts and sacrifices. The Muse dwells there, and everywhere there is the swirl of dancing virgins, with the music of lyre and flute. Their heads are wreathed with golden laurels, and they banquet sumptuously. Disease nor old age infests this consecrated race.

The land of the Hyperboreans is a glorified Thessaly, and P. was to come back to it years after in O. 3. What Perseus saw, what Perseus wrought, was marvellous; but was he not the son of Danaë, was he not under the guidance of Athena? (v. 45). And so we have an echo of the duality with which the poem began; and as Pindar, in the second triad (v. 21), bows before the power of God, so in the third (v. 48) he says: e)moi\ de\ qauma/sai | qew=n telessa/ntwn ou)de/n pote fai/netai | e)/mmen a)/piston.

And now, with the same sudden start that we find in his later poems, Pindar returns to the victor and himself. And yet he is haunted by the image of the Hyperboreans, and as he hopes “that his song sweetly sung by the Ephyraian chorus will make Hippokleas still more a wonder for his victories mid elders as mid
mates, and to young virgins a sweet care,” the notes of the lyres and the pipings of the flutes and the dances of the Hyperborean maidens (vv. 38-40) come before him. Again a moralizing strain is heard. The highest blessing is the blessing of the day. “What each one striveth for, if gained, he must hold as his near and dear delight. That which is to be a year hence is beyond all ken” (vv. 61, 62). What is that but the to\ d' ai)ei\ para/meron e)slo\n | u(/paton e)/rxetai panti\ brotw=| of O. 1.99? Only the young poet has the eager clutch of youth (a(rpale/an fronti/da), and a year was a longer time for him in P. 22 than in Ol. 77. Then P. thanks the magnate who yoked this four-horse chariot of the Pierides, the chariot which would never be yoked on so momentous occasion for the poet (see O. 6.22), and the ode closes with a commendation of the noble brethren who bear up the state of the Thessalians. On them, the Good Men, depends the blessing of the right governance of the cities ruled by their fathers (vv. 55-72). The last word of the fourth triad is the praise of Blood, as the great thought of the third is God.

Leopold Schmidt has detected the signs of youthfulness in every element of the poem — in periodology, in plan, in transitions, in the consciousness of newly acquired art, in the treatment of the myth, in the tropology, in the metres, in the political attitude. In an edition like this the examination of so subtile a study cannot find a place. A few words on the general subject will be found in the Introductory Essay, p. lvii.
It is noteworthy that the triads do not overlap. Praise occupies the first triad; prayer, fortified by an illustration of God's power, the next two; hope takes up the fourth.
The measures are logaoedic. The mood is set down as a mixture of Aiolian and Lydian.

div3.head: Strophe 1
div3.p: o)lbi/a ... ma/kaira: Climax. Asyndeton and climax remain characteristics of P. to the end.
*(hrakle/os: The Aleuadai were of the Herakleid stock.

ti/; kompe/w para\ kairo/n; “What? Am I giving utterance to swelling words untimely?” This is Mommsen's reading, and more natural and lively than ti/ kompe/w para\ kairo/n; “Why this swelling (prelude) untimely? with the implied answer, ‘It is not untimely.’”
a)lla/: “Nay — but.”

*pelinnai=on: Also called *pe/linna (*pe/lina), in Hestiaiotis, east of Trikka, above the left bank of the Peneios.
identified with the ruins near Gardhiki.
a)pu/ei: For the sing. (as it were, “with one voice”), compare O. 9.16; P. 4.66; 11, 45.

*)aleu/a ... pai=des: The Aleuadai were one of the great aristocratic families of Thessaly. It does not appear in what relation Hippokleas stood to them. Perhaps he was the favorite, or a)i/tas (Theokr. 12, 14), of Thorax, who ordered the song. Fennell, however, thinks that Thorax was the father. See v. 16.
*(ippokle/a|: The form objected to by Ahrens has been defended by Schneidewin on the authority of inscriptions.
a)gagei=n: As a bride to her husband. Compare also v. 66.

div3.head: Antistrophe 1
div3.p: geu/etai ga\r a)e/qlwn: Cf. P. 9.38; N. 6.27: po/nwn e)geu/santo, *i. 4 (5), 19: to\ d' e)mo\n ke/ar u(/mnwn geu/etai.
stratw=|: O. 5.12. Pure dative dependent on a)ne/eipen.
o( *parna/sios ... muxo/s: Cf. P. 5.38: koilo/pedon na/pos.
diaulodroma=n: For the di/aulos, see O. 13.37.
*)/apollon, gluku\ de/: On de/, see O. 1.36. gluku/ is predicative, “waxes a thing of sweetness,” “a delight.”

te/los a)rxa/ te: The whole, from beginning to end, hence the sing. au)/cetai, as a)pu/ei, v. 4. There were two te/lh and two a)rxai/ in the di/aulos. The first te/los is the second a)rxh/, and dai/monos o)rnu/ntos is needed for both. Hence perhaps the position, though pra=cis o(doi/ te (P. 9.74) would suffice as a parallel, “the end as the beginning.”
to\ de\ suggene/s: Accus. dependent on e)mbe/baken. Pindaric variation for tw=| suggenei= opposed to teoi=s ge mh/desin.
e)mbe/baken: Cf. N. 11.44: megalanori/ais e)mbai/nomen.

div3.head: Epode 1
div3.p: polemado/kois: On the armor of the o(plitodro/mos, see P. 9.1. As the shield is the important part, the adjective is well chosen.

baqulei/mwn: So with Hartung for baqulei/mwn' b. seems to be a fit epithet for the low-lying course, a)gw/n, for which see P. 9.124. Compare also P. 1.24: baqei=an ... pla/ka. The acc. baqulei/mwn(a) is tr. by Fennell “rising from rich meadows.”
u(po\ ... pe/tran: “Stretching along under,” hence the accusative. For pe/tran, compare P. 5.37: *krisai=on lo/fon.
krathsi/poda: Dependent on qh=ken. “Made prevalent of foot,” “victorious in the race.”

*friki/an: The position is emphatic, but the examples cited by Rauchenstein are all nominatives, *o. 10 (11), 34. 38. 56; P. 12.17; I. 5 (6), 30. 35. The emphatic acc. naturally takes the head of the sentence. *f. is the victor's father; according to Hermann and others a horse.
If Phrixos is an aristocratic Thessalian name, Phrikias might also be suffered to pass muster.
a)nqei=n: As if e(/poito moi=ra were equivalent to ei)/h moi=ra.
sfi/sin: Depends on e(/poito. The extremes are rhythmically near. Compare Hdt. 1, 32: ei) mh/ oi( tu/xh e)pi/spoito pa/nta kala\ e)/xonta teleuth=sai eu)= to\n bi/on.

div3.head: Strophe 2
div3.p: fqonerai=s e)k qew=n | metatropi/ais: Cf. I. 6 (7), 39: o( d' a)qana/twn mh\ qrasse/tw fqo/nos, Hdt. 1, 32: to\ qei=on pa=n fqonero/n.
qeo\s ei)/h = qeo\s e)/stw. Compare O. 3.45. Schneidewin's ai)ei/ is unnecessary, nor need we take ei)/h as = ei)/h a)/n. “Let him that is free from heartache be a god.” “Set him down as a god.”
gi/netai sofoi=s: “Is accounted in the eyes of the wise.” More natural than u(mnhto\s sofoi=s, “a theme for poets.”

o(\s a)
 xersi
 h)\ podw=n a)reta=|, kte(.: Cf. Od. 8. 147: ou) me
 ga mei=zon kle/os a)ne/ros o)/fra k' e)/h|sin | h)\ o(/ ti possi/n te r(e/ch| kai\ xersi
 e(h=|sin.

div3.head: Antistrophe 2
div3.p: kat' ai)=san = kata\ to\ prosh=kon (Schol.). “Duly” with tuxo/nta. Cf. P. 4.107.
tuxo/nta: On the aor. part. with i)/dh|, see P. 5.84.
stefa/nwn: According to the Scholiast, Hippokleas gained both di/aulos and sta/dion the same day. See v. 58.
o( xa/lkeos ou)rano/s: Compare the story about Diagoras, quoted in the introduction to O. 7, Cic. Tusc. 1, 46, 111: Morere, Diagora, non enim in caelum ascensurus es.

o(/sais ... plo/on: “Whatsoever brilliant achievements we men of mortal race attain, he sails to the outmost bound.” Combine perai/nei plo/on pro\s e)/sxaton with Rauchenstein and Leop. Schmidt. Cf. *i. 5 (6), 12: e)sxatia\s ... pro\s o)/lbou. The dative with a(/ptesqai, as *i. 3 (4), 29: a)nore/ais d' e)sxa/taisin | oi)/koqen sta/laisin a(/ptonq' *(hraklei/ais. Compare the close of O. 3.
a)glai+/ais: For the word, see O. 13.14; the pl., O. 9.106.
nausi/: On the omission of ou)/te, see P. 6.48, and compare below, v. 41: no/sos ou)/te gh=ras.

ken eu(/rois: Simply eu(/rois in the old MSS. a)/n is supplied by Moschopulos. In such passages, P. prefers ken. See v. 62; O. 10 (11), 22; P. 7.16; N. 4.93. Bergk, following an indication of the Scholia, writes ta/x', the opt. being used in the old potential sense. See note on O. 3.45.
*(uperbore/wn: See O. 3.16.
a)gw=na = a)gora/n (Eustathios).
qaumata/n: O. 1.28.

div3.head: Epode 2
div3.p: *perseu/s: See P. 12, 11.

o)/nwn: The ass is a mystic animal. Hence the ready belief that the Jews worshipped an ass. See Justin Martyr, Apol. I. 32, and esp. c. 54, where
Christ and Perseus, Pegasos and the foal of an ass are paralleled.
e)pito/ssais = e)pituxw/n. Cf. P. 3.27: to/ssais, 4, 25: e)pe/tosse.
qew=|: Apollo.
r(e/zontas: The acc., as if e)pito/ssais were = eu(rw/n.

u(/brin o)rqi/an: “Rampant lewdness” (Paley). “Towering wantonness.” u(/bris is “braying,” and its accompaniments (compare Hdt. 4, 129: u(bri/zontes w)=n oi( o)/noi e)ta/rasson th\n i(/ppon tw=n *skuqe/wn ), and o)/rqios in P. is regularly used of sound (O. 9.117; N. 10.76), as Mezger notes, but o(rw=n cannot be explained away. On the sacrifice of the ass to Apollo, the musical beast to the musical god, see A. B. Cook, Journ. Hell. Stud. XIV., pt. 1, where this passage is illustrated by a fresco found at Mycenae representing two rampant asses with lolling tongues and leering eyes.
knwda/lwn: Properly used of “gnawing” (ravening) monsters; hence, as here, of untamed beasts of draught, Aisch. P. V. 407: e)/zeuca prw=tos e)n zugoi=si knw/dala.

div3.head: Strophe 3
div3.p: tro/pois e(pi\ sfete/roisi : e)pi/ of the conditions. See P. 1.84. “With such ways as theirs” to make her stay. “Such are their ways.” These ways are next set forth
sfete/roisi: See note on O. 9.84.
boai/: O. 3.8: boa\n au)lw=n, *n. 5, 38: kala/moio boa=|, which seem to us more natural.
done/ontai: The music swirls with the dance and as well as the dance. N. 7.81: polu/faton qro/on u(/mnwn do/nei h(suxa=|.
da/fna| te xruse/a|: O. 11 (10), 13: e)pi\ stefa/nw| xruse/as e)lai/as, and see note on O. 8.1.
a)nadh/santes: Where we might expect the middle, but ko/mas will serve for the reflexive. See note on O. 14.24: e)stefa/nwse.
ei)lapina/zoisin: Od. 1. 226: ei)lapi/nh h)=e ga/mos; e)pei\ ou)k e)/ranos ta/de g' e)sti/n.
no/soi d' ou)/te gh=ras: See v. 29.
ke/kratai: Is “blended” with the current of their blood. See O. 10 (11), 114.

div3.head: Antistrophe 3
div3.p: u(pe/rdikon: This stern (over-just) goddess they had escaped, not that they were not subject to her, but because they had satisfied her; they had been found guiltless before her
qrasei/a| de\ pne/wn kardi/a|: A variation from what we should expect, qrasu/ or qrase/a, like xamhla\ pne/wn (P. 11.30); kenea\ pneu/sas (O. 10 [11], 102).
a(gei=to: Parenthetic imperf.
poiki/lon: Cf. P. 8.46: dra/konta poiki/lon.
drako/ntwn fo/baisi = drakontei/ois fo/baisi. The locks were snakes.
nasiw/tais: The Seriphians. See P. 12.12.

qauma/sai: “For wondering.” “To rouse my wonder.” The strict grammatical dependence is on a)/piston. In prose, a)/piston w(/ste qauma/sai. Schol. Flor.: e)gw\ pisteu/wn pa/nta tou\s qeou\s du/nasqai ou) qauma/zw.

div3.head: Epode 3
div3.p: sxa/son: “Check,” “hold.” sx. is a nautical word. Eur. Phoen. 454: sxa/son de\ deino\n o)/mma kai\ qumou= pnoa/s . Asyndeton in a sudden shift
a)/gkuran: The boat-figure grows out of nasiw/tais, and xoira/dos pe/tras out of li/qinon qa/naton. Cf. P. 12.12. x. p. “reef,” “rocky reef.”
e)/reison xqoni/: “Let it go and grapple the bottom.” The dat. is instrumental.
prw/|raqe: P. 4.191.
a)/lkar: “A guard against.”

e)gkwmi/wn: Do not land. Your bark will be dashed against the rocks of a long story. Your ship must go to other shores, your song to other themes, as a bee hies from flower to flower. Pindar lives himself into a metaphor, as if it were no metaphor; hence metaphor within metaphor. No mixed, only telescoped, metaphor.
a)/wtos: Is hardly felt as our “flower” or “blossom.” This would make both me/lissa and lo/gon flowers, and P., even in his nonage, could hardly have been guilty of that.

div3.head: Strophe 4
div3.p: *)efurai/wn: Ephyra, afterwards Kranon, was ruled by the Skopadai, great lovers of art. The inhabitants belonged to the stock of the Herakleidai, from Ephyra, in Thesprotia.
a)mfi\ *phnei+o/n: At Pelinna.
glukei=an: Proleptic.
to\n *(ippokle/an: The article seems prosaic to G. Hermann. Rauchenstein writes poq'. The other examples are not exactly parallel, but “this Hippokleas of ours” will serve.
e)/ti kai\ ma=llon: Even more than he now is, by reason of his victories.
su\n a)oidai=s: Much more lively than a)oidai=s or di' a)oidw=n. Cf. P. 12.21.
stefa/nwn: See v. 26.
ne/aisi/n te parqe/noisi me/lhma: A hint that Hippokleas is passing out of the boy-stage. Compare the allusions to love in P. 9, esp. v. 107.

u(pe/knisen: Danger is a nettle, e)/rws is a kni/dh. kni/zein is used of love, Hdt. 6, 62: to\n de\ *)ari/stwna e)/knize a)/ra th=s gunaiko\s tau/ths o( e)/rws . Cf. I. 5 (6), 50: a(dei=a d' e)/ndon nin e)/knicen xa/ris, where e)/ndon = u(po/.

div3.head: Antistrophe 4
div3.p: tw=n ... o)rou/ei : o)r. with genitive, like e)/ramai. Compare also P. 6.50: o)rga=|s o(\s i(ppeia=n e)so/dwn.
tuxw/n ken ... sxe/qoi = ei) tu/xoi, sxe/qoi ken. Similar positions of a)/n are common enough in prose. Here the opt. with ken is an imperative.
a(rpale/an = w(s a(rpale/on ti. “With eager clutch.” Compare P. 8.65: a(rpale/an do/sin.
fronti/da = me/lhma.
pa\r podo/s: Cf. P. 3.60: gno/nta to\ pa\r podo/s, and I. 7 (8), 13: to\ de\ pro\ podo\s a)/reion ai)ei\ skopei=n.
ei)s e)niauto/n: “A year hence.”

ceni/a|: Thessalian
magnates were famous for a rather rude hospitality. See note on P. 4.129. Xen. Hell. 6, 1, 3: h)=n de\ kai\ a)/llws filo/ceno/s te kai\ megalopreph\s to\n *qettaliko\n tro/pon.
*qw/rakos: Thorax was the magnate who ordered the poem. His relation to Hippokleas is obscure.

e)ma
 poipnu/wn xa/rin: Acc. to the Schol. e)ma
 xa/rin=th
 e)c e)mou= xa/rin, “my song of victory.” poipnu/wn would then be transitive, “panting to gain.” But the other interpretation, “in panting eagerness for my sake,” would be more appropriate to the circumstances of the young and unknown poet. Thorax was a personal friend of victor and singer.
to/de: “This” of mine.
a(/rma *pieri/dwn: Compare O. 6.22 and I. 7 (8), 62: *moisai=on a(/rma. This is for P. a grand occasion.
tetra/oron: Böckh sees an allusion to the four triads, and sees too much.

file/wn file/ont' a)/gwn a)/gonta: We should say, in like manner, “lip to lip, and arm in arm,” so that it should not appear which loves, which leads. Whether this refers to Hippokleas or to Pindar depends on the interpretation of xa/rin.

div3.head: Epode 4
div3.p: pre/pei: “Shows” what it is.
ka)delfeou\s me\n e)painh/somen: With Hermann. Thorax, Eurypylos, and Thrasydaios were at the headquarters of Mardonios before the battle of Plataia (Hdt. 9, 58).
no/mon: The state. Cf. P. 2.86.
e)n d' a)gaqoi=si kei=ntai: Cf. P. 8.76: ta\ d' ou)k e)p' a)ndra/si kei=tai. Some MSS. have kei=tai (schema Pindaricum), for which see O. 11 (10), 6. a)gaqoi=si in the political sense.
patrw/iai: Another mark of the youthful aristocrat. Besides, Pindar had nothing to hope for from the mob.

div2.p: According to the Scholia, Thrasydaios, a Theban, was victorious, as a boy, in the foot-race, Pyth. 28 (Ol. 75, 3 = 478 B.C.), the year after the battle of Plataia. He was long afterwards victorious in the di/aulos, Pyth. 33 (Ol. 80, 3 = 458 B.C.), before the battle of Tanagra. The expression gumno\n sta/dion (v. 49) has led some to suppose that the earlier victory is meant. See the passage. The failure to mention the trainer of Thrasydaios may mean that Thrasydaios, like Hippokleas of P. 10, had outgrown his attendant, although in a poem supposed to be full of obscure hints we might see in Pylades and in Kastor the reflection of that unnamed friend. The ode shows that Thrasydaios belonged to a wealthy and prominent family. His father had been successful at Pytho (v. 43), and another of the same house had gained a victory with a chariot at Olympia (v. 47). The song was sung in the procession to the temple of Ismenian Apollo, to whom the prizer was to return thanks for the guerdon of a victory.
Pindar calls on the daughters of Kadmos and Harmonia to chant Themis and Pytho in honor of the victory of Thrasydaios, which he won in the land of Pylades, the host of Orestes (vv. 116).

Upon this invocation — an unbroken sentence that extends through a whole triad and bristles with proper names — follows the familiar story of Orestes, which ends here with the death of Klytaimnestra and her paramour, Aigisthos, a myth which hardly seems to belong to a joyous epinikion (vv. 17-37).

If Pindar had kept his usual proportion, the story would have extended through the third triad, but, with a common poetical device, he exclaims that he has been whirled out of his course, summons the Muse to fulfil the promised task, and praises the achievements of Pythonikos, the father, and Thrasydaios, the
son, recounting how the house had won in the chariot-race at Olympia and put to shame their rivals at Pytho (vv. 38-50).

Then, putting himself in the victor's place, P. prays for a right spirit, for the love of what is noble, for self-control in the midst of effort. Hence the middle rank is best, not the lofty fate of overlords. But if the height is scaled, then avoid insolence. Such a noble soul is Thrasydaios, son of Pythonikos; such Iolaos, son of Iphikles; such Kastor and Polydeukes, sons of the gods, who dwell one day at Therapnai, one within Olympos (vv. 51-64).

The eleventh Pythian has given the commentators much trouble. In most of the odes the meaning of the myth, its office as an incorporation of the thought, can, at least, be divined. Here the uncertainty of the date and the unusual character of the story combine to baffle historical interpretation. Historical romances have been framed to fit the supposed fortunes of the house of Thrasydaios. The figures of Agamemnon, Klytaimnestra, Kassandra, Orestes, have been made to represent, now political characters, now political combinations and conflicts. What does the praise of the middle estate mean? What light does that throw on the question of the date? Or are we simply to say that the poem belongs to a period in Pindar's earlier career, when he had not yet acquired the art of handling the myth, and is the story of Orestes a mere ornament, without deeper significance?

The two main difficulties, then, are the selection of the myth of Orestes and the praise of the middle estate. Apart from all historical side-lights, which here seem to confuse rather than to help, the meaning of the myth of Orestes is given by the poet in the line i)/sxei te ga\r o)/lbos ou) mei/ona fqo/non (v. 29). This is true of all the figures in the piece — Agamemnon, Klytaimnestra, Aigisthos, Orestes. Pindar does not carry out the story of Orestes, simply because he feels that he might do what some of his commentators have done so often, and push the parallel between the hero of the myth and the hero of the games too far. So he drops the story, as he has done elsewhere — drops it just as Bellerophon is dismissed (O. 13) when his further fortunes would be ominous. The return to the praise of Thrasydaios and his house is, however, a reinforcement of the moral Pindar has just been preaching — the moral that lies in the myth — and when he reaches the point at which the house of Thrasydaios put the
Greeks to shame by their speed, he pauses and prays for moderation, the corrective of too great prosperity. This is all too high for him, the glory is too great. So, in the commonwealth, he chooses the middle station and dreads the fortunes of tyrants. The feats he aims at are within the common reach. And yet even the highest is not in danger of envy, if there is no o'erweening pride nor insolence. Witness Iolaos, a Theban, townsman of Thrasydaios; witness Kastor and Polydeukes, brothers of Klytaimnestra. Doubtless this is not all that the poem means — but shall we ever know more?

The first triad is occupied with the introduction. The myth begins with the beginning of the second triad, but is stopped in the third triad by the whirl (v. 38), which prepares the return to the victor and his house.
The rhythms are logaoedic.

div3.head: Strophe 1
div3.p: *ka/dmou ko/rai: O. 2.24: e(/petai de\ lo/gos eu)qro/nois | *ka/dmoio kou/rais.

*seme/la ... a)guia=tis: “Neighbor.” One would expect a special office, as in the case of *)apo/llwn a)guieu/s, for Semele is a special favorite (O. 2.28), and lives at the court end of Olympos. Ov. Met. 1, 172: plebs habitat diversa locis: a fronte potentes caelicolae clarique suos posuere penates.
*)inw\ de\ *leukoqe/a: Familiar from Od. 5. 333 on. Compare O. 2.33.
a)ristogo/nw|: Mommsen reads (with the Schol.) a)ristogo/nou, but Herakles does not need the adjective, and it is time for Alkmena to have it.
*meli/an: Who bare Ismenios and Teneros to Apollo, Paus. 9, 10, 5.
xruse/wn ... tripo/dwn: Golden tripods were sent to this shrine by the *qhbagenei=s — the old pre-Boeotian stock — and the high-priest was chosen yearly from the dafnhfo/roi.
*loci/as: Oracular name in connection with an oracle. So P. 3.28.

div3.head: Antistrophe 1
div3.p: manti/wn: More natural than mantei+/wn = manteuma/twn (Schol.). The divination was di' e)mpu/rwn.
*(armoni/as: Wife of Kadmos.

e)pi/nomon: With strato/n. e)pi/nomon is glossed by su/nnomon, but the other version seems more natural: ta\s [sc. h(rwi/das] e)pinemome/nas kai\ e)popteuou/sas ta\s *qh/bas. e)pi/nomon would then be proleptic. The host of heroines is invited to visit (e)pi/nomon) the shrine in a body (o(magure/a), and the two daughters of Harmonia (v. 7) are to sing (v. 10).
kalei=: Sc. *loci/as.
*qe/min: Gaia was the first, Themis the second mistress of the Pythian shrine. See note on P. 4.74.

ga=s o)mfalo/n:
See P. 6.3.
keladh/sete: We have a right to call this a subjunctive. See O. 6.24.
a)/kra| su\n e(spe/ra|: “The edge of even,” “nightfall.” See the commentators on So. Ai. 285, where Jebb translates this passage “at fall of eventide.”

div3.head: Epode 1
div3.p: xa/rin: Apposition to the action. keladh/sete = poih/sesqe ke/ladon. “To grace.”
a)gw=ni ... *ki/rras: P. 10.15: u(po\ *ki/rras a)gw\n | pe/tran.
e)/mnasen: Causative. The herald was the agent. Compare P. 1.32: ka=ruc a)ne/eipe/ nin.
e)pi/: With balw/n.
a)rou/raisi *pula/da: The father of Pylades was Strophios, king of Phokis.
*la/kwnos: Orestes was made king of Lakedaimon, acc. to Paus. 2, 18, 5.

div3.head: Strophe 2
div3.p: to/n: The relative begins the myth, as often. See Index.
*)arsino/a: By others called *laoda/meia, *ki/lissa.
u(po/ = u(pe/k: Cf. O. 5.14: u(p' a)maxani/as, 6, 43: u(p' w)di=nos.
ka)k: So after Bergk's kh)k for the simple e)k of the MSS., which gives a harsh construction.
o(po/te: See P. 3.91.
*dardani/da^: With ko/ran.
*)agamemnoni/a| | yuxa=|: O. 2.13.
a)kta\n par' eu)/skion : para/ not strictly as in prose, not “along the shore,” but “to the stretch of the shore.”

div3.head: Antistrophe 2
div3.p: nhlh\s guna/: On the position, see O. 1.81; 10 (11), 48; P. 12.17.
*)ifige/neia . . . sfaxqei=sa: Rather than to\ sfaxqh=nai, o(/ti e)sfa/xqh, sfagh/. See O. 3.6; P. 2.23.
e)p' *eu)ri/pw|: At Aulis.

e(te/rw| le/xei+ damazome/nan: The paraphrast: e(te/rw| a)ndri\ misgome/nhn. Fennell tr. “humiliated by another connection on Agamemnon's part.” This would bring in Kassandra, but the sense cannot be extracted from the words. Pindar enlarges on the more shameful alternative, “guilty passion and sensual delight.”
e)/nnuxoi pa/ragon koi=tai: P. 2.35: eu)nai\ para/tropoi.
to\ de\ ne/ais , kte(.: Inevitable Greek moralizing, as inevitable to Pindar as to Euripides.

div3.head: Epode 2
div3.p: a)llotri/aisi glw/ssais: “Owing to alien tongues,” as if di' a)llotri/as glw/ssas.
i)/sxei te ... o( de/: Cf. P. 4.80.
ou) mei/ona: Sc. tou= o)/lbou. Prosperity is envied to its full height. The groundling may say and do what he pleases. No one notices him.
xamhla\ pne/wn: Compare O. 10 (11), 102: kenea\ tneu/sais, *n. 3, 41: a)/llot' a)/lla pne/wn.

a)/fanton bre/mei: To him who lives on the heights the words and works of o( xamhla\ pne/wn amount to
nothing more than an “obscure murmur.” The contrast is, as the Scholiast puts it, between o( e)pifanh/s and o( a)fanh/s.
xro/nw|: P. 4.78: xro/nw| i(/ket(o).

klutai=s e)n *)amu/klais: Homer puts the scene in Mykenai, Stesichoros in Amyklai. Acc. to O. Müller, Amyklai was the old capital of the Pelopidai, and the same city that Homer calls Lakedaimon. See Paus. 3, 19, 5, on the statue of Kassandra and the monument of Agamemnon at Amyklai.

div3.head: Strophe 3
div3.p: ma/ntin ... ko/ran: “Prophetic maid,” or “maiden prophetess.”
purwqe/ntwn | *trw/wn: Not genitive absolute.
a(bro/tatos: Depends on e)/luse. “Reft of luxury.” Such a combination as do/mous a(bro/tatos = do/mous a(brou/s, plousi/ous, is very unlikely.
o( de/: Orestes. Return to the hero of the myth, v. 16.
*stro/fion: See note on P. 4.51.
ne/a kefala/: So with Bergk for ne/a| kefala=|. The paraphrast has ne/os w)\n e)/ti, though that is not conclusive. The appositional nominative gives a tender touch.
xroni/w| su\n *)/arei: Keep the personification. “With Ares' tardy help.”
e)n fonai=s: Notice the effect of the plural. “Weltering in his gore.” qei=nai regularly with e)n everywhere.

div3.head: Antistrophe 3
div3.p: a)meusi/poron tri/odon: Lit. “path-shifting fork.” The tri/odos is the place where two roads go out of a third. Plat. Gorg. 524 A: e)n th=| trio/dw| e)c h(=s fe/reton tw\ o(dw/ . See my note on Justin Martyr, Apol. II. 11, 8. “The place where three roads meet” is misleading without further explanation.
tri/odo_n: Notice the prolongation of the last syllable, P. 3.6.
o)rqa\n ke/leuqon: vv. 1-16. The words o)rqa\n ke/leuqon suggest the paths of the sea, and the image changes.
w(s o(/te: Compare O. 6.2: w(s o(/te qahto\n me/garon.
a)/katon ei)nali/an: For the figure, see P. 10.51.
*moi=sa, to\ de\ teo/n: For de/, see O. 1.36. With to\ de\ teo/n, compare O. 5.72: to\ d' e)mo/n.
misqoi=o: In these matters P. is to us painfully candid.
pare/xein: As sune/qeu is a verb of will, the future is not necessary.
u(pa/rguron: “For silver.” The double meaning of “silver voice” is plain enough. Much disputed is I. 2, 8: a)rgurwqei=sai pro/swpa malqako/fwnoi a)oidai/.
a)/llot' a)/lla| tarasse/men , kte(.: “That is thy duty, to let it flit now this way, now that — now to father, anon to son.” P. has already flitted from land (tri/odon) to water (plo/ou).

div3.head: Epode 3
div3.p:
*puqoni/kw|: Elsewhere *puqio/nikos. Bergk considers
it a proper name.
e)pifle/gei: Cf. O. 9.23: fi/lan po/lin | malerai=s e)pifle/gwn a)oidai=s. For the sing. of a welded pair, see P. 10.10, and for English usage Fitzedward Hall in Am. Journ. of Phil. II. p. 424.
e)n a(/rmasi: Cf. P. 2.4: tetrasri/as ... e)n a(=| krate/wn.
e)/sxon: O. 2.10.
qoa\n a)kti=na: “The swift halo,” “swiftly the halo.” Cf. P. 4.179: taxe/es ... e)/ban. For a)kti=na, cf. I. 3 (4), 60: e(rgma/twn a)kti\s kalw=n a)/sbestos ai)ei/,
su\n i(/ppois: Not simply = di' i(/ppwn.

div3.head: Strophe 4
div3.p: *puqoi= te: With preceding me/n, as v. 31.
gumno\n e)pi\ sta/dion: “The bare course,” usually opposed to the o(pli/ths dro/mos, as I. 1, 23. Here the course, where the runner has nothing to help him; opp. to e)n a(/rmasi, su\n i(/ppois.
h)/legzan: “Put to the blush.”

qeo/qen e)rai/man kalw=n: P. often uses the first person when he desires to put himself in the place of the victor (O. 3.45; P. 3.110). A familiar trick of familiar speech, and suited to the easy terms on which P. stood with most of his “patrons.” The sense “May the gods so guide my love for that which is fair that I may not go beyond the limit of my power.” Others: qeo/qen kalw=n, “The goods the gods provide.” There is not the least necessity for considering e)rai/man as = e)rai/man a)/n.
maio/menos: The participle is restrictive, w(/ste ta\ dunata\ mo/non mai/esqai.
e)n a(liki/a|: “In my life's bloom.”

tw=n ga\r a)\m po/lin , kte(.: Some see in this an oblique reference to the men who were carrying things with a high hand at Thebes in 478 B.C. For the condition of Thebes at the time of the Persian war, see the speech of the Thebans in Thuk. 3, 62: o(/per de/ e)sti no/mois me\n kai\ tw=| swfronesta/tw| e)nantiw/taton, e)gguta/tw de\ tura/nnou, dunastei/a o)li/gwn a)ndrw=n ei)=xe ta\ pra/gmata.
ma/ssoni = makrote/rw|, the MS. reading, which is unmetrical (Bergk). m. = mei/zoni. See P. 2.26: makro\n o)/lbon.

div3.head: Antistrophe 4
div3.p: cunai=s d' a)mf' a)retai=s : cunai\ a)retai/ are achievements that are within the reach of all, that are open to all (Dissen). Mezger prefers “Excellences that inure to the good of all,” such as victories. This is to/ g' e)n cunw=| peponame/non eu)= of P. 9.101. Jebb: “Those virtues move my zeal which serve the folk.” But the stress is laid directly on the avoidance of envy

te/tamai: “I am at full stretch” as it were, with his arms about the prize. Compare P. 9.129:
o(\s d' a)\n prw=tos qorw\n
a)mfi/ voi yau/seie pe/plois.

a)tai: The MSS. have a)/ta)/, a)/ta|. The dat. makes no satisfactory
sense. a)mu/nesqai occurs only once more in P., and then in the common sense “to ward off” (I. 6 [7], 27). “The evil workings of envy are warded off” (pass.) makes a tolerable sense. This, of course, makes fqoneroi/ fem., for which we have analogy elsewhere. a)=tai would embrace both human and divine (Mezger). a)=tai, as a masculine nominative plural, “mischief-makers,” “workers of a)/th,” would account for fqoneroi. For the metre read a)=tai ei) as two syllables, not three (synizesis).
