a)/kron e(lw/n: Compare P. 9.128: te/los a)/kron, and I. 1, 51: ke/rdos u(/yiston.

me/lanos ... genea=|: I have rewritten the passage after Bergk with no great confidence. “A fairer end in black death does he find (than the u(bristai/), having bequeathed to his sweet race the favor of a good name, the highest of treasures.”
kra/tiston: So Bergk for krati/stan.

div3.head: Epode 4
div3.p: a(/ te: Sc. xa/ris.
*)ifiklei/dan: As P. is praising transmitted glory he does not forget the genealogy of Iolaos and of the Dioskuroi.
diafe/rei: “Spreads [the fame] abroad.”
*)io/laon: Iolaos and Kastor are coupled, I. 1, 16. 30, as the difrhla/tai kra/tistoi.

se/ te, va/nac *polu/deukes: Cf. P. 4.89. Polydeukes was the son of Zeus, and when Kastor fell, Zeus said to Polydeukes (N. 10.85):
ei) de\ kasignh/tou pe/ri
ma/rnasai, pa/ntwn de\ noei=s a)poda/ssasqai vi/son,
h(/misu me/n ke pne/ois gai/as u(pe/nerqen e)w/n,
h(/misu d' ou)ranou= e)n xruse/ois dw/masin.
par' a)mar: “Day about,” “every other day.”

*qera/pnas: I. 1, 31: *tundari/das d' e)n *)axaioi=s d' u(yi/pedon *qera/pnas oi)ke/wn e(/dos. *n. 10, 56: u(po\ keu/qesi gai/as e)n gua/loisi *qera/pnas. On the left bank of the Eurotas, where the Menelaïon commanded Sparta as the Janiculum Rome. “Nowhere does ancient Sparta come so vividly before the traveller as on the high plateau of Therapne, with its far-reaching view” (E. Curtius).

div2.p: Midas of Akragas, a famous au)lhth/s, master of the Athenian Lamprokles, who in his turn taught Sophokles and Damon, was victorious in au)/lhsis twice, Pyth. 24 and 25, and likewise, according to the Scholia, at the Panathenaic games. We do not know positively for which of the two victories at Pytho this poem was composed; but if Pindar had been celebrating the second victory, he would, according to his usual manner, have mentioned the first. If this is the first victory, the poem belongs to the same year with P. 6 (494 B.C.), in which Pindar celebrated the success of another Agrigentine, his friend Xenokrates, brother of Theron, and we have in P. 12 one of Pindar's earliest odes.

The contest in au)lw|di/a (song with flute accompaniment) was abolished at the second Pythiad, and the game at which Midas won was the yilh\ au)/lhsis. The antique au)lo/s, like the old English flute, was a kind of clarionet, with a metallic mouth-piece, and one or two tongues or reeds. Midas had the ill-luck to break the mouth-piece of his flute, but continued his playing, to the great delight of his audience, and succeeded in winning the prize.

The poem is constructed on the usual Pindaric lines. It announces the victory, tells of the origin of flute music, the invention of the tune called kefala=n polla=n no/mos (poluke/falos no/mos), and returns to the victor with some not unfamiliar reflections on moil and toil linked with prosperity.

According to Mezger, e)feu=re, v. 7, and eu(=ren, v. 22, which mark beginning and end of the myth, show the tendency of the poem. The value of the victory consists in its having been gained in an art invented by Athena.

Mezger notices a resemblance to O. 3 in the handling of the myth. In both poems the person of the victor is brought into
connection with the centre of the mythical narrative — the olive there, the poluke/falos no/mos here.
The rhythms are dactylo-epitrite.

div3.head: Strophe 1
div3.p: fila/glae: Not without allusion to the function of *)aglai+/a, O. 14, 13
kalli/sta brotea=n poli/wn: Cf. P. 9.75 (of Kyrene): kalli/stan po/lin.
*fersefo/nas e(/dos: The whole island was presented by Zeus to Persephone ei)s ta\ a)nakalupth/ria (the presents given to the bride when she first took off her veil).
o)/xqais ... kolw/nan: The commanding position of this u(yhla\ po/lis, as P. calls it elsewhere, is emphasized by travellers, old and new. o)/xqais: See P. 1.64.
nai/eis: Heroine and city are blended, after Pindaric fashion. See P. 9.75.
*)akra/gantos: The river.
va/na = a)/nassa.
su\n eu)menei/a|: The favor that he is to find in his reception, not the favor that he has already found.
stefa/nwma: The song as well as the wreath. See P. 9.4.
*mi/da|: For the dat., see P. 4.23. It is to Midas's honor that the offering is to be received.

te/xna|, ta/n, kte(.: Acc. to the common tradition, Athena invented the flute, Olympos this special melody (o( poluke/falos no/mos). P. modifies the tradition so as to give both to Athena. We cannot limit te/xna| to Midas's art in this one melody, in spite of the coincidence of e)feu=re and diaple/caisa.
diaple/caisa: “Winding.”

div3.head: Strophe 2
div3.p: parqeni/ois = parqe/nwn. The sisters of Medusa, Euryale and Stheno
u(po/ t' a)pla/tois: The virgins are bowed in grief, which position is better brought out by u(po/, with the dat. On u(po/, with the second word, see O. 9.94.
o)fi/wn: Acc. to another version, only Medusa had the snake locks.

leibo/menon: After the analogy of xei=n ( I. 7 [8], 58: qrh=non ... e)/xean ), and da/krua lei/bein. The ou)/lios qrh=nos brought with it a shower of tears (a)stakti\ lei/bwn da/kruon, Soph.), hence the blending.
su/n, Almost equivalent to “amid.”
o(po/te: “What time.” Cf. P. 3.91.
tri/ton ... me/ros: Medusa was one of three sisters. Cf. P. 4.65: o)/gdoon ... me/ros *)arkesi/las.
a)/nussen: “Despatched.”

ei)nali/a| te *seri/fw| toi=si/ te: So Hermann. ei)nali/a| *seri/fw| laoi=si, the reading of the best MSS., makes i in *s. short. toi=si = au)toi=s = *serifi/ois. If laoi=si is retained, it must be read as a dissyllable. Seriphos was turned into a solid rock, and the inhabitants, who had maltreated Danaë, mother of Perseus, were petrified by the apparition of the Gorgon's head

*fo/rkoio:
The father of the three Graiai, as well as of the three Gorgons.
mau/rwsen: “Blinded.” The Graiai had one eye in common, of which Perseus robbed them in order to find his way to the abode of the Gorgons.

*polude/kta|: Polydektes of Seriphos, enamoured of Danaë, made her his slave, and, pretending to desire wedlock with Hippodameia, invited the princes of the realm to a banquet, in order to receive contributions towards the e(/dna. Perseus promised, as his contribution to this e)/ranos, the head of Medusa.

eu)para/|ou ... *medoi/sas: Medusa is mortal, the others immortal. See the story in Ov. Met. 4, 792:
clarissima forma
multorumque fuit spes invidiosa procorum.
After she yielded to Poseidon, her hair was turned into serpents by Athena, of whose temple she was priestess, and with whom she vied in beauty. The transmutation of Medusa in plastic art from a monster to a beauty is well known.

div3.head: Strophe 3
div3.p: ui(o\s *dana/as: On the position, see O. 10 (11), 38.
a)po\ xrusou= ... au)toru/tou: The shower of gold in which Zeus descended to Danaë. I. 6 (7), 5: xrusw=| mesonu/ktion ni/fonta ... to\n fe/rtaton qeo/n .
fi/lon a)/ndra: Perseus was special liegeman of Athena.
teu=xe: The tentativeness of the inventor may be noted in the tense, as in the *e*p*o*i*e*i of the Greek artist, though in earlier times *e*p*o*i*h*s*e is more common (Urlichs).
pa/mfwnon: Cf. O. 7.12: pamfw/noisi/ t' e)n e)/ntesin au)lw=n , and P. 3.17: pamfw/nwn i)axa\n u(menai/wn .
to\n ... go/on: On the long suspense, see O. 12.5.
*eu)rua/las: The eminence is due to the metrical form of the name.
karpalima=n genu/wn: Quivering jaws.
xrimfqe/nta: Lit. “brought nigh,” “that assailed her ears.”
su\n e)/ntesi: “With the help of instruments” instead of the simple instrumental e)/nt. Cf. P. 4.39.

a)ndra/si qnatoi=s e)/xein: This would seem to imply that she does not mean to use the flute herself. Still the story that Athena threw away the flute after she invented it, because it disfigured her face, is doubtless an Athenian invention aimed at the Boeotians.
e)/xein: Epexegetic infinitive.
kefala=n polla=n no/mon: Fanciful explanation of the “winding bout,” or “many-headed” tune.
laosso/wn: The au)lo/s called to games as well as battles.

div3.head: Strophe 4
div3.p: qa/ma = a(/ma (Bergk). See O. 7.12.
dona/kwn: For which Boeotia was famous.
para\ kallixo/rw| ... po/lei: The dat. is more poetical than the acc. See O. 1.20.

*xari/twn: The
city of the Charites is Orchomenos. See O. 14.3:
w)= lipara=s a)oi/dimoi basi/leiai
*xa/rites *)orxomenou=
.
*kafisi/dos: The nymph Kopaïs.
pistoi\ xoreuta=n ma/rtures: The au)lo/s is the timekeeper, and so the witness of the dances.
a)/neu kama/tou: Allusion to the mishap of Midas, though the story may have been imported.
nin = ka/maton.
tina: Sc. se/. Some read ti/n = soi/, dependent on dw/sei.

a)elpti/a| balw/n: “Smiting with unexpectedness.” “With unexpected stroke.” a)elpti/a is a be/los. Less likely is a)elpti/a| as semi-personification as Il. 7, 187: kune/h| ba/le , where the helmet catches the lot.
e)/mpalin gnw/mas: Compare O. 10 (11), 95: neo/tatos to\ pa/lin .
to\ me\n dw/sei, kte(.: While it will give part, will part postpone. A note of unsatisfied longing on the part of Midas.
